-145.001 (AESCHYLUS, Persians)
AESCHYLUS, Persians
	[c darkmagenta][b]AESCHYLUS, Persians[/b][/c]
		[m1]\ [/m][b]Aeschylus[/b]
	[b]Persians[/b]
	According to the ancient headnote (Hypothesis), [c dimgray]Persians[/c]
	was produced in 472 bc, as the second play in a four-play
	production (see below) which won first prize; it is thus, if
	the currently accepted dating of [c dimgray]Suppliants[/c] to the 460s
	is correct, the earliest surviving European drama. The
	[c dimgray]choregos[/c] who financed the production was none other
	than Pericles, then about twenty-three years old. Pericles’
	father, Xanthippus, had played a notable role in the Persian
	war: he had been the Athenian naval commander, in
	succession to Themistocles, in 479, had led the Athenian
	contingent at the victorious battle of Mycale, and then, after
	his Peloponnesian allies had abandoned the campaign,
	had gone on to capture Sestos on the Hellespont, whence
	he brought home to Athens, for dedication in a sanctuary,
	the cables of the bridge of boats by which Xerxes’ army had
	crossed the straits[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]—a bridge of which our play has a great
	deal to say.[c dimgray][sup]2[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Persians[/c] was not the first tragedy to take its subject
	from recent events instead of from those of heroic times.
	Aeschylus’ great predecessor, Phrynichus, had done the
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]Herodotus 8.131.3; 9.90–106, 114, 120–1 (the dedication of
	the cables is the very last event in Herodotus’ main narrative).
	[c dimgray][sup]2[/sup][/c][c dimgray]Persians[/c] 65–73, 112–3, 130–1, 722–5, 745–750.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 1[/c]

	same thing at least twice. In 493 or 492 he had produced
	[c dimgray]The Capture of Miletus,[/c] highlighting the calamity that had
	befallen this famous Ionian city, a calamity for which many
	Athenians felt Athens was partly to blame for having withdrawn
	its support from the Ionians rebelling against Persian

	of the play prohibited.[c dimgray][sup]3[/sup][/c] Much later, probably in 476 and
	with Themistocles himself—the hero of Salamis, and the
	creator of the fleet that triumphed there—as his [c dimgray]choregos,[/c][c dimgray][sup]4[/sup][/c]
	Phrynichus had staged a production at least part of which
	was devoted to the Graeco-Persian war,[c dimgray][sup]5[/sup][/c] seen from the
	side of the Persians (and their non-Greek subject nations)
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]3[/sup][/c]Herodotus 6.21.2. Presumably the prohibition referred to
	possible performances at local deme festivals; it was to be many
	years before anyone thought of producing the same play a second
	time at the City Dionysia itself.
	[c dimgray][sup]4[/sup][/c]It is known that Phrynichus won a victory, with Themistocles
	as [c dimgray]choregos,[/c] in this year (Plutarch, [c dimgray]Themistocles[/c] 5.5); there is no
	proof that this victory was gained with his Persian War plays, but
	the parallel with Pericles’ sponsorship of Aeschylus’ production,
	and the unlikelihood that a shrewd politician like Themistocles
	would miss the opportunity for self-promotion that such a production
	on such a subject would provide, raise a strong presumption
	that it was. Indeed, it is quite possible that Themistocles had [c dimgray]suggested[/c]
	the subject to Phrynichus.
	[c dimgray][sup]5[/sup][/c]Our sources, including the Hypothesis to [c dimgray]Persians,[/c] mostly
	refer in this connection to Phrynichus’ [c dimgray]Phoenician Women,[/c] but
	the [c dimgray]Suda’s[/c] list of his plays (φ762) also mentions another play
	for which it offers three alternative titles—[c dimgray]The Righteous Men,
	The Persians,[/c] and [c dimgray]The Committee[/c] (lit. “men sitting together”).
	Probably the title [c dimgray]The Phoenician Women,[/c] being that of the best-known
	play in the production, was sometimes applied to the
	whole of it.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 2[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m][b]Aeschylus[/b]
	and presented less as a Greek triumph than as their enemies’
	catastrophe. The plays, especially [c dimgray]The Phoenician
	Women,[/c] were long remembered for the beauty of their
	lyrics.[c dimgray][sup]6[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	It is likely that at the time when Aeschylus produced
	[c dimgray]Persians,[/c] Phrynichus had recently died. The opening
	words of Aeschylus’ play are a near-quotation from the
	opening of the corresponding play of Phrynichus’ production;
	it is unlikely that Aeschylus would have chosen to pay
	such a compliment to a living rival, and there is no evidence
	of Phrynichus being alive at any later date. Aeschylus
	thus advertises that he is following in Phrynichus’ footsteps,
	but we can be sure that his treatment of the theme
	was very different from that of his older contemporary.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	In particular, whereas Phrynichus had spread the story
	over at least two (possibly three) plays,[c dimgray][sup]7[/sup][/c] Aeschylus concentrates
	it into one. In the play of Phrynichus’ production
	(probably [c dimgray]The Righteous Men[/c])[c dimgray][sup]8[/sup][/c] whose opening line Aeschylus
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]6[/sup][/c]The old jurors in Aristophanes’ [c dimgray]Wasps,[/c] on their way to court,
	are said to sing μέλη ἀρχαιομελισιδωνοφρυνιχήρατα (“lovely
	old honeyed Sidonian \[i.e. Phoenician\] Phrynichus songs”)
	([c dimgray]Wasps[/c] 219–220).
	[c dimgray][sup]7[/sup][/c]That our sources tell us of only two relevant plays of his is of
	no significance: we only know the titles of ten plays of Phrynichus
	altogether, from a career that may have lasted nearly forty years.
	[c dimgray][sup]8[/sup][/c]The Hypothesis says it was [c dimgray]The Phoenician Women,[/c] but the
	scene it describes, with a eunuch “spreading <fleeces or textiles
	over> chairs for the assessors of the ruling power”, is clearly one of
	preparation for a meeting of Persian councillors, and surely therefore
	must come from the play that was named after them; see H.
	Lloyd-Jones, [c dimgray]Greek Epic, Lyric and Tragedy[/c] (Oxford, 1990) 233–4

-145.005 (AESCHYLUS, Persians)
AESCHYLUS, Persians
	[c darkmagenta][b]AESCHYLUS, Persians[/b][/c]
	[b]Aeschylus[/b]
	imitated, “the defeat of Xerxes”—this must mean
	Salamis, the only Greek victory over the Persians at which
	Xerxes was present in person—was already known about
	in the Persian capital and was mentioned in the prologue
	speech; it is plausible therefore to suppose that [c dimgray]The Phoenician Women[/c]
	came first, and that in the course of that play
	the chorus learned of the disaster of Salamis and of their
	own widowhood. The depth of their grief, and the poignancy
	of its expression, can well be imagined: many tragic
	choruses mourn and lament, but no surviving tragic chorus
	laments a personal bereavement which its members
	have [c dimgray]themselves[/c] experienced, or learned of, during the
	course of the play.[c dimgray][sup]9[/sup][/c] Perhaps in the following play, as Persia
	struggled to recover from Salamis (and with Xerxes now
	back home?), word may have arrived of the crowning catastrophe
	of Plataea.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	Aeschylus ingeniously reshapes these elements into a
	new and much tauter package. He takes from Phrynichus’
	[c dimgray]second[/c] play the chorus of Persian councillors, with a council
	meeting (140–5) as the first significant event, but like
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]9[/sup][/c]The Persian elders in Aeschylus’ play learn of a disaster
	which must have cost the lives of some of their sons, but their grief
	remains always national, not personal. In Aeschylus’ lost [c dimgray]Daughters
	of the Sun,[/c] however, the chorus will have learned of the death
	of their brother Phaëthon, and in his [c dimgray]Danaids[/c] the chorus almost
	certainly lost their father Danaus. In Euripides’ [c dimgray]Children of
	Heracles[/c] the chorus lose a sister when one of Heracles’ daughters
	(often, but not in the play itself, called Macaria) offers herself as a
	sacrifice to secure victory for the Athenians over Eurystheus’
	army; but far from grieving over her death they urge Iolaus [c dimgray]not[/c] to
	grieve, because the maiden has won herself eternal glory (618–629).
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 4[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m][b]Aeschylus[/b]
	Phrynichus’ [c dimgray]first[/c] play, this one begins with the fate of
	Xerxes’ expedition still entirely unknown, and the shattering
	news of Salamis[c dimgray][sup]10[/sup][/c] arrives in the course of the play. Few
	will then have expected to hear of Plataea too, but Aeschylus
	contrives to include it by having the ghost of Darius
	summoned up from below and making him deliver a precise
	prophecy of the coming defeat, even though he is represented
	as at first knowing nothing of what has happened
	at Salamis.[c dimgray][sup]11[/sup][/c] Then, and only then, a humiliated Xerxes returns
	home, apparently in rags—in the sharpest contrast to
	the elaborate, costly robes of his councillors, and those in
	which we have just seen his father clad;[c dimgray][sup]12[/sup][/c] and the feminine
	laments with which [c dimgray]The Phoenician Women[/c] so abounded
	are put in the mouths of the male Xerxes and the male chorus—for,
	as Edith Hall has shown, the image of the Persian
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]10[/sup][/c]All the more shattering because, up to that point, the Persians
	at home seem entirely unaware that the Greeks have a navy
	at all; we have heard of the Persian fleet (19, 39, 55, 76, 83), but
	the Greeks are thought of simply as spear-fighters (85, 148–9,
	240), and the information about Athens which the Elders give the
	Queen (231–244) includes not a word about ships.
	[c dimgray][sup]11[/sup][/c]This is achieved by supposing that Darius, and apparently
	no one else (not even Xerxes, 744), knows of an oracle that predicted
	these events; he had assumed that it would be fulfilled in
	some distant future (740–1), but now, seeing that the first part of
	the prophecy has come true, he knows that the second part will
	soon come true also, “for oracles are not fulfilled by halves” (802).
	[c dimgray][sup]12[/sup][/c]There has earlier been a similar contrast between the robes
	of the Queen at her first, vehicle-borne entrance (150ff) and the
	simple garb in which she returns, “without my carriage and without
	my former luxury” (607–8).
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	Although, however, Aeschylus has thus concentrated
	the substance of Phrynichus’ two (or three) plays into one,
	he may nevertheless have suffused his entire production
	with the glow of the great Greek victory over the barbarian.
	The production of 472 is the only one by Aeschylus[c dimgray][sup]14[/sup][/c]
	that is known to have consisted of four plays whose stories
	were, on the face of it, unrelated—indeed, they were not
	even placed in proper chronological order. The first play
	was [c dimgray]Phineus,[/c] about an episode in the saga of the Argonauts.
	[c dimgray]Persians[/c] followed; then the audience were taken back to
	the heroic age with [c dimgray]Glaucus of Potniae[/c]—which might have
	made a vaguely appropriate sequel to [c dimgray]Phineus,[/c] since
	Glaucus was killed (torn apart by his own horses) at the funeral
	games of Pelias whose death had been caused by the
	wiles of Medea after Jason’s return from Colchis, if only
	[c dimgray]Persians[/c] had not intervened—and then to a satyr-play
	about Prometheus ([c dimgray]Prometheus the Fire-Bearer[/c] or[c dimgray]Fire-Kindler[/c]).
	Such a miscellaneous collection would have been
	quite normal later in the century, but it is somewhat surprising
	to find it at this date—and it is far from surprising
	to find that repeated efforts have been made to find
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[c dimgray][sup]14[/sup][/c]Though Aristias in 467 put on a production in which a

	each other at all except that both were sons of Zeus.

	In a forthcoming article[c dimgray][sup]16[/sup][/c] I have suggested that the unifying
	feature of, at least, the three tragic plays in this production
	was nothing other than the Persian War itself.
	[c dimgray]Phineus[/c] dealt with the rescue of Phineus and the destruction
	of his tormentors, the Harpies, by Zetes and Calaïs,
	sons of Boreas the North Wind and the Athenian princess
	Oreithyia; and it was to Boreas and Oreithyia that the
	Athenians successfully prayed (or so they said) before the
	northeasterly gale that wrecked many of the Persians’
	ships near Cape Sepias shortly before the simultaneous
	battles of Artemisium and Thermopylae.[c dimgray][sup]17[/sup][/c] Phineus was a
	prophet, and is reported elsewhere to have given, in that
	capacity, valuable information to the Argonauts;[c dimgray][sup]18[/sup][/c] he could
	very well have added a prediction of the blessing that
	Boreas would one day confer on the descendants of his father-in-law
	Erechtheus. As to [c dimgray]Glaucus of Potniae[/c]—one of
	two lost Aeschylean plays about different mythical characters
	named Glaucus—there is an Aeschylean fragment
	(25a), cited by a scholiast on Pindar simply as from Aeschylus’
	[c dimgray]Glaucus,[/c] in which someone speaks of having come to
	the river Himeras (or the city of Himera) in Sicily. This has,

	[c darkmagenta][b]AESCHYLUS, Persians[/b][/c]
	[b]Aeschylus[/b]
	on the face of it, nothing to do with the plot either of
	[c dimgray]Glaucus of Potniae[/c] (whose action, on and off stage, was set
	in Boeotia and Thessaly) or of Aeschylus’ other play of the
	same name, [c dimgray]Glaucus the Sea-god[/c] (whose settings were
	Boeotia, Euboea, and the straits between them); it does,
	however, have something to do with the Persian War, or
	rather with the simultaneous war between Carthage and
	the Sicilian Greeks, in which the latter won a major victory
	at Himera on, it was believed, the same day as the Greeks
	of the homeland did at Salamis.[c dimgray][sup]19[/sup][/c] I have suggested that fr.
	25a comes from [c dimgray]Glaucus of Potniae[/c];[c dimgray][sup]20[/sup][/c] that its speaker was
	Poseidon, an appropriate god to appear in a play about the
	mistreatment and revenge of a team of horses;[c dimgray][sup]21[/sup][/c] and that
	he narrated a journey he had made to Himera[c dimgray][sup]22[/sup][/c] and prophesied
	that one day (in gratitude for good treatment he had
	received there?) he would give the Greeks of Sicily victory
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]19[/sup][/c]Herodotus 7.166.
	[c dimgray][sup]20[/sup][/c]This play also contained another reference to the western
	Greek lands, very likely in the same speech: fr. 40a (33 Nauck),
	cited by Hesychius from [c dimgray]Glaucus of Potniae[/c] (though arbitrarily ascribed
	to [c dimgray]Glaucus the Sea-god[/c] by most scholars since Hermann),
	refers to a harbour in or near the Strait of Messina.
	[c dimgray][sup]21[/sup][/c]And a god whom Xerxes is mentioned in [c dimgray]Persians[/c] (750) as
	having particularly offended.
	[c dimgray][sup]22[/sup][/c]Has he now come directly thence to Potniae to deal with
	the situation created by Glaucus’ death, as Athena in [c dimgray]Eumenides[/c]
	(397ff) comes directly from Sigeum in the Troad to Athens to answer
	the appeal of Orestes? And is it significant that Potniae was
	on the road from Plataea to Thebes, so that Athenian troops would
	have passed through the village when they marched on Thebes a
	few days after the battle of Plataea?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 8[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m][b]Aeschylus[/b]
	over their enemies.[c dimgray][sup]23[/sup][/c] Thus each of the first three plays of
	this production would narrate and/or foretell an important
	episode or episodes in the defeat of the great barbarian invasions
	of 480/79.[c dimgray][sup]24[/sup][/c] We do not know enough about the
	fourth play to be able to determine whether it too followed

	[m1]\ [/m]
	The production of a tragedy (indeed, if the argument of
	the last paragraph is right, of a whole trilogy) about events
	of a war that was still in progress—a play, moreover, which,
	while it did not mention any individual Athenian, alluded
	clearly enough to the exploits of Xanthippus (see above)
	and especially of Themistocles (353–363, not to mention
	the whole great narrative of his victory at Salamis)—has inevitably
	caused speculation as to whether it might have
	been designed to have some political impact, particularly
	in light of the earlier production by Phrynichus on the
	same subject for which Themistocles himself was probably
	[c dimgray]choregos[/c] (see above). It is known that Themistocles was
	ostracized at some time in the late 470s, but it is not known
	precisely when; all the same, even if this occurred later
	than 472, it was probably not his enemies’ first attempt to
	get rid of him.[c dimgray][sup]25[/sup][/c] Both Themistocles and (when he entered
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]23[/sup][/c]The Carthaginian commander, Hamilcar, had been killed
	by Syracusan [c dimgray]cavalry[/c] while making a sacrifice to [c dimgray]Poseidon[/c]
	(Diodorus Siculus 11.21.4–22.1).
	[c dimgray][sup]24[/sup][/c]Salamis, Plataea and Himera are likewise mentioned together
	in Pindar’s [c dimgray]First Pythian[/c] (75–80), performed before
	Hieron at Aetna in 470.
	[c dimgray][sup]25[/sup][/c]Before any particular individual could be ostracized (banished
	for ten years without loss of property) three hurdles had to
	be surmounted: (i) the Assembly had to vote that an ostracism be held; (ii) at a special Assembly held some two months later, a total
	of at least 6000 votes had to be cast; (iii) the person who had the
	most votes against him would then be ostracized. There may have
	been one or several attempts at ostracizing Themistocles which
	failed at the first or second hurdle, before the one that finally succeeded.
	[m1]\ [/m]

-145.011 (AESCHYLUS, Persians)
AESCHYLUS, Persians
	[c darkmagenta][b]AESCHYLUS, Persians[/b][/c]
	[b]Aeschylus[/b]
	politics) Pericles were opponents of the other outstanding
	political figure of this period, Cimon,[c dimgray][sup]26[/sup][/c] who had gained
	great prestige in the previous few years by the capture of
	Eion and Scyros and the restoration to Athens of the bones
	of Theseus;[c dimgray][sup]27[/sup][/c] so it is certainly not impossible that there was
	some political motivation behind the production of this
	particular play at this particular time.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	There was certainly political motivation behind the restaging
	that took place at Syracuse, probably a year or two
	later, at the invitation of its tyrant Hieron.[c dimgray][sup]28[/sup][/c] Hieron had
	taken part in the victory of Himera alongside his brother
	Gelon (who had been the ruler of Syracuse at that time),
	and it is reasonable to suppose—though we have no actual
	evidence—that Aeschylus was asked to, and did, produce
	[c dimgray]Glaucus of Potniae[/c] in Sicily as well.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]

	<span class="stage">[c dimgray]Produced[/c]: 472 bc, as second play in the tetralogy [c dimgray]Phineus,

	[c dimgray]Scene[/c]: Susa. Twelve chairs are set out for a meeting of the
	royal council. A mound (ignored until attention is drawn to
	it) represents the tomb of Darius. One side-passage is
	imagined as leading to the city and palace, the other towards

	Of the Persians, who have departed
	for the land of Greece, we are called the Trusted,[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]
	the guardians of the wealthy palace rich in gold,
	whom our lord himself, King Xerxes
	son of Darius, chose by seniority
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]A Greek term for the close counsellors of the Persian king;
	cf. Xenophon, [c dimgray]Anabasis[/c] 1.5.15. The opening of the play closely
	echoes that of Phrynichus’ earlier play on the same theme
	(Phrynichus fr. 8), but for βεβηκότων “who have gone” Aeschylus
	substitutes οἰχομένων, which carries a strong (though by the
	speakers unintended) suggestion that those who have departed
	are destined not to return.

	to supervise the country.
	But by now the spirit within me,
	all too ready to foresee evil, is troubled
	about the return of the King
	and of his vast army of men;
	for all the strength of the Asiatic race
	has departed, and <in every house
	the woman left behind> howls for her young husband;[c dimgray][sup]2[/sup][/c]
	and no messenger, no horseman,
	has come to the Persian capital.
	They left the walls of Susa and Agbatana[c dimgray][sup]3[/sup][/c]
	and the ancient ramparts of Cissia[c dimgray][sup]4[/sup][/c]
	and went, some on horseback,
	some on board ship, and the marching infantry
	providing the fighting masses.
	Such were Amistres and Artaphrenes
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]2[/sup][/c]For this tentative restoration cf. 63–64, 123–5, 135–9, 541–5,
	and see generally A. F. Garvie, [c dimgray]Lexis[/c] 17 (1999) 26–28. If we do not
	posit a lacuna, we are forced to assume that the νέος ἀνήρ is
	Xerxes (cf. 782) and that it is “the strength of the Asiatic race” (i.e.
	the army) which is “howling” about him; but it makes no sense that
	the chorus should make confident assertions about the state of
	opinion in the army when the whole context is concerned with the
	apprehensions that are assailing them owing to their total lack of
	information about what the army is doing and how it is faring.
	[c dimgray][sup]3[/sup][/c]The capital of Media, about 300 km north of Susa; usually
	called Ecbatana by Herodotus and later Greek authors (modern
	Hamadan).
	[c dimgray][sup]4[/sup][/c]Aeschylus seems to take this as the name of a city (cf. 120); it
	was in fact the name of the region (today Khuzestan, or al-Ahwaz,
	in south-western Iran) of which Susa was the chief city.

	great Arsames, the ruler
	of holy Memphis, and Ariomardus
	who governs ancient Thebes;
	and dwellers in the marshes,[c dimgray][sup]6[/sup][/c] rowing ships,
	formidable and in numbers past counting.
	Following them are a mass of Lydians
	of luxurious lifestyle, who control every race
	born on the mainland;[c dimgray][sup]7[/sup][/c] Mitragathes
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]5[/sup][/c]Here begins the first of three long catalogues of leaders of
	the army (the others are at 302–328 and 957–999). A substantial
	proportion of them are, certainly or probably, genuine Persian names; most of the others would give a Greek ear the impression
	of being Persian or at least exotic. Aeschylus does not seem to have
	been interested in prosopographical accuracy, at least not to any
	significant extent; of the twelve principal commanders named by
	Herodotus (7.82, 88, 97) not one is mentioned in the play.
	[c dimgray][sup]6[/sup][/c]Of the Nile delta.
	[c dimgray][sup]7[/sup][/c]“The mainland” (ἤπειρος) here means (western) Asia Minor,
	which had once been controlled by the kingdom of Lydia and was
	now governed from that kingdom’s former capital, Sardis, by a
	Persian satrap.

	ample,[c dimgray][sup]27[/sup][/c] but I fear for our very eye; for I consider the master,

	this, considering the situation to be as I have said, be my
	counsellors about this matter, you venerable, trusty Persians;
	for all the good advice I receive comes from you.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	Be well assured, Queen of this land, that you do not have to
	tell us twice to do any service in word or deed, so far as our
	ability permits:[c dimgray][sup]28[/sup][/c] we on whom you call for advice are your
	loyal friends.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]queen[/b][/c]
	Dreams of the night have been my frequent companions
	ever since my son led out his army and departed in order
	to lay waste the land of the Ionians;[c dimgray][sup]29[/sup][/c] but never yet have
	I had one that was so plain as during the night just past. I
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]26[/sup][/c]In other words, human and material resources are alike essential
	to the acquisition and maintenance of political power (cf.
	Sophocles, [c dimgray]Oedipus the King[/c] 540–2), and a regime that is strong in
	only one of these respects may well be in danger.
	[c dimgray][sup]27[/sup][/c]lit. “irreproachable”.
	[c dimgray][sup]28[/sup][/c]lit. “of those in which ability
	is willing to lead (us)”.
	[c dimgray][sup]29[/sup][/c]The Persians and many other
	peoples of western Asia applied the name “Ionian” (Old Persian
	[c dimgray]Yauna[/c], Hebrew [c dimgray]Yawan[/c], etc.) to all Greeks, doubtless because the
	first Greeks with whom they came into contact, those of Asia Minor,
	mostly belonged to the Ionian branch of the Greek people.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	will tell you about it. There seemed to come into my sight

	other in Doric robes,[c dimgray][sup]30[/sup][/c] outstandingly superior in stature to
	the women of real life, of flawless beauty, and sisters of the
	same stock: one, by the fall of the lot, was a native and inhabitant
	of the land of Greece, the other of the Orient.[c dimgray][sup]31[/sup][/c] I
	seemed to see these two raising some kind of strife between
	themselves; my son, perceiving this, tried to restrain
	and calm them, yoked them under his chariot, and passed
	the yoke-strap under their necks. One of them, thus arrayed,
	towered up proudly, and kept her jaw submissively
	in harness; but the other began to struggle, tore the harness
	from the chariot with her hands, dragged it violently
	along without bridle or bit, and smashed the yoke in half.
	My son fell out. His father Darius appeared, standing beside
	him and showing pity; but when Xerxes saw him, he
	tore the robes that clothed his body. That, I say, is what I
	saw in the night. When I had risen and washed my hands in

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]30[/sup][/c]Aeschylus chooses to dress the woman representing Greece
	in “Doric” rather than “Ionic” style, not because he is imagining
	her as a Dorian Greek (e.g. a Spartan)—both styles were in use in the Athens of his day—but because the Doric [c dimgray]chiton[/c] (typically
	woollen, and pinned at the shoulders) symbolized Greek simplicity,
	in contrast to Persian luxury, more effectively than the Ionic
	(draped, and often of fine linen). Both styles are seen, for example,
	on an amphora of about 460 bc in Oxford (Ashmolean 280)
	showing a father, mother and sister bidding farewell to a departing
	warrior; see S. Lewis, [c dimgray]The Athenian Woman[/c] (London, 2002) 41
	fig. 1.22.
	[c dimgray][sup]31[/sup][/c]Frequently in this play Persians speak of themselves as
	βάρβαροι, properly a Greek term for those who did not speak the
	Greek language; I have translated this throughout as “orient(al)”
	or “Eastern(er)” (but in other plays, where the term is used by
	Greeks, I have retained the traditional rendering “barbarian”).

	οὔτε θαρσύνειν· θεοὺς δὲ προστροπαῖς ἱκνουμένη,
	εἴ τι φλαῦρον εἶδες, αἰτοῦ τῶνδ᾿ ἀποτροπὴν τελεῖν,
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]210[/sup][/c]ἐμοί τε Blomfield: ἐμοὶ [c dimgray]b[/c]: ἔμοιγε M I [c dimgray]b k.[/c]<li id="note_LCL145_36_210-1" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]210[/sup][/c]εἰσιδεῖν Hartung: ἐς ἰδεῖν vel sim. M [c dimgray]b[/c] (ἐστ᾿ ἐσιδεῖν [c dimgray]b΄[/c]):
	ἔστ᾿ ἰδεῖν vel sim. I [c dimgray]b k.[/c]<li id="note_LCL145_36_211" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]211[/sup][/c]τ᾿ [c dimgray]k[/c]: δ᾿ M I [c dimgray]b.[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 36[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Persians[/b][/c]
	in my hand, wishing to pour a rich libation to the deities
	who avert evil, for whom such rites are appropriate. Then I
	saw an eagle fleeing for refuge to the altar of Phoebus[c dimgray][sup]32[/sup][/c]—and I was rooted speechless to the spot with terror, my
	friends. Next I saw a hawk swooping on him at full speed
	with beating wings, and tearing at his head with its
	talons[c dimgray][sup]33[/sup][/c]—and he simply cowered and submitted.[c dimgray][sup]34[/sup][/c] This
	was terrifying for me to behold, and must be terrifying for
	you to hear; for you know well that if my son were successful
	he would be a very much admired man, but were he to
	fail—well, he is not accountable to the community,[c dimgray][sup]35[/sup][/c] and if
	he comes home safe he remains ruler of this land.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	Mother, we do not wish to say what would make you either
	unduly fearful or unduly optimistic. You should approach
	the gods with supplications and ask them, if there was anything
	sinister in what you saw, to ensure that it is averted,
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]32[/sup][/c]The omen is easy to interpret (as is evident from the fact
	that Aeschylus leaves his audience to interpret it for themselves):
	that the mother of the greatest of human kings, full of anxiety
	about his fate, sees the “king of birds” ([c dimgray]Agamemnon[/c] 114) fleeing
	from a bird of lesser status and submitting without resistance to
	degrading treatment, speaks for itself. Various explanations have
	been offered for why the eagle is represented as seeking the altar
	of Phoebus (Apollo) in particular; I suggest that the point is that the eagle is going [c dimgray]to the worst possible place[/c]—for the eagle is the
	bird of Zeus, not Apollo, and the latter, though his best-known
	avian connection is with swans, also has one with hawks ([c dimgray]Iliad[/c]
	15.237; [c dimgray]Odyssey[/c] 15.526; Aristophanes, [c dimgray]Birds[/c] 516). Contrast Aesop,
	[c dimgray]Fable[/c] 3 Perry, where the eagle seeks sanctuary from an
	enemy by nesting in the lap of Zeus. Has Xerxes too gone to the
	most unpropitious place he could have chosen?
	[c dimgray][sup]33[/sup][/c]No real hawk would or could do this (even if, [c dimgray]per impossibile,[/c]
	it were to attack an eagle), but cf. [c dimgray]Odyssey[/c] 15.526–7.
	[c dimgray][sup]34[/sup][/c]lit. “provided his body” (to be abused).
	[c dimgray][sup]35[/sup][/c]Unlike an Athenian general such as Miltiades, who not long
	after his victory at Marathon was nearly sentenced to death for
	failing to capture Paros, and eventually died in prison (Herodotus
	6.136; Plato, [c dimgray]Gorgias[/c] 516d-e; Plutarch, [c dimgray]Cimon[/c] 4.4).
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 37[/c]

	[c darkmagenta][b]Persians[/b][/c]

	And who is the shepherd, master and commander over
	their host?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	They are not called slaves or subjects to any man.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]

	[m1]\ [/m]

	What you say is fearful to think about, for the parents of
	those who have gone there.\[[c dimgray]A messenger[/c] is seen approaching from the west, in great

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	Well, it seems to me that you will soon know the whole
	story precisely. The way this man runs clearly identifies
	him as Persian,[c dimgray][sup]43[/sup][/c] and he will be bringing some definite
	news, good or bad, for us to hear.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]messenger[/b][/c]
	O you cities of the whole land of Asia! O land of Persia,
	Repository[c dimgray][sup]44[/sup][/c] of great wealth! How all your great prosperity
	has been destroyed in a single blow, and the flower of the
	Persians are fallen and departed! \[[c dimgray]To the chorus[/c]\] Ah me, it
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]43[/sup][/c]This has been seen as a reference to the Persians’ system of
	fast couriers (Aeschylus alludes to them at [c dimgray]Agamemnon[/c] 282—but
	they were mounted), or as a chauvinistic gibe, from a Greek point
	of view, at Persians’ alleged cowardice (they run very fast—away
	from the enemy); more likely it is simply based on observation of
	the actual running styles of Greeks and Persians respectively. It would not be surprising if these styles tended to differ, given that
	Greek running techniques had been honed by many generations
	of athletic competition.
	[c dimgray][sup]44[/sup][/c]lit. “harbour”.

	[c dimgray][sup]313, 312[/sup][/c]transposed by Merkel.<li id="note_LCL145_51_315-314" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]315, 314[/sup][/c]transposed by Heimsoeth.<li id="note_LCL145_51_52" class="note">[c dimgray][sup]52[/sup][/c]lit. “light”.
	[c dimgray][sup]53[/sup][/c]According to the scholia (as emended
	with the help of Hesychius), this name was given to a part of the
	coastline of Salamis near “Trophy Point”. Probably the reference
	is to one side of the long peninsula of Cynosura at the eastern
	extremity of the island.
	[c dimgray][sup]54[/sup][/c]πολεῖ would normally imply wandering or ranging across
	the actual territory of the island, but here the context, and the
	audience’s knowledge, make it clear that what is meant is that
	Tenagon’s corpse is drifting around its shores.
	[c dimgray][sup]55[/sup][/c]This may be another way of describing Salamis, or may designate
	a small island in its vicinity.
	[c dimgray][sup]56[/sup][/c]This line (315) is clearly out of place where it stands in the
	mss., since Matallus could not be described both as a “commander
	of ten thousand” and as a “leader of thirty thousand”.
	[c dimgray][sup]57[/sup][/c]Possibly the town of this name in the Troad is meant (cf.
	[c dimgray]Iliad[/c] 1.37), or possibly the place-name (“city of gold”) is an invented
	one (cf. the “Golden Mountains” of Persia in Aristophanes,
	[c dimgray]Acharnians[/c] 82).
	[c dimgray][sup]58[/sup][/c]sc. of blood.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[c darkmagenta][b]Persians[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]messenger[/b][/c]
	I assure you that, so far as numbers are concerned, the
	fleet of the Easterners would have prevailed. The Greeks
	had a grand total of about three hundred ships,[c dimgray][sup]61[/sup][/c] and ten of
	these formed a special select squadron; whereas Xerxes—I
	know this for sure—had a thousand under his command,
	and those of outstanding speed numbered two hundred
	and seven.[c dimgray][sup]62[/sup][/c] Such is the reckoning; I hardly imagine you’ll
	consider we were inferior in [c dimgray]that[/c] respect in the battle! It
	was some divinity that destroyed our fleet like this, weighting
	the scales so that fortune did not fall out even: the gods
	have saved the city of the goddess Pallas.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]queen[/b][/c]
	Then the city of Athens is still unsacked?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]messenger[/b][/c]
	While she has her men, her defences are secure.[c dimgray][sup]63[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]61[/sup][/c]lit. “ten thirties of ships”. Herodotus (8.43–48) gives the
	total of the Greek fleet as 385, of which 180 were Athenian. The
	Persian messenger cannot of course give an exact figure, and Aeschylus
	rounds down rather than up so as to maximize the disparity
	between the two fleets.
	[c dimgray][sup]62[/sup][/c]The natural way of understanding this is to take the 207
	extra-fast ships to be part of the total of 1000, just as the ten ships
	of the Greek élite squadron are part of their total of 300.
	Herodotus (7.89. 1, 7.184.1) seems to have read the passage otherwise,
	for he gives the total numbers of the Persian fleet, when it first reached Greece, as precisely 1207; they suffered, however,
	according to his narrative, severe losses before Salamis (by storm,
	and in the battle of Artemisium), and at Salamis they did not
	greatly outnumber the Greeks (8.13; contrast 8.66 where he implausibly
	claims that the losses were made good by reinforcements
	from subjugated Greek states).
	[c dimgray][sup]63[/sup][/c]This either alludes to, or else it inspired, the story of
	Themistocles’ retort to the Corinthian Adeimantus at the Greek
	council of war which finally decided to stand and fight at Salamis.
	Adeimantus had tried to silence Themistocles, and prevent his
	proposal being put to a vote, because Themistocles was “a man
	without a city”, Attica having been evacuated by its population,
	its territory occupied by the Persians, and the city sacked and
	burned; to which Themistocles replied “We have a city and a
	country greater than yours, while we have two hundred ships and
	their crews” (Herodotus 8.61).
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 55[/c]

	Ah, wretched me, my friends, this terrible catastrophe! By

	[c darkmagenta][b]messenger[/b][/c]
	There is an island in front of Salamis,[c dimgray][sup]72[/sup][/c] small and offering
	no good anchorage for ships, whose seashore is a haunt of
	Pan, lover of dances.[c dimgray][sup]73[/sup][/c] Xerxes sent these men there so that,
	when shipwrecked enemy men were trying to reach safety
	on the island, they could kill the Greek warriors when they
	were an easy prey while rescuing their own men from the
	straits of the sea; he was reading the future badly. When
	god had given the triumph in the naval battle to the
	Greeks, that same day they clad themselves in stout bronze
	armour, leaped off their ships, and landed all around the island,
	so that the Persians had no idea which way to turn.
	They were being heavily battered by hand-thrown stones,
	and hit and killed by arrows shot from the bowstring, until
	finally the Greeks charged them in a simultaneous rush
	and struck them down, hacking the wretched men’s limbs
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]72[/sup][/c]This island was Psyttaleia, on which, according to
	Herodotus (8.76.1–2), Xerxes stationed “many of the Persians”
	(Pausanias 1.36.2 gives the number as about 400) with the same
	objective as is stated here; they were killed to the last man by an Athenian hoplite force, led by Aristeides, which crossed over from
	Salamis while the naval battle was in progress (Herodotus 8.95).
	In Aeschylus’ treatment, on the other hand, the Greek attack on
	the island is made immediately [c dimgray]after[/c] the naval battle, and by the
	same men who had fought it. Psyttaleia has been identified in
	modern times, sometimes with the island now officially so named
	(formerly Lipsokoutali) between Cynosura and the Peiraeus,
	sometimes with the island of Aghios Georghios in the bay north of
	Salamis town.
	[c dimgray][sup]73[/sup][/c]Pausanias [c dimgray]loc.cit[/c]. noted that there were many roughly-carved
	wooden images of Pan on the island.

	into the Thermaic Gulf, marks approximately the point at which
	the Persians’ line of march turned from north to east.
	[c dimgray][sup]79[/sup][/c]This lake formed part of the boundary between the
	Chalcidic region to the south of it, with its Greek colonies, and the
	Macedonian kingdom.
	[c dimgray][sup]80[/sup][/c]The mention of Mount Pangaeum
	is technically out of place, since it lies [c dimgray]east[/c] of the Strymon;
	but probably all that is meant is that the army came [c dimgray]in sight[/c] of the
	mountain.
	[c dimgray][sup]81[/sup][/c]lit. “caused the middle of the channel to move
	apart” (διῆκε is aorist of διίημι).
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 69[/c]

	For now all, yes all, the emptied land
	of Asia groans:
	Xerxes took them—popoi!
	Xerxes lost them—totoi!
	Xerxes handled everything unwisely,
	he and his sea-boats.
	Why did Darius for his part
	do so little harm[c dimgray][sup]85[/sup][/c] when he was the bowmaster
	who ruled over the citizenry,
	the dear leader of Susiana?
	Land-soldiers and seamen—
	the dark-faced,86 equal-winged[c dimgray][sup]87[/sup][/c]
	ships brought them—popoi!—
	ships destroyed them—totoi!—
	ships, with ruinous ramming,
	and driven by Ionian hands!
	And the King himself,
	so we hear, barely escaped,
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[c dimgray][sup]86[/sup][/c]The ship’s “face” is her prow (cf. the Homeric formula νεὸς
	Κυανοπρῴροιο—and, for the metaphor, the “crimson-cheeked
	ships” of [c dimgray]Odyssey[/c] 11.124 and, in reverse, καλλίπρῳρος “fair-faced”,
	used of Parthenopaeus in [c dimgray]Seven[/c] 533 and of Iphigeneia in
	[c dimgray]Ag.[/c] 235), possibly with allusion to the eyes so often painted on
	ships’ bows.

	[c dimgray][sup]88[/sup][/c]This is a long wail, a prolonged vowel \[ε:\] followed by a
	shorter, slightly closer vowel \[e\].
	[c dimgray][sup]89[/sup][/c]Cychreus was a Salaminian hero (\[Hesiod\] fr. 226; Pherecydes
	fr. 60 Fowler; Diodorus Siculus 4.72.4–7; \[Apollodorus\], [c dimgray]Library[/c]
	3.12.7; Plutarch, [c dimgray]Theseus[/c] 10.3, [c dimgray]Solon[/c] 9.1). He was linked
	mythically to the family of Telamon and Ajax by being said to have
	died leaving a daughter who became either the mother or the wife
	of Telamon. During the battle of Salamis he appeared to the Athenians
	in the form of a serpent (Pausanias 1.36.1). Sophocles (fr.
	579) refers to a “Cychrean rock” on the island.
	[c dimgray][sup]90[/sup][/c]The “Undefiled” is the sea, which washes away all ritual pollution
	and can never become polluted itself; cf. Euripides, [c dimgray]Iphigeneia
	in Tauris[/c] 1193, and see R. Parker, [c dimgray]Miasma[/c] (Oxford, 1983)
	226–7. Its “children” are the fish.

	of directive authority. Medus[c dimgray][sup]111[/sup][/c] was the first leader of our

	ruler in the succession from him was Cyrus, a man blessed
	by the gods, who gave peace to all those he cared for, since
	his intelligence was in control of[c dimgray][sup]112[/sup][/c] his fighting spirit; he
	gained mastery over the peoples of Lydia and Phrygia, and
	overran all of Ionia by force. God did not hate him, because
	he was wise. The son of Cyrus[c dimgray][sup]113[/sup][/c] was the fourth to
	direct the host. The fifth ruler was Mardus,[c dimgray][sup]114[/sup][/c] a disgrace
	to his country and to his ancient throne. He was killed in

	Artaphrenes[c dimgray][sup]115[/sup][/c] together with some friends who took on

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]111[/sup][/c]Probably to be taken as the (mythical) eponymous founder
	of the kingdom of the Medes (cf. on 236). Later tragedians spoke
	of a Medus, son of Medea and Aegeus, as the ancestor of the
	Median people (Diodorus Siculus 4.55.5–56.1; \[Apollodorus\],
	[c dimgray]Library[/c] 1.9.28). Alternatively Μῆδος may mean “a Mede”, in
	which case the reference will be to Cyaxares (reigned ca.625–585),
	the first Median king to extend his rule into Asia Minor; in
	that case his son will be Astyages, the maternal grandfather of
	Cyrus, eventually deposed by him.
	[c dimgray][sup]112[/sup][/c]lit. “turned the helm of”.
	[c dimgray][sup]113[/sup][/c]This was Cambyses (reigned 529–522), the conqueror of
	Egypt.
	[c dimgray][sup]114[/sup][/c]In Herodotus (3.61–79) he is called Smerdis and said to be
	a usurper impersonating Cambyses’ brother of the same name (in
	Persian [c dimgray]Bardiya[/c]); so too Darius himself in the Behistun inscription
	(§§11–15; translated in M. Brosius, [c dimgray]The Persian Empire from
	Cyrus II to Artaxerxes I[/c] \[London, 2000\] 23–24, 27–40) except that
	he calls the usurper Gaumata.
	[c dimgray][sup]115[/sup][/c]Herodotus (3.70ff) calls this man Intaphrenes, which is
	considerably closer to the Persian [c dimgray]Vindafarnā[/c]; evidently Aeschylus
	has confused him with a man much better known to Greeks,
	Darius’ brother, the governor of Sardis at the time of the Ionian
	revolt (Herodotus 5.25.1 etc.), whose son of the same name had
	been joint commander of the Persian forces at Marathon.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]116[/sup][/c]i.e. we (either all the conspirators—so in effect Herodotus
	3.84–88—or Darius and Artaphrenes alone) drew lots for the
	kingship, and I won. If the additional line (778) present in the mss.
	is retained in the text, the meaning will be: “He was killed . . . by
	the admirable Artaphrenes, together with some friends who took
	on this duty; the sixth <to rule> was Maraphis, the seventh
	Artaphrenes and myself; and I gained by chance the lot I desired.”
	The genuineness of the line is defended by M. L. West in M. A.
	Flower and M. Toher ed. [c dimgray]Georgica: Studies in Honour of George[/c] [c dimgray]Cawkwell[/c] (London, 1991) 184–8; but the text in this form gives no
	indication of who Maraphis was, leaves the nature of the connection
	between Artaphrenes and Darius completely undefined,
	makes Darius claim no credit at all for the assassination of the
	“disgrace” Mardus, and fails to explain why Artaphrenes, having
	masterminded Mardus’ death, did not succeed immediately himself.
	See W. Kraus, [c dimgray]Wiener Studien[/c] 104 (1991) 90–91. The interpolated
	line may derive ultimately from a marginal variant
	(Μάραφις for Μάρδος) on 774, itself based on an apparent statement
	by the historian Hellanicus ([c dimgray]FGrH[/c] 4 F 180, cited in a
	scholium on 770) that Cambyses’ brothers were named Maraphis
	and Merphis; if the variant was written at the bottom of a column,
	below line 777, it could have been mistaken for a remnant of a lost
	line, and a “restoration” of that line cobbled together.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	What do you mean? Hasn’t the whole of the Eastern army
	crossed back from Europe over the strait of Helle?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ghost of darius[/b][/c]
	Few out of many, if one is to place any credence in the oracles
	of the gods, looking at what has now happened—for
	oracles are not fulfilled by halves.[c dimgray][sup]117[/sup][/c] If that is indeed so,
	Xerxes, seduced by vain hopes, has left behind a large, select
	portion of his army. They remain where the Asopus[c dimgray][sup]118[/sup][/c]
	waters the plain with its stream, bringing welcome enrichment
	to the soil of the Boeotians.[c dimgray][sup]119[/sup][/c] There the destiny
	awaits them of suffering a crowning catastrophe, in requital
	for their outrageous actions and their godless arrogance.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]117[/sup][/c]lit. “for it is not the case that some things come to pass and
	others do not”. Darius’ point is that the same oracle which had
	foretold the naval defeat at Salamis also foretold a crushing defeat
	on land, soon after, at Plataea. The first part of this oracle had now
	been fulfilled; therefore the second part would be, too.
	[c dimgray][sup]118[/sup][/c]The principal river of Boeotia, which separates Thebes
	from Plataea and Mt Cithaeron to the south.
	[c dimgray][sup]119[/sup][/c]Aeschylus has simplified the course of events. Mardonius’
	army actually wintered in Thessaly (Herodotus 8.113–135), and in
	the spring he advanced on Athens, which was captured and later
	burnt for the second time (Herodotus 9.1–3, 9.13.2); only when it
	was clear that Athens would not come to terms, and that the Spartans
	were on the march, did he retreat into Boeotia and prepare to
	meet the enemy there (Herodotus 9.12–15).
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]123[/sup][/c]lit. “all-sufficing”, i.e. always satisfying the needs of any
	situation.
	[c dimgray][sup]124[/sup][/c]The transmitted text is unmetrical, and, to the extent that it
	can be tortured into sense, seems to refer to the excellence and
	stability of Persian laws, a subject with no relevance to the surrounding
	context which relates exclusively to Persian success in war. Moreover, the scholia clearly reflect a text that made some
	reference to the sacking of cities (for this theme cf. 65, 105–8, 178,
	348). I suspect therefore that πάντ᾿ ἐπεύθυνον is a fragment of a
	marginal note (probably part of a quotation from another play)
	which has driven the original ending of this line out of the text.
	[c dimgray][sup]125[/sup][/c]lit. “and returns from wars brought <our men . . .”
	[c dimgray][sup]126[/sup][/c]This river (now the Kizilirmak) divides northern Asia Minor
	into an eastern and a western half, and had formerly been the
	boundary between the Median and Lydian empires.
	[c dimgray][sup]127[/sup][/c]lit. “Acheloian”: the name of the river Achelous (the largest
	in Greece, and sometimes spoken of as the father of all rivers—cf.
	Euripides, [c dimgray]Bacchae[/c] 519), was used in poetry to mean “(fresh) water”
	([c dimgray]ibid[/c]. 625; Sophocles fr. 5; Aristophanes, [c dimgray]Lysistrata[/c] 381).
	[c dimgray][sup]128[/sup][/c]The reference is to the lake-villages of the Strymon basin
	(cf. Herodotus 5.16), well known to Athenians in 472 because of
	Cimon’s recent campaign on the lower Strymon, which included a
	large-scale clearance of the Thracians in the neighbourhood (Plutarch,
	[c dimgray]Cimon[/c] 7.2).
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]

	In response to your return
	I shall send forth, send forth with many tears
	the shout of woeful words, the cry of woeful thoughts
	of a Mariandynian dirge-singer.[c dimgray][sup]137[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]136[/sup][/c]With W. Kraus,[c dimgray]Wiener Studien[/c] 104 (1991) 101 n.50, I take
	ἀγδαβάται to mean ἄγδην (Lucian, [c dimgray]Lexiphanes[/c] 10) βαίνοντες “marching as if led away by force”.
	[c dimgray][sup]137[/sup][/c]The Mariandyni were a people of north-western Asia Minor
	(in the hinterland of the Greek colony of Heraclea Pontica),
	whose ritual laments were famous.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]146[/sup][/c]i.e. a carriage with curtains (the normal Greek word was
	ἁρμάμαξα), to Greeks an emblem of Persian luxury (cf. Aristophanes, [c dimgray]Acharnians[/c] 70). On his westward march to Greece,
	Xerxes travelled sometimes in a chariot, sometimes in a ἁρμάμαξα,
	with “a thousand of the noblest and bravest Persians”
	following him, together with other picked troops (Herodotus
	7.41.1–2). The Persian elders had expected that he would return
	in similar style, with his carriage and his escort: he has come back
	with neither.
	[c dimgray][sup]147[/sup][/c]I translate West’s conjecture ([c dimgray]Studies[/c] 94–95), which involves
	a syntactic construction not exactly paralleled but gives
	excellent sense, especially in contrasting the Persians’ “age-old
	good fortune” with their “new” (1010) and unanticipated (1006)
	disaster.
	[m1]\ [/m]

-145.139 (AESCHYLUS, Seven against Thebes)
%Aeschylus
AESCHYLUS, Seven against Thebes
	[c darkmagenta][b]AESCHYLUS, Seven against Thebes[/b][/c]
		[m1]\ [/m][b]Aeschylus[/b]
	[b]Seven Against Thebes[/b]
	[c dimgray]Seven against Thebes[/c][c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c] was produced at the City Dionysia
	of 467 bc as the third part of a four-play production—that
	is, the last play in a tragic trilogy; it was preceded by [c dimgray]Laius[/c]
	and [c dimgray]Oedipus,[/c] and followed by the satyr-drama [c dimgray]The Sphinx.[/c]
	The production won first prize. Both the rival dramatists
	on this occasion were sons of famous tragic poets of the
	previous generation. One of them, Aristias (who took second
	place) was actually producing the plays of his father
	Pratinas,[c dimgray][sup]2[/sup][/c] who doubtless had died recently leaving these
	compositions behind him, just as the last plays of Euripides
	and of Sophocles were produced posthumously by
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]This title, though already current in the late fifth century
	(Aristophanes, [c dimgray]Frogs[/c] 1021), is unlikely to be Aeschylean, since nowhere
	in the play are Thebes or the Thebans referred to under
	those names; they are always called the city and people of
	Cadmus. I have argued, indeed, that in Aeschylus’ time, where the
	plays of a tragic trilogy presented a sequence of episodes in a single
	story, it was not customary to give separate titles to the individual
	dramas; see [c dimgray]Hermes[/c] 117 (1989) 432–6 and [c dimgray]Seminari Romani[/c] 5
	(2002) 4–5.
	[c dimgray][sup]2[/sup][/c]So the papyrus version of the Hypothesis ([c dimgray]Oxyrhynchus Papyrus[/c]
	2256 fr. 2); in the early medieval manuscript M (the only
	one to preserve the relevant part of the Hypothesis) the satyrdrama
	alone is said to have been Pratinas’ work.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 139[/c]

	adorning the chariot of Adrastus[c dimgray][sup]9[/sup][/c] with mementoes of

	of pity passed their lips: there breathed within them a
	steel-hearted spirit, blazing with courage, like that of lions

	in learning this by any slowness of mine: I left them
	drawing lots, so that according to the fall of the lot each
	should lead his company against a gate. In view of this, you
	should speedily post men of excellence, the pick of the city,
	at the entrances of the gates; for the Argive army, fully
	equipped, is already coming close, raising the dust, and
	white foam from the horses’ lungs is dripping and staining
	the soil. Be like a good ship’s captain and make the city
	tight, before the squalls of war assail her—for this army is
	like a roaring land-wave—and take the very quickest opportunity
	of doing this. For my part, from now on, I will
	keep a faithful daytime scout’s eye out,[c dimgray][sup]11[/sup][/c] and through my
	clear reports you will know what is happening outside and
	not come to harm.<span class="stage">[c dimgray]Exit scout[/c], by the way he came.

	(as in Euripides, [c dimgray]Phoenician Maidens[/c] 1134); but he invariably survives
	the war, and Aeschylus evidently wanted to have all the
	Seven perish.
	[c dimgray][sup]10[/sup][/c]Probably locks of hair; on eight vase-paintings ([c dimgray]LIMC[/c]
	Septem 24–31) datable between 490 and 460, one of the Seven is
	shown cutting a lock.
	[c dimgray][sup]11[/sup][/c]Implying that his first scouting expedition had been in darkness
	or at least twilight (cf. 29).
	[m1]\ [/m]

	Curse and Fury of my father,[c dimgray][sup]12[/sup][/c] do not let my [c dimgray]city[/c][c dimgray][sup]13[/sup][/c] be captured
	by its foes, do not extirpate it from Greece, root and
	branch, in utter destruction! Never bind this free land and
	this free city of Cadmus with the yokestrap of slavery! Be
	its defence! I believe I am speaking in our common interest;
	for when a city enjoys success, it honours its gods.<span class="stage">[c dimgray]Exit eteocles[/c] towards the walls. The chorus of Theban
	maidens enter, from the town, in terror and confusion.
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]

	<Ah, ah,> I cry for great, fearful sufferings!
	The army has been let loose, it has left its camp!
	This great host of horse is pouring forward at the gallop!
	The dust I see in the air shows me it is so,
	a voiceless messenger, but true and certain!
	The soil <of my land>,
	struck by hooves, sends the noise right to my ear!
	It’s flying, it’s roaring like an irresistible
	mountain torrent!
	Oh, oh, you gods and you goddesses, keep off
	the surge of evil!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]12[/sup][/c]The Furies (Erinyes) seem in early times to have been
	identified with curses, especially [c dimgray]parental[/c] curses; cf. [c dimgray]Iliad[/c] 9.454,
	571, [c dimgray]Odyssey[/c] 2.135; Hesiod, [c dimgray]Theogony[/c] 472. In [c dimgray]Eumenides[/c] 417 the
	Furies say that “Curses” is their name in their homes beneath the
	earth.
	[c dimgray][sup]13[/sup][/c]The word πόλιν “city” is given extra stress by the particle
	γε, implying that Eteocles is prepared to lose his own life so long
	as the city is saved.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	The noise <of a war-cry comes> over the walls:
	the army with their white shields rise
	plain to see, coming swift<footed> against the city![c dimgray][sup]14[/sup][/c]
	Who, who of the gods or goddesses
	will protect us, who will ward them off?
	Should I, then, fall down before
	the <ancestral> images of our gods?
	O blest ones, in your fair abode!
	Now is the moment to clasp the images: why do we wait
	and moan to no purpose?
	Do you hear, or do you not, the clatter of shields?
	When, when, if not now, shall we be able <to adorn
	the gods> with robes and garlands as prayer-offerings?
	I see the noise[c dimgray][sup]15[/sup][/c]—it is the clatter of many spears!
	What do you mean to do, Ares, ancient god
	of this land?[c dimgray][sup]16[/sup][/c] betray your own country?
	God of the golden helmet, watch over, watch over the
	city
	which you once held worthy of your love!<span class="stage">[c dimgray]They approach the shrine, prostrate themselves and embrace
	the images.[/c]
	Gods who dwell in this city and land, come hither, all of
	you,
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]14[/sup][/c]The enemy infantry have now joined the cavalry (80–4) in
	the attack.
	[c dimgray][sup]15[/sup][/c]i.e. it creates a vivid picture in my mind’s eye.
	[c dimgray][sup]16[/sup][/c]Ares plays a crucial role in the story of the founding of
	Thebes by Cadmus (the dragon that Cadmus slew and/or the
	spring which it guarded being sacred to him); he was the father of
	Cadmus’ wife Harmonia.

	[c darkmagenta][b]Seven Against Thebes[/b][/c]
	comes the clean[c dimgray][sup]23[/sup][/c] conclusion to battle that decides a war,
	and you, blest queen Onca, dwelling before the city,[c dimgray][sup]24[/sup][/c]
	protect your seven-gated home.
	O gods, you almighty defenders,
	O gods and goddesses with decisive power
	to guard the walls of this land,
	do not betray this city in the toils of battle
	to an enemy of alien speech![c dimgray][sup]25[/sup][/c]
	Do not fail to hear, to hear the prayers
	of maidens with uplifted hands!
	O beloved gods,
	stand over our city to liberate it
	and show how you love it,
	take heed of the people’s worship,
	take heed, and defend them;
	and be mindful, I beg you,
	of the city’s loving sacrificial rites.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]23[/sup][/c]Greek ἁγνόν “holy, pure, free of pollution”, possibly hinting
	at a wish for the god to protect the lives of non-combatants like
	themselves (the killing of enemies [c dimgray]in battle[/c] did not count as homicide
	and involved no pollution).
	[c dimgray][sup]24[/sup][/c]The sanctuary of this local goddess was just outside one of
	the city gates (501–2).
	[c dimgray][sup]25[/sup][/c]The enemy, of course, spoke Greek (though a different dialect
	or dialects), and worshipped the very same gods; but Aeschylus
	seems to be inviting the audience to compare Theban fears to
	their own when facing the Persian invasion of 480.

	I ask you, you insufferable creatures, is this the best policy,
	does it help save our city, does it give confidence to our beleaguered
	population, to fall down before the images of
	the city’s gods and cry and howl in a way any sensible person
	would abhor? Whether in trouble or in welcome prosperity,
	may I not share my home with the female gender!
	When a woman is in the ascendant, her effrontery is impossible
	to live with; when she’s frightened, she is an even
	greater menace to family and city. So now, with you running
	around in all directions like this, your clamour has
	spread panic and cowardice among the citizens; you are
	doing your very best to advance the cause of the enemy
	outside—the city is being sacked by its own people from
	within! That’s the sort of thing you’ll get if you live with
	women! Now then, if anyone fails to obey my command,
	whether a man or a woman or anything in between, a vote
	of death will be passed against them and there is no way
	they will escape execution by public stoning. Out-of-door
	affairs are the concern of men; women are not to offer
	opinions about them. Stay inside and do no harm!
	[m1]\ [/m]

	Dear son of Oedipus, I was frightened when I heard

	he utters these cries he shakes three crests casting long

	his shield bells of beaten bronze make a terrifying clang.
	Fashioned upon his shield he bears this proud device: a
	blazing firmament, full of stars. Conspicuous in the centre
	of the shield is a brilliant full moon, the greatest of the
	stars, the eye of night. Raving thus, in his boastful armour,
	he screams by the banks of the river, longing for battle, like
	a horse panting against the force of bit and bridle and impatiently
	awaiting the sound of the trumpet. Whom will
	you station to oppose this man? Who can be relied on to
	stand before Proetus’ Gate when its bolts are undrawn?

	So indeed may the gods grant him good fortune! Capaneus
	has been allotted the position at the Electran Gate. This
	second one is a giant,[c dimgray][sup]55[/sup][/c] bigger than the man previously
	mentioned,[c dimgray][sup]56[/sup][/c] and his boasts show a pride beyond human
	limits; for he says that he will sack the city, god willing or
	unwilling, and that not even the weapons of Zeus crashing
	down to earth will stand in his way or hold him back—he
	compares the lightnings and thunderbolts to the heat of
	the noonday sun. As his device he bears a naked man carrying
	fire: the torch with which he is armed blazes in his
	hands, and in golden letters he declares “I will burn the
	city”. Against such a man you must send—but who can
	stand against him? Who will await without panic the onset
	of this braggart man?

	ready to [c dimgray]act.[/c] With contempt for the gods he takes a foolish

	that he will get his deserts, when something does come to

	music. His shield is decorated in no petty style. A fully-armed
	soldier is climbing a scaling ladder to the top of
	the enemy’s wall, aiming to sack the city; and he too[c dimgray][sup]60[/sup][/c] is
	crying out in written syllables, saying that not even Ares
	can throw him off the wall. Against this man too you must
	send someone who can be relied on to save this city from
	the yoke of slavery.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]eteocles[/b][/c]
	He has been sent already, bearing his boast in his
	Hands[c dimgray][sup]61[/sup][/c]—Megareus, son of Creon,[c dimgray][sup]62[/sup][/c] of the race of the
	Sown Men. He will not be terrified into retreating from the
	gate by the noise of horses’ wild neighing: he will either, by
	his death, pay his full debt of nurture to this land, or else
	will adorn his father’s house with booty after conquering
	two men[c dimgray][sup]63[/sup][/c] and the city on the shield. Brag about another
	one;[c dimgray][sup]64[/sup][/c] don’t be grudging about informing me.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]60[/sup][/c]Like the man on Capaneus’ shield.
	[c dimgray][sup]61[/sup][/c]i.e. expressing his pride not in words but in action.
	[c dimgray][sup]62[/sup][/c]This is the same Creon (son of Menoeceus and brother of
	Iocaste) who figures in Sophocles’ three Theban plays and in Euripides’
	[c dimgray]Phoenician Maidens.[/c] In Sophocles, [c dimgray]Antigone[/c] 1303–5, the
	death of Megareus is mentioned as if the audience would be familiar
	with the story, and it is implied that Creon was somehow responsible
	for it; Aeschylus is evidently not following that version
	(whatever precisely it was), but it is striking that Megareus is the
	only one of the defending champions (other than himself) whose
	death Eteocles mentions as a possibility (477).
	[c dimgray][sup]63[/sup][/c]viz. Eteoclus himself and the man portrayed on his shield.
	[c dimgray][sup]64[/sup][/c]Eteocles speaks as if the Scout were himself making the
	boasts that he reports the attackers are making.

	Truly I pray that fortune may be with you,
	O defender of my home, and may not be with them:
	as they bluster loudly against the city
	with maddened heart, so may an indignant
	Zeus look upon them with wrath!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Scout[/b][/c]
	Another, the fourth, assigned to the neighbouring Gate of
	Athena Onca, is standing near it uttering loud cries, the
	vast figure and form of Hippomedon. I shuddered, I won’t
	deny it, to see him brandish his great round threshing-floor
	of a shield. And it can’t have been a cheap artist who gave
	him that device on the shield, Typhon[c dimgray][sup]65[/sup][/c] emitting dark
	smoke, the many-coloured sister of flame, from his fire-breathing
	lips; the round circle of the hollow-bellied shield
	is floored with coiling snakes.[c dimgray][sup]66[/sup][/c] The man himself raised a
	great war-cry; he is possessed by Ares, and he rages for a
	fight like a maenad, with a fearsome look in his eye. You
	need to guard well against the attack of a man like this: Terror
	itself is now vaunting at the gate.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]65[/sup][/c]Typhon (also called Typhoeus or Typhos) was the last oppo- nent whom Zeus vanquished before his rulership of the universe
	was finally established (Hesiod, [c dimgray]Theogony[/c] 821–68). He was an
	Earth-born monster, with a hundred fiery serpent-heads; but after
	a great battle Zeus defeated him with the thunderbolt and hurled
	him down to Tartarus (in Pindar, [c dimgray]Pythian[/c] 1.15–28, and in [c dimgray]Prometheus[/c]
	351–72, he lies under Mount Etna).
	[c dimgray][sup]66[/sup][/c]This expression is easily understood in the light of artistic
	representations of Typhon (including an Argive shield found at
	Olympia; see D. W. Berman, [c dimgray]Myth and Culture in Aeschylus’
	Seven against Thebes[/c] \[Rome, 2007\] 59–60 and figs. 1a, 1b), in
	which he regularly has one or two coiling snakes where his legs
	should be (see [c dimgray]LIMC[/c] s.v. Typhon).
	[m1]\ [/m]

	In the first place, Pallas Onca, close neighbour to our city’s
	gate, hates this man’s arrogance and will keep him off,
	like a mother-bird[c dimgray][sup]67[/sup][/c] protecting her nestlings from a hostile
	serpent. And a man has been chosen to face this man,
	Hyperbius, the brave son of Oenops, ready to learn his fate
	in this crisis of fortune, faultless in form, in spirit, and also
	in the handling of arms. And Hermes[c dimgray][sup]68[/sup][/c] has brought them
	together appropriately: the man is an enemy of the man
	he will face,[c dimgray][sup]69[/sup][/c] and on their shields they will bring together
	two antagonistic gods. One of them has the fire-breathing
	Typhon, and on Hyperbius’ shield resides Father Zeus,
	standing with his flaming bolt in his hand. Such are their
	alliances with gods; and we are on the side of the winners,
	they of the losers, that is if Zeus is Typhon’s superior in battle.
	It is to be expected that the human opponents will fare
	likewise, and by the logic of Hyperbius’ emblem the Zeus
	he has on his shield should become his Saviour.[c dimgray][sup]70[/sup][/c]

	“They \[the Athenians\] are under the wings of Pallas”.
	[c dimgray][sup]68[/sup][/c]Hermes was thought to be responsible for unexpected

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Seven Against Thebes[/b][/c]
	the adversary of Zeus, the unlovely form of an earth-born
	divinity, an image hateful to mortals
	and to the long-lived gods,
	will lose[c dimgray][sup]71[/sup][/c] his head before the gates!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Scout[/b][/c]
	So may it be. Now I tell you of the fifth, assigned to the fifth
	gate, the North Gate, right by the tomb of Amphion,[c dimgray][sup]72[/sup][/c] son
	of Zeus. He stands there with a savage pride, not at all in
	keeping with his maidenish name,[c dimgray][sup]73[/sup][/c] and a fierce eye. He
	swears by the spear he holds, resolved to revere it more
	than a god and more highly than his eyes, that he will sack
	the city of the Cadmeans by force. He who says this is the
	offspring of Ares by a mountain-dwelling mother,[c dimgray][sup]74[/sup][/c] a fair-faced
	man, little more than a boy: the down is just growing
	thick and spreading over his cheeks as he comes to the
	prime of beauty. But he does not stand before the gate
	without a boastful emblem: on his shield of beaten bronze,
	the circular protector of his body, he wielded our city’s
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]71[/sup][/c]lit. “throw”.
	[c dimgray][sup]72[/sup][/c]Who, together with his brother
	Zethus, built the walls of Thebes. The tomb was on a hill to the
	north of the Cadmea (see Berman [c dimgray]op.cit.[/c] 103 and map 4).
	[c dimgray][sup]73[/sup][/c][c dimgray]Partheno[/c]-paeus.
	[c dimgray][sup]74[/sup][/c]His mother was the huntress
	Atalanta; his father is usually named as Melanion (occasionally
	Meleager), but \[Apollodorus\], [c dimgray]Library[/c] 3.9.2 gives Ares as an alternative.
	The transmitted text offers a very different construction
	and meaning: “. . . that he will sack the city of the Cadmeans in despite
	of Zeus: so says the offspring of (ἐξ) a mountain-dwelling
	mother . . .”. However, when a person’s mother is named with the
	preposition ἐκ (ἐξ), the father is normally also identified explicitly
	or implicitly; hence Weil’s conjecture.
	[m1]\ [/m]

Hutchinson (Π has the line).<li id="note_LCL145_208_549" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]549[/sup][/c]τοῖσδ᾿ M I [c dimgray]b k[/c]: δείν᾿ (cf. {426}) [c dimgray]k[/c].<li id="note_LCL145_208_558" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]558[/sup][/c]δάκος [c dimgray]b k[/c]: δάκους M I [c dimgray]b k.[/c]<li id="note_LCL145_208_559" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]{559}[/sup][/c]εἰκὼ φέροντα

	[c darkmagenta][b]Seven Against Thebes[/b][/c]
	disgrace, the Sphinx, eater of raw flesh, her bright form
	beaten out and fastened on with rivets, and under her she
	bears a man, one of the Cadmeans—so that a great many
	weapons may be thrown at that man.[c dimgray][sup]75[/sup][/c] Having come here,
	he is not likely to fight on a petty scale,[c dimgray][sup]76[/sup][/c] nor to show himself
	unworthy of the long journey he has made: Parthenopaeus
	the Arcadian. This man, such as I have described—
	an immigrant, paying back to Argos the debt due for his
	fine upbringing[c dimgray][sup]77[/sup][/c]—is making threats against these walls
	which may god not fulfil!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]eteocles[/b][/c]
	May they receive from the gods a fate that matches their
	own intentions, they and those unholy boasts of theirs;
	then they would surely perish utterly and wretchedly! But
	for this man too, the Arcadian you speak of, there is a man
	who does not boast but whose hand can see what needs to
	be done—Actor, brother of the last-mentioned. He will
	not allow a tongue with no deeds to its credit to flood in
	through the gates[c dimgray][sup]78[/sup][/c] and breed trouble, nor that hateful,
	hurtful beast to pass from the outside to the inside. She will
	blame her bearer when she gets an intense pounding below
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]75[/sup][/c]When the Thebans throw their spears at Parthenopaeus,
	they risk hitting the Theban on his shield—a bad omen for their side.
	[c dimgray][sup]76[/sup][/c]lit. “to be a retailer (κάπηλος) of battle”: rather, like a
	trader (ἔμπορος) who goes on long voyages, he can be expected to
	conduct his dealings on a [c dimgray]wholesale[/c] basis.
	[c dimgray][sup]77[/sup][/c]This parenthesis may be interpolated: if Parthenopaeus has
	travelled further than his colleagues to fight at Thebes (545–6), he
	can hardly have been brought up at Argos as here implied. The
	interpolator may have been inspired by Euripides, [c dimgray]Suppliants[/c]
	888–900, where much stress is laid on the excellent upbringing
	that Parthenopaeus had received at Argos.
	[c dimgray][sup]78[/sup][/c]The ship image again.

	The sixth man I have to speak of is a man of the highest
	virtue and an excellent fighter, powerful Amphiaraus,
	the prophet. Stationed before the Homoloïd Gate, he is
	casting many reviling words at powerful Tydeus—“murderer”,
	[c dimgray][sup]79[/sup][/c] “wrecker of your city”, “Argos’ great instructor in
	evil”, “arouser of a Fury”,[c dimgray][sup]80[/sup][/c] “high priest[c dimgray][sup]81[/sup][/c] of Carnage”,
	“Adrastus’ counsellor in these crimes”. And then again he
	loudly addresses your brother, turning his name inside out
	and dwelling on its significance,[c dimgray][sup]82[/sup][/c] and these are the words
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]79[/sup][/c]Tydeus had fled from his native Calydon to Argos after killing
	one or more kinsmen (early accounts vary widely as to the details);
	like Polyneices, he married a daughter of Adrastus. Amphiaraus’
	ensuing words should not be taken to imply that Tydeus
	alone was the prime mover behind Adrastus’ decision to attack
	Thebes, since he also blames Polyneices for urging this course on
	Adrastus (585).
	[c dimgray][sup]80[/sup][/c]i.e. inciter of an act that will incur certain
	and terrible vengeance.

	personification of Carnage (Φόνος) as a deity cf. Hesiod, [c dimgray]Theogony[/c]
	228 and [c dimgray]Shield of Heracles[/c] 155.
	[c dimgray][sup]82[/sup][/c]Polyneices means
	“Much-strife”. The passage as transmitted is corrupt, and I suspect
	that several words that were originally annotations (Polyneices’
	name, δίς, and ἐν τελευτῇ) have been incorporated into
	the text; I have omitted these in the above translation.

	he utters from his lips: “Is an act like this really smiled on

	and tell of, to devastate one’s fatherland and its native gods
	by bringing a foreign army to invade it? What claim of justice

	is conquered by the spear thanks to your incitement, how
	can you expect it to be your ally? For my part, I will enrich

	the prophet spoke, wielding calmly his shield all of bronze.
	On its circle there was no image; for he desires not the appearance

	with them all, by the scourge of god. So too this seer, the
	son of Oecles, a virtuous, upright, courageous and pious

	with impious men of arrogant speech, who are marching

	to come back;[c dimgray][sup]88[/sup][/c] and, Zeus willing, he will be dragged down

	[c dimgray][sup]85[/sup][/c]lit. “with headstrong sailors and some villainy”.
	[c dimgray][sup]86[/sup][/c]Amphiaraus’ wife Eriphyle was the sister of Adrastus; after
	an earlier quarrel with Adrastus, Amphiaraus had sworn that in any future dispute between the two men he would abide by her
	decision. When he was reluctant to join the expedition against
	Thebes (knowing through his prophetic power that it was doomed
	to disaster) Polynices bribed Eriphyle with the necklace of Harmonia,
	and she, invoking Amphiaraus’ oath, instructed him to go
	on the expedition. The story was known in some form to Homer
	([c dimgray]Odyssey[/c] 11.326–7, 15.244–7); it is told consecutively in the
	scholia to [c dimgray]Odyssey[/c] 11.326 (citing Asclepiades).
	[c dimgray][sup]87[/sup][/c]lit. “stretching out a procession”.
	[c dimgray][sup]88[/sup][/c]A meiotic reference to the road to death, from which there
	is [c dimgray]no[/c] coming back.

	[c darkmagenta][b]Scout[/b][/c]
	Now this is the seventh, at the Seventh Gate:[c dimgray][sup]91[/sup][/c] your own
	brother. I will tell what a fate and curse he prays may befall
	this city[c dimgray][sup]92[/sup][/c], sounding out a jubilant paean for its capture: to
	join battle with you, kill you, and die beside you, or else, if
	you survive, to punish you, as the one who degraded him
	and drove him out, in the same manner—by banishment.
	Such is the cry of powerful Polyneices, and he is calling on
	the ancestral gods of his fatherland to look favourably on
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]91[/sup][/c]Both Aeschylus and Euripides ([c dimgray]Phoenician Maidens[/c] 1104–40),
	in listing the Seven and the gates they attacked, give names to the first six gates but call the last simply “the seventh”. For Euripides
	this gate is of no particular importance (in his account no one
	is killed there), and he clearly regarded “Seventh” as its [c dimgray]name.[/c] In
	\[Apollodorus\], [c dimgray]Library[/c] 3.6.6, and Pausanias 9.8.4, what seems to
	be the same gate is called the Hypsistan; if “Seventh” was an alternative
	name for it, it may have been due to the presence nearby of
	a sanctuary of Apollo (cf. 800–1).
	[c dimgray][sup]92[/sup][/c]Polyneices actually wants to rule Thebes (647–8), not to destroy
	it, and even expects its gods to be his allies (639–41); but the
	Scout, like Amphiaraus (582–3), evidently assumes that if the enemy
	are victorious Polyneices will not be able to prevent them
	from sacking and burning the city (cf. 427, 434, 467, 531, 549).
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]eteocles \[[c dimgray]who has meanwhile put on his corslet[/c][/b][/c]
	\]Since the god is plainly hastening things to their conclusion,
	let it run before the wind, the whole house of

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]

	An all too harshly stinging lust is provoking you
	to perpetrate a homicide, shedding unlawful blood,
	that will bear bitter fruit.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]eteocles \[[c dimgray]who has meanwhile buckled on his sword[/c][/b][/c]
	\]Yes, for the hateful <black\[?\]>[c dimgray][sup]100[/sup][/c] Curse of the father who

	comes after”.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]

	Don’t be provoked! You will not be called a coward
	if you find an honourable way to stay alive; the Fury’s
	black squall
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]98[/sup][/c]Compared with their earlier exchanges (180–286), the reversal
	in the positions of Eteocles and the chorus is so complete that this chorus of young maidens even speak to him as if his superiors

	[c dimgray][sup]100[/sup][/c]A word of the text has been displaced by letters accidentally

	mastered by his own cherished, unwise counsels,[c dimgray][sup]109[/sup][/c]
	begot his own death,
	Oedipus the father-slayer,
	who sowed the sacrosanct soil
	of his mother, where he had been nurtured,
	and suffered a bloodstained progeny:
	it was mindless madness
	that brought that bridal couple[c dimgray][sup]110[/sup][/c] together.
	Now the sea, as it were, is bringing waves of trouble;
	the first one subsides, but it raises up another
	of triple strength, which breaks loudly
	around the very poop of the city;
	and for protection, in between,
	stretches the slim breadth of this wall.
	I fear lest together with the princes
	the city may be laid low.
	Fulfilled is the grievous reconciliation
	spoken of in the curse long ago:[c dimgray][sup]111[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]109[/sup][/c]Possibly this alludes to sexual desire (cf. Euripides, [c dimgray]Phoenician Maidens[/c] 21), but more likely to the desire for offspring which had prompted his initial rejection of the oracle’s warning
	(cf. previous note).
	[c dimgray][sup]110[/sup][/c]The bridegroom here is probably
	Laius rather than Oedipus: Oedipus had no way of knowing that
	he was marrying his mother (cf. 778–9; the story of his having
	been told by Apollo that he was destined to do so is unlikely to
	predate Sophocles), and “mindless madness” describes not inappropriately
	an act by Laius which has already been called ill-counselled,
	a transgression, and a defiance of Apollo.
	[c dimgray][sup]111[/sup][/c]This too (cf. 710–11) may refer to something said in
	[c dimgray]Oedipus[/c]; for the idea of the brothers’ death as their reconciliation,
	cf. 884–5, 908–9, 941.

	by the gods in their shared abode[c dimgray][sup]112[/sup][/c]
	and by the much-trodden meeting-place of mortals[c dimgray][sup]113[/sup][/c]
	as in those days they admired Oedipus
	who removed from the land
	the man-snatching demon?[c dimgray][sup]114[/sup][/c]
	But when he became aware,
	wretched man, of his appalling marriage,
	enraged by grief,
	with maddened heart,
	he perpetrated two evils:
	by his own father-slaying hand
	he was robbed of his <  > eyes,[c dimgray][sup]115[/sup][/c]
