	They killed each other with hands that all too truly shared
	the same blood. Thus the controlling power[c dimgray][sup]121[/sup][/c] was one and
	the same for both, and he has himself utterly destroyed
	that ill-fated family. Such are the things we have to rejoice
	and to weep over: the city is faring well, but its chiefs, the
	leaders of the two armies,[c dimgray][sup]122[/sup][/c] have had the whole possession
	of their inheritance divided between them by hammered
	Scythian iron: they will have so much of the land as they
	will take in burial, having been swept away to an evil fate in
	accordance with their father’s curse.<span class="stage">[c dimgray]He departs.[/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[c dimgray][sup]123[/sup][/c][/b][/c]

	{O great Zeus and you gods of the city,
	who <have shown your concern> to save
	these walls of Cadmus,
	shall I hail with shouts of joy
	the unharmed salvation of the city,
	or shall I weep for the wretched, ill-starred,
	childless warlords
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]121[/sup][/c]ὁ δαίμων seems at first to denote a power, not clearly personalized,
	governing the brothers’ fate; but αὐτός “he himself”
	turns our thoughts towards a personal divinity, evidently Apollo.
	[c dimgray][sup]122[/sup][/c]It is now irrelevant, and forgotten, that the attacking army
	was actually commanded by Adrastus: all attention is to be concentrated
	on the two dead brothers.
	[c dimgray][sup]123[/sup][/c]Abnormalities of language, metre and sense make it unlikely
	that Aeschylus was responsible for the anapaests 822–31;
	see R. D. Dawe in Dawe et al. ed. [c dimgray]Dionysiaca: Nine Studies . . .
	presented to Sir Denys Page[/c] (Cambridge, 1978) 88–9.

(-ορα [c dimgray]k΄[/c])· δίδυμα νῦν ὁρῶ Hutchinson.<li id="note_LCL145_242_850-1" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]850[/sup][/c]δίμορα τέλεα Hermann: δίμοιρα τέλεια codd.<li id="note_LCL145_242_850-2" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]850[/sup][/c]τάδε [c dimgray]k[/c]: τὰ M [c dimgray]b k[/c]: om. I [c dimgray]b[/c].<li id="note_LCL145_242_852" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]852[/sup][/c]δόμων Robortello:
	πόνων δόμων codd.: πόνων Heimsoeth.<li id="note_LCL145_242_857" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]857[/sup][/c]ἄνοστον West (τὰν ἄνοστον Tucker): τὰν (τὸν [c dimgray]b΄[/c])
	ἄστονον codd. [c dimgray]t[/c]: τὰν ἄστολον Thom.<li id="note_LCL145_242_858" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]858[/sup][/c]ναυστολῶν [c dimgray]b[/c] (?), Schwenck: ναύστολον codd.<li id="note_LCL145_242_859" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]859[/sup][/c]Παιῶνι Ahrens: Ἀπόλλωνι codd.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 242[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Seven Against Thebes[/b][/c]<span class="stage">[c dimgray]The bodies of eteocles[/c] and polynices are brought on, and laid down side by side.
	Here it is, plain to see; the messenger’s words are visible
	reality;
	with double lamentation <I now behold(?)> this twin
	disaster;
	the sad event is fulfilled, a double death by kindred
	hands. What shall I say?
	What else but that suffering is a resident in the house?
	Friends, with the wind of lamentation in your sails
	ply in accompaniment the regular beating of hands on
	head,[c dimgray][sup]128[/sup][/c]
	which is for ever crossing the Acheron,[c dimgray][sup]129[/sup][/c]
	propelling on a sacred mission from which there is no
	Return[c dimgray][sup]130[/sup][/c]
	the black-sailed ship,
	on which Apollo Paeon never treads[c dimgray][sup]131[/sup][/c] and the sun never
	shines,
	to the invisible shores that welcome all.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]128[/sup][/c]Head-beating, a common gesture of mourning, is here
	compared to the rhythmic beat of a ship’s oars.
	[c dimgray][sup]129[/sup][/c]The river, or lake, in the underworld, across which Charon
	was usually imagined as ferrying the souls of the dead. In the picture
	created here, it is the words and actions of the mourners that
	provide the motive power to take souls across the water on that
	final journey.
	[c dimgray][sup]130[/sup][/c]Alluding to the sacred ship sent annually by the Athenians
	to Delos in honour of Apollo, in commemoration, it was said, of
	the ship that Aegeus sent to Crete with seven youths and seven
	maidens, destined as a tribute for the Minotaur, whom Theseus
	rescued (cf. Plato, [c dimgray]Phaedo[/c] 58a-c). On the return voyage Theseus
	forgot to change the black sail for a red or white one, so that
	Aegeus thought he was dead and committed suicide (Simonides,
	[c dimgray]PMG[/c] 550—who makes the unused sail a red one; Catullus
	64.225–45; Plutarch, [c dimgray]Theseus[/c] 17.4–5, 22.1). The ship of the dead
	[c dimgray]always[/c] has black sails.
	[c dimgray][sup]131[/sup][/c]Mourning was abhorrent to Apollo ([c dimgray]Agamemnon[/c] 1074–9).
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 243[/c]

	their possessions, so as to gain equal lots;
	but their friends do not see
	their reconciler[c dimgray][sup]136[/sup][/c] as free of blame,
	or Ares as pleasing.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]first semichorus[/b][/c]

	By the stroke of iron they are as they are now,
	and there await them, one might well say,
	portions of their father’s sepulcher
	dug[c dimgray][sup]137[/sup][/c] by the stroke of iron.

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]135[/sup][/c]The transmitted text has the property awaiting ἐπίγονοι:
	but in the Theban saga ἐπίγονοι denotes the sons of the Seven,
	who later avenged their fathers by capturing and destroying
	Thebes, and any allusion to them here would clash with the assumption,
	basic to the last third of this play, that the house of Laius
	is now extinct. Moreover, the first of two paraphrases offered by
	the scholia in M says merely “[c dimgray]others[/c] will have the property for
	which they \[the brothers\] perished”.
	[c dimgray][sup]136[/sup][/c]viz. Iron (cf. 727–33, 816–17, 884–5, 941–3).
	[c dimgray][sup]137[/sup][/c]The noun λαχή can be taken as meaning either “an allotted
	portion” (~λαγχάνω) or “something dug” (~λαγχαίνω).
	[m1]\ [/m]

	characters.

	[c dimgray][sup]146[/sup][/c]This probably refers to Eteocles, who had gone out of the

	three plays of the trilogy.

	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1003[/sup][/c]ἔνθα Headlam: ὅπου codd.<li id="note_LCL145_265_151a" class="note">[c dimgray][sup]151[/sup][/c]After this, in the transmitted text, come two lines which
	are appropriate only to Antigone and Ismene: “But above all to me.—And even more to me.” They will have been inserted when
	the sisters were brought into the play; evidently (and rightly) the
	adaptor felt that it would be absurd to have the sisters sing a sobbing
	antiphon like 961–1004 and yet make no reference whatever
	to their personal grief.
	[c dimgray][sup]152[/sup][/c]The language irresistibly suggests that to bury Eteocles
	and Polyneices close to their father would be to inflict on him the
	same kind of injury that he inflicted on [c dimgray]his[/c] father (to whom he
	gave pain, and whose bed he unknowingly usurped). Since the
	first suggestion as to where the brothers should be buried has thus
	been (at least provisionally) rejected, Aeschylus’ text cannot have
	ended here: once the question of their burial-place has been
	raised, the bodies cannot be taken off until it has been settled.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[c darkmagenta][b]Seven Against Thebes[/b][/c]
	<span class="stage">[c dimgray]The last few lines of the original text have been lost; the two
	semichoruses must have agreed on where Eteocles and
	Polynices should be buried, and escorted the bodies off
	stage.[/c]
	<span class="stage">{[c dimgray]Enter a herald[/c].
	[c darkmagenta][b]herald[/b][/c]
	I have to announce the opinion and the decision of the
	people’s council of this city of Cadmus. It has been resolved
	that Eteocles here, on account of his loyalty to his
	country, shall be buried in the loving recesses of the earth;
	for he found death while keeping out the enemy at the
	gates, and in pious defence of the temples of his fathers he
	has died blamelessly where it is honourable for the young
	to die. That is what I have been instructed to say about
	him; but his brother, the dead Polyneices here, is to be cast
	out unburied, a prey for the dogs, as one who would have
	been the destroyer of the land of Cadmus, had not some
	god stood up to hinder his armed attack. Even in death he
	shall bear the pollution and curse of his ancestral gods,
	whom he insulted when he tried to capture the city, bringing
	a foreign army to attack it. So it is decided that he
	should get his due reward by receiving a dishonourable funeral
	from the flying birds; that he should neither lie under
	a laboriously raised burial-mound[c dimgray][sup]153[/sup][/c] nor be dignified with
	high-pitched musical wailings; and that he should not have
	the honour of a funeral procession from his family. Such is
	the decision of the aforementioned Cadmean authorities.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]153[/sup][/c]The literal sense is apparently meant to be “that neither
	should mound-raising hand-work accompany him . . .”.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[c darkmagenta][b]Seven Against Thebes[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]antigone[/b][/c]
	And [c dimgray]I[/c] say to the leaders of the Cadmeans: if no one else is
	willing to join in burying this man, I will bury him, I will
	brave the danger of burying my brother, and I will not be
	ashamed to display such disobedient insubordination to
	the city. The power of the common womb from which we
	are sprung, children of a wretched mother and a miserable
	father, is a formidable thing. Therefore, my soul, with a
	sister’s heart, living with dead, share willingly in the sufferings
	that he endures unwillingly. His flesh <shall not
	be eaten by dogs or birds>[c dimgray][sup]154[/sup][/c] nor torn by hollow-bellied
	wolves—let no one think it will; for I shall myself, woman
	though I am, contrive to provide him with a funeral and
	burial, carrying it[c dimgray][sup]155[/sup][/c] in the fold of my fine linen robe, and
	myself cover him up—and let no one think otherwise.
	Courage will find a means to do it.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]herald[/b][/c]
	I tell you not to flout the city’s will by doing this.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]antigone[/b][/c]
	I tell you not to make useless proclamations to me.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]herald[/b][/c]
	But a people that has escaped danger can be brutal.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]154[/sup][/c]A line has apparently been lost from the text, probably because
	a scribe’s eye slipped from a negative word in one line to a
	similar negative in the next line.
	[c dimgray][sup]155[/sup][/c]The text does not make it clear what she will be carrying
	(strictly interpreted, indeed, it ought to mean she will be carrying
	the body itself!); but the writer expected his audience to understand
	that she would bring earth to throw over the body (cf. Sophocles,
	[c dimgray]Antigone[/c] 249–56).

-145.277 (AESCHYLUS, Suppliants)
%Aeschylus
AESCHYLUS, Suppliants
	[c darkmagenta][b]AESCHYLUS, Suppliants[/b][/c]
		[m1]\ [/m][b]Aeschylus[/b]
	[b]Suppliants[/b]
	It has long been universally accepted that [c dimgray]Suppliants[/c] was
	part of a sequence of plays that also contained [c dimgray]Danaids[/c],
	which likewise had the daughters of Danaus as its chorus
	and which, as fr. 43 showed, presented a later stage of their
	story, being set on the day after their marriage to their
	cousins, the sons of Aegyptus, and the murder of all but
	one of the bridegrooms by their unwilling brides. The
	other play of the trilogy has almost always been identified
	as [c dimgray]Egyptians[/c] (despite the fact that only one word of that
	play survives),
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c] since the Danaid story is intimately bound
	up with Egypt and no other Aeschylean tragedy is known
	to have had any significant connection with that country;
	[c dimgray][sup]2[/sup][/c]
	whether it preceded or followed [c dimgray]Suppliants[/c] was, and is,
	disputed (see below). The satyr-drama that wound up the
	production, if (as was normal) it dealt with another section
	of the same myth, had to be [c dimgray]Amymone[/c], whose title character
	was one of the Danaids; but until 1952, it was not
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]Even Hermann, who thought that the other play was
	[c dimgray]Chamber-makers[/c], took [c dimgray]Egyptians[/c] to be an alternative name for
	that same drama. In fact [c dimgray]Chamber-makers[/c] was probably a satyr-play;
	see the section on it in Volume III.
	[c dimgray][sup]2[/sup][/c]The only Aeschylean play, outside the Danaid group, that [c dimgray]is[/c]
	known to have had a significant connection with Egypt is [c dimgray]Proteus[/c],
	the satyr-drama of the [c dimgray]Oresteia[/c] production.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 277[/c]

	Until 1952, also, it was generally taken as all but certain
	that [c dimgray]Suppliants[/c] was the earliest of Aeschylus’ surviving
	plays and therefore the oldest known European drama:
	the active role of the chorus, the dominance of song (more
	than half the text is sung or chanted), the apparent presence
	of two singing subsidiary choruses (Egyptians in 825–
	865, Argive soldiers or the Danaids’ maidservants in 1034–
	61), the scant use made of the second actor, and the simplicity
	and slightness of the plot, all seemed to point in that
	direction.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	One of its many fragments (fr. 3) comes from a Hypothesis
	giving information about the result of the City Dionysia
	tragic competition in a particular year; we cannot identify
	the year for sure, since all that is left of the date-rubric is
	ἐπὶ α\[ and the last two letters of that might be the beginning
	of the archon’s name or merely (as apparently in fr. 2
	of the same papyrus, a Hypothesis to [c dimgray]Laius[/c])
	[c dimgray][sup]3[/sup][/c] the beginning
	of the name of his office (ἄρ\[χοντος\]). The papyrus then
	goes on to say that Aeschylus was victorious with a production
	which included, as its third and fourth plays, [c dimgray]Danaids[/c]
	and the satyr-drama [c dimgray]Amymone[/c]; Sophocles was second, and
	one Mesatus was third. Mesatus’ name was followed by a
	series of play-titles, some of which are enclosed in brackets;
	the likeliest explanation
	[c dimgray][sup]4[/sup][/c] is that the bracketed titles belong

	[m1]\ [/m][b]Aeschylus[/b]
	to Sophocles (the brackets indicating that they are out

	Now unless we resort to some desperate suppositions,

	competing. Sophocles won his first victory in 468;
	[c dimgray][sup]6[/sup][/c] according

-145.281 (AESCHYLUS, Suppliants)
AESCHYLUS, Suppliants
	[c darkmagenta][b]AESCHYLUS, Suppliants[/b][/c]
	[b]Aeschylus[/b]
	to 463, the only relevant year with an archon whose
	name (Archedemides) matches these letters; but it is not
	certain, or even very probable.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	The story of the Danaids exists in dozens of variants.
	[c dimgray][sup]10[/sup][/c]
	Their common core is that a quarrel between the brothers
	Danaus and Aegyptus, great-grandsons of Zeus and Io of
	Argos, leads to Danaus and his fifty daughters
	[c dimgray][sup]11[/sup][/c] fleeing
	from Egypt to Argos, their ancestral home, pursued by
	Aegyptus
	[c dimgray][sup]12[/sup][/c] and his fifty sons, who desired to take their
	cousins in marriage regardless of the Danaids’ or their
	father’s wishes. The conflict is seemingly resolved when
	Danaus agrees to the marriages taking place, but he secretly
	supplies weapons to his daughters, and all but one of
	them kill their bridegrooms on the wedding night. The
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]10[/sup][/c]Set out in full by Friis Johansen and Whittle in the introduction
	to their edition (pp. 40–55); see also Gantz 198–208.
	[c dimgray][sup]11[/sup][/c]When [c dimgray]Suppliants[/c] was thought to be a very early play, it was
	often suggested that its chorus actually numbered fifty. There was
	never any justification for this. If in a Euripidean play of the 420s
	(coincidentally of the same name) a conventional tragic chorus of
	fifteen can represent a group who are repeatedly described as the
	mothers of the [c dimgray]Seven[/c] against Thebes (Euripides, [c dimgray]Suppliants[/c] 12–
	13, 100–2, etc.) and even as “seven mothers of seven sons” ([c dimgray]ib.[/c]
	963–4), it cannot be seriously doubted that several decades earlier
	it would have been possible for a conventional chorus of (as it then
	was) twelve to represent a group of fifty.
	[c dimgray][sup]12[/sup][/c]That Aegyptus came to Argos together with his sons was
	“the most frequent account” according to Euripides (fr. 846, cf.
	[c dimgray]Orestes[/c] 872); the scholia on [c dimgray]Orestes[/c] 872 say that Aeschylus’ tragic
	predecessor, Phrynichus, had Aegyptus accompany his sons to
	Argos, and their silence about Aeschylus himself suggests that
	Aeschylus did not follow Phrynichus in this respect.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 280[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m][b]Aeschylus[/b]
	survivor, Lynceus, in many versions seeks and gains revenge
	upon Danaus; at any rate, he and his wife, Hypermestra,
	regularly become the founders of a new royal line
	of Argos and the ancestors of such heroes as Perseus and
	Heracles. Hypermestra’s sisters are in some versions punished
	(sometimes eternally), in others new husbands are
	found for them.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[c dimgray]Suppliants[/c] only covers one small section of this story—
	the arrival and reception of the Danaids and their father at
	Argos, and the Argive refusal of a demand for their surrender,
	resulting in a declaration of war by the herald speaking
	in the name of the sons of Aegyptus. Its references to earlier
	events are scanty and vague (we are told far more
	about Io than we ever are about the past history of Danaus,
	his brother and their families), and while some things said
	in [c dimgray]Suppliants[/c] are clearly designed to foreshadow the coming
	mass-murder,
	[c dimgray][sup]13[/sup][/c] hardly any further information about
	Aeschylus’ treatment of the later part of the story can be
	safely inferred from the text of the surviving play. As a result
	of this, and of the survival of only two significant fragments
	from the companion tragedies, we cannot even say
	with confidence whether [c dimgray]Suppliants[/c] was the first or the
	second play of its trilogy.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	The third play, as was generally accepted even before
	the papyrus confirmed it, was [c dimgray]Danaids.[/c] We know two
	things about this play, apart from the obvious fact that,
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]13[/sup][/c]For example, the reference to the Danaids’ suppliant-boughs
	as ἐγχειριδίοις (21), literally “things held in the hand” but
	in ordinary usage “daggers”; or their father’s injunction to them to
	“value . . . chastity more than life itself” (1013), not specifying
	[c dimgray]whose[/c] life they should value less.

-145.283 (AESCHYLUS, Suppliants)
AESCHYLUS, Suppliants
	[c darkmagenta][b]AESCHYLUS, Suppliants[/b][/c]
	[b]Aeschylus[/b]
	very unusually, the Danaids formed the chorus for the second
	time in the trilogy. One is that it began on the morning
	after the fatal weddings: fr. 43, while corrupt, clearly
	refers to the rising of the sun and to the ceremonial, musical
	“awakening” of the bridal couples. The other is that,
	doubtless later in the play, Aphrodite appeared and made a
	speech which contained an eloquent affirmation of the
	universality of mutual sexual desire in nature with particular
	reference to the primal union of Heaven and Earth (fr.
	44)—clearly with a view to vindicating Hypermestra, or
	to condemning Danaus,
	[c dimgray][sup]14[/sup][/c] or both, but certainly also to
	condemning the sons of Aegyptus who, in the surviving
	play, are represented—by their own herald as much as by
	their enemies—as unilaterally demanding the satisfaction
	of their own desires regardless of anyone else’s.
	[c dimgray][sup]15[/sup][/c] It would
	be highly fitting if this were followed up by the marriage of
	the Danaids other than Hypermestra to new husbands
	with whom they [c dimgray]could[/c] form a union as true as that of
	Heaven and Earth; and it is likely too that before the end
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]14[/sup][/c]It is fairly clear that in Aeschylus’ treatment, Danaus was
	presented as the inspirer of his daughters’ actions; they themselves
	call him “the originator of our plan, the leader of our band,
	\[who,\] surveying the situation like a gameboard, ordained \[that we
	should\] flee headlong over the waves of the sea” (11–14).
	[c dimgray][sup]15[/sup][/c]“You may take these women,” says King Pelasgus to the herald,
	“so long as they consent with friendly heart, if pious words of
	yours should persuade them” (940–1); and the herald regards this
	insistence on consent as a [c dimgray]casus belli[/c] (950)!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 282[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m][b]Aeschylus[/b]
	of this play Danaus had met his death.
	[c dimgray][sup]16[/sup][/c] The rest is speculation.
	[c dimgray][sup]17[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	What of [c dimgray]Egyptians[/c]? It has usually been supposed that
	this was the second play of the trilogy, in which case its subject
	must have been the events leading from the conclusion
	of the Argive-Egyptian war (in which, it is generally
	accepted, King Pelasgus must have been killed, with
	Danaus perhaps taking over as a quasi-tyrant)
	[c dimgray][sup]18[/sup][/c] to the arrangement
	and celebration of the marriages between
	Danaus’ daughters and Aegyptus’ sons. There are, however,
	serious difficulties with this view, which I have set out
	elsewhere:

	[m1]\ [/m]

	The title . . . implie\[s\] a chorus of Egyptians . . . . In
	that case it \[is\] at first sight hard to see how Danaos
	and his daughters could have contrived their murder-plot.
	Various possibilities, indeed, \[exist\]: perhaps
	[m1]\ [/m]

-145.285 (AESCHYLUS, Suppliants)
AESCHYLUS, Suppliants
	[c darkmagenta][b]AESCHYLUS, Suppliants[/b][/c]
	[b]Aeschylus[/b]
	the play, like Aristophanes’ [c dimgray]Frogs[/c], was named
	after a secondary chorus, the Danaids being the
	main chorus; perhaps the plot was so familiar a part
	of the story that the dramatist took the audience’s
	knowledge of it for granted, and exploited it to
	ironic effect in scenes of negotiation between
	Danaos and his enemies. But \[neither\] of these expedients
	seem\[s\] fully satisfactory.
	The alternative view, supported by several nineteenth-century
	scholars but revived in recent times by Wolfgang
	Rösler and myself,
	[c dimgray][sup]20[/sup][/c] is that [c dimgray]Egyptians[/c] was the [c dimgray]first[/c] play of
	the trilogy, was set in Egypt (with a chorus of male Egyptians,
	perhaps elders), and presented the quarrel between
	Danaus and Aegyptus. This view has won relatively little
	support, perhaps because both Rösler and I put the main
	stress in our arguments on a six-word scholium on [c dimgray]Suppliants[/c]
	37 which we took, following Martin Sicherl,
	[c dimgray][sup]21[/sup][/c] as evidence
	that Aeschylus imagined Danaus to have received
	an oracle that he would be killed by his daughter’s bedfellow
	(so that he was determined at all costs to keep his
	daughters permanently virgin), but which A. F. Garvie
	[c dimgray][sup]22[/sup][/c]
	has shown that we misinterpreted. This does not, however,
	in itself disprove the hypothesis that [c dimgray]Egyptians[/c] was the
	first play of the trilogy, which does not depend solely on
	this piece of evidence; nor does it prove that Aeschylus
	did not use the oracle story, since, again, there is other
	[m1]\ [/m]

	evidence suggesting that he did. In [c dimgray]Suppliants[/c] 1006–9
	Danaus appears to be saying that the whole object of the
	flight from Egypt had been to preserve his daughters’ virginity
	not just from their cousins but absolutely—an idea
	that to any Greek would be utterly incomprehensible except
	in the light of the oracle story or something very like
	it.
	[c dimgray][sup]23[/sup][/c] And since the oracle is nowhere mentioned in [c dimgray]Suppliants[/c],
	the surviving play, as Rösler insisted, cannot have
	stood first in the trilogy. We cannot argue against this that
	the oracle was so regular and familiar a part of the myth
	that the audience’s knowledge of it could be taken for
	granted, for we know that in one quite recent poetic version
	of the myth Danaus actually survived to arrange the
	remarriage of his daughters.
	[c dimgray][sup]24[/sup][/c] I thus remain of the view
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]23[/sup][/c]It was considered a great wrong against a woman if her father
	or guardian deliberately kept her unmarried; this is regularly
	mentioned as one of the grievances of Electra against Aegisthus
	(and Clytaemestra), and when Lysias is describing the crimes of
	the Thirty who ruled Athens in 404–403, he climaxes his indictment
	not with their execution of hundreds of citizens without
	trial, but with a claim that they prevented many men’s daughters
	from being married (Lysias 12.21). Other than Danaus and
	Aegisthus, the only major mythical character who acts similarly is
	Acrisius, who walls up his daughter Danaë because an oracle has
	told him he will be killed by his grandson (the story appears first in
	Aeschylus’ contemporary Pherecydes \[[c dimgray]FGrH[/c] 3 F 10\]).

AESCHYLUS, Suppliants

	[c dimgray][sup]25[/sup][/c] but the issue cannot be regarded as settled.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	On the satyr-drama, [c dimgray]Amymone[/c], see the section on that
	play in Volume III.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	Many attempts have been made to find contemporary
	political relevance in the Danaid trilogy, but in view of our
	uncertainty as to its precise date none of them can be regarded
	as compelling.
	[c dimgray][sup]26[/sup][/c] It is, however, worth recording
	that [c dimgray]Suppliants[/c] contains the earliest evidence for the existence
	of the word δημοκρατία “democracy”: the word it-
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]25[/sup][/c]P. Sandin, [c dimgray]Aeschylus’ Supplices: Introduction and Commentary
	on vv.1–523[/c] (Göteborg, 2003) 9–11, argues that this sequence
	would entail that “the entire dramatic conflict that leads to
	. . . the wedding-night murder would be \[merely\] recounted in a
	prologue”; some might feel, contrariwise, that a play standing between
	[c dimgray]Suppliants[/c] and [c dimgray]Danaids[/c], and leading up to (but not including)
	the murders, would be singularly lacking in “dramatic conflict”,
	since the only action it would need to contain, once Pelasgus
	was removed from the scene, would be for Danaus to make peace
	proposals to his nephews that included acceptance of their marriage
	to his daughters, to have them accepted, and somehow to
	plot with his daughters the murder of their bridegrooms. There
	would be nothing surprising in important events of a myth being
	consigned, as it were, to the gap between two plays of
	an Aeschylean trilogy: the trilogy based on the [c dimgray]Odyssey[/c] seems
	to have jumped straight from Odysseus’ visit to the underworld
	(in IGhost-Raisers, [c dimgray]q.v.[/c]) to his first meeting with Penelope (in
	[c dimgray]Penelope, q.v.[/c]), omitting events that take up at least nine books of
	the [c dimgray]Odyssey[/c] (12, 5–8 and 13–16).
	[c dimgray][sup]26[/sup][/c]This applies as much to my own attempt ([c dimgray]Aeschylean Tragedy[/c]
	403–9; also in C. B. R. Pelling ed. [c dimgray]Greek Tragedy and the Historian[/c]
	\[Oxford, 1997\] 74–79) as to any other.

	shrine (with altars) to the major gods of the city. One side-passage
	is imagined as leading to the city, the other to

	our band, which set forth by ship
	from the fine sands at the mouth
	of the Nile. We have left the land of Zeus,

	[c dimgray][sup]9[/sup][/c]ἔφαψις, whence the child’s name Ἔπαφος.
	[c dimgray][sup]10[/sup][/c]If the text here is rightly restored and understood, it implies
	that at the time of Epaphus’ conception Zeus told Io (as Gabriel told Mary) that she would bear a child and what name he should
	be given.
	[c dimgray][sup]11[/sup][/c]The wife of Tereus (with or without the aid of
	her sister) killed their only child, Itys. In early versions of the story
	the killing may have been accidental (as in the parallel story of [c dimgray]Odyssey[/c]
	19.518–523, Pherecydes [c dimgray]FGrH[/c] 3 F 124, where the husband
	is Zethus); in Sophocles’ later [c dimgray]Tereus[/c] it is a deliberate act of revenge
	for Tereus’ rape of his wife’s sister; in our passage it could be
	either. Both husband and wife were transformed into birds, the
	latter into a nightingale (who continues eternally to lament for
	Itys), the former into a hawk (in Sophocles a hoopoe). The wife’s
	name in archaic art, and in Pherecydes [c dimgray]loc.cit.[/c], is Aëdon or Aëdona
	(“Nightingale”); in Sophocles and thereafter it is Procne.

	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]16[/sup][/c]Fugitives from war, whose enemies are only trying to assert
	the accepted rights of the victor, are safe from seizure if they take
	sanctuary at an altar: how much more should the Danaids be
	protected, since their enemies are trying to claim that to which
	(according to the Danaids) they have no right whatsoever!
	[c dimgray][sup]17[/sup][/c]Friis Johansen and Whittle plausibly take the metaphor to
	refer to a leopard (or feline predator of similar habits) springing
	from a tree and landing on its feet—appropriate here, where the
	stress is on Zeus’s power to punish and destroy.
	[c dimgray][sup]18[/sup][/c]lit. “head”.

	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]19[/sup][/c]Cf. Xenophanes fr. 25, 26 D-K: “\[God\] moves everything by
	mental will, without toil. . . . He always remains in one place, without
	moving at all.”
	[c dimgray][sup]20[/sup][/c]i.e. the sons of Aegyptus.
	[c dimgray][sup]21[/sup][/c]West’s conjecture, which I render here, is based on the par- allel of [c dimgray]Ag.[/c] 218–223, where Agamemnon is said to have had his
	mind transformed (μετέγνω, cf. μεταγνούν here) by an insane
	determination to sacrifice Iphigenia.
	[c dimgray][sup]22[/sup][/c]A name for Argos (cf. [c dimgray]Ag.[/c] 256–7), explained in 260–270 below;
	by its similarity to Ἆπις, the Egyptian bull-god sometimes
	identified with Epaphus (cf. Herodotus 2.153), it suggests a link
	between Argos and Egypt, just as βοῦ-νιν “hilly land” suggests a
	link with the bovine Io.
	[c dimgray][sup]23[/sup][/c]Although, in accordance with the conventions of tragedy,
	the words that actually come out of the Danaids’ mouths are
	Greek, we are expected to imagine that they are speaking Egyptian
	(just as e.g. we are expected to imagine that the performers’
	linen masks are human faces).
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 303[/c]

	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]41[/sup][/c]The image of Zeus apparently has an eagle perching on its
	head or hand (cf. Aristophanes, [c dimgray]Birds[/c]514–5); the Egyptian god Amun-Re, whom Greeks identified with Zeus, was often portrayed
	as, or with the head of, a hawk which represented the sun
	(see E. M. Hall, [c dimgray]Inventing the Barbarian[/c] \[Oxford, 1989\] 144–6).
	Aeschylus and his audience evidently knew about the Egyptian
	sun-bird, and may well have been misled by the identification of
	Amun-Re with Zeus into supposing that the bird was an eagle:
	later sources (Diodorus Siculus 1.87.9, Strabo 17.1.40) say that in
	Thebes (the greatest centre of Amun’s cult) the eagle was worshipped.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[c dimgray][sup]46[/sup][/c]πρόξενοι, citizens of one state (State A) who were recognized
	by another state (State B) as standing in a relationship of
	guest-friendship with State B as a community, and who could normally
	be relied on to render assistance to citizens of State B residing
	in, or visiting, State A; see G. Herman, [c dimgray]Ritualised Friendship
	and the Greek City[/c] (Cambridge, 1987).

	that respect will ‘the Greek land’ be in agreement with a guess”.

	holy Strymon, on the side of the setting sun,
	[c dimgray][sup]49[/sup][/c] and I mark as
	my boundary the land of the Paeonians,
	[c dimgray][sup]50[/sup][/c] and the parts beyond
	Pindus near the Perrhaebians,
	[c dimgray][sup]51[/sup][/c] and the mountains of
	Dodona; the limit that cuts it short is the watery sea. I rule
	what is on the hither side of these. The soil of this land itself,
	Apia, received its name long ago in honour of a healer.
	Apis the healer and seer, son of Apollo, came from the land
	of Naupactus across the sea,
	[c dimgray][sup]52[/sup][/c] and cleansed this land of the
	man-destroying creatures which the angry earth, stained
	by the pollution of old bloodshed, had sent up from below,
	a hostile horde of serpents sharing our home. From these
	Apis effected, beyond all cavil, a decisive,
	[c dimgray][sup]53[/sup][/c] liberating cure
	for the Argive land, and in return won as his reward the
	right to be remembered in prayers. Now you have the
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]49[/sup][/c]i.e. of all the land to the west of the (lower) Strymon.
	[c dimgray][sup]50[/sup][/c]The Paeonians were a non-Greek tribe living in western
	Thrace and eastern Macedonia.
	[c dimgray][sup]51[/sup][/c]In the fifth century Perrhaebia was the name of a district in
	north-eastern Thessaly (Herodotus 7.128.1, Thucydides 4.78.5–
	6); but in the [c dimgray]Iliad[/c] (2.749–750) the Per(rh)aebi live “near
	Dodona”, and Sophocles (fr. 271) places them near Mounts
	Pindus and Lacmus, which separate Thessaly on the east from
	Epirus on the west and in which rise tributaries of those regions’
	major rivers, the Peneus ([c dimgray]Iliad[/c] 2.751–5) and the Achelous (Soph.
	loc.cit.).
	[c dimgray][sup]52[/sup][/c]On the north side of the Corinthian Gulf, near its western
	end.
	[c dimgray][sup]53[/sup][/c]lit. “by cutting, surgical”, hence “(drastic but) effective” (cf.
	Hippocrates, [c dimgray]Aphorisms[/c] 7.87 “What drugs will not cure, the knife
	will”).

	[c darkmagenta][b]Suppliants[/b][/c]
	evidence from me, you can declare what race you are of,
	and tell me more. However, our city does not love long
	speeches.
	[c dimgray][sup]54[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	Our statement is brief and clear. We declare that we are
	Argive by race, the offspring of the cow that bore a fine
	child; and to show that this is true, we will add proofs to
	what we have said.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]pelasgus[/b][/c]
	What you say, strangers, is unbelievable for me to hear,
	that this group of yours is of Argive descent. You bear more
	resemblance to the women of Libya—certainly not to
	those of this country. The Nile, too, might nurture such a
	crop; and a similar stamp is struck upon the dies of Cyprian
	womanhood by male artificers.
	[c dimgray][sup]55[/sup][/c] I hear, too, that there are
	nomad women in India, near neighbours to the Ethiopians,
	[c dimgray][sup]56[/sup][/c] who saddle their way across country on camels that
	run like horses; and then the man-shunning, meat-eating
	Amazons—if you were equipped with bows, I’d be very inclined
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]54[/sup][/c]The Argives, as well as the Spartans, had a reputation for
	brevity of speech; cf. Pindar, [c dimgray]Isthmian[/c] 6.58–59; Sophocles fr. 64.
	[c dimgray][sup]55[/sup][/c]i.e. Cyprian fathers, impregnating Cyprian mothers, procreate
	children whom you resemble; see [c dimgray]BICS[/c] 24 (1977) 69–71.
	[c dimgray][sup]56[/sup][/c]Greeks gave the name Αἰθίοπες not only to the black peoples
	of inner Africa but also to a people whom they called the
	“eastern Ethiopians”, straight-haired and living near the Indians
	(Herodotus 7.70). In [c dimgray]Prom[/c]. 808–9 the two seem to be identified,
	as if there were continuous land linking south Asia directly to the
	upper Nile.
	[m1]\ [/m]

Zakas, <θέρος> Dawe.

	[c darkmagenta][b]Suppliants[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	Those who dwell near the Nile call it [c dimgray]oistros[/c].

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]pelasgus[/b][/c]

	[c dimgray][sup]63[/sup][/c]

	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]

	<And who was Epaphus’ child?>
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]62[/sup][/c]οἶστρος is a Greek, not an Egyptian word; cf. on 119 and 220.
	[c dimgray][sup]63[/sup][/c]Canobus was a town at one of the mouths of the Nile, just
	east of what was to become the site of Alexandria; in [c dimgray]Prom[/c]. 846–9
	it is prophesied that Io’s wanderings will end there. Memphis, the
	ancient capital of Egypt, was further inland, a little south of modern
	Cairo.

	Greek name from her.

	τὸ πᾶν ἔχθει μ᾿ ἀποπτύουσαν Friis Johansen & Whittle.<li id="note_LCL145_332_333" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]333[/sup][/c]μ᾿ Abresch: om. M.<li id="note_LCL145_332_337" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]337[/sup][/c]φιλοῦσ᾿ Bamberger, ὠνοῖτο Turnebus: φίλουσ ὤνοιτο

	[c darkmagenta][b]Suppliants[/b][/c]
	and wherever you look you will never see trouble
	showing the same face.
	[c dimgray][sup]67[/sup][/c] Who ever supposed that I would
	take to flight like this, against all expectation, and land at
	Argos, rejecting with disgust a marriage-tie with my close
	kindred through loathing of the marital bed?
	[c dimgray][sup]68[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]pelasgus[/b][/c]
	Why do you say you are supplicating me in the name
	of these Assembled Gods, holding these fresh-plucked,
	white-wreathed boughs?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	So that I may not become a slave to the sons of Aegyptus.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]pelasgus[/b][/c]
	Is this because of hatred, or are you talking about something
	wrongful?
	[c dimgray][sup]69[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	Who would love someone whom she was buying as an
	owner?
	[c dimgray][sup]70[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]67[/sup][/c]lit. “feather”, the metaphor being from birds whose feathers
	seem to change colour when viewed from different angles.
	[c dimgray][sup]68[/sup][/c]I translate a restoration considered, but not adopted, by
	Friis Johansen and Whittle [c dimgray]ad loc[/c]. West’s emendation (see apparatus)
	gives the sense “Who ever supposed that there would land at
	Argos, on this unforeseen flight, a former family connection, fluttered
	into a change of location by hatred of marriage?” (West,
	[c dimgray]Studies[/c] 142); but κῆδος normally means “family connection
	[c dimgray]through marriage[/c]” and is the last term the Danaids would use to
	describe the [c dimgray]blood[/c] kinship with the Argives which they have just
	painstakingly proved they possess, while on the other hand κῆδος
	ἐγγενές “a kindred marriage alliance” precisely describes the
	marriage to their cousins from which they are fleeing.
	[c dimgray][sup]69[/sup][/c]i.e. are you saying that the Aegyptiads are demanding something
	to which they have no lawful right?
	[c dimgray][sup]70[/sup][/c]For this equation of marriage with slavery cf. Euripides,
	[c dimgray]Medea[/c] 232–4: “we have to buy a husband at a high price and take
	him as absolute master of our person.”

	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]

	ἀλλ᾿ ἡ Δίκη γε ξυμμάχων ὑπερστατεῖ.

	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]339[/sup][/c]δυστυχούντων [c dimgray]m[/c], γ᾿ Turnebus: δυστυχόντων τ᾿ M[c dimgray][sup]s[/sup][/c]:
	δυστυχόντων M.<li id="note_LCL145_334_341" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]341[/sup][/c]μὴ ᾿κδοὺς Schütz: μἠκδῶισ Μ.<li id="note_LCL145_334_342" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]342[/sup][/c]ἄρασθαι [c dimgray]m[/c]: αἴρασθαι Μ.<li id="note_LCL145_334_344" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]344[/sup][/c]κοινωνὸς ἦν Sophianus,
	Turnebus: κοινὸσ ἦν M[c dimgray][sup]pc[/sup][/c]: κοιν\[. .΄ .\]ν M[c dimgray][sup]ac[/sup][/c].<li id="note_LCL145_334_345" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]345[/sup][/c]ἐστεμμένην Robortello, Turnebus: ἐστεμμένη M.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Suppliants[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]pelasgus[/b][/c]
	That is how people increase their strength.
	[c dimgray][sup]71[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	Yes, and when they fall into misfortune they’re easily got
	rid of.
	[c dimgray][sup]72[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]pelasgus[/b][/c]
	Well then, how can I act piously towards you?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	By not giving us back into the hands of Aegyptus’ sons
	when they demand us.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]pelasgus[/b][/c]
	That’s a hard thing you’re asking—to provoke an outbreak
	of war.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	But Justice stands by those who fight for her.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]pelasgus[/b][/c]
	She will, [c dimgray]if[/c] she was a partner in your cause from the beginning.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	Respect the poop of the ship of state, garlanded as it is.
	[c dimgray][sup]73[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]71[/sup][/c]The Danaids have in effect rejected the principle of Greek
	social organization that marriage is the transfer of a woman, object-like,
	from one family to another; Pelasgus replies with the
	conventional wisdom—that arranged marriages enable families to
	build up alliances and strengthen their social position.
	[c dimgray][sup]72[/sup][/c]i.e. a marriage alliance between two families gives no security
	to the weaker, since the stronger can easily repudiate it.
	[c dimgray][sup]73[/sup][/c]The poop, where the steersman stood, was the most vital
	part of the ship (cf. [c dimgray]Seven[/c] 2); and this shrine, claim the Danaids, is
	the most vital spot in Argos—all the more so now it has been “garlanded”
	with their suppliant-boughs. There is an allusion to the
	garlanding of the sterns of ships on sacred missions (cf. Plato,
	[c dimgray]Phaedo[/c] 58a-c).
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 335[/c]

	[c darkmagenta][b]pelasgus[/b][/c]
	I see this company, shaded by fresh-plucked boughs, supplicating
	in the name of these Assembled Gods. May the
	business of these citizen-strangers
	[c dimgray][sup]75[/sup][/c] not prove ruinous,
	and may this event, never expected or planned for, not
	bring strife to the community: the city doesn’t need that!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]

	May the Right that protects suppliants, servant
	[c dimgray][sup]76[/sup][/c] of Zeus
	Klarios,
	[c dimgray][sup]77[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]74[/sup][/c]Cf. 354–5 below.
	[c dimgray][sup]75[/sup][/c]The Danaids are ἀστόξενοι because, though foreigners (ξέναι) inasmuch as they have come to Argos from abroad and are
	of alien appearance, they are citizens (ἀσταί) by descent.
	[c dimgray][sup]76[/sup][/c]Or “daughter”; the Greek text merely describes Right
	(Themis) as “of Zeus”. In the twenty-third [c dimgray]Homeric Hymn[/c], and in
	Pindar, [c dimgray]Olympian[/c] 8.21–22, Themis is said to sit close to Zeus (cf.
	Dike in Aesch. fr. 281a.10).
	[c dimgray][sup]77[/sup][/c]This title of Zeus is otherwise known only from Tegea
	(Pausanias 8.53.9) where, perhaps significantly, it is associated
	with “the elevated place on which stand most of the Tegeans’ altars”.
	Alternatively, it may here be an alternative designation of
	Zeus as god of suppliants (Hikesios); suppliants’ boughs could
	apparently be called κλάριοι (cf. Hesychius κ2870).
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 337[/c]

	[c dimgray][sup]83[/sup][/c]The “booty” that Battle may seize (or destroy) will consist in
	Argive lives and possibly the city itself (cf. 401).
	[c dimgray][sup]84[/sup][/c]In general, ἀλάστορες (avenging spirits) tend to be thought
	of as a vague plurality, and one speaks of “an ἀλάστωρ” (e.g. [c dimgray]Pers.[/c]
	354; Euripides, [c dimgray]Hippolytus[/c] 820) or of the ἀλάστωρ of a particular person or act (e.g. [c dimgray]Ag[/c]. 1501; Sophocles, [c dimgray]Oedipus at Colonus[/c] 788).
	Here, however Ἀλάστωρ seems to be spoken of as an individual
	divine person. The pattern of usage of Ἐρινύ(ε)ς is quite similar,
	and Erinyes (Furies) too are said to pursue their victims even
	beyond death ([c dimgray]Eum[/c]. 175–8, 339–340).
	[c dimgray][sup]85[/sup][/c]Greek πρόξενος (cf. on 239).
	[c dimgray][sup]86[/sup][/c]Elsewhere in the play the Danaids make it quite clear that
	they fled from Egypt by their own and/or their father’s choice; it is
	an “expulsion” only in the sense that they could not have remained
	there without accepting the marriages they abhor.

	Do not tolerate seeing the suppliant
	dragged away from the divine images, in defiance of
	justice,
	by the headband, like a horse,
	and grabbed by my richly woven robes.
	Know this: whichever decision you make
	will hereafter affect

	by the grace of Zeus god of possessions, by other goods in

	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]87[/sup][/c]lit. “will remain for”.
	[c dimgray][sup]88[/sup][/c]“Either against the gods or
	against the sons of Aegyptus” (scholia).
	[c dimgray][sup]89[/sup][/c]The ship represents
	Pelasgus’ decision, and its launching, now imminent, represents
	the moment when that decision will become irrevocable and
	its consquences unavoidable. The construction of the hull is now
	complete, but the vessel is still attached by cables to a windlass on
	shore; once the cables are let go, the ship will be waterborne. See
	Friis Johansen and Whittle [c dimgray]ad loc[/c].; also D. J. Blackman in J. S.
	Morrison and R. T. Williams, [c dimgray]Greek Oared Ships 900–322[/c]

	(Cambridge, 1968) 183, 185, and L. Casson, [c dimgray]Ships and Seamanship
	in the Ancient World[/c] (Princeton, 1971) 364.

	and a tongue that has loosed off words that are out of

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	Listen to the conclusion of my many respectful words.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]pelasgus[/b][/c]
	I am listening. Speak on; it will not escape me.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	We have girdles and belts to hold our robes together.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]90[/sup][/c]The text of this sentence is very uncertain, but the general
	sense is clear.
	[c dimgray][sup]91[/sup][/c]Since the only bloodshed Pelasgus currently fears is that of a
	war between Argos and Egypt, it is surprising at first sight that he
	should speak of [c dimgray]kindred[/c] blood being spilt. The likeliest explanation
	is that he is implying that in asking him to fight a war on their
	behalf against their cousins, the Danaids are in effect seeking to
	commit kindred-murder by proxy. He again stresses the kinship of
	the two hostile families at 474.
	[c dimgray][sup]92[/sup][/c]lit. “as a remedy for”; but the “remedy” in this case must be
	prophylactic rather than curative, for bloodshed, unlike hurtful
	words or loss of property, once it has occurred is beyond any
	remedy.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[c dimgray][sup]97[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]pelasgus[/b][/c]
	Go, men: what the stranger says is right. Take him to the
	city altars and the abodes of the gods. And you must not be
	talkative with those you meet while escorting this man who
	took sanctuary at the gods’ hearth.
	[c dimgray][sup]98[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	<span class="stage">
	[c dimgray]
	danaus[/c] departs for the city, escorted by some of the soldiers.
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	You have spoken to him; he has had his instructions and is
	on his way. But what shall I do? How will you give me reason
	to be confident?
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]95[/sup][/c]The principal river of Argos.
	[c dimgray][sup]96[/sup][/c]i.e. if you are overconfident
	of my safety, and so fail to provide me with adequate
	protection, the result may be that I find myself in fear of my life.
	[c dimgray][sup]97[/sup][/c]i.e. mistaking him for an enemy: Danaus fears the Argives
	may take [c dimgray]him[/c] for an enemy because of his alien appearance.
	[c dimgray][sup]98[/sup][/c]Plainly implying that he wants the escorts to say nothing
	about Danaus except that he is a suppliant—which will be obvious
	anyway from the boughs. Pelasgus does not wish any further information
	about the affair to become public until he presents it himself
	at the forthcoming assembly meeting.

Τυφῶ Friis Johansen: τυφῶ . . . νείλου M.<li id="note_LCL145_362_561" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]561[/sup][/c]τε Pauw: τὸ M.<li id="note_LCL145_362_563" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]563[/sup][/c]κεντροδαλήτισι Erfurdt: κεντροδαλήτοις M.<li id="note_LCL145_362_566" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]566[/sup][/c]δείματι Arsenius: δειμακτι M.

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Suppliants[/b][/c]
	speeding across the land of the Pamphylians,
	[c dimgray][sup]106[/sup][/c]
	its ever-flowing rivers
	and its deep rich soil, and the land
	of Aphrodite
	[c dimgray][sup]107[/sup][/c] abundant in wheat.
	And she arrived, while the winged cowherd
	was still piercing her with its sting,
	in the plain of Zeus,
	[c dimgray][sup]108[/sup][/c] rich in all kinds of pasture,
	the snow-fed meads
	[c dimgray][sup]109[/sup][/c] over which flows
	the might of the Nile
	and the water untouched by the plagues of Typhos,
	[c dimgray][sup]110[/sup][/c]
	maddened by undeserved sufferings
	and agonies inflicted by the hurtful sting,
	a maenad of Hera.
	[c dimgray][sup]111[/sup][/c]
	And the men who then dwelt in that land
	felt their hearts leap with green fear
	[c dimgray][sup]112[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]106[/sup][/c]In classical times the part of southern Asia Minor called
	Pamphylia lay well to the west of Cilicia, and Io would have come
	to it first; but Sophocles too (fr. 180a) applied the name Pamphylia
	to (part of) the later Cilicia.
	[c dimgray][sup]107[/sup][/c]Phoenicia and Palestine, famous for the worship of Astarte
	(equated by Greeks with Aphrodite).
	[c dimgray][sup]108[/sup][/c]Egypt (or perhaps,
	more specifically, the Nile delta), cf. 4–5.
	[c dimgray][sup]109[/sup][/c]It was believed that the Nile’s floods were fed by melting
	mountain snow; cf. Aesch. fr. 126a (300); Euripides, [c dimgray]Helen[/c] 2–3;
	Anaxagoras 59 A 91 D-K; Herodotus 2.22.1.
	[c dimgray][sup]110[/sup][/c]i.e. free from storms: Typhos, whom Zeus defeated soon after
	becoming ruler of the universe, was father of the storm-winds
	(Hesiod, [c dimgray]Theogony[/c] 869–880). The mention of these calm waters
	recalls the Danaids’ own storm-free voyage (134–7) and, by contrast,
	their prayer that their pursuers be overwhelmed and
	drowned in a tempest (30–36).
	[c dimgray][sup]111[/sup][/c]i.e. driven into frenzy by Hera as bacchic maenads are by
	Dionysus.
	[c dimgray][sup]112[/sup][/c]The pallor of intense fear was thought to be caused by a
	flow of bile; cf. [c dimgray]Cho[/c]. 183–4, Theocritus 23.13.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 363[/c]

	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]135[/sup][/c]One of the functions of Artemis was to protect women in
	childbirth (cf. Euripides, [c dimgray]Hippolytus[/c] 166–9). From the fifth century
	onwards, Hecate, originally a distinct goddess (cf. Hesiod,
	[c dimgray]Theogony[/c] 411–452), was often identified with Artemis; the relevance
	of such an identification here may be that one of Hecate’s
	roles was as a “nurturer of boys” (κουροτρόφος, [c dimgray]ibid.[/c] 450–2).
	[c dimgray][sup]136[/sup][/c]The reference is specifically to civil strife, as 683 shows.
	[c dimgray][sup]137[/sup][/c]Apollo Lykeios (cf. [c dimgray]Seven[/c] 146–7), who is here being begged
	[c dimgray]not[/c] to be wolf-like towards the young Argives.
	[c dimgray][sup]138[/sup][/c]With the result that, over the years, the quality of the flocks
	as a whole will steadily improve; cf. Plato, [c dimgray]Republic[/c] 459a-b, and
	for the posited sense of πρόνομος, cf. Gregory of Nazianzus in
	[c dimgray]Patrologia Graeca[/c] xxxvii 1538.14. See Ch. Simelidis, [c dimgray]Philologus[/c]
	147 (2003) 343–7 and 149 (2005) 154–5.

	And may the people, which rules the city,

	[c dimgray][sup]139[/sup][/c]
	a government acting with craft and foresight for the
	common good;
	and to foreigners may they offer

	[c dimgray][sup]140[/sup][/c]

	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]139[/sup][/c]i.e. may the sovereign people [c dimgray]as a collectivity[/c] protect the
	rights that citizens have [c dimgray]as individuals.[/c]
	[c dimgray][sup]140[/sup][/c]The reference is probably not to treaties (ξυμβολαί or
	ξύμβολα) prescribing rules for the judicial settlement of disputes
	between [c dimgray]citizens[/c] of one state and those of another (since problems arising out of such treaties would not be particularly likely to precipitate
	war) but to treaties requiring disputes [c dimgray]between the contracting
	states themselves[/c] to be submitted to arbitration (δίκας
	διδόναι καὶ δέχεσθαι), cf. Thucydides 1.85.2, 1.140.2, 1.144.2,
	7.18.2. The Danaids’ prayer is that the Argive people, acting “with
	foresight for the common good”, will seek a peaceful solution to
	any interstate dispute, through arbitration if necessary, before
	resorting to war.
	[c dimgray][sup]141[/sup][/c]Laurel, though it was Apollo’s sacred plant, was used in
	other cults too.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[c darkmagenta][b]danaus[/b][/c]
	I praise you, dear daughters, for these wise prayers. Now
	do not be afraid when you hear from your father this unexpected
	and untoward news. From this lookout post, which
	received you as suppliants, I can see the boat. It is unmistakable.
	I cannot fail to observe the ship’s sailing-gear,
	[c dimgray][sup]143[/sup][/c] its
	side-screens,
	[c dimgray][sup]144[/sup][/c] and the prow which scans the way ahead
	with eyes,
	[c dimgray][sup]145[/sup][/c] obeying all too well the guiding helm at the
	very stern of the ship, as if unfriendly to us;
	[c dimgray][sup]146[/sup][/c] and the men
	on board the ship are conspicuously visible, their black
	limbs set against white garments. Now the other ships and
	all the assisting forces are plain to see, and the leading vessel
	herself is close inshore, has furled her sail and is rowing
	in with all oars. Now you must look at this matter in a calm
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]142[/sup][/c]The reference is to a set of fundamental ethical principles
	sometimes called the “unwritten laws”, nearly always three in
	number; these are variously formulated in our sources, but in Aeschylus
	(cf. [c dimgray]Eum.[/c] 269–272, 538–548), perhaps under Eleusinian
	influence (see my edition of Aristophanes’ [c dimgray]Frogs[/c] \[Warminster, 1996\], comm. on 145–153), they prescribe the giving of due
	honour to gods (704–6), to ξένοι (701–3), and to parents. The
	Danaids have prayed that the Argives may give due honour to
	ξένοι and to the gods, but they do not pray for them to respect
	their parents, and here apparently they are explaining why not—because this is only the third of the “unwritten laws” (cf. [c dimgray]BICS[/c] 24
	\[1977\] 75–76).
	[c dimgray][sup]143[/sup][/c]Apparently a periphrasis for “sail”, from
	a distance the ship’s most conspicuous feature.
	[c dimgray][sup]144[/sup][/c]For the protection of the crew, especially from enemy missiles;
	see Morrison and Williams, [c dimgray]Greek Oared Ships[/c] 110–14.
	[c dimgray][sup]145[/sup][/c]Greek warships regularly had large eyes painted on their
	port and starboard bows.
	[c dimgray][sup]146[/sup][/c]Possessed of senses (it “sees” the way ahead and, literally,
	“hears” the helm) and in purposeful, well-guided motion, the ship
	seems like a living being, and almost as hostile to Danaus and his
	family as the men it bears.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 381[/c]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Suppliants[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]danaus[/b][/c]
	Well, rumour has it that wolves
	[c dimgray][sup]151[/sup][/c] are stronger than dogs;
	and papyrus fruit
	[c dimgray][sup]152[/sup][/c] can’t beat ears of corn.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	Their tempers are like those of wanton, impious beasts: we
	must take care they do not get control of us!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]danaus[/b][/c]
	You can’t send out a naval expedition quickly, and you can’t
	bring one in quickly either. Nor is it a speedy job running
	stern cables ashore to keep the ship safe,
	[c dimgray][sup]153[/sup][/c] and their
	custodians
	[c dimgray][sup]154[/sup][/c] don’t immediately feel secure when they’ve
	dropped anchor, especially when they’ve come to a
	harbourless coast as the sun is departing and night approaching—
	night tends to breed travail in the mind of an
	expert helmsman. So even to land an army
	[c dimgray][sup]155[/sup][/c] would not be
	a good idea until the fleet was secure in its anchorage. But
	as you’re afraid, be sure not to forget the gods; <I will come
	back from town as soon as possible> having secured assistance.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]151[/sup][/c]The wolf was an emblem of Argos, and appears regularly
	on its coins (see C. M. Kraay, [c dimgray]Archaic and Classical Greek Coins[/c]
	\[London, 1976\] 96 and pl. 16 no. 287).
	[c dimgray][sup]152[/sup][/c]It was actually the root and lower stalk of the papyrus plant
	that (some) Egyptians used as food (Herodotus 2.92.5); the implication
	in this sentence that they did not eat cereal foods is of
	course absurd.
	[c dimgray][sup]153[/sup][/c]Danaus assumes that the ships will cast anchor in water of
	sufficient depth and then moor themselves with long cables from
	the stern (cf. e.g. [c dimgray]Iliad[/c] 1.436, [c dimgray]Odyssey[/c] 10.95–96). See Morrison
	and Williams, [c dimgray]Greek Oared Ships[/c] 56–57.
	[c dimgray][sup]154[/sup][/c]lit. “shepherds”.
	[c dimgray][sup]155[/sup][/c]sc. much less to launch an attack.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 387[/c]

	[c dimgray][sup]156[/sup][/c]
	what is going to happen to us? Where in the land of Apia
	can we flee in the hope that there is somewhere a dark
	hiding-place?

	up among
	[c dimgray][sup]157[/sup][/c] the clouds of Zeus,
	to fly up without wings, invisible, imperceptible,
	like dust, and end my existence altogether!

	my heart within is shaken, its flesh turned black.
	[c dimgray][sup]158[/sup][/c]

	with terror!

	[c dimgray][sup]156[/sup][/c]Because it is the land of our ancestress Io (alluded to by

	near where the moist clouds turn into snow,
	or a slippery crag, where no goat climbs,

	For the offspring of Aegyptus <are advancing on us,>
	intolerable in their male wantonness!
	I fled, but they run after me in pursuit
	and in their clamorous lust
	seek to seize me by force.
	The beam of the balance
	[c dimgray][sup]162[/sup][/c] is yours, all yours:

	[c dimgray][sup]163[/sup][/c] appears

	on finding their prey; from the following lines there survive
	the words[/c] I am the seizer [c dimgray](826)[/c], on the ship [c dimgray](826a) and[/c] on
	the land [c dimgray](826b), after which there was probably another
	line in which they declared their intention of taking the
	Danaids to their ship. The chorus[/c] reply Before that,
	seizer, may you wear away—yugh!
	[c dimgray][sup]164[/sup][/c]
	[c dimgray](827). Of their next
	line (828) there survive two letters which may be part of
	the word for eye and, after a gap, the phrase[/c] going down
	straight away; [c dimgray]possibly they are telling the Egyptians to get

	[c dimgray][sup]166[/sup][/c]These three lines, the first surviving full lines sung by the
	Egyptians, are the only place where it is hard to resist the conclusion
	that Aeschylus gave them broken Greek to sing.
	[c dimgray][sup]167[/sup][/c]It is not known what kind of vessel an ἀμᾶς was, but since
	the word is attested only here and in [c dimgray]Proteus[/c] (fr. 214) it was presumably
	an Egyptian type.
	[c dimgray][sup]168[/sup][/c]i.e. your ship.
	[c dimgray][sup]169[/sup][/c]Rendering a very tentative text (emendations of Voss and
	Weil).
	[c dimgray][sup]170[/sup][/c]This line (required for strophic responsion) is lost except
	for ἰὼ ἰὸν, of which nothing can be made.
	[c dimgray][sup]171[/sup][/c]The Egyptians (profess to) believe that right is on their side
	(cf. 916–920) and therefore that the Argives, if they are pious, will
	not resist them on the Danaids’ behalf.

	[c dimgray][sup]172[/sup][/c]Of the Nile.
	[c dimgray][sup]173[/sup][/c]The scholiast’s note is clumsily expressed, but his source
	appears to have correctly interpreted this passage to mean that
	Nile water promotes male fertility. If so, it may be our earliest
	source for the belief that semen was a derivative of blood. This belief
	is otherwise first attested in Diogenes of Apollonia (fr. 6 D-K),
	later becoming part of Aristotle’s theory of reproduction ([c dimgray]De
	Generatione Animalium[/c] 726b3–9), but it may well have much
	older roots, of the nature of folklore rather than philosophy.
	[c dimgray][sup]174[/sup][/c]Rendering West’s emendation.
	[c dimgray][sup]175[/sup][/c]Rendering the tentative suggestions of West (many widely
	differing restorations have been proposed).

Μ.<li id="note_LCL145_400_878" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]878[/sup][/c]περιχαμπτὰ M: περίχαυνα Enger (nothing better).<li id="note_LCL145_400_878-9" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]878-9[/sup][/c]βρυάζεισ ὃσ ἐρωτᾶσ M: βρυάζει σὸς ἔρως· ἀλλ᾿
	Newman.<li id="note_LCL145_400_880" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]880[/sup][/c]Πότμος ὑβρίζοντ᾿ West: νεῖλοσ ὑβρίζοντα σε M.<li id="note_LCL145_400_880-1" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]880-1[/sup][/c]ἀποτρέψειεν ἄητον (ἄατον) Friis Johansen: ἀπὸ τρέψει ἔναιστον M.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 400[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Suppliants[/b][/c]
	drifting before the winds blowing from Syria
	on to the piled sands of Sarpedon’s bank!
	[c dimgray][sup]176[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]herald[/b][/c]
	I order you to go with all speed to the curved
	[c dimgray][sup]177[/sup][/c] boat; let no
	one make any delay, or you will be dragged by the hair
	without the least scruple.
	[c dimgray][sup]178[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]

	Oh, oh!
	I wish you would be uttering your insults beneath the
	earth!
	<Your desire is> swelling
	<with great vanity>.
	[c dimgray][sup]179[/sup][/c] May great Destiny avert the
	monstrous outrage
	that you are committing!
	[c dimgray][sup]180[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]176[/sup][/c]At the mouth of the river Calycadnus in Cilicia; the coast at
	that point faces nearly due east, towards northern Syria, so a wind
	“blowing from Syria” would drive the ship on to a lee shore. The
	ship is imagined to have sailed all along the south coast of Asia Minor;
	it would have continued to Egypt either along the Syrian
	coast or via Cyprus.
	[c dimgray][sup]177[/sup][/c]The epithet ἀμφίστροφον is adapted from that used in the
	Homeric phrase νέος ἀμφιελίσσης.
	[c dimgray][sup]178[/sup][/c]lit. “for dragging will certainly not in any way show reverence
	for your locks”.
	[c dimgray][sup]179[/sup][/c]Rendering the conjectures of Enger and Newman (but the
	text here is beyond confident restoration).
	[c dimgray][sup]180[/sup][/c]A person’s πότμος was his “personal destiny or lot,  especially
	as manifested in \[his\] death” (West, [c dimgray]Studies[/c] 163—emphasis
	mine); the Danaids’ hope is thus that their enemy may be destroyed
	before he can wreak his evil will.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	(πικρότερον Emperius, ἀχήσεις West, οἰζύος νόμον Burges).<li id="note_LCL145_402_885" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]885[/sup][/c]βρέτεος ἄρος Abresch, cf. Σ ἡ τῶν βρετέων ἐπικουρία:

Voss (after Pauw), cf. Σ ὦ πάτερ: βᾶ M.

	[c darkmagenta][b]Suppliants[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]herald[/b][/c]
	Cry and howl and call on gods—you won’t jump out of the
	Egyptian boat.
	[c dimgray][sup]181[/sup][/c] You’ll soon be uttering an even bitterer
	song of anguish.
	[c dimgray][sup]182[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	<span class="stage">
	[c dimgray]The herald[/c] and his men begin to advance steadily towards the shrine.
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]

	Oh, oh, Father,
	[c dimgray][sup]183[/sup][/c] the protection of your image
	is failing me! He is taking me by force to the sea,
	coming step by step, like a spider—
	a dream, a black dream!
	Ototototoi!
	Mother Earth, Mother Earth, avert
	the fearsome <assailant>!
	[c dimgray][sup]184[/sup][/c]
	O Father Zeus, child of Earth!
	[c dimgray][sup]185[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]181[/sup][/c]It would in fact be perfectly easy, and an obvious move, for
	the Danaids to avoid the hated marriage by such a leap to a watery
	grave—[c dimgray]unless[/c]they are to be chained or tied up during the voyage.
	Are the Egyptians who have come with the Herald perhaps holding
	ropes of fetters, which they brandish when the Herald speaks
	these words?
	[c dimgray][sup]182[/sup][/c]The transmitted text of this sentence is meaningless, and
	has not been convincingly emended, but the words “bitterer”
	(πικρότερ-) and “of anguish” (οἰζύος) are fairly secure.
	[c dimgray][sup]183[/sup][/c]The context, especially the singular βρέτεος, indicates
	strongly that this is addressed to Zeus, not Danaus.
	[c dimgray][sup]184[/sup][/c]This supplement is intended only to give an idea of the
	approximate sense.
	[c dimgray][sup]185[/sup][/c]Rhea, the mother of Zeus, was identified with the Asiatic
	mother-goddess Cybele, who was in turn sometimes identified
	with Earth (e.g. Sophocles, [c dimgray]Philoctetes[/c] 391–4). In the ordinary
	divine genealogy, Earth was mother of Cronus and grandmother
	of Zeus.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 403[/c]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]190[/sup][/c]A foreigner, claiming that property or persons currently in
	Argos were his and ought to be surrendered to him, should not
	take the law into his own hands but should approach an appropriate
	Argive πρόξενος, who would negotiate or litigate on his behalf.
	[c dimgray][sup]191[/sup][/c]μαστήριος is not known to have been (though it may have
	been) a cult-title of Hermes, but the Herald’s meaning is anyway
	clear: as a herald, under Hermes’ protection, he claims the right to
	search for and take “his property” wherever it may be.
	[c dimgray][sup]192[/sup][/c]A reference to the procedure of ἐξαίρεσις (or ἀφαίρεσις)
	εἰς ἐλευθερίαν, whereby if A was attempting to seize B, claiming
	that B was his slave (cf. 918 “my own lost property”), a third party
	could prevent the seizure (pending a trial of the issue) by asserting
	that B was in fact free; cf. Isocrates 17.14, Lysias 23.9–12.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 409[/c]

	consider wisely where we should reside

	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]196[/sup][/c]i.e. in accommodation reserved for you alone (rather than
	being shared “with many others”). Without Burges’ transposition,
	neither the audience nor the Danaids would be clear how many
	and what options were being offered for them to choose between;
	in fact there are just two (cf. 1009–11)—non-exclusive accommodation
	in public dwellings, or exclusive accommodation in the
	palace or another building owned by the king. No doubt we will
	discover, later in the trilogy, that Danaus has chosen the latter, which will minimize contact between his daughters and ordinary
	Argives and, in due course, facilitate the wedding-night murders.
	See P. Sandin, [c dimgray]Eranos[/c] 100 (2002) 150–2 (though he takes a different
	view on the textual issue).
	[c dimgray][sup]197[/sup][/c]The Danaids are μέτοικοι (609, 994). At Athens a metic
	was required to nominate some citizen as his προστάτης (he
	could be prosecuted for failing to do so); the legal functions of the
	προστάτης are not clear, but he would no doubt normally in practice
	befriend the metic and help him in any business which a citizen
	could handle more effectively than a foreigner. The Danaids
	will be in the unique position of having the king and the entire
	citizen body as their προστάται.
	[c dimgray][sup]198[/sup][/c]Possibly a hint that Danaus should be sent with an escort
	(cf. 954–5).
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 415[/c]

	<span class="stage">
	[c dimgray]
	pelasgus[/c] departs for the city with some of his men, leaving the remainder to guard and escort the Danaids. The transmitted text here continues:

	Arrange yourselves, dear maids, in the way
	in which Danaus allotted you to each of us
	as a dowry in the form of a servant.

	 There is, however, no other clear evidence in the text for the
	existence of these maidservants: they can hardly have only
	just come on stage (where could they have been before?),
	and had they been with their mistresses from the start, one
	would have expected some notice to be taken of them, especially
	by Pelasgus. Moreover, Pelasgus is still apparently
	being addressed in 973–4 and can hardly leave the scene
	before then, and it would be clumsy (and unparalleled) to
	have Danaus arrive from the same direction almost immediately
	afterwards. It is therefore likely that the maids, and
	the three lines addressed to them, were added to the play
	by a later producer, perhaps in place of a short choral
	song.
	[c dimgray][sup]200[/sup][/c] The chorus probably descended from the mound
	before singing the song.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	been our saviours. They gave a hearing to my
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]199[/sup][/c]In other words: no country, however welcoming it tries to
	be to refugees, is free from xenophobia, which can be activated by
	almost any (real or fancied) misdemeanour by, or special favours
	conferred on, the incomers.
	[c dimgray][sup]200[/sup][/c]See my discussion in B. Zimmermann ed. [c dimgray]Griechischrömische Komödie und Tragödie[/c] (Stuttgart, 1995) 120–1 and n.46
	(also M. Ewans, [c dimgray]Aischylos: Suppliants and Other Dramas[/c] \[London,
	1996\] 218–9), modifying more drastic proposals by O. P.
	Taplin, [c dimgray]The Stagecraft of Aeschylus[/c] (Oxford, 1977) 222–238. Perhaps
	the producer transferred the lines from [c dimgray]Danaids,[/c] where the
	Danaids are (or have been) married and could well have been
	assigned servants to take with them to their new homes, as brides

	[c dimgray][sup]201[/sup][/c]i.e. to you and me.
	[c dimgray][sup]202[/sup][/c]lit. “an ever-living burden”; the burden is that of the guilt
	and pollution of having failed to protect the life of a suppliant and

	[c dimgray][sup]203[/sup][/c]Something must have been lost here, since in the transmitted
	Text μήτε “neither” in 987 has no “nor” to answer it; West’s suggestion,
	supposing τιμιωτέραν ἐμοῦ (meaningless where it is
	transmitted, at the end of 990) to have been displaced thither
	from one of the lost lines, is the most plausible that has been
	made. In any event, the decreeing of an armed personal bodyguard
	to Danaus is a sinister development; at Athens, as elsewhere,
	it had in the past been the prelude to the establishment of a
	tyranny (cf. Herodotus 1.59.4–5).

	know and esteem you.

	that you have which makes men turn their heads. Tender
	fruit is not at all easy to guard: beasts and men alike
	devour
	[c dimgray][sup]206[/sup][/c] it, do they not? In the case of animals, winged or
	walking, Cypris
	[c dimgray][sup]207[/sup][/c] advertises the availability of juicy fruits
	before they are ripe, preventing them <from resisting> desire;

	[c dimgray][sup]208[/sup][/c] and likewise with the charms of a maiden fair of
	form, every passer-by is vanquished by desire and shoots a
	glance of the eye at her that can melt her heart. Bearing
	that in mind, let us not suffer what we endured long sorrow
	and ploughed a long sea-furrow with our keel to avoid;
	[c dimgray][sup]209[/sup][/c]
	let us not cause disgrace to ourselves and pleasure to my
	enemies. We have two kinds of housing available—one set
	offered by Pelasgus, another by the city—to live in free of
	rent. That is easy. Only keep in mind these precepts of your
	father’s, and value your chastity more than life itself.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]206[/sup][/c]lit. “destroy”; but since ἀκήρατος can mean “virgin”, the
	verb is probably also felt as having a slight sexual tinge.
	[c dimgray][sup]207[/sup][/c]Aphrodite.
	[c dimgray][sup]208[/sup][/c]The transmitted text of 1002 is unintelligible, and none of
	the many proposed restorations is acceptable. My rendering (“before
	they are ripe . . . resisting desire”), based mostly on the
	Wecklein-Murray restoration, is intended only to give an approximate
	sense (and to suggest that (αν) θωσμένειν might conceal an
	infinitive meaning “resist” or the like—but I cannot find a suitable
	verb).West’s proposal, giving the sense “and at the same time softening
	up the less ripe, so as to madden them with desire”, unsatisfactorily
	distinguishes between ripe juicy (female) fruit ([c dimgray]towards
	which[/c] Cypris apparently directs the desire of the male animals)
	and unripe fruit ([c dimgray]in which[/c] she implants desire), leaving it unclear
	which of the two corresponds to the Danaids; in some respects it is
	also dubious linguistically (e.g. μωλύω, when it has a living being
	as object, usually refers to a change that [c dimgray]diminishes[/c] the creature’s
	health or vigour).
	[c dimgray][sup]209[/sup][/c]lit. (with a zeugma) “let us not suffer
	that because of which much toil (πόνος) and much sea (πόντος)
	was ploughed by our ship”.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	In all else may the Olympian gods give us good fortune—but so far as my “fruit” is concerned, father, you can have
	confidence: unless the gods have decided on some new
	plan, I will not deviate from the track my mind has followed
	till now.
	Go
	[c dimgray][sup]210[/sup][/c] now to the town, glorifying
	the blessed lords, the gods,
	both those of the city and those who dwell around
	the ancient stream of Erasinus.
	[c dimgray][sup]211[/sup][/c]
	Accept our song,
	you escorts, and let praise enfold this city
	of the Pelasgians; no longer let us
	sing in honour of the mouths of the Nile,
	but of the rivers that pour their tranquil waters
	through this land, to drink for health
	and for fertility, softening
	[c dimgray][sup]212[/sup][/c] the soil of the land
	with their oil-smooth streams.
	May chaste Artemis watch over
	this band in pity, and may Cytherea’s
	[c dimgray][sup]213[/sup][/c] consummation
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]210[/sup][/c]Since the participle γανόωντες is masculine, this is presumably
	addressed by the Danaids to themselves [c dimgray]and their father[/c];
	the only other males present, the Argive soldiers, are asked at
	1022–3 (not to sing but) to [c dimgray]receive[/c] the song (as representatives of
	Argos).
	[c dimgray][sup]211[/sup][/c]The Danaids will be crossing this small river en route from
	the coast to Argos. The other river of Argos, the Inachus (497),
	flows past the city on the far (north) side.
	[c dimgray][sup]212[/sup][/c]lit. “propitiating”, i.e. making friendly (to man’s agricultural
	activity).
	[c dimgray][sup]213[/sup][/c]Cytherea is another by-name of Aphrodite.

	not come to us by compulsion:

	<span class="speaker sc">argive soldiers
	[c dimgray][sup]215[/sup][/c]
	But it is a wise rule not to ignore Cypris;
	for she holds power very close to Zeus, together with
	Hera,
	[c dimgray][sup]216[/sup][/c]
	a goddess of cunning wiles
	who is honoured for awesome deeds.
	[c dimgray][sup]217[/sup][/c]
	Partners and associates with their dear mother
	are Desire and the charmer Persuasion,
	to whom nothing can be refused,
	and also given to Aphrodite as her portion
	[c dimgray][sup]218[/sup][/c] are
	Union
	[c dimgray][sup]219[/sup][/c]
	and the whispering paths of love-making.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]214[/sup][/c] lit. “belong to the Styx” (one of the underworld rivers).
	[c dimgray][sup]215[/sup][/c]M marks no change of speaker anywhere in 1018–73, but
	the text makes it clear that 1018–33 come from one group, 1034–51
	from another group (or maybe individual), and 1052–61 is an
	altercation between the two. The dissenter(s) have been identified
	as half of the Danaids disputing with the other half
	(Hermann), as the maidservants of 977–9 (Kirchhoff), and as
	Danaus (Taplin); the currently favoured candidates are the escort
	of Argive soldiers (first suggested by H. Freericks; see more re- cently H. Friis Johansen, [c dimgray]Classica et Mediaevalia[/c] 27 \[1966\] 61–64,
	and R. Seaford, [c dimgray]Dioniso[/c] 55 \[1984\] 221–9). Yet another possibility
	is that Hypermestra, the future rebel, here for the first time (and
	in breach of normal tragic convention) takes a stand against her
	sisters; see D.A. Hester, [c dimgray]Antichthon[/c] 21 (1987) 9–18.
	[c dimgray][sup]216[/sup][/c]Hera was a patron of marriage: cf. [c dimgray]Eum.[/c] 213–6.
	[c dimgray][sup]217[/sup][/c]Referring not so much to “accomplishments of the sexual
	act” (Friis Johansen and Whittle) as to the broader power that
	Aphrodite exercises over the whole living world (cf. 998–1005).
	[c dimgray][sup]218[/sup][/c]Cf. Hesiod, [c dimgray]Theogony[/c] 203–6, where Aphrodite is said to
	have had allotted as her portion (μοῖραν) from the beginning “the
	whisperings and smiles and deceptions of maidens, and sweet delight
	and love-making (φιλότητα, cf. next note) and gentleness”.
	[c dimgray][sup]219[/sup][/c]Ἁρμονία (properly “joining together”) is used by Empedocles
	(frr. 27.3, 122 D-K) as a synonym for Φιλότης, the power
	that presided over that phase in the history of the universe when
	all the elements were intimately united.
	[m1]\ [/m]
