-145.433 (AESCHYLUS, Prometheus Bound)
%Aeschylus
AESCHYLUS, Prometheus Bound
	[c darkmagenta][b]AESCHYLUS, Prometheus Bound[/b][/c]
	[b]Prometheus Bound[/b]
	[b]Prometheus Bound[/b]
	In late antiquity and the Middle Ages [c dimgray]Prometheus Bound[/c]
	was the most read of Aeschylean plays, and in subsequent
	centuries it has remained among the most popular; in particular,
	its portrayal of a god who endures potentially unending
	torment, for the sake of humanity, from the agents
	of a tyrannical Zeus, appealed very powerfully to thinkers,
	authors and artists of the revolutionary and romantic periods,
	notably Goethe, Byron, Shelley, Marx and Nietzsche.
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]
	From the mid nineteenth century, however, doubts began
	to appear about whether the play was in fact his work.
	Some of these rested on the inadequate basis of supposed
	inconsistencies between the theology of this play and that
	of the rest of the Aeschylean corpus, but increasingly attention
	has been drawn to important features of style and
	technique in which [c dimgray]Prometheus Bound[/c] (as well as its evident
	sequel, [c dimgray]Prometheus Unbound[/c]) differ markedly from
	the undisputed plays of Aeschylus, and to possible echoes
	of other texts that were not composed until after his death.
	The issue remains in dispute, and the play’s authenticity
	continues to find powerful defenders, not least because it
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]For a review of the reception of this play in ancient, medieval
	and modern times, see A. J. Podlecki, [c dimgray]Aeschylus: Prometheus
	Bound[/c] (Oxford, 2005) 41–68.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 432[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m][b]Prometheus Bound[/b]
	was never questioned in antiquity; but at present it would
	probably be true to say that a majority of scholars would regard
	it as being by a slightly later hand.
	[c dimgray][sup]2[/sup][/c] West’s suggestion
	([c dimgray]Studies[/c] 67–72) that the hand is that of Aeschylus’ son
	Euphorion, passing his own work off as that of his father, is
	a very tempting one, not least because it gives full value to
	the play’s audacious grandeur of concept, reminiscent of
	that of the [c dimgray]Oresteia[/c] and quite unlike anything found in
	Sophocles or Euripides, which surely suggests Aeschylean
	inspiration even if the detailed technique may not suggest
	Aeschylean workmanship.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	We have no direct information as to when the play was
	produced. Whether by Aeschylus or not, it can hardly be
	earlier than [c dimgray]Suppliants,[/c] to which it contains a clear reference;

	[c dimgray][sup]3[/sup][/c] and it cannot be later than about 430, since in (probably)
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]2[/sup][/c]The play’s authenticity was first doubted by Robert Westphal
	in A. Rossbach and R. Westphal, [c dimgray]Metrik der griechischen
	Dramatiker und Lyriker[/c] (Leipzig, 1856) 3, and denied with powerful
	arguments by W. Schmid, [c dimgray]Untersuchungen zum Gefesselten
	Prometheus[/c] (Stuttgart, 1929). These, however, made little impact
	on English-speaking scholarship until the appearance of Mark
	Griffith’s [c dimgray]The Authenticity of Prometheus Bound[/c] (Cambridge,1977)
	which focused on linguistic, metrical and other technical
	arguments against authenticity. Important later studies taking the
	same view have included M. L. West, [c dimgray]JHS[/c] 99 (1979) 130–148
	and [c dimgray]Studies[/c] 51–72, and R. Bees, [c dimgray]Zur Datierung des Prometheus
	Desmotes[/c] (Stuttgart, 1993); the play’s authenticity has been defended
	by, among others, M. P. Pattoni, [c dimgray]L’autenticità del Prometeo
	Incatenato di Eschilo[/c] (Pisa, 1987) and Podlecki, [c dimgray]Aeschylus: Prometheus
	Bound[/c] 195–200.
	[c dimgray][sup]3[/sup][/c]The image of the doves and hawks applied to the Danaids and their cousins in [c dimgray]Prom.[/c] 857 echoes the same image in [c dimgray]Supp.[/c] 223–4.

	companion plays in 472. [c dimgray]Prometheus the Fire-Bearer[/c] has
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]19[/sup][/c]He does not mention dismounting or remounting, though
	his line “Your words are plainly meant to send me back home”
	(387)—his first single-line speech in the scene—provide a possible
	occasion for the latter.
	[c dimgray][sup]20[/sup][/c]See notes on 128 and 140.
	[c dimgray][sup]21[/sup][/c]See note on 283/4.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 438[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m][b]Prometheus Bound[/b]
	usually been taken to be the title of a tragedy produced together
	with [c dimgray]Bound[/c] and [c dimgray]Unbound,[/c] either as the first play of
	a trilogy (dealing with Prometheus’ theft of fire) or as the
	last (dealing, perhaps, with the establishment of his Athenian
	cult). There are, however, serious objections to either
	view, and it is more likely that [c dimgray]Prometheus the Fire-Bearer[/c]
	is merely an alternative (and arguably a more appropriate)
	title for the satyr-drama of 472.
	[c dimgray][sup]22[/sup][/c] In that case we have no
	way of knowing what the third (or for that matter the
	fourth) play was that Aeschylus, or Euphorion, or whoever
	it may have been, produced together with the two in which
	Prometheus was first taken down to Hades and then
	brought back up to fresh torment and then to release and
	glory.

	bonds; for it was your glory, the gleam of fire that makes all
	skills attainable, that he stole and gave to mortals. For such
	an offence he must assuredly pay his penalty to the gods, to
	teach him that he must accept the autocracy of Zeus and
	abandon his human-loving ways.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[c dimgray][sup]2[/sup][/c] of

	from men. Here you will hear no mortal voice, see no
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]This pair come from Hesiod, [c dimgray]Theogony[/c] 385–401, where they

	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]3[/sup][/c]i.e. the coming of night will temporarily end one kind of suffering
	(from the sun) only to bring another (cold) from which, in
	turn, you will long for relief; and vice versa.
	[c dimgray][sup]4[/sup][/c]Hephaestus should no doubt be taken to intend this as an understatement
	for “will never be born”; the audience will probably
	detect an ironic allusion to Heracles (cf. Hesiod, [c dimgray]Theogony[/c] 526–531),
	but they will later discover (757–768) that Prometheus
	knows of another sense in which a being not yet born could end his
	suffering.
	[c dimgray][sup]5[/sup][/c]“Bending the knee” idiomatically means “resting” (396; [c dimgray]Iliad[/c]
	7.118, 19.71); but Prometheus in his bonds will be [c dimgray]literally[/c] unable
	to bend his.
	[c dimgray][sup]6[/sup][/c]Not entirely logical, since Hephaestus is also
	close kin (nephew) to Zeus.
	[c dimgray][sup]7[/sup][/c]This may possibly foreshadow
	the cultic association in classical Athens between Prometheus and
	Hephaestus (they shared an altar in the Academy district, cf.
	Apollodorus [c dimgray]FGrH[/c] 244 F 147), but this can hardly be imagined as
	existing at the time of the play’s action; the poet may be thinking
	rather of Prometheus’ alliance with the Olympians in their war
	against Cronus and the Titans (cf. 214–221).
	[m1]\ [/m]

	binding (chest) parallel to that of the first phase (arms) and the last
	phase (legs)—as Dyson schematically expresses it, “‘Do it’—‘Done’—‘Make it firmer’—‘Done’”. It also (a point not made by

	which can be so made that when it is (lightly) hammered it fastens
	itself into the chest-band and stays in position.

	[c dimgray][sup]16[/sup][/c] and it has shown itself to be mortals’
	great resource and their teacher of every skill. Such is the
	offence for which I am paying this penalty, pinned in these
	bonds under the open sky.
	\[[c dimgray]Suddenly[/c]\] Hey, what is that?
	What sound, what scent has been wafted to me, unseen,
	from gods, from mortals, or from both together?
	Has someone come to this rock at the end of the world
	to be a spectator of my sufferings—or what do they
	want?
	Behold me, the prisoner, the god in misery,
	the enemy of Zeus, who incurred
	the hostility of all the gods

	It is painful for me even to speak of these things, but it is
	also painful to keep silent: it is wretched either way. As
	soon as the gods began to quarrel and mutual strife was
	stirred up among them, some wishing to depose Cronus
	from his throne—so that Zeus could reign, forsooth!—while those on the other side were determined that Zeus
	should never rule over the gods, at that time I gave the best
	advice to the Titans, the children of Uranus and Gaea,
	[c dimgray][sup]23[/sup][/c]
	but could not persuade them. They despised ingenious
	stratagems, and in the pride of their strength they thought
	they could retain control with ease by brute force. But my
	mother Themis, also called Gaea—one person under multiple
	names
	[c dimgray][sup]24[/sup][/c]—had more than once prophesied to me how
	the future would come to pass, saying that it was destined
	that the victors should be those who excelled not in might
	nor in power but in guile.
	[c dimgray][sup]25[/sup][/c] I spoke to them explaining this,
	but they simply did not see fit even to look at the idea. Well,
	[m1]\ [/m]

	called Χθών (as in [c dimgray]Eum.[/c] 6), but Γαῖα in 210.
	[c dimgray][sup]24[/sup][/c]This identification is almost certainly an [c dimgray]ad hoc[/c] invention; it
	is otherwise attested only by the existence in Roman Athens of a priestess of Γῆ Θέμις ([c dimgray]IG[/c] ii<sub>2</sub> 5130). The poet wanted Prometheus
	to be one of the Titans (cf. note on 165), but also wanted his
	mother to be Themis, a prophetic goddess (cf. [c dimgray]Eum.[/c] 2–4; Euripides,
	[c dimgray]Iphigenia in Tauris[/c] 1259–69) who according to Pindar ([c dimgray]Isthmian[/c]
	8.30–45) alone had knowledge that the son of Thetis was
	destined to be mightier than his father. Traditionally Themis was
	[c dimgray]daughter[/c] of Gaea (and Uranus) (Hesiod, [c dimgray]Theogony[/c] 135).
	[c dimgray][sup]25[/sup][/c]In Hesiod, [c dimgray]Theogony[/c] 626–8, Gaea is said to have advised
	Zeus and the Olympians to release from their underground
	imprisonment Briareus, Cottus and Gyges (the “Hundredhanders”),
	who played a decisive role (though they used force, not
	guile!) in the final defeat of the Titans ([c dimgray]ibid.[/c] 669–675, 713–720).
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 467[/c]

	from me, and this is the evil reward with which he
	has recompensed me! It seems that this malady is built into
	autocracy, that of not trusting one’s friends. But as to the
	question you ask, what is the cause of his thus degrading
	me, I will now explain it. As soon as he took his seat on his
	father’s throne, he immediately assigned to the various
	gods their various privileges,
	[c dimgray][sup]26[/sup][/c] and organized his government;
	but of those wretched creatures, mortals, he took no
	account at all—on the contrary, he wanted to obliterate the
	race altogether and create another new one. And no one
	resisted that plan except me. I had the courage to do it, and
	rescued mortals from the fate of being shattered and going
	to Hades.

	[c darkmagenta][b]prometheus[/b][/c]

	the goodwill that inspired my gifts to them. In the

	[c dimgray][sup]54[/sup][/c] like dream-figures
	they lived a life of utter random confusion all their days.
	They knew nothing of brick-built, sun-warmed houses, nor
	of wooden construction; they dwelt underground, like tiny
	ants, in the sunless recesses of caves. Nor had they any reliable
	indicator of winter, or of flowery spring, or of fruitful
	summer; they did everything without planning, until I
	showed them the hard-to-discern risings and settings of
	stars.
	[c dimgray][sup]55[/sup][/c] I also invented for them the art of number, supreme
	among all techniques, and that of combining letters
	into written words, the tool that enables all things to be
	remembered and is mother of the Muses.
	[c dimgray][sup]56[/sup][/c] And I was the
	first to bring beasts
	[c dimgray][sup]57[/sup][/c] under the yoke as slaves to the yoke-strap
	and the pack-saddle, so that they might relieve humans
	of their greatest labours; and I brought horses to love
	the rein and pull chariots, making them a luxurious ornament
	for men of great wealth. And it was no one other than
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]54[/sup][/c]lit. “seeing, they saw to no effect; hearing, they did not hear”.
	[c dimgray][sup]55[/sup][/c]Any given star rises (and sets) four minutes earlier each day,
	and Greeks used as markers of the seasons the days when prominent
	stars or star-groups (e.g. Sirius, Arcturus, the Pleiades) could
	first be seen rising (or, six months later, setting) before daybreak.
	These risings and settings are “hard to discern” because knowledge
	of them presupposes the ability to pick out the marker stars
	from the thousands of others in the sky.
	[c dimgray][sup]56[/sup][/c]i.e. facilitates the composition of poetry. There is a wordplay
	on the traditional genealogy of the Muses, who were daughters
	of Zeus and Mnemosyne (Memory) (Hesiod, [c dimgray]Theogony[/c] 915–7).
	[c dimgray][sup]57[/sup][/c]Oxen (for ploughing) and asses (for transport); horses will
	be mentioned separately in 465–6.

	[c darkmagenta][b]prometheus[/b][/c]
	When you have heard the rest of what I have to say, you will
	be even more amazed by all the skills and devices that I
	have contrived. The greatest was this. If anyone fell sick,
	there was no means of aiding him, neither by food nor ointment
	nor potion: they withered and decayed for want of
	remedies, until I showed them how to mix gentle curative
	drugs, with which they can now defend themselves against
	all kinds of diseases. I also systematized many kinds of

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]58[/sup][/c]The manuscripts’ reading would mean “You have suffered a
	painful degradation, (namely that) you are straying, robbed of your wits”. Everywhere else, however, the “painful degradation”
	that Prometheus has suffered is the binding and torment, and the
	simile of the doctor confirms this: both Prometheus and the doctor
	are prevented by [c dimgray]their own mental shortcomings[/c] from finding
	a way to escape a predicament in which [c dimgray]external forces[/c] (respectively,
	the will of Zeus and disease) have placed them. Heimsoeth’s
	emendation makes the chorus’s words coherent: they (profess to)
	think that Prometheus’ mood of rigid defiance—which, as they
	see things, forecloses any possibility of release—is due to his mind
	having been warped by his sufferings.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	difficult inferences, and opening their eyes to the signs
	the flames gave, which till then had been dark to them.
	So much for that; but as for the things hidden beneath
	the earth that benefit humanity—copper, iron, silver and
	gold—who can claim to have discovered them before I
	did? No one, I know for sure, unless he wanted to spout
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]59[/sup][/c]Words that a person happened to (over)hear, or individuals
	or animals that he happened to meet, might in certain circumstances
	be regarded as omens of predictive significance; see for
	example Aristophanes, [c dimgray]Lysistrata[/c] 391–7 (women’s laments for the
	death of Adonis punctuating a speech advocating the despatch of
	the Sicilian Expedition) and Theophrastus, [c dimgray]Characters[/c] 16.3 (a
	polecat crossing one’s path as a sign of bad luck).
	[c dimgray][sup]60[/sup][/c]Knowledge of these was important for augury because it enabled the seer to relate the observed behaviour of a bird to (what was believed to be) its normal behaviour. Thus, when Xenophon
	was setting out from Ephesus to join Cyrus’ expedition, a sedentary
	eagle screamed on his right side (Xenophon, [c dimgray]Anabasis[/c]
	6.1.23); the seer whom he consulted told him that while this omen
	foretold greatness and glory, it also betokened suffering (because
	“other birds mostly attack the eagle when it is sedentary”) and did
	not portend material gain (because “the eagle normally gets its
	food when it is on the wing”).
	[c dimgray][sup]61[/sup][/c]This, and what follows as far as 499, refers to the drawing of
	omens from the appearance of the internal parts of sacrificed animals,
	and from the manner in which they burned on the altar.
	[c dimgray][sup]62[/sup][/c]Prometheus is said by Hesiod ([c dimgray]Theogony[/c] 535–557) to have
	been the inventor of this Greek sacrificial practice, but there he
	does it in an attempt (unsuccessful, and disastrous for mankind) to
	deceive Zeus, whereas here his object is to enable mortals to use
	the flames for divination.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	μαίνομαι.<li id="note_LCL145_504_576" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]576[/sup][/c]ποποῖ (πόποι) [c dimgray]k[/c]: ποῖ ποῖ πόποι πόποι vel

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Prometheus Bound[/b][/c]
	that I see, wind-battered,
	harnessed to the rocks?
	For what crime are you thus being murdered?
	Tell me where on earth
	I have wandered in my misery.<span class="stage">
	[c dimgray]She begins to dance wildly.[/c]
	Oh, oh! ah, ah!
	A gadfly is stinging me again, wretched me!—<span class="stage">\[[c dimgray]Suddenly changing direction[/c]\]
	[c dimgray][sup]68[/sup][/c]
	Keep him off! Ah, dah! I <am mad with> fear,
	seeing the myriad-eyed cowherd!
	[c dimgray][sup]69[/sup][/c]
	He is on the move, keeping a crafty eye:
	even though he is dead, the earth cannot cover him—
	he crosses over from the underworld
	to hunt me—wretched me!—and makes me wander
	starving along the sands of the seashore;
	and in accompaniment the noisy reed-pipe, fashioned
	with wax,
	[c dimgray][sup]70[/sup][/c]
	drones its soporific
	[c dimgray][sup]71[/sup][/c] melody.
	Ió, ió, popoi—
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]68[/sup][/c]The gadfly, which drove Io on from land to land (674–7,
	681–2, cf. [c dimgray]Supp.[/c] 306–9), will have stung her from behind; but she
	can [c dimgray]see[/c] the ghost of Argus, which must therefore be imagined as
	being in front of her.
	[c dimgray][sup]69[/sup][/c]Argus; cf. 677–681 and [c dimgray]Supp.[/c] 302–5.
	[c dimgray][sup]70[/sup][/c]The reference is to a herdsman’s pan-pipes, whose reed-stems
	were held together with wax (cf. Euripides, [c dimgray]Iphigenia in
	Tauris[/c] 1125–7; Virgil, [c dimgray]Eclogue[/c] 2.32–33).
	[c dimgray][sup]71[/sup][/c]Hermes, in some accounts, played the pan-pipes to lull
	Argus to sleep before killing him (so probably Bacchylides 19.35–36;
	later, Ovid, [c dimgray]Metamorphoses[/c] 1.682–714). The epithet ἄχέτας
	may suggest a comparison with the chirping of cicadas (cf.
	Aristophanes, [c dimgray]Peace[/c] 1159, [c dimgray]Birds[/c] 1095), which can also induce
	sleep (cf. Plato, [c dimgray]Phaedrus[/c] 259a).
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 505[/c]

	from lands more or less known to Greeks (with violent but human
	inhabitants) to the realm of pure fantasy (populated mainly by
	monsters) described in 791–809. The boundary between Europe
	and Asia was sometimes said to lie at the Cimmerian Bosporus,
	sometimes (as in Aesch. fr. 191) at the river Phasis (Rioni) in
	Colchis (cf. Herodotus 4.45): either the poet has been misled into
	supposing these two watercourses to be one and the same, or he
	has deliberately shifted the location of the Bosporus in order to
	present it more strongly as a point of transition into a different and
	even more terrifying world. See further West, [c dimgray]Studies[/c] 304–6.

	[c darkmagenta][b]Prometheus Bound[/b][/c]
	to sailors, the stepmother of ships.
	[c dimgray][sup]88[/sup][/c] They will
	be very glad to guide you on your way. You will then come
	to the Cimmerian isthmus,
	[c dimgray][sup]89[/sup][/c] right at the narrow gateway
	to the lake; with a bold heart you must leave it, and cross
	the Maeotic channel. Your crossing will in all future time
	be much spoken of among men, and the channel will be
	named after it—Bosporus, “Strait of the Cow”. Having
	thus left the land of Europe, you will have come to the continent
	of Asia. \[[c dimgray]To the chorus[/c]\] Do you think that the autocrat
	of the gods is equally brutal in all his dealings? That
	god, because he wanted to sleep with this mortal girl,
	imposed these wanderings on her! \[[c dimgray]To io[/c]\] You found an
	unpleasant suitor for your hand, young woman; for with all
	of what you’ve so far heard, you should consider that you’re
	not yet even at the beginning of things.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]io[/b][/c]
	Ió, oh, oh! ah, me!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]prometheus[/b][/c]
	You are crying out and moaning aloud again. What can one
	imagine you will do when you learn what remains of your
	troubles?
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]88[/sup][/c]This digression on the future abode of the Amazons is irrelevant,
	unless it foreshadows a mention (not directly attested) in
	[c dimgray]Prometheus Unbound[/c] of Heracles’ battle with the Amazons at
	Themiscyra (cf. \[Apollodorus\], [c dimgray]Library[/c] 2.5.9). It also involves a further geographical confusion. Themiscyra, at the mouth of the
	river Thermodon, was in northern Asia Minor, nearer the eastern
	than the western end of the Black Sea; Salmydessus was in
	Thrace, north-west of Byzantium and the (Thracian) Bosporus,
	and the danger to ships in that area arose not from a rocky promontory
	but from extensive shoals (Xenophon, [c dimgray]Anabasis[/c] 7.5.12).
	Possibly the poet was thinking of the cape near Themiscyra later
	called Herakleios Akra (Strabo 12.3.17).
	[c dimgray][sup]89[/sup][/c]The eastern peninsula of the Crimea, ending at Panticapaeum
	(Kerch), capital of the Bosporan kingdom.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 523[/c]

	Since you are so eager, I will not refuse to tell you everything
	you ask for. First, Io, I shall tell you about the wanderings
	on which you will be driven: inscribe them on the
	memory-tablets of your mind. When you have crossed
	the stream that parts the two continents, go on towards
	the fiery rising of the sun, crossing a waveless sea,
	[c dimgray][sup]93[/sup][/c] until
	you reach the land of the Gorgons, the plain of Cisthene,
	where the Phorcides
	[c dimgray][sup]94[/sup][/c] dwell, three ancient maidens of
	swan-like aspect,
	[c dimgray][sup]95[/sup][/c] owning an eye in common and having
	only a single tooth, whom neither the sun with his rays, nor
	the moon by night, ever looks upon;
	[c dimgray][sup]96[/sup][/c] and near them their
	three winged sisters, the snake-tressed Gorgons, haters of
	humans, whom no mortal can look on and draw another
	breath. This is what I tell you as a warning to beware; now
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]

	S. R. West, [c dimgray]Hermes[/c] 125 (1997) 377–8.
	[c dimgray][sup]94[/sup][/c]Also called the Graeae. Like the Gorgons, they belong to
	the story of Io’s descendant Perseus, who by seizing their shared
	eye and tooth forced them to tell him how to find the nymphs who
	possessed the equipment he needed to cut off Medusa’s head.
	[c dimgray][sup]95[/sup][/c]Presumably meaning “white-haired” (cf. Euripides, [c dimgray]Bacchae[/c]
	1365; Aristophanes,[c dimgray]Wasps[/c] 1064–5): the Graeae were whitehaired
	from birth (Hesiod, [c dimgray]Theogony[/c] 271).
	[c dimgray][sup]96[/sup][/c]The language echoes [c dimgray]Odyssey[/c] 11.16, describing the Cimmerians,
	on whom the sun never looks because their country is
	“shrouded in mist and cloud”.

	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]116[/sup][/c]Greek Ἀδράστεια, lit. “inescapability”. “I bow to Adrasteia”
	was a formula used to apologize for a remark that risked
	offending some divine power; the apology was usually made in
	advance (e.g. Plato, [c dimgray]Republic[/c] 451a; Menander, [c dimgray]Samia[/c] 503), but
	sometimes in arrear (e.g. Menander, [c dimgray]Perikeiromene[/c] 304). The
	chorus are thus telling Prometheus that if he is wise, he will apologize
	at once for his rash remarks about Zeus.
	[c dimgray][sup]117[/sup][/c]Greek σοφιστής (see note on 62).
	[c dimgray][sup]118[/sup][/c]lit. “bitterly over-bitter”, implying that Prometheus’ disobedience
	to Zeus was the product of envy or resentment.

	[c dimgray][sup]131[/sup][/c]The staging of this finale must be consistent with the text,
	must respect the limits of what was possible in the fifth-century
	theatre, and must avoid the anticlimax that would certainly be felt
	if, when the words and the music had ended and the chorus had
	departed, Prometheus was seen bound to the rock as if nothing
	had happened. I suggested in [c dimgray]Aeschylean Tragedy[/c] 313 that Prometheus

	resting on, the central doors of the [c dimgray]skēnē[/c], and these doors are suddenly opened (inwards . . .) \[so that\] the board with Prometheus

	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]7[/sup][/c]ἀστέρας codd.: \]\[ Π: <τηρῶν> A.Y. Campbell.

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Agamemnon[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Watchman[/b][/c]
	I beg the gods to give me release from this misery—from
	my long year of watch-keeping, during which I’ve spent my
	nights on the Atreidae’s roof, resting on my elbows like a
	dog,
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c] and come to know thoroughly the throng of stars of
	the night, and also those bright potentates, conspicuous in
	the sky, which bring winter and summer to mortals,
	[c dimgray][sup]2[/sup][/c] <observing>
	them as some set and others rise. And now I’m
	looking out for the agreed beacon-signal, the gleam of fire
	bringing from Troy the word and news of its capture; for
	such is the ruling of a woman’s hopeful heart, which plans
	like a man. But while I keep this night-walker’s bed, wet
	with dew, this bed of mine not watched over by dreams
	[c dimgray][sup]3[/sup][/c]—for
	it is Fear instead of Sleep that stands beside me, preventing
	me from closing my eyes firmly in sleep—but
	when I decide to sing or hum, applying
	[c dimgray][sup]4[/sup][/c] this remedy to
	charm away sleep, then I weep, grieving over the fortunes
	of this house, which is not now admirably managed as it
	used to be. But now may there be a happy release from
	misery, by the appearance in the darkness of the fire that
	brings good news.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]The comparison is to a dog resting with forelimbs stretched
	forward and head slightly raised; this would be a good, and reasonably
	sustainable, position in which to look out for a fire on a distant
	hill.
	[c dimgray][sup]2[/sup][/c]Such as the Pleiades (cf. 826), Sirius (cf. 967), and Arcturus
	(cf. Sophocles, [c dimgray]Oedipus the King[/c] 1137), whose first visible rising
	or setting before sunrise marked the onset of one or another
	season of the year.
	[c dimgray][sup]3[/sup][/c]“Watched over” and “stands beside” evoke the Homeric
	picture (e.g. [c dimgray]Iliad[/c] 2.20) of the dream-figure standing over the
	sleeper’s head and speaking to him.
	[c dimgray][sup]4[/sup][/c]lit. “incising”, a metaphor from the extraction of herbal remedies
	from plants by making incisions in their roots or stems;
	ἀντίμολπον “to charm away” (lit. “singing against”) alludes to
	another method of healing, the chanting of incantations.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 5[/c]

	[c darkmagenta][b]Agamemnon[/b][/c]<span class="stage italic">He suddenly leaps up in joy.O welcome, beacon, bringing to us by night a message of
	light bright as day, a message that will be the cause of many
	choral dances in Argos in response to this good fortune!
	Ahoy, ahoy! I proclaim plainly to the wife of Agamemnon
	that she should raise herself from her bed, as quickly as
	may be, and on behalf of the house raise a shrill, auspicious
	cry of triumph
	[c dimgray][sup]5[/sup][/c] over this beacon, if indeed the city of Ilium
	has been taken as the fire-signal vividly declares. And I will
	dance a prelude myself \[[c dimgray]skipping about in delight[/c]\]: I shall
	take advantage of
	[c dimgray][sup]6[/sup][/c] the dice that have fallen well for my
	masters—this beacon-watch has thrown me a triple six!
	Well, anyway, may it come to pass that the master of the
	house comes home and that I clasp his well-loved hand in
	this hand of mine. About other matters I say nothing; a
	great ox has stepped upon my tongue. The house itself,
	were it to find voice, might speak very plainly; as far as I
	am concerned, I am deliberately speaking to those who
	know—and for those who do not, I am deliberately forgetting.
	[c dimgray][sup]7[/sup][/c]<span class="stage italic">He descends into the house, and out of sight. A woman’s cry
	of triumph is heard within.
	[c dimgray][sup]8[/sup][/c] A servant comes out of the palace,
	kindles incense on the altar in front of its door, and departs
	towards the city centre.
	[c dimgray][sup]9[/sup][/c] Then enter, from the same
	side, the chorus of Argive elders.

	[c dimgray][sup]5[/sup][/c]Greek ὀλολυγμός, a ululation normally uttered by women
	and particularly associated with climactic moments such as the
	slaughter of a sacrificial beast.
	[c dimgray][sup]6[/sup][/c]lit. “make a move in accordance with”, as if in πεσσοί (a
	game somewhat resembling backgammon).
	[c dimgray][sup]7[/sup][/c]The Watchman is in effect saying (to imaginary listeners):
	“Do you know what I was talking about? If you do, I needn’t tell
	you. If you don’t, I [c dimgray]can’t[/c] tell you, because I’ve deliberately forgotten
	it myself!” The theatre audience, knowing the story well, will understand that he is alluding to the adultery of Clytaemestra and
	Aegisthus.

	[c dimgray][sup]40[/sup][/c]Πριάμω M V: Πριάμου [c dimgray]f.[/c]<li id="note_LCL146_8_48" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]48[/sup][/c]μεγάλ᾿ Page: μέγαν codd.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 8[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Agamemnon[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]

	This is the tenth year since against Priam
	his great prosecutor,
	King Menelaus, together with Agamemnon,
	the Atreidae, a pair firmly yoked
	in the honour of their twin thrones and twin scepters
	given by Zeus,
	launched the thousand-ship expedition of the Argives
	[c dimgray][sup]10[/sup][/c]
	from this land
	as military backers for their suit,
	uttering from their hearts a great cry for war,
	like birds of prey
	[c dimgray][sup]11[/sup][/c] who, crazed
	by grief
	[c dimgray][sup]12[/sup][/c] for their children, wheel around
	high above their eyries,
	rowing with wings for oars,
	having seen the toil of watching
	over their nestlings’ beds go for nothing;
	and some Apollo on high, or Pan,
	or Zeus, hearing the loud shrill wailing cries
	of the birds, exacts belated revenge
	on behalf of these denizens of his realm
	by sending a Fury against the transgressors.
	So the sons of Atreus were sent
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]10[/sup][/c]Throughout this play Aeschylus exploits the ambiguity of
	Ἀργεῖοι, which can mean either “men of Argos” or (as regularly in
	Homer) “Greeks”.
	[c dimgray][sup]11[/sup][/c]αἰγυπιός is usually rendered “vulture”, but in Homer (esp.
	[c dimgray]Iliad[/c] 17.460) they are raptors (like eagles), not scavengers; probably
	the lammergeyer or bearded vulture ([c dimgray]Gypaetus barbatus[/c]) is
	meant, since this bird was (wrongly) believed by the ancients to be
	a raptor. See J. R. T. Pollard, [c dimgray]Birds in Greek Life and Myth[/c] (London,
	1977) 79–80.
	[c dimgray][sup]12[/sup][/c]lit. “in out-of-their-path grief”, i.e. in grief that makes them
	wildly alter their normal flight patterns.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 9[/c]

	[c dimgray][sup]13[/sup][/c]The more common Greek name for the person better
	known to Romans and moderns as Paris (and so called at 399 and

	seducing and eloping with his host’s wife.
	[c dimgray][sup]15[/sup][/c]For this ironic use of προτέλεια, properly sacrifices offered
	before a wedding, cf. 227 below. The “wedding” to which these sacrifices/battles are preliminary is the reunion of Helen and

	sometimes actually called αἰών “life” (e.g. Pindar fr. 111).

	“So very kindly disposed is the Fair One
	to the unfledged seed of fiery lions,
	and so delightsome to the suckling whelps
	of all beasts that roam the wild:
	she demands to bring about a counterpart to this.
	<I interpret> the portent as auspicious but not
	unblemished.
	So I call on the healer Paeon:
	[c dimgray][sup]32[/sup][/c]
	let her not cause any persistent adverse winds that hold
	back the Danaan ships
	from sailing, bent on another sacrificial slaughter, one
	without music or feasting,
	a fashioner of strife, bred in the race, not fearing
	any man; for there awaits, to arise hereafter, a fearsome,
	guileful keeper of the house, a Wrath that remembers
	and will avenge a child.”
	[c dimgray][sup]33[/sup][/c]
	Such were the words that Calchas cried forth, together
	with great blessings,
	words fateful for the royal house, prompted by the birds
	seen by the way;
	and in unison with them
	cry sorrow, sorrow, but may good prevail!
	Zeus—whoever he may be, if it pleases him
	to be so called,
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]32[/sup][/c]Calchas, who as a prophet is a servant of Apollo, begs his
	patron god to intercede with his sister Artemis.
	[c dimgray][sup]33[/sup][/c]In Calchas’ oracular words—unintelligible to his original
	hearers, and mostly also to the Elders now, but easily interpretable
	by the audience—the coming sacrifice of Iphigeneia is half-identified
	with the wrath it will generate, which in turn is half-identified
	with the person (a “guileful keeper of the house . . . that
	. . . will avenge a child”) in whom that wrath will reside.

	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]45[/sup][/c]This seems to imply that at first Calchas had refrained from
	stating that Artemis was responsible for the adverse winds and
	that the fleet could not sail for Troy unless Iphigeneia was sacrificed;
	the sacrifice will then be called “another remedy” in contrast
	to remedies that had already been tried without success
	(such as, say, animal sacrifices to the wind-god Boreas).
	[c dimgray][sup]46[/sup][/c]Agamemnon puts the alternative in the worst possible light.
	In fact it is, and was, neither cowardly nor criminal for a com- mander to abandon or discontinue a military enterprise when its
	aims clearly cannot be fulfilled except at ruinous material or moral
	cost; see Sommerstein [c dimgray]AT[/c] 363–5.
	[c dimgray][sup]47[/sup][/c]The phrase ξυμμαχίας ἁμαρτών could probably also mean
	“failing in my obligations to my allies”; but nothing in this play,
	or even in the [c dimgray]Iliad[/c], suggests that Agamemnon is under any relevant
	obligation to any of his allies except perhaps Menelaus—and Menelaus, we know (cf. 202–4 above), was as distressed by
	Calchas’ declaration as Agamemnon was. The rendering adopted
	here, which is easier grammatically, will refer to the possible loss
	of Agamemnon’s hegemonic position after the blow to his prestige
	that would result from the abandonment of a great undertaking to
	which he had set his hand.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]50[/sup][/c]lit. “on her fair-prowed mouth”, equating Iphigeneia’s body
	to a ship and her head to its bows.
	[c dimgray][sup]51[/sup][/c]A sacrificial victim had to be seen to go to death willingly;
	an act or sound indicating reluctance or resistance would invalidate
	the sacrifice—and here, where the victim was human,
	would make it a blatant act of murder. Agamemnon’s orders for his
	daughter-victim to be forcibly kept silent of course prove completely
	ineffective in preventing a “curse on his house”.
	[c dimgray][sup]52[/sup][/c]Iphigeneia, who had expected to be the central figure of a joyful celebration, is wearing a κροκωτός, “a woman’s most attractive
	and dressy costume” (L. M. Stone, [c dimgray]Costume in Aristophanic
	Comedy[/c] \[New York, 1981\] 175); as she is held aloft, its folds fall
	towards the ground in a splash of yellow.
	[c dimgray][sup]53[/sup][/c]This clause explains how Iphigeneia knew the names of the
	Greek leaders.
	[c dimgray][sup]54[/sup][/c]lit. “unbulled”; possibly a technical cultic
	term for a sacrificial heifer.
	[c dimgray][sup]55[/sup][/c]To Zeus the Saviour; cf. on [c dimgray]Supp[/c]. 26.
	[c dimgray][sup]56[/sup][/c]Or “did not”, in which case “what followed” will be a euphemistic
	reference to the actual slaying of Iphigeneia, and the event
	vindicating Calchas’ prophecy will be the changing of the wind;
	with the rendering adopted here, the chorus elide the slaying altogether
	as their thoughts move forward to the war itself, which
	Calchas had predicted (126–130) would be long but victorious.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 29[/c]

	“goat” and ἀλᾶσθαι “wander”) between Athens and Eleusis; the lake or bay (λίμνη) called Gorgopis (“fierce-eyed” or “Gorgon-eyed”)
	will then be the bay of Eleusis. The mountain has also
	been identified with Mt Geraneia on the Megara-Corinth border,
	or with Aegina; but these identifications account less well for
	αἰγίπλαγκτον, and they make the λίμνη and/or the headland of
	306–7 harder to identify plausibly.

	like) must be the sense.

	above), the “headland” will probably be Cape Spiri (see Quincey
	[c dimgray]op.cit.[/c] 132), the most prominent headland between the Isthmus
	and Epidaurus, which overlooks the ferry-route (πορθμός) between
	Epidaurus and Aegina—the same waters that are called the
	πόντος Σαρωνικός in Euripides, [c dimgray]Hippolytus[/c] 1200.

	[c dimgray][sup]71[/sup][/c]This was trivially true in ordinary torch-races, where every
	member of the winning team had contributed to the victory and
	would share in its glory. Here, however, there has been no competition,
	and some spectators (though not the chorus) may detect a
	sinister secondary meaning. The fire-message was first started
	on its journey by Agamemnon, and the last to receive it was
	Clytaemestra (cf. 316): the message announced Agamemnon’s
	victory over Troy—and for Clytaemestra it was the signal to prepare
	for the victory we know she will gain over Agamemnon.

	[c dimgray][sup]77[/sup][/c]The Elders will take this to mean either the pain felt by the
	spirits of Greek and Trojan dead who have been left unburied, or
	(more likely, cf. 433–451 below) the pain of Greek families who
	have lost kinsmen in the war; the audience will perceive that by
	“the dead” Clytaemestra means primarily Iphigeneia, and that she
	intends to make sure that an “unexpected stroke of evil fate” [c dimgray]does[/c]
	occur.

	the two conditional clauses each of the form “if \[not “even if”\] all goes well”, requires a statement slanted in the direction of
	safety, not of danger.
	[c dimgray][sup]79[/sup][/c]One could pray to the gods for new blessings and/or for
	the continued enjoyment (ὄνησις) of existing blessings, and we
	sometimes find prayers or wishes for the latter that explicitly exclude
	the former (e.g. Euripides, [c dimgray]Alcestis[/c] 334, [c dimgray]Hecuba[/c] 996–7).
	Clytaemestra professes to regard the safe return of the army (and
	Agamemnon) as so great a boon that, if it is granted, she will be
	content with it and will not desire more. In fact, of course, the
	“enjoyment” she will gain from the return of Agamemnon will be
	of a kind undreamed of by the Elders.

	like many a king in reality and fiction, had adorned his palace
	to remind himself of the beauty of his wife even when for the moment
	she was not actually with him; now they have become a
	mockery and a torment, their dead, painted eyes reminding him
	that the living woman is gone. If, as many scholars believe, the reference
	were to any and all statues of beautiful young women, it
	would not be clear why the sight of [c dimgray]statues[/c] in particular should be
	said to distress Menelaus, rather than that of attractive maidservants
	or even of Helen’s daughter Hermione, which one might
	have thought would be even more powerful reminders of his loss.

	Hail, soil of my fathers, land of Argos! On this day, after

	[c dimgray][sup]104[/sup][/c] I have come back to you, achieving one

	[c dimgray]525[/c]Τροίαν κατασκάψαντα τοῦ δικηφόρου
	[c dimgray]526[/c]Διὸς μακέλλῃ, τῇ κατείργασται πέδον

Salzmann.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Agamemnon[/b][/c]
	whom heralds love and revere, and the heroes who sent us
	forth,
	[c dimgray][sup]107[/sup][/c] praying that they may receive back with favour the
	army, or what the war
	[c dimgray][sup]108[/sup][/c] has spared of it. \[[c dimgray]Turning towards
	the palace[/c]\] Hail, palace, beloved home of my kings, and
	august seats,
	[c dimgray][sup]109[/sup][/c] and you deities who face the sun!
	[c dimgray][sup]110[/sup][/c] Let
	these eyes of yours be bright, if they ever have been before,
	as you welcome your king home in glory at long last;
	for he has come, bringing light out of darkness to you and

	people of Argos[/c]

	[c dimgray][sup]111[/sup][/c]\] Give him a noble welcome, for that is
	truly proper, when he has dug up Troy with the mattock of
	Zeus the Avenger, with which the ground has been worked
	Over
	[c dimgray][sup]112[/sup][/c] and the seed of the whole country destroyed.
	[c dimgray][sup]113[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]107[/sup][/c]Cf. Xenophon, [c dimgray]Cyropaedia[/c] 2.1.1: “They crossed the frontier,
	after praying to the gods and heroes who dwelt in the land of
	Persia to send them forth with favour and kindness; and after
	crossing it, they prayed again to the gods who dwelt in the land of
	Media to receive them with favour and kindness.”
	[c dimgray][sup]108[/sup][/c]lit. “the spear”.
	[c dimgray][sup]109[/sup][/c]This would be understood as referring
	to stone seats outside the palace where the kings sat to receive
	petitions, give judgement, etc.; cf. [c dimgray]Odyssey[/c] 3.404–416.
	[c dimgray][sup]110[/sup][/c]From Hesychius α5360 (citing Euripides fr. 538) and
	Tertullian, [c dimgray]On Idolatry[/c] 15.6, it appears that δαίμονες (or θεοὶ)
	ἀντήλιοι were divinities who had shrines in front of the entrance
	to a building; perhaps the term was originally applied to shrines in
	front of temples (whose entrances normally faced the rising sun)
	and later generalized. In front of Agamemnon’s palace, as in front of many real Athenian houses, there is certainly a shrine of Apollo
	Agyieus (cf. 1072–87 below) and probably an image of Hermes
	(see note on [c dimgray]Cho[/c]. 583); we do not know whether there are also
	shrines of one or more other deities.
	[c dimgray][sup]111[/sup][/c]The actor no doubt
	delivered the rest of this speech straight at the audience.
	[c dimgray][sup]112[/sup][/c]Here the mss. add “and the altars and the abodes of the
	gods have disappeared”. That this would be an appalling sacrilege
	to commit, let alone to boast of, is not on its own a reason for rejecting
	the line; nor is its close resemblance to [c dimgray]Pers[/c]. 811. However,
	the line interrupts the metaphor of the “mattock of Zeus” which
	works over the ground (526) and destroys the seed in the soil
	(528); and [c dimgray]pace[/c] Murray and others, we do not need 527 to tell us
	that the army has behaved as badly as was feared in 338–344—we
	knew that already (see note on 338–9). The line was probably
	added by a producer or actor for a revival in the late fifth century.
	[c dimgray][sup]113[/sup][/c]This expression, like the mattock itself, is figurative; the
	Trojan “seed” that has been destroyed is Troy’s human population
	(contrast the βροτείων σπερμάτων σωτηρίαν which is to be assured
	to the Athenians, [c dimgray]Eum[/c]. 909).
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 61[/c]

	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]126[/sup][/c]χαλκός, strictly “bronze”, can denote any metal used in
	tools and weapons, as in Pindar, [c dimgray]Pythian[/c] 3.48, where it is called
	πολιός—the colour of iron (similarly a χαλκεύς would normally
	be both an iron- and a bronze-worker). Iron was tempered (hardened)
	by being dipped (βαφή) in cold water (cf. [c dimgray]Odyssey[/c] 9.391–3;
	Sophocles, [c dimgray]Ajax[/c] 650–1); bronze was not. The audience may reflect
	(cf. previous note) that Clytaemestra’s statement is strictly true: if
	she knows at least as much about “dipping metal” as she does
	about “pleasure from another man”, it means she knows quite a lot
	about both—and indeed she soon [c dimgray]will[/c] be “dipping metal” . . . in
	her husband’s blood (cf. [c dimgray]Cho.[/c] 1011).
	[c dimgray][sup]127[/sup][/c]It might be thought unseemly for a woman to make mention
	of sexual matters in public, even in order to proclaim her
	purity; but Clytaemestra claims that she can do so without disgrace
	because (i) she is of noble birth (and so cannot be accused of
	behaving with casual, ignorant recklessness) and (ii) her assertion
	is true. Later (1431–47) she will go a great deal further down this
	road.
	[c dimgray][sup]128[/sup][/c]Evidently an attempt to hint that Clytaemestra’s words
	should be viewed with some suspicion. The Elders know that her
	statement that the city “passionately desires” Agamemnon (605) is
	not true (cf. 445–460); whether they know or suspect anything
	beyond this is not clear.
	[c dimgray][sup]129[/sup][/c]i.e. “I [c dimgray]could[/c] tell you some comforting lies, but you’d find
	out the truth soon anyway.”
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 73[/c]

	εὔφημον ἦμαρ οὐ πρέπει κακαγγέλῳ
	γλώσσῃ μιαίνειν· χωρὶς ἡ τιμὴ θεῶν.
	ὅταν δ᾿ ἀπευκτὰ πήματ᾿ ἄγγελος πόλει
	σμοιῷ προσώπῳ πτωσίμου στρατοῦ φέρῃ,
	[c dimgray]640[/c]πόλει μὲν ἕλκος ἓν τὸ δήμιον τυχεῖν,
	πολλοὺς δὲ πολλῶν ἐξαγισθέντας δόμων
	ἄνδρας διπλῇ μάστιγι, τὴν Ἄρης φιλεῖ,
	δίλογχον ἄτην, φοινίαν ξυνωρίδα—τοιῶνδε
	μέντοι πημάτων σεσαγμένον
	[c dimgray]645[/c]πρέπει λέγειν παιῶνα τόνδ᾿ Ἐρινύων·
	σωτηρίων δὲ πραγμάτων εὐάγγελον
	ἥκοντα πρὸς χαίρουσαν εὐεστοῖ πόλιν,
	πῶς κεδνὰ τοῖς κακοῖσι συμμείξω, λέγων
	χειμῶν᾿ Ἀχαιοῖς οὐκ ἀμήνιτον θεῶν;
	[c dimgray]650[/c]ξυνώμοσαν γάρ, ὄντες ἔχθιστοι τὸ πρίν,
	πῦρ καὶ θάλασσα, καὶ τὰ πίστ᾿ ἐδειξάτην
	φθείροντε τὸν δύστηνον Ἀργείων στρατόν.
	ἐν νυκτὶ δυσκύμαντα δ᾿ ὠρώρει κακά·
	[c dimgray]654[/c]ναῦς γὰρ πρὸς ἀλλήλαισι Θρῄκιαι πνοαὶ
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]639[/sup][/c]σμοιῷ M. Schmidt, cf. Hesychius σ1270: στυγνῷ [c dimgray]f.[/c]<li id="note_LCL146_76_644" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]644[/sup][/c]σεσαγμένον Schütz: σεσαγμένων [c dimgray]f[/c].<li id="note_LCL146_76_649" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]649[/sup][/c]Ἀχαιοῖς . . . θεῶν Blomfield: Ἀχαιῶν . . . θεοῖς [c dimgray]f[/c].
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 76[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Agamemnon[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Herald[/b][/c]
	It is not proper to defile a day of good omen by the uttering
	of bad news: the honour due to the gods stands apart from
	that.
	[c dimgray][sup]132[/sup][/c] When a grim-faced messenger brings a city the
	painful news of an army lost, news it had prayed not to receive—that the city has suffered one wound collectively,
	while many men have been taken from many houses as
	sacrificial victims,
	[c dimgray][sup]133[/sup][/c] by the double whip that Ares loves,
	in a two-pronged ruin, in gory double harness
	[c dimgray][sup]134[/sup][/c]—well,
	when someone is loaded down with [c dimgray]that[/c] kind of misery, it
	is fitting to sing this paean to the Furies.
	[c dimgray][sup]135[/sup][/c] But when one is
	coming with good tidings of success to a city rejoicing in
	prosperity—how can I mix together good and evil, by telling
	of the storm that showed no lack of divine anger against
	the Achaeans? Two powers who had formerly been fierce
	enemies, Fire and Sea, made conspiracy together,
	[c dimgray][sup]136[/sup][/c] and
	gave proof of their covenant by destroying the ill-fated
	Argive host. In the night there arose a terrible wave of
	troubles: winds from Thrace,
	[c dimgray][sup]137[/sup][/c] together with lightning,
	[c dimgray][sup]138[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]132[/sup][/c]i.e. by speaking of such things we would dishonour the
	gods who have given us victory (so Triclinius).
	[c dimgray][sup]133[/sup][/c]The “sacrifice” is here metaphorical, the reference being
	to the men in the annihilated army.
	[c dimgray][sup]134[/sup][/c]lit. “a gory pair of chariot-horses”; the duality emphasized in this and the two preceding phrases appears to refer to the public
	and private griefs contrasted in 640–1.
	[c dimgray][sup]135[/sup][/c]This is a “blasphemous paradox” (Fraenkel), since a paean
	is normally a song of joy.
	[c dimgray][sup]136[/sup][/c]Aeschylus suppresses the traditional
	cause of the storm, the wrath of Athena whose temple had
	been violated by the seizure of Cassandra (cf. [c dimgray]Odyssey[/c] 3.135, [c dimgray]Sack
	of Troy[/c] Arg. 3 West, [c dimgray]Returns[/c] Arg. 1 and 3 West); Athena is never
	mentioned in the first two plays of the [c dimgray]Oresteia[/c]. The idea of a conspiracy
	between old enemies to wreck the Achaean fleet is taken
	up in the prologue of Euripides’ [c dimgray]Trojan Women[/c], where the conspirators
	are Athena (with her father’s thunderbolt) and Poseidon.
	[c dimgray][sup]137[/sup][/c]Cf. on 192.
	[c dimgray][sup]138[/sup][/c]Strictly speaking a πρηστήρ was a waterspout accompanied
	by lightning (Aristotle, [c dimgray]Meteorologica[/c] 371a15–17).
	[m1]\ [/m]

	branches before reaching the sea, and the Simois (Dümrek) joins
	the more easterly branch; but in classical times it was believed
	(Herodotus 2. 10; cf. Strabo 13.1.36), notwithstanding [c dimgray]Iliad[/c] 5.774, that at the time of the Trojan War much of the lower plain had
	been under water, so that the Simois would have reached the sea
	separately. See J. M. Cook in L. Foxhall and J. K. Davies ed. [c dimgray]The
	Trojan War[/c] (Liverpool, 1984) 163–7.
	[c dimgray][sup]150[/sup][/c]Because Strife (Eris) by her nature delights in conflict, but
	also with reference to her provocation of the quarrel between
	Athena, Hera and Aphrodite that led to the Judgement of Paris
	and hence to his abduction of Helen (cf. [c dimgray]Cypria[/c] Arg. 1 West).
	[c dimgray][sup]151[/sup][/c]In the Greek the play is on two senses of κῆδος, “marriage-bond”
	(between two families) and “mourning”.

	anomaly.

	Elders are warning Agamemnon against disaffected citizens of
	Argos who may pretend to welcome him warmly but are really his enemies (cf. 830ff); they have previously indicated (445–460) that
	there is widespread public hostility against the Atreidae. It is unlikely
	that they have any suspicion of Clytaemestra; otherwise,
	while they might still not have believed Cassandra’s prophecies
	about her, they would surely at least have understood them.

	with the two sides putting their cases not by making speeches
	but by fighting and dying.
	[c dimgray][sup]170[/sup][/c]The immediate reference is to the dangerously long leap
	from the belly of the gigantic Wooden Horse (cf. [c dimgray]Sack of Troy[/c] fr. 1 West) to the ground below, apparently called “the Trojan leap” in
	Euripides, [c dimgray]Andromache[/c] 1139; see E. K. Borthwick, [c dimgray]JHS[/c] 87 (1967)
	18–23. In the next line, however, the leap metamorphoses into the
	spring of a lion over Troy’s walls and on to its prey.
	[c dimgray][sup]171[/sup][/c]In early November, when the Pleiades could first be seen
	setting before sunrise (the phrase cannot denote a particular time
	of the night, because neither the Pleiades nor any other group of
	stars set at a fixed time of the night). This casual reference to the
	time of year—which moreover contradicts the usual tradition that
	Troy fell in the month of Thargelion (May/June), a tradition already
	found in fifth-century sources (Damastes fr. 7 Fowler,
	Hellanicus fr. 152 Fowler)—is best accounted for by noting that
	the setting of the Pleiades heralded the stormy season when sailing
	was dangerous (Hesiod, [c dimgray]Works and Days[/c] 619–629; cf. on 5–7
	above), so that by setting sail for home immediately after sacking
	the city Agamemnon was asking for trouble—which he duly got.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 95[/c]

	prelude I have addressed to the gods. \[[c dimgray]To the chorus[/c]\] As
	for your thoughts, I remember well what you told me, I say
	the same, and you have my full concurrence. Few men
	have it in their nature to honour a friend who is enjoying
	good fortune, without being jealous of him. When a man
	has an affliction, the poison of ill-will sits close to his heart
	and doubles his burden: he is weighed down by his own
	sufferings, and he also grieves to see the success of another.
	I can say with knowledge—for I am very well acquainted
	with the mirror of social relations
	[c dimgray][sup]172[/sup][/c]—that <the
	loyalty of friends is> a mere shadowy phantom. <I know
	that many of the leaders of my army were really my jealous
	enemies,> though to all appearance they were very
	friendly to me.
	[c dimgray][sup]173[/sup][/c] Only Odysseus, the one who sailed
	against his will,
	[c dimgray][sup]174[/sup][/c] proved himself, once yoked, my willing
	right-hand man
	[c dimgray][sup]175[/sup][/c]—whether it is a dead or a living man
	that I am speaking of. As regards other matters concerning
	the community and the gods, we will hold public assemblies
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]172[/sup][/c]Social intercourse is called a “mirror” because a person’s
	social behaviour reveals his true inner nature and feelings as faithfully
	and unflatteringly as a mirror reveals his true outward appearance.
	[c dimgray][sup]173[/sup][/c]On the need to posit a lacuna here, see H. D. F. Kitto, [c dimgray]Form
	and Meaning in Drama[/c] (London, 1956) 23 n.2. Agamemnon is evidently
	thinking primarily of Achilles and Ajax, but his statement that [c dimgray]only[/c] Odysseus was truly loyal is likely to have been perceived
	by the audience as grossly unjust to most of his other colleagues.
	[c dimgray][sup]174[/sup][/c]Odysseus feigned madness in order to avoid joining the
	expedition, but Palamedes contrived a stratagem that proved he
	was actually sane ([c dimgray]Cypria[/c] Arg. 5 West).
	[c dimgray][sup]175[/sup][/c]lit. “trace-horse”. In classical times, a chariot team consisted
	either of two horses (yoked to the chariot) or of four; in
	the latter case, the outer horses were controlled by traces, and
	their power and speed (especially that of the horse on the driver’s
	right) were vital to the team when rounding bends (cf. Sophocles,
	[c dimgray]Electra[/c] 721–2). In Homer, trace-horses are mentioned only occasionally
	([c dimgray]Iliad[/c] 8.81–88, 16.152) and there is never more than one
	in a team.

	[c dimgray][sup]178[/sup][/c]—and could boast that he had donned a

	Don’t be surprised by this. He is being brought up by a

	the Phocian,
	[c dimgray][sup]180[/sup][/c] who plainly pointed out to me two potential
	disasters—the danger you were in at Troy, and the possibility
	that the clamorous populace, in the absence of a
	ruler, might hatch a wicked plot
	[c dimgray][sup]181[/sup][/c]—and said it was part of

	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]178[/sup][/c]Geryon was a triple-bodied monster. Heracles’ tenth labour
	was to steal his cattle, and (as much early artistic evidence
	shows) he had to slay each one of Geryon’s bodies separately; see
	T. R. Gantz, [c dimgray]Early Greek Myth[/c] (Baltimore, 1993) 402–3.
	[c dimgray][sup]179[/sup][/c]The rescuers are imagined as finding Clytaemestra just in
	time to save her; some of them hold her up, despite her resistance
	(implied by πρὸς βίαν), while others cut the rope and then undo
	the noose.
	[c dimgray][sup]180[/sup][/c]Strophius was a brother-in-law of Agamemnon’s (Euripides,
	[c dimgray]Iphigeneia in Tauris[/c] 917–8; Pausanias 2.29.4); his son Pylades
	appears in the next play.
	[c dimgray][sup]181[/sup][/c]The twin dangers were (i) that Agamemnon might be killed
	and (ii) that his mere absence might make possible a popular revolution
	and the overthrow of the dynasty; in either case the child
	Orestes would be in mortal peril.

	Well, in my eyes the gushing fountains of tears have dried
	up, and there is not a drop left; and I have damaged those
	eyes by lying late awake, weeping for the beacon-sites set
	up to signal your return
	[c dimgray][sup]182[/sup][/c] which always remained idle.
	And amid my dreams I kept being awakened by the light
	buzz of a trumpeting mosquito,
	[c dimgray][sup]183[/sup][/c] having seen more sufferings
	afflict you than could fit into the time they shared
	my bed. Now, after enduring all this, with a heart no longer
	grieving, I shall speak of this man as the watchdog of his
	homestead, the forestay
	[c dimgray][sup]184[/sup][/c] that saves the ship, the firmly-footed
	pillar that supports a lofty roof, a father’s only
	son;
	[c dimgray][sup]185[/sup][/c] as land appearing to sailors in despair, as the daylight
	that is such a fair thing to behold after a storm, as a
	flowing spring to a thirsty traveller. Such, I say, are the appellations
	I hold him worthy of—but let us not court jealousy,

	[c dimgray][sup]186[/sup][/c] for we have endured many sufferings already. Now
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]182[/sup][/c]lit. “the torch-holding places concerning you”.
	[c dimgray][sup]183[/sup][/c]This seemingly oxymoronic expression was well explained
	by W. S. Barrett (ap. Fraenkel iii 630): the buzz is [c dimgray]objectively[/c]
	“light” and has, in Barrett’s words, “no business to wake a healthy
	sleeper”, but once it has awakened the restless Clytaemestra she
	finds it much too loud for her to have any chance of getting back to
	sleep.
	[c dimgray][sup]184[/sup][/c]One of two ropes, secured to the prow of a ship, by which
	the mast was raised and lowered; if they broke in a storm (as in
	[c dimgray]Odyssey[/c] 12.409–410) the mast would collapse, often with catastrophic
	results. See J. S. Morrison and R. T. Williams, [c dimgray]Greek
	Oared Ships 900–322[/c]
	bc (Cambridge, 1968) 55.
	[c dimgray][sup]185[/sup][/c]Agamemnon is not, of course, an only son; this phrase, like
	the previous three, metaphorically describes him as one on whom
	depends the whole safety of the house and/or the city. The following
	three expressions (899–901) make a slightly different point,
	describing him as one who [c dimgray]brings[/c] safety after peril.
	[c dimgray][sup]186[/sup][/c]lit. “let (sc. divine) jealousy be absent”: if such jealousy
	were to be aroused by presumptuous speech, the gods might be
	provoked into inflicting yet further sufferings. Having said this,
	Clytaemestra immediately sets out to tempt Agamemnon into acting
	in the way most likely to arouse divine jealousy!

	Λήδας γένεθλον, δωμάτων ἐμῶν φύλαξ,
	[c dimgray]915[/c]ἀπουσίᾳ μὲν εἶπας εἰκότως ἐμῇ·
	μακρὰν γὰρ ἐξέτεινας· ἀλλ᾿ ἐναισίμως
	αἰνεῖν, παρ᾿ ἄλλων χρὴ τόδ᾿ ἔρχεσθαι γέρας.
	καὶ τἄλλα μὴ γυναικὸς ἐν τρόποις ἐμὲ
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]907[/sup][/c]ὦναξ [c dimgray]z[/c]: ἄναξ [c dimgray]f.[/c]<li id="note_LCL146_104_909" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]909[/sup][/c]στορνύναι Elmsley: στρωννύναι [c dimgray]f.[/c]<li id="note_LCL146_104_913" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]913[/sup][/c]θεοῖς εἱμαρμένα [c dimgray]f[/c]: θεοῖσιν ἄρμενα Karsten.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Agamemnon[/b][/c]
	then, please, dear heart,
	[c dimgray][sup]187[/sup][/c] step out of this carriage—but
	do not set your foot on the earth, my lord, the foot that
	sacked Troy! Servants, why are you waiting, when you have
	been assigned the duty of spreading fine fabrics
	[c dimgray][sup]188[/sup][/c] over the
	ground in his path? Let his way forthwith be spread with
	crimson, so that Justice may lead him into a home he never
	hoped to see.
	[c dimgray][sup]189[/sup][/c] \[[c dimgray]The attendants spread out the fabrics to
	form a path from the carriage to the palace door[/c].\] Careful
	thought, not overcome by sleep, will set everything else
	<in order>
	[c dimgray][sup]190[/sup][/c] in accordance with justice, with the gods’
	help.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]agamemnon[/b][/c]
	Daughter of Leda, guardian of my house, you have made a
	speech that was like my absence—you stretched it out to a
	great length; but to be fittingly praised is an honour that
	ought to come to me from others.
	[c dimgray][sup]191[/sup][/c] For the rest, do not
	pamper me as if I were a woman; do not fall to the ground
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]187[/sup][/c]lit. “dear head”.
	[c dimgray][sup]188[/sup][/c]The fabric is later spoken of as “clothing” (921, 963); it is
	evidently fine in texture and richly embroidered (923, 926, 936),
	and might have served either as a garment of exceptional luxury
	or as a wall-hanging (the literal meaning of πετάσματα, here
	rendered “fine fabrics”). It should on no account be spoken or
	thought of as a “carpet”: carpets are made to be trodden on,
	whereas this fabric will be ruined, its beauty and value destroyed,
	even by the single, brief passage over it of Agamemnon’s unshod
	feet (948–9, cf. 958–963).
	[c dimgray][sup]189[/sup][/c]Or “that never hoped to see him”. For Agamemnon “Justice”
	will allude to his war of revenge on Paris and Troy; but
	Clytaemestra is thinking of the revenge [c dimgray]she[/c] is about to take.
	[c dimgray][sup]190[/sup][/c]I translate Karsten’s conjecture, which introduces a word
	not otherwise found in tragedy but at least gives more or less the
	sense required; the transmitted reading, “fated”, goes very badly
	with the emphasis placed in 912 on careful, wakeful thought.
	[c dimgray][sup]191[/sup][/c]The point is (i) that a man should not be publicly praised by
	a member of his own family (cf. Pindar fr. 181), since their praise
	might be thought to stem merely from affection or deference, and
	perhaps also (ii) that it is unseemly for a woman to make public
	speeches.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[c darkmagenta][b]ΑΓΑΜΕΜΝΩΝ[/b][/c]

	γνώμην μὲν ἴσθι μὴ διαφθεροῦντ᾿ ἐμέ.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΚΛΥΤΑΙΜΗΣΤΡΑ[/b][/c]

	ηὔξω θεοῖς δείσας ἂν ὧδ᾿ ἔρξειν τάδε;

	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]933[/sup][/c]ἔρξειν Headlam: ἔρδειν [c dimgray]f.[/c]

	before me
	[c dimgray][sup]192[/sup][/c] and utter open-mouthed cries in the manner
	of a barbarian; and do not strew my path with clothing and
	thereby make it invidious. It is gods, you know, who should
	be honoured with such objects; to my mind, for a mortal to
	tread on beautiful embroideries cannot be anything but
	perilous.
	[c dimgray][sup]193[/sup][/c] I tell you to revere me like a man, not a god. It
	is cryingly obvious that the words “embroidered” and
	“doormat” don’t go well together;
	[c dimgray][sup]194[/sup][/c] and good sense is the
	greatest of god’s gifts. A man should be called fortunate
	only when he has finished his life in the prosperity that all
	desire. If I am one who will act consistently on these principles,
	I have nothing to fear.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]clytaemestra[/b][/c]
	Now tell me this, without disguising your opinion—
	[m1]\ [/m]

	Be assured that I shall not be false to my opinion.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]clytaemestra[/b][/c]
	Might you have vowed to the gods, in a moment of danger,
	that you would do this thing?

	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]192[/sup][/c]Cf. [c dimgray]Pers.[/c] 150–4, 694–702. There is no need to suppose that
	Clytaemestra has actually done this, any more than she has uttered
	“open-mouthed cries”; Agamemnon is giving examples of
	the kinds of adulation he does not want, as a preliminary to objecting
	to the particular kind of adulation that Clytaemestra has offered
	him.
	[c dimgray][sup]193[/sup][/c]lit. “is in no way without fear”.

	cries out divergently”.
	[c dimgray][sup]195[/sup][/c]In a critical situation it was common to vow that, in return
	for immediate divine assistance, one would later give up a precious
	possession by sacrifice, dedication or otherwise (cf. 963–5).
	Clytaemestra is not suggesting that Agamemnon has actually
	made any such vow; she is trying to persuade him that there are
	[c dimgray]some[/c] circumstances in which it would not be improper to act as
	she is asking him to do.

	[c darkmagenta][b]agamemnon[/b][/c]
	Well, if that’s what you want, let someone quickly take off
	my shoes, which serve like slaves for my feet to tread on;
	and as I walk on these purple-dyed <robes>,
	[c dimgray][sup]200[/sup][/c] may no jealous
	eye strike me from afar! For I feel a great sense of
	impropriety about despoiling this house under my feet,
	ruining its wealth and the woven work bought with its
	silver. Well, so much for that. \[[c dimgray]His shoes having now been
	removed, he descends from the carriage, but does not yet
	step on the fabrics. He gestures towards cassandra[/c].\] This
	foreign woman—please welcome her kindly. He who exercises
	power gently is regarded graciously by god from afar.
	No one wears the yoke of slavery willingly; and this woman
	has come with me as a gift from the army, the choice flower
	of its rich booty. Now, since I have been subjugated into
	obeying you in this, I will go, treading on purple, to the
	halls of my house.

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]199[/sup][/c]Cf. Sophocles, [c dimgray]Ajax[/c] 1353 (also addressed to Agamemnon):
	“You are still the master, you know, if you let your friends vanquish
	you.”
	[c dimgray][sup]200[/sup][/c]I translate Wecklein’s tentative conjecture. The transmitted
	reading, “these purple-dyed objects of the gods”, is open to the objections (i) that there is no other indication that the fabrics
	are the sacred property of the gods (indeed, 948–9 and 958–962
	imply that they belong to the family), (ii) that if the act of treading
	on the fabrics were to be seen as sacrilegious as well as arrogant,
	one would have expected Agamemnon to mention this somewhere
	in 918–930, and (iii) that the adjective ἁλουργής is not
	used as a noun in the classical period to denote a purple-dyed object
	but only to denote the colour purple (the word for a purple
	garment is ἁλουργίς, and Aeschylus could here, if he wished,
	have written ταῖσδ᾿ . . . ἁλουργίσιν).

	what poverty is.
	[c dimgray][sup]203[/sup][/c] To contrive a means of bringing this
	man back alive, I would have vowed to trample [c dimgray]many[/c] garments,
	if that had been prescribed to our family in an
	oracle. For while the root remains, foliage comes to a
	house,
	[c dimgray][sup]204[/sup][/c] spreading shade over it against the dog-star
	Sirius;
	[c dimgray][sup]205[/sup][/c] and likewise, now you have come to the hearth of
	our home, your coming signifies warmth in winter, while
	when Zeus is making wine out of the sour young grapes,
	[c dimgray][sup]206[/sup][/c]
	even then it is cool in the house, when the man who is its
	lord is present in his home. \[[c dimgray]
	agamemnon[/c] disappears into
	the palace. clytaemestra raises her hands to heaven.\]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]201[/sup][/c]The dye is made from the secretions of one or more of
	several Mediterranean molluscs, notably [c dimgray]Haustellum[/c] (formerly
	[c dimgray]Murex) brandaris[/c] and [c dimgray]Hexaplex[/c] (formerly [c dimgray]Murex) trunculus.[/c]
	[c dimgray][sup]202[/sup][/c]Cf. Theopompus, [c dimgray]FGrH[/c] 115 F 117.
	[c dimgray][sup]203[/sup][/c]Clytaemestra is responding to Agamemnon’s concern
	about “despoiling this house” (948–9): the sea will never run short of purple, and despite its high price the family (god willing) will
	never run short of resources with which to buy it.
	[c dimgray][sup]204[/sup][/c]Agamemnon—long absent, sometimes despaired of, but
	alive—is compared to a great tree that may be drastically pruned,
	struck by lightning, etc., but which, so long as it has not actually
	been killed, can grow back to its old glory. A similar image appears
	in the account of Clytaemestra’s dream in Sophocles, [c dimgray]Electra[/c] 417–
	423.
	[c dimgray][sup]205[/sup][/c]The dog-days of late July and August, when Sirius begins to
	rise before the sun, are the hottest time of the year.
	[c dimgray][sup]206[/sup][/c]i.e. in summer; the time of vintage is at the morning rising
	of Arcturus (Hesiod, [c dimgray]Works and Days[/c] 609–611) in mid-September.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 113[/c]

	as above; the same point is made in the Hippocratic [c dimgray]Aphorisms[/c]
	(1.3), “In athletes a high state of physical fitness is dangerous
	if taken to an extreme”. Modern medicine agrees: “Excessive
	exercise, such as is undertaken by \[athletes\] preparing for the

	reduces this capability . . . \[because\] the heavy training

	from a sling of generous dimensions,

	the whole house does not founder
	when crammed too full in surfeit,
	nor does he wreck the ship:
	the gifts of Zeus are surely great, coming abundantly
	from furrows teeming year after year
	to destroy the plague of hunger.
	But once the black blood of death
	has fallen on the earth in front of a man,
	who by any incantation can summon it back again?

	by the gods, prevents another destiny
	from getting more than its due,
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]216[/sup][/c]The ship is envisaged as having run on to the reef because
	it is too heavily laden, and as being refloated by jettisoning part of
	its cargo. It represents in metaphor a house that has become excesively
	rich (cf. 376ff) and is saved from disaster by giving up
	part of its possessions: the family may for a while be in straitened
	circumstances, but a few good harvests (1014–6) can set things right. The “sling” is probably nothing more sophisticated than
	a large piece of sailcloth or the like, in which two men could
	carry heavy items of cargo, and from which they could throw them
	overboard with enough horizontal momentum to avoid fouling or
	damaging the side of the ship.
	[c dimgray][sup]217[/sup][/c]Asclepius (here envisaged as a hero, not a god—as always
	in Athens before the 420s); when he raised, or attempted to raise,
	one or more men from the dead (scarcely any two sources agree
	on the beneficiary’s identity), Zeus destroyed him with a thunderbolt.
	See E. J. and L. Edelstein, [c dimgray]Asclepius[/c] (Baltimore, 1945) i 37–
	48, ii 39–53.
	[c dimgray][sup]218[/sup][/c]I translate West’s emendation, which, though not entirely
	convincing, gives better sense than other proposed corrections of
	the unmetrical reading of the manuscripts.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	ἐπαργέμοισι θεσφάτοις δυσμηχανῶ.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΚΑΣΣΑΝΔΡΑ[/b][/c]


	[c dimgray]στρ. ε[/c] ἒ ἒ παπαῖ παπαῖ, τί τόδε φαίνεται;
	[c dimgray]1115[/c]ἦ δίκτυόν τί γ᾿ Ἅιδου;
	ἀλλ᾿ ἄρκυς ἡ ξύνευνος, ἡ ξυναιτία
	φόνου. στάσις δ᾿ ἀκόρετος γένει
	κατολολυξάτω θύματος λευσίμου.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΧΟΡΟΣ[/b][/c]

	ποίαν Ἐρινὺν τήνδε δώμασιν κέλῃ
	[c dimgray]1120[/c]ἐπορθιάζειν; οὔ με φαιδρύνει λόγος·
	ἐπὶ δὲ καρδίαν ἔδραμε κροκοβαφὴς
	σταγών, ἅτε καὶ δορὶ πτωσίμοις
	ξυνανύτει βίου
	δύντος αὐγαῖς. ταχεῖα δ᾿ ἄτα πέλει.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1111[/sup][/c]ὀρέγματα Hermann, cf. Σ[c dimgray][sup]Μ[/sup][/c]: ὀρεγμένα [c dimgray]f[/c]: ὀρεγόμενα Μ
	(-ομένα M[c dimgray][sup]pc[/sup][/c]).<li id="note_LCL146_132_1117" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]1117[/sup][/c]ἀκόρετος Hermann: ἀκόρεστος codd.<li id="note_LCL146_132_1122" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]1122[/sup][/c]δορὶ πτωσίμοις Casaubon: δορία πτώσιμος M: δωρία
	πτώσιμος [c dimgray]f[/c].
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 132[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Agamemnon[/b][/c]
	It will come soon. Hand after hand
	extends itself at full stretch.
	[c dimgray][sup]238[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	I still don’t understand; the riddling words in these obscure
	oracles leave me quite at a loss.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]cassandra[/b][/c]

	Ah, ah! Papai, papai! What is this I see?
	Is it, is it, a net of death?
	The net is she who shares the bed, who shares the guilt
	of the murder! Let the insatiable spirit of strife raise a
	cry of triumph
	[c dimgray][sup]239[/sup][/c]
	over the family for this sacrifice that merits stoning!
	[c dimgray][sup]240[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	What do you mean by bidding this Fury raise a loud cry
	over the house? Your words do not cheer me—<span class="stage">\[[c dimgray]singing[/c]\]
	and to my heart there flow saffron-coloured
	drops, the same which, when men fall in battle,
	arrive there with the last setting rays
	of their life.
	[c dimgray][sup]241[/sup][/c] Disaster comes swiftly.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]238[/sup][/c]The audience probably will not be able to interpret this sinister
	sentence very precisely, but Aeschylus may be imagining that
	Cassandra’s vision at this moment is of Clytaemestra reaching
	down to pick up the robe which she is about to throw over Agamemnon.
	[c dimgray][sup]239[/sup][/c]For the association between the women’s
	cry of triumph (ὀλολυγμός) and sacrifices, see on 28. Here the “sacrifice” is metaphorical, and blasphemous.
	[c dimgray][sup]240[/sup][/c]Cf. 1615–
	6 where the chorus predict that Aegisthus will be stoned by the
	enraged people for his part in Agamemnon’s murder.
	[c dimgray][sup]241[/sup][/c]i.e. “I am as pale with terror as a mortally wounded warrior.”
	Cf. [c dimgray]Cho[/c]. 183–4 where Electra, “stricken as if transfixed by a
	weapon”, says there is “a surge of bile close to \[her\] heart”. There
	were thought to be two kinds of bile, yellow and black; the bile set
	in motion by fear was the yellow variety. The Hippocratic treatise
	[c dimgray]On Diseases[/c] (2.5) says that “fainting occurs when phlegm or bile
	comes close to the heart”.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 133[/c]

	τύπτει· πίτνει δ᾿ ἐν ἐνύδρῳ τεύχει.
	δολοφόνου λέβητος τέχναν σοι λέγω.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[c dimgray]1130[/c]οὐ κομπάσαιμ᾿ ἂν θεσφάτων γνώμων ἄκρος
	εἶναι, κακῷ δέ τῳ προσεικάζω τάδε.
	ἀπὸ δὲ θεσφάτων τίς ἀγαθὰ φάτις
	βροτοῖς τέλλεται; κακῶν γὰρ διαὶ
	πολυεπεῖς τέχναι
	[c dimgray]1135[/c]θεσπιῳδῶν φόβον φέρουσιν μαθεῖν.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[c dimgray]στρ. ζ[/c] ἰὼ ἰὼ ταλαίνας κακόποτμοι τύχαι·
	τὸ γὰρ ἐμὸν θροῶ πάθος ἐπεγχύδαν.
	ποῖ δή με δεῦρο τὴν τάλαιναν ἤγαγες;
	οὐδέν ποτ᾿ εἰ μὴ ξυνθανουμένην· τί γάρ;
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1127[/sup][/c]μελαγκέρῳ Μ[c dimgray][sup]pc[/sup][/c]
	[c dimgray][sup]γρ[/sup][/c]>Σ[c dimgray][sup]Μ[/sup][/c]: μελαγκέρων M[c dimgray][sup]ac[/sup][/c] Σ[c dimgray][sup]Μ[/sup][/c]
	[c dimgray]f[/c].<li id="note_LCL146_134_1128" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]1128[/sup][/c]ἐν Schütz: om. codd.<li id="note_LCL146_134_1129" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]1129[/sup][/c]τέχναν Weil: τύχαν codd.<li id="note_LCL146_134_1133" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]1133[/sup][/c]τέλλεται Emperius: στέλλεται codd.<li id="note_LCL146_134_1135" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]1135[/sup][/c]θεσπιῳδῶν Portus: θεσπιῳδὸν codd.<li id="note_LCL146_134_1137" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]1137[/sup][/c]ἐπεγχύδαν Headlam: ἐπεγχέασα M [c dimgray][sup]i[/sup][/c]Σ[c dimgray][sup]Μ[/sup][/c]: ἐπαγχέασα [c dimgray]f[/c].
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 134[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Agamemnon[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]cassandra[/b][/c]

	Oh, oh! See, see! Keep the bull
	away from the cow! She traps him
	in the robe, the black-horned
	[c dimgray][sup]242[/sup][/c] contrivance,
	and strikes—and he falls into the tub full of water.
	I am telling you of the device that worked treacherous
	murder in a bath.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	I would not claim to be a first-class interpreter of prophecies,
	but this seems to me like something bad.<span class="stage">\[[c dimgray]singing[/c]\]
	But what good word comes to mortals
	from prophecies? The wordy arts
	of oracle-chanters tell
	of evil, and bring tidings fearful to learn.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]cassandra[/b][/c]

	Ió ió, my evil fate, my wretched fortune!
	I cry out my own sufferings, pouring them on top of
	these.
	Why have you
	[c dimgray][sup]243[/sup][/c] brought me here in my misery?
	For no reason on earth, if not to die with him—what
	else?
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]242[/sup][/c]The robe is neither black (cf. [c dimgray]Cho[/c]. 1013, [c dimgray]Eum[/c]. 635) nor
	horned; but it is the first implement of attack wielded by the “cow”
	against the “bull”, and on being thrown over Agamemnon it envelops
	him in darkness (whence he will shortly be dispatched to the
	darkness of Hades).
	[c dimgray][sup]243[/sup][/c]Probably Apollo (who knows what Cassandra’s fate will be)
	rather than Agamemnon (who does not).
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 135[/c]

	ἀκόρετος βοᾶς, φεῦ, φιλοίκτοις φρεσὶν
	Ἴτυν Ἴτυν στένουσ᾿ ἀμφιθαλῆ κακοῖς
	[c dimgray]1145[/c]ἀηδὼν μόρον.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[c dimgray]ἀντ. ζ[/c] ἰὼ ἰὼ λιγείας βίος ἀηδόνος·
	περέβαλον γάρ οἱ πτεροφόρον δέμας
	θεοὶ γλυκύν τ᾿ αἰῶνα κλαυμάτων ἄτερ·
	ἐμοὶ δὲ μίμνει σχισμὸς ἀμφήκει δορί.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[c dimgray]1150[/c]πόθεν ἐπισσύτους θεοφόρους ἔχεις

	μελοτυπεῖς ὁμοῦ τ᾿ ὀρθίοις ἐν νόμοις;
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1143[/sup][/c]ἀκόρετος Ald.: ἀκόρεστος codd.<li id="note_LCL146_136_1145" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]1145[/sup][/c]μόρον Page: βίον codd.<li id="note_LCL146_136_1146" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]1146[/sup][/c]βίος ἀηδόνος Page: ἀηδόνος μόρον codd.<li id="note_LCL146_136_1147" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]1147[/sup][/c]περέβαλον Wieseler: περεβάλοντο M: περιβαλόντες [c dimgray]f[/c].<li id="note_LCL146_136_1149" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]1149[/sup][/c]αἰῶνα [c dimgray][sup]γρ[/sup][/c]M: ἀγῶνα M [c dimgray]f[/c].<li id="note_LCL146_136_1150" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]1150[/sup][/c]ἔχεις Hermann: τ᾿ ἔχεις codd.
