	[c dimgray]Page number 136[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Agamemnon[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]

	You are out of your mind, divinely possessed;
	you cry forth about yourself
	a song that is no song,
	[c dimgray][sup]244[/sup][/c] like a vibrant-throated
	[c dimgray][sup]245[/sup][/c] bird
	wailing insatiably, alas, with a heart fond of grieving,
	the nightingale lamenting “Itys, Itys!” for a death
	in which both parents did evil.
	[c dimgray][sup]246[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]cassandra[/b][/c]

	Ió ió, the life of the clear-voiced nightingale!
	The gods have clothed her with a feathered form
	and given her a pleasant life with no cause to grieve;
	[c dimgray][sup]247[/sup][/c]
	while what awaits me is to be cloven by a two-edged
	weapon.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]

	Whence do you get this possession coming violently
	upon you,
	this futile misery,
	and sound out these fearful things in song, at once
	in tones hard to interpret and in notes loud and shrill?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]244[/sup][/c]Because one expects singing to be associated with joy, not
	sorrow.
	[c dimgray][sup]245[/sup][/c]The epithet ξουθός is often applied to the nightingale, but
	its precise meaning is unclear and may well have been unclear in
	Aeschylus’ time too; see M. S. Silk, [c dimgray]CQ[/c] 33 (1983) 317–9, and
	Dunbar on Aristophanes, [c dimgray]Birds[/c] 214.
	[c dimgray][sup]246[/sup][/c]For the story of the nightingale, see [c dimgray]Suppliants[/c] 60–67, with
	notes. The adjective ἀμφιθαλής denotes properly a child who has
	both parents living; applied to Itys’ death, it is horribly perverted
	to remind us that one of his parents killed him and the other ate
	his flesh.
	[c dimgray][sup]247[/sup][/c] She continues to grieve for her [c dimgray]past[/c] sorrows, but there are
	none in her [c dimgray]present[/c] life.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 137[/c]

	[c darkmagenta][b]Agamemnon[/b][/c]
	Whence do you get the direction
	[c dimgray][sup]248[/sup][/c] of your path of

	which speaks of evil?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]cassandra[/b][/c]

	Ió, the wedding, the wedding of Paris, fatal to his kin!
	Ió, Scamander, the stream from which my fathers drank!
	Once, wretched me, upon your banks
	I was nurtured to maturity;
	now it seems I shall soon be prophesying
	beside Cocytus and the steep banks of Acheron.
	[c dimgray][sup]249[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]

	Why have you uttered these words that are all too clear?
	A babe hearing them could understand.
	I am stricken by your painful fate
	as if by a bloody bite, as you cry and whimper
	in a way that it shatters me to hear.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]cassandra[/b][/c]

	Ió, the sufferings, the sufferings of my city, utterly
	destroyed!
	Ió, the sacrifices my father offered before the walls,
	slaying many grazing beasts! But they furnished
	no remedy to prevent
	the city from suffering as it was bound to—
	and I shall soon shed a flow of warm blood to the
	ground.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]

	What you have uttered now follows on from what went
	before,
	and some divinity that wishes you ill
	is assailing you very heavily and causing you
	to sing of woeful, deadly sufferings;
	I am at a loss how it will end.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]cassandra[/b][/c]
	Well, now my prophecies will no longer be looking through
	a veil like a newly-wedded bride; rather you may expect
	that it will sweep down from the sunrise
	[c dimgray][sup]250[/sup][/c] like a bright
	fresh wind, so that there will break upon the beach,
	[c dimgray][sup]251[/sup][/c] so to
	speak, a wave of sorrow far greater than this one.
	[c dimgray][sup]252[/sup][/c] No
	longer will I give you information through riddles. I want
	you to testify that I am following close on the scent of evils
	perpetrated in former times. There is a group of singers
	that never leaves this house. They sing in unison, but not
	pleasantly, for their words speak of evil. Moreover, this
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]250[/sup][/c]The mss. have “towards the sunrise”; see J. Lavery, [c dimgray]Hermes[/c]
	132 (2004) 12–13.
	[c dimgray][sup]251[/sup][/c]The mss. have “against the sun’s rays”, and editors refer to
	the beautiful simile of Catullus (64.269–277) describing the sight
	of morning sunlight shinig through waves raised by a west wind; but here, as the end of the sentence shows, the waves are being
	thought of not as a thing of beauty but as a potentially harmful
	force of nature. It was almost inevitable that the rare word ἀγὰς
	(cf. Sophocles fr. 969, Apollonius Rhodius 1.554) would be corrupted
	into the common αὐγὰς when the sun had been mentioned
	only two lines earlier.
	[c dimgray][sup]252[/sup][/c]his is usually taken to mean that Cassandra’s second utterance
	of her prophecies will pain the Elders more than the first
	because it will be more clearly understood; but it may instead, or
	additionally, foreshadow a future, climactic crime which she has
	not yet mentioned—the matricide of Orestes (1279–84, 1317–26),
	which she will call “the coping-stone \[of\] these disasters for
	the family”.

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]253[/sup][/c]A κῶμος was properly a roving band of revellers which
	might force its way into a house where a symposium is in progress
	and demand drink or entertainment; normally, once this was supplied,
	they would leave to try their luck elsewhere.
	[c dimgray][sup]254[/sup][/c]“Kindred” because they have been called into existence by
	the murder of members of the family by other members of the
	family.
	[c dimgray][sup]255[/sup][/c]lit. “they spit out”.
	[c dimgray][sup]256[/sup][/c]The bed was the marital bed of Atreus; its defiler was his
	brother Thyestes.
	[c dimgray][sup]257[/sup][/c]Like the mendicant priests and prophets who “go to the
	doors of the rich and try to persuade them that they have a power
	vouchsafed by the gods” to effect, for a small fee, the forgiveness
	of their sins, the harming of their enemies, etc. (Plato, [c dimgray]Republic[/c]
	364b-c). Cassandra will later say that in Troy she was regarded as
	just such a person (1273–4).
	[c dimgray][sup]258[/sup][/c]Cassandra is challenging the Elders to deny on oath, if they
	can, that they know she is telling the truth about the past events to
	which she has referred; of course they cannot, and they accordingly
	decline to take the oath (1198–9). The exchange is designed
	to recall a procedural device of the Athenian lawcourts. In the
	fourth century, a person who was called as a witness, but did not
	want to confirm the statement prepared for him by the litigant
	who had called him, was required to declare on oath that he did
	not know the statement to be true (with a fine of 1000 drachmae if
	he refused); see C. Carey, [c dimgray]CQ[/c] 45 (1995) 114–9. This procedure
	cannot have existed in quite this form in the fifth century, when
	witnesses, rather than merely confirming statements drawn up in
	advance, answered oral questions and could be invited to speak [c dimgray]ad
	libitum[/c] (cf. Andocides 1.14, 69); but it is likely enough that when a
	witness refused to confirm a proposition put to him, he could be
	challenged to swear that he did not know the proposition to be
	true.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	of Iphigeneia and/or to her hostility to her son, whom she has already
	banished (877–886) and whom in some versions of the story
	she later attempted to kill in defence of Aegisthus. In art, from the
	mid sixth century onwards, she is often shown in scenes of the
	death of Aegisthus, running towards Orestes with an axe (Prag
	C7a, C11, C12, C15–22, C24, C25); cf. [c dimgray]Cho[/c]. 889.
	[c dimgray][sup]269[/sup][/c]Most probably referring to the tone of Clytaemestra’s
	prayer in 973–4; it is very unlikely that she literally uttered an
	ὀλολυγμός at that time.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 149[/c]

	[c dimgray]1300[/c]ὁ δ᾿ ὕστατός γε τοῦ χρόνου πρεσβεύεται.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΚΑΣΣΑΝΔΡΑ[/b][/c]

	ἥκει τόδ᾿ ἦμαρ· σμικρὰ κερδανῶ φυγῇ.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΧΟΡΟΣ[/b][/c]

	ἀλλ᾿ ἴσθι τλήμων οὖσ᾿ ἀπ᾿ εὐτόλμου φρενός.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΚΑΣΣΑΝΔΡΑ[/b][/c]

	οὐδεὶς ἀκούει ταῦτα τῶν εὐδαιμόνων.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΧΟΡΟΣ[/b][/c]

	ἀλλ᾿ εὐκλεῶς τοι κατθανεῖν χάρις βροτῷ.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΚΑΣΣΑΝΔΡΑ[/b][/c]

	[c dimgray]1305[/c]ἰώ πάτερ σοῦ σῶν τε γενναίων τέκνων.
	[c dimgray]1313[/c]ἀλλ᾿ εἶμι κἀν δόμοισι κωκύσουσ᾿ ἐμὴν
	[c dimgray]1314[/c]Ἀγαμέμνονός τε μοῖραν· ἀρκείτω βίος.
	[c dimgray]1315[/c]ἰὼ ξένοι—
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΧΟΡΟΣ[/b][/c]

	[c dimgray]1306[/c]τί δ᾿ ἐστὶ χρῆμα; τίς σ᾿ ἀποστρέφει φόβος;
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΚΑΣΣΑΝΔΡΑ[/b][/c]

	φῦ φῦ.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΧΟΡΟΣ[/b][/c]

	τί τοῦτ᾿ ἔφυξας; εἴ τι μὴ φρενῶν στύγος.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1305[/sup][/c]σῶν Auratus: τῶν [c dimgray]f.[/c]<li id="note_LCL146_158_1313-5" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]1313-5[/sup][/c]transposed by A. Y. Campbell (1313–4 by Enger) to
	follow 1305.<li id="note_LCL146_158_1307-8" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]1307-8[/sup][/c]φῦ φῦ and ἔφυξας Heyse: φεῦ φεῦ and ἔφευξας [c dimgray]f.[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 158[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Agamemnon[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	But people put special value on the last bit of time they
	have.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]cassandra[/b][/c]
	That day has come. I shall gain little by running away.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	Well, I tell you, your resolution comes from a courageous
	heart.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]cassandra[/b][/c]
	That’s something that’s never said about anyone who is
	happy.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	But it’s a gratification to any mortal, you know, to die creditably.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]cassandra[/b][/c]
	Ió, my father, for you and your noble sons!
	[c dimgray][sup]281[/sup][/c] Now I shall
	go to bewail, even within the house, my own fate and Agamemnon’s.
	Enough of life! \[[c dimgray]She makes to go inside, but
	suddenly recoils and cries out[/c].\] Help, friends!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	What’s the matter? What fear is making you turn away?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]cassandra[/b][/c]
	Ugh, ugh!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	Why are you going “ugh” like that? Unless it’s some mental
	horror.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]281[/sup][/c]“Cassandra’s thoughts instantly fly to the death of her
	father and \[brothers\] as the experience she has had of what is
	called so glorious, the death of the brave” (J. B. Conington, [c dimgray]Τhe[/c]
	Agamemnon of Aeschylus \[London, 1848\] 143); the audience will
	probably think of the sacrilegious slaughter of Priam and the
	abuse of Hector’s corpse.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[c dimgray]1312[/c]οὐ Σύριον ἀγλάισμα δώμασιν λέγεις.

	[c dimgray]1316[/c]οὔτοι δυσοίζω θάμνον ὡς ὄρνις φόβῳ

	[c dimgray]1320[/c]ἐπιξενοῦμαι ταῦτα δ᾿ ὡς θανουμένη.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	ὦ τλῆμον, οἰκτίρω σε θεσφάτου μόρου.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	ἅπαξ ἔτ᾿ εἰπεῖν ῥῆσιν ἢ θρῆνον θέλω
	ἐμὸν τὸν αὑτῆς· ἡλίου δ᾿ ἐπεύχομαι
	πρὸς ὕστατον φῶς, <δεσπότου> τιμαόροις
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1309[/sup][/c]φόνον [c dimgray]z[/c]: φόβον [c dimgray]f.[/c]<li id="note_LCL146_160_1317" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]1317[/sup][/c]ἄλλως· Hermann: ἀλλ᾿ ὡς [c dimgray]f.[/c]<li id="note_LCL146_160_1323" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]1323[/sup][/c]ἡλίου Jacob: ἡλίω [c dimgray]f.[/c]<li id="note_LCL146_160_1324" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]1324[/sup][/c]δεσπότου M. Schmidt: τοῖς ἐμοῖς (from 1325) [c dimgray]f.[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 160[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Agamemnon[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]cassandra[/b][/c]
	The house breathes blood-dripping murder!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	What on earth do you mean? That’s the smell of sacrifices
	at the hearth.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]cassandra[/b][/c]
	The scent is very plain—just like the whiff of a grave!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	You can’t be talking about the Syrian fragrance
	[c dimgray][sup]282[/sup][/c] which is
	adding splendour to the palace!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]cassandra[/b][/c]
	I am not shying away out of empty terror, as a bird does
	from a bush.
	[c dimgray][sup]283[/sup][/c] Bear me witness of this
	[c dimgray][sup]284[/sup][/c] after my death,
	when a woman dies in return for me, a woman, and a man
	falls in return for a man who had an evil wife. As one about
	to die, I claim this as my guest-right.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	Unhappy one, I pity you for the death you have foretold.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]cassandra[/b][/c]
	I wish to make one more speech—or should I say dirge, my
	own dirge for myself. Looking on my last sunlight, I pray
	that my enemies may pay to my master’s avengers the penalty
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]282[/sup][/c]Referring to incense; cf. 94–96, and (for its association with
	Syria) Euripides, [c dimgray]Bacchae[/c] 144, and Hermippus fr. 63.13.
	[c dimgray][sup]283[/sup][/c]“The bird that hath been limèd in a bush / With trembling
	wings misdoubteth every bush” (Shakespeare, [c dimgray]Henry VI Part 3[/c]
	V.vi.13–14)—even though most bushes do not in fact conceal
	limed twigs or other traps.
	[c dimgray][sup]284[/sup][/c]viz. that there was good reason for my fear and disgust.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 161[/c]

	[c dimgray]1325[/c]ἐχθροὺς φόνευσιν τὴν ἐμὴν τίνειν ὁμοῦ,
	δούλης θανούσης, εὐμαροῦς χειρώματος.
	ἰὼ βρότεια πράγματ᾿· εὐτυχοῦντα μὲν
	σκιᾷ τις ἂν πρέψειεν· εἰ δὲ δυστυχῇ,
	βολαῖς ὑγρώσσων σπόγγος ὤλεσεν γραφήν.
	[c dimgray]1330[/c]καὶ ταῦτ᾿ ἐκείνων μᾶλλον οἰκτίρω πολύ.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΧΟΡΟΣ[/b][/c]

	τὸ μὲν εὖ πράσσεν ἀκόρεστον ἔφυ
	πᾶσι βροτοῖσιν· δακτυλοδείκτων δ᾿
	οὔτις ἀπειπὼν εἴργει μελάθρων,
	“μηκέτ᾿ ἐσέλθῃς”, τάδε φωνῶν.
	[c dimgray]1335[/c]καὶ τῷδε πόλιν μὲν ἑλεῖν ἔδοσαν
	μάκαρες Πριάμου,
	θεοτίμητος δ᾿ οἴκαδ᾿ ἱκάνει·
	νῦν δ᾿ εἰ προτέρων αἷμ᾿ ἀποτεισῃ
	καὶ τοῖσι θανοῦσι θανὼν ἄλλων
	[c dimgray]1340[/c]ποινὰς θανάτων ἐπικράνῃ,
	τίς ἂν ἐξεύξαιτο βροτῶν ἀσινεῖ
	δαίμονι φῦναι ταδ᾿ ἀκούων;
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1325[/sup][/c]ἐχθροὺς Pearson, φόνευσιν Bothe, τὴν ἐμὴν Heller:
	ἐχθροῖς φονεῦσι τοῖς ἐμοῖς [c dimgray]f.[/c]<li id="note_LCL146_162_1328" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]1328[/sup][/c]ἂν πρέψειεν Boissonade: cf. Aesch. fr. 439: ἀντρέψειεν [c dimgray]f.[/c]<li id="note_LCL146_162_1334" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]1334[/sup][/c]μηκέτ᾿ ἐσέλθῃς Hermann: μηκέτι δ᾿ εἰσέλθῃς [c dimgray]f[/c].<li id="note_LCL146_162_1338" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]1338[/sup][/c]ἀποτείσῃ Zakas: ἀποτίσει [c dimgray]f.[/c]<li id="note_LCL146_162_1340" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]1340[/sup][/c]ἐπικράνῃ Zakas: ἐπικρανεῖ [c dimgray]f[/c]: ἄγαν ἐπικρανεῖ [c dimgray]z.[/c]<li id="note_LCL146_162_1341" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]1341[/sup][/c]ἐξεύξαιτο Schneidewin: εὔξαιτο [c dimgray]f.[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 162[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Agamemnon[/b][/c]
	for my murder as well—for the death of a slave, an easy
	victim. Alas for the fortunes of mortals! When they prosper,
	one may liken them to a shadow; and if things go badly,
	a few strokes of a damp sponge wipe their image out. And
	I pity the latter much more than the former. \[[c dimgray]She goes
	Inside[/c].\]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]

	All mortals have by nature an insatiable appetite
	for success; and no one bans it
	and keeps it away from houses at which fingers are
	pointed,
	[c dimgray][sup]285[/sup][/c]
	saying “Don’t come in here any more!”
	So to this man it was granted by the Blessed Ones
	to capture the city of Priam,
	and he comes home honoured by the gods;
	but now, if he pays for the blood shed by his forefathers
	and by dying causes the dead
	to exact further deaths as a penalty,
	[c dimgray][sup]286[/sup][/c]
	what mortal, hearing this, can boast
	that he was born to a destiny free from harm?<span class="stage italic">A sudden cry from within cuts across the chorus’s last
	Words.

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]285[/sup][/c]In admiration and/or envy.
	[c dimgray][sup]286[/sup][/c]his brief clause spans three generations: “the dead”
	(Iphigeneia and/or the children of Thyestes) are avenged by the
	death of Agamemnon, but this will in turn give rise to “further
	deaths” (those foretold by Cassandra in 1279–84, 1318–9 and
	1324–5, though the Elders did not fully understand her) which
	will still have arisen from the same original cause. Cf. [c dimgray]Choephori[/c]
	1065–74.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 163[/c]

	σῖγα· τίς πληγὴν ἀυτεῖ καιρίως οὐτασμένος;

	[c darkmagenta][b]ΧΟΡΟΣ[/b][/c]

	τοὔργον εἴργασθαι δοκεῖ μοι βασιλέως οἰμώγμασιν·

	ψηφίζομαι τὸ δρᾶν τι· μὴ μέλλειν δ᾿ ἀκμή.
	[c dimgray]—[/c]ὁρᾶν πάρεστι· φροιμιάζονται γὰρ ὡς
	[c dimgray]1355[/c]τυραννίδος σημεῖα πράσσοντες πόλει.

	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1347[/sup][/c]βουλεύματ᾿ ᾖ Enger: βουλεύματα [c dimgray]f.[/c]<li id="note_LCL146_164_1353" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]1353[/sup][/c]το δρᾶν τι· Musgrave: τί δρᾶν· τὸ [c dimgray]f.[/c] | 1356 τῆς
	μελλοῦς [c dimgray]t:[/c] τῆς μελλούσης (ης above the line) [c dimgray]f[/c]: μελλούσης [c dimgray]z.[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 164[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Agamemnon[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]agamemnon \[[c dimgray]within[/c][/b][/c]
	\]Ah me, I am struck down, a deep and deadly blow!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	Hush! Who’s that screaming about being struck and mortally
	wounded?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]agamemnon \[[c dimgray]within[/c][/b][/c]
	\]Ah me again, struck a second time!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	To judge by the king’s cries, I think the deed has been
	done. Let us deliberate and see if there might be any safe
	plan to follow.<span class="stage italic">Each member of the chorus now gives his individual
	opinion.1. I tell you what my proposal is: to proclaim an urgent
	Call
	[c dimgray][sup]287[/sup][/c] for the citizens to come here to the palace.2. I think we should burst in straight away, and get proof
	of the crime when the blood is flowing freshly from the
	sword.3. I share that opinion, and vote for doing something.
	This is a moment for not delaying.4. You can see that. Their first actions show the behaviour
	of men giving the signal that they mean to be tyrants
	of this city.5. Yes, we’re wasting time, while they are trampling the
	much-touted virtues
	[c dimgray][sup]288[/sup][/c] of delay into the ground and not
	letting their hands sleep.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]287[/sup][/c]lit. “cry”, i.e. cry for immediate help. The Elders, this man
	suggests, should either go themselves or send messengers to the
	ἀγορά to summon the citizens to storm the palace and overpower
	the assassins.
	[c dimgray][sup]288[/sup][/c]lit. “the (high) reputation”, probably with allusion to the
	proverb σπεῦδε βραδέως “make haste slowly”,“more haste, less speed” (Polyaenus, [c dimgray]Strategemata[/c] 8.24.4; Aulus Gellius 11.10.5;
	Suetonius, [c dimgray]Divus Augustus[/c] 25.4).
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 165[/c]

	now. How else could anyone, pursuing hostilities against
	enemies who think they are friends, set up their hunting-nets
	[c dimgray][sup]293[/sup][/c]
	to a height too great to overleap? This showdown
	was something that had long been in my thoughts, arising
	from a long-standing grievance; now it has come—at long
	last. I stand where I struck, with my work accomplished. I
	did it this way—I won’t deny it—so that he could neither
	escape death nor defend himself. I staked out around him
	an endless net,
	[c dimgray][sup]294[/sup][/c] as one does for fish—a wickedly opulent
	garment. Then I struck him twice, and on the spot, in the
	space of two cries, his limbs gave way; and when he had
	fallen I added a third stroke, in thanksgiving to the Zeus
	of the underworld,
	[c dimgray][sup]295[/sup][/c] the saviour of the dead, for the fulfilment
	of my prayers. Thus, having fallen, he forced out
	his own soul,
	[c dimgray][sup]296[/sup][/c] and he coughed up a sharp spurt of blood
	and hit me with a black shower of gory dew
	[c dimgray][sup]297[/sup][/c]—at which I
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]293[/sup][/c]lit. “fortify the place where the nets are set up”.
	[c dimgray][sup]294[/sup][/c]From other descriptions of the robe/net ([c dimgray]Cho.[/c] 980–4, 997–1004;
	[c dimgray]Eum.[/c] 634–5) we gather that it was thrown over Agamemnon
	like a tent and covered him completely, that it fettered his hands and hobbled his feet, and that it was the sort of device that a robber
	might use. This strongly suggests, as do other fifth-century
	references to this robe (Sophocles fr. 526; Euripides, [c dimgray]Orestes[/c] 25—
	both of which also call the robe “endless”), that it is imagined as
	something like what is already shown, a decade or so before the
	[c dimgray]Oresteia[/c], on the Dokimasia Painter’s krater (Boston 63.1246 = A6
	Prag), in which Agamemnon is completely enveloped in a delicate
	garment that has no holes for his head or arms (though his feet
	seem to have considerable freedom of movement).
	[c dimgray][sup]295[/sup][/c]i.e. Hades/Pluto (cf. [c dimgray]Supp[/c]. 156–7, 230–1). The collocation
	τρίτην . . . Διὸς . . . σωτῆρος links this bloodthirsty action, blasphemously,
	to the third libation after a feast (see on [c dimgray]Supp[/c]. 26).
	[c dimgray][sup]296[/sup][/c]i.e. his last breaths were hard, spasmodic pants.
	[c dimgray][sup]297[/sup][/c]his passage is imitated by Sophocles, [c dimgray]Antigone[/c] 1238–9
	(where the blood is that of the dying Haemon embracing the
	already dead Antigone).
	[m1]\ [/m]

	fulfilled Justice that was due for my child, by Ruin and by
	the Fury, through whose aid I slew this man, no fearful apprehension
	stalks my house, so long as the fire upon my
	hearth is kindled by Aegisthus and he remains loyal to me
	as hitherto; for he is an ample shield of confidence for me.
	Here lies this abuser of his wife,
	[c dimgray][sup]304[/sup][/c] the charmer of Chryseis
	and the rest
	[c dimgray][sup]305[/sup][/c] at Troy, and with him this captive, this
	soothsayer, this chanter of oracles who shared his bed, this
	faithful consort, this cheap whore
	[c dimgray][sup]306[/sup][/c] of the ship’s benches.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]303[/sup][/c]The point of “just as” is that the Elders see Clytaemestra’s
	arrogant words as being caused by her mental derangement (as in 1407ff they supposed that her actions and attitude resulted from
	taking a noxious drug).
	[c dimgray][sup]304[/sup][/c]lit. “the abuser of this woman”
	(meaning herself)—an expression that would normally be applied
	to a rapist or to the seducer of a married woman (cf. [c dimgray]Cho.[/c] 764 \[of
	Aegisthus!\]; Euripides, [c dimgray]Hippolytus[/c] 1068, [c dimgray]Bacchae[/c] 354).
	[c dimgray][sup]305[/sup][/c]lit. “the Chryseises”, i.e. Chryseis ([c dimgray]Iliad[/c] 1.11–120, 430–457) and other captive women.
	[c dimgray][sup]306[/sup][/c]lit. “mast-rubber”, where
	ἱστός “mast” is metaphorical as in Strabo’s tale (8.6.20) of the
	Corinthian [c dimgray]hetaera[/c] who said, when taunted with the fact that she
	did no proper work, “I’ve lowered three ἱστοί before now in
	\[snapping her fingers?\] [c dimgray]this[/c] length of time”. On the obscenity,
	unparalleled in tragedy, see my discussion in A. Willi ed. [c dimgray]The Language
	of Greek Comedy[/c] (Oxford, 2002) 155–6.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 175[/c]

	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]

	Ah, if only some fate could swiftly come—
	not a painful one, nor one
	that left us long bedridden—that would bring us
	eternal, unending sleep, now that he has been laid low,
	our most kindly guardian,
	who endured so much because of a woman
	and now has lost his life at a woman’s hands!
	Ió, ió, demented Helen,
	who alone brought death to so many,
	so very many souls at Troy,
	now you have adorned yourself with a final adornment,
	never to be forgotten,
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]307[/sup][/c]This is the earliest known reference to the belief, evidently
	already familiar, that the swan (which, significantly for this passage,
	has close associations with Apollo) sings just before it dies.
	[c dimgray][sup]308[/sup][/c]The Greek word is masculine in form, insinuating that Cassandra
	was the dominant partner and/or that Agamemnon had
	something effeminate about him.
	[c dimgray][sup]309[/sup][/c]The transmitted text means, if it means anything, “has
	brought a side-dish to my bed, to the pleasure in which I luxuriate”;
	probably, as Fraenkel suggests, εὐνῆς “bed” was a mistaken
	gloss on χλιδῆς “luxuriant pleasure” (which here denotes the
	pleasure, not of sex, but of revenge), perhaps displacing an adjective
	agreeing with παροψώνημα.

	[c dimgray][sup]320[/sup][/c]Clytaemestra first criticizes the chorus for believing that
	she (i.e. Agamemnon’s wife) is Agamemnon’s murderer, and then
	tells them not to believe that she (i.e. Agamemnon’s murderer) is
	Agamemnon’s wife; this contradiction is doubtless deliberate on
	the poet’s part, drawing attention (as the chorus will, more directly,
	in 1505–7) to the sheer incoherence of any attempt to deny
	her guilt.

	Insult comes in return for insult,
	and it is a hard struggle to judge.
	The ravager is ravaged, the killer pays;
	it remains firm while Zeus remains on his throne
	that he who does shall suffer, for that is his ordinance.
	Who can cast the seed of the curse out of the house?
	The family is glued fast to ruin.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]clytaemestra[/b][/c]

	You have struck on this oracular saying
	with truth; but be that as it may,
	I am willing to make a sworn agreement
	with the spirit of the Pleisthenids
	[c dimgray][sup]327[/sup][/c]
	that I will be content with what has happened,
	hard though it is to endure, but that for the future it
	should leave
	this house and vex some other family
	with internecine killings.
	Even if I am left with only a small part of our
	possessions
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]327[/sup][/c]Pleisthenes is a shadowy name in the family to which Agamemnon
	belongs, found at several different points in its genealogy
	(see Gantz 552–6). Most often, Pleisthenes is a son of Atreus
	who dies young and whose children, Agamemnon and Menelaus, are brought up by Atreus who comes to be regarded as their father.
	However, on the version of events that is assumed in this play,
	the curse or evil spirit originated not with this Pleisthenes but
	with Atreus (and Thyestes), and both this passage and 1602 will
	make most sense if “Pleisthenes” is assumed to be here merely
	an alternative name for Atreus himself (cf. the doubly named
	Paris/Alexander); such an equation will have been encouraged by
	the practice of some lyric poets (Ibycus, [c dimgray]PMG[/c] 282; Bacchylides
	15.6, 48) who speak of Agamemnon and/or Menelaus both as
	“Pleisthenids” and as “Atreids” or “sons of Atreus”.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 191[/c]

	because of this, you see, that you now behold this man

	I was my wretched father’s third child; Atreus spared me

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]331[/sup][/c]This passage is badly corrupt. Key considerations in restoring
	and interpreting it are, firstly, that it cannot have been only the
	hands and feet that were “chopped up . . . so \[ as to be\] unrecognizable”—hence something must have been lost between 1594 and
	1595—and secondly, that Herodotus, in writing the parallel story
	of Astyages and Harpagus (1.119), appears to have had our passage
	in mind (note especially his phrase ἄκρων χειρῶν τε καὶ ποδῶν), so it is likely that here, as in Herodotus, mention was
	made of the children’s heads, the display of which to their father
	would be the most unmistakable demonstration of what he had
	been tricked into doing. In the lacuna I translate Rose’s tentative
	supplement, which gives approximately the sense required. That
	the diners were sitting “each by himself” is mentioned to explain
	how it was possible for the children’s flesh to be served to Thyestes
	alone.
	[c dimgray][sup]332[/sup][/c]This does not give the wording of Thyestes’ curse (that is
	given in 1602) but is Aegisthus’ comment on it: as the new heads of
	the royal house, he and Clytaemestra officially take the (of course
	hypocritical) view that the curse and its consequences, including
	the death of Agamemnon, however gratifying to themselves, have
	been disastrous to the interests of the family as a whole (cf. 1570–
	6, 1655–6, 1659–60, [c dimgray]Cho[/c]. 841–3).
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]333[/sup][/c]There is irony in πᾶσαν . . . μηχανὴν δυσβουλίας, since it
	could also mean “every ill-counselled device”.
	[c dimgray][sup]334[/sup][/c]Here, and again at 1627 and 1634–5, the chorus distinguish
	between Aegisthus who “planned” the murder and Clytaemestra
	who actually performed it. In Athenian law, when a
	wilful homicide had been committed, its planner was as guilty of
	murder as its perpetrator (cf. 1613 “you intentionally killed this man”) and was liable to the same penalty (cf. Andocides 1.94); see
	E. M. Harris in E. Cantarella and G. Thür ed. [c dimgray]Symposion 1997[/c]
	(Cologne, 2001) 75–88 = Harris, [c dimgray]Democracy and the Rule of Law
	in Classical Athens[/c] (Cambridge, 2006) 391–404.
	[c dimgray][sup]335[/sup][/c]it. “that your head will not escape stoning-like curses,
	know it well, flung by the people, in justice”. In view of Aegisthus’
	armed guard, they cannot now seriously suppose (contrast 1430)
	that the people will be able to put him or Clytaemestra to death,
	by stoning or otherwise; they can stone him, as it were, only with
	words—but this they are willing to do, at whatever risk, just as at
	1652 they are ready to fight with walking-sticks against swords.
	[c dimgray][sup]336[/sup][/c]it. “healer-seers”.

	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]340[/sup][/c]From here to the end the text is in trochaic tetrameters,
	which were chanted to musical accompaniment.
	[c dimgray][sup]341[/sup][/c]Verrall’s creation of this additional speaking character, and
	Thomson’s assignment of 1651 to him (Verrall had given him
	1650), are essential. Neither 1650 nor 1651 can be spoken by
	the chorus-leader: λοχῖται (1650) is Aeschylus’ designation for
	Aegisthus’ bodyguard ([c dimgray]Cho.[/c] 768), and the members of the chorus, who even ten years ago were too old for military service, certainly
	do not wear swords (ξίφος 1651). Thus 1650 must be spoken by
	Aegisthus; and since it is pointless for him to give two successive
	orders, only the second of which has any effect, the natural inference
	is that he first gives an inexplicit but easily understood order
	to the captain who then gives a precise, drill-like instruction to his
	men. Another character in the trilogy who has only one line to
	speak is the Doorkeeper ([c dimgray]Cho[/c]. 657).
	[c dimgray][sup]342[/sup][/c]The sword is to be held horizontally, ready for drawing, but
	not yet actually drawn.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[c darkmagenta][b]Agamemnon[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]aegisthus[/b][/c]
	We accept the omen of “to die”,
	[c dimgray][sup]343[/sup][/c] and we opt for that outcome!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]clytaemestra[/b][/c]
	 \[[c dimgray]coming forward to intervene[/c]\]
	[c dimgray][sup]344[/sup][/c]Dearest of men, please let us not do further harm. What
	we have is enough to have reaped, a terrible harvest. There
	is sufficient grief already: let us not get blood on our
	hands.
	[c dimgray][sup]345[/sup][/c] Go now, honourable elders, to your homes,
	<yielding to fate> before you suffer. These things must <be
	Accepted> as we have done them.
	[c dimgray][sup]346[/sup][/c] If, I tell you, a cure for
	these troubles were to appear, we would accept it, after
	having been so wretchedly struck by the heavy talon of the
	evil spirit. Such are the words of a woman, if anyone sees fit
	to learn from them.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]aegisthus[/b][/c]
	But to think that these men should <shoot off>
	[c dimgray][sup]347[/sup][/c] their
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]343[/sup][/c]lit. “you say ‘to die’ to those who accept it”.
	[c dimgray][sup]344[/sup][/c]The [c dimgray]ekkyklēma[/c] was probably withdrawn during the confrontation
	between Aegisthus and the chorus (Clytaemestra having
	stepped off it, then or earlier); note that there are no more
	references to Agamemnon as “this man”, such as had occurred
	regularly until 1644, suggesting that his corpse is no longer visible.
	[c dimgray][sup]345[/sup][/c]Of course they have blood on their hands already; but
	Clytaemestra does not regard the killing of Agamemnon as a
	crime (cf. 1405–6), whereas, even in her view, the massacre of the
	Elders [c dimgray]would[/c] be.
	[c dimgray][sup]346[/sup][/c]The emendations of Madvig and Hermann, which I translate
	here, are far from certain; the transmitted reading ἔρξαντες,
	giving the sense “before you suffer for what you have done”, has
	the ring of authenticity (cf. 1564) but makes it even harder to
	restore the rest of the text.
	[c dimgray][sup]347[/sup][/c]I translate Blomfield’s conjecture, but only as a stopgap;
	the transmitted text gives the absurd meaning “pluck like a flower”.
	[m1]\ [/m]

West<li id="note_LCL146_210_4-5" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]4-5[/sup][/c]Aristophanes, [c dimgray]Frogs[/c] 1172–3<li id="note_LCL146_210_6-7" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]6-7[/sup][/c]Scholia to Pindar, [c dimgray]Pythian[/c], 4.145 (“said by Orestes to Agamemnon”);

	but several lines of it are quoted by other authors. The reconstruction
	offered below (with supplements indicated by
	angled brackets) is not intended to do more than indicate
	what appears to have been the gist of the passage so far as it
	can be determined; some sections may well have disappeared
	without trace.
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]orestes[/b][/c]
	Hermes of the Underworld, you who watch over my father’s
	power,
	[c dimgray][sup]2[/sup][/c] be, I pray you, my saviour and my ally! I have
	come to this land and returned <from long exile to take
	revenge for my father, who> perished violently <and ignobly>
	at the hand of a woman by concealed treachery.
	< . . .
	[c dimgray][sup]3[/sup][/c]> And on this his grave-mound I make proclamation
	to my father to hearken and hear me <and to aid me. I have
	already offered> a lock of hair to Inachus
	[c dimgray][sup]4[/sup][/c] in recompense
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]On the reconstruction of this part of the prologue, see M. L.
	West, [c dimgray]Liverpool Classical Monthly[/c] 10 (1985) 130–1, and M.
	Griffith, [c dimgray]AJP[/c] 108 (1987) 377–382.
	[c dimgray][sup]2[/sup][/c]Either the power which Agamemnon’s angry spirit can exercise
	from the underworld over events on earth, or the royal power
	which his son hopes to regain, or (very likely) both. “Aeschylus” in
	[c dimgray]Frogs[/c] 1144–6 explains the phrase as referring not to Orestes’ fa- ther but to Hermes’ own father (Zeus), but this interpretation may
	be merely meant to provide a feed for a joke by Dionysus (1147–9).
	[c dimgray][sup]3[/sup][/c]Here Orestes, like Electra in 124–8, may have asked Hermes,
	in his role as communicator between the upper and nether
	worlds, to bid the gods below respond favourably to his prayers.
	[c dimgray][sup]4[/sup][/c]The river(-god) of Argos (cf. [c dimgray]Supp[/c]. 497, [c dimgray]Prom[/c]. 590, 663,
	705). Similarly Achilles was growing a lock of his hair with the intention
	of cutting it on his return home and offering it to his local
	river(-god) Spercheius ([c dimgray]Iliad[/c] 23.140–9); knowing he will never return
	home, he presents it instead to his dead comrade Patroclus.
	The dedication of hair to a river as a nurture-offering survived as a
	regular ritual at Phigaleia in Arcadia (Pausanias 8.41.3). For the
	cutting of hair in mourning ritual cf. [c dimgray]Odyssey[/c] 4.197–8, 24.45–46
	(both passages couple it with the shedding of tears) and Plato,
	[c dimgray]Phaedo[/c] 89b.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[c dimgray][sup]6[/sup][/c]<span class="stage italic">A procession of serving-women (the chorus) begins to
	emerge from the palace door.
	[c dimgray][sup]7[/sup][/c] They are elderly, and are
	dressed all in black; there are rents in their clothes and
	gashes on their cheeks. Two of them carry jars on their
	heads.<Hey,> what is this I see? What may this gathering of
	women be that comes here, so striking in their black garments?
	What event shall I guess that it betokens? Has
	some new disaster befallen the house, or will I be right
	in conjecturing that these women are bringing drink-offerings
	for my father to propitiate the powers below?
	\[[c dimgray]
	electra[/c] comes out of the door, a little after the others,
	also carrying a jar.\] It can be nothing else, because I think I
	see my sister Electra coming with them, striking in her bitter
	grief. Zeus, grant that I may avenge the death of my father,
	and may it be your will to be my ally! Pylades, let us
	stand out of the way, so that I can learn for sure what this
	women’s supplication is about. \[[c dimgray]
	orestes[/c] and pylades
	conceal themselves.\]

	2004) 76–77 (“valediction”).
	[c dimgray][sup]6[/sup][/c]It is possible that there followed here a passage, now lost, in which Orestes prayed for the assistance of his father’s spirit in his
	task of taking revenge (cf. 128–148, 456–460, 479–509); but it is
	also possible that the appearance of the women’s procession interrupted
	him before he could do so.
	[c dimgray][sup]7[/sup][/c]That the chorus in this play enter from the [c dimgray]skēnē[/c], rather than
	by a side-passage as usual, is well argued by S. Scullion, [c dimgray]Three

	I have come from the house, having been sent
	to escort the drink-offerings with rapid beating of

	hands;
	[c dimgray][sup]8[/sup][/c]
	my cheek stands out red with gashes,
	with furrows freshly cut by my nails
	(though all my life my heart
	has fed on cries of woe);
	the tearing sound of garments rent in grief
	has ruined their linen weave
	[c dimgray][sup]9[/sup][/c]—
	the folds of my robes over my breast, savaged
	by mirthless disaster.
	A clear prophetic dream, breathing out wrath in sleep,
	which made the house’s hair stand on end,
	raised a loud cry of terror at dead of night in the
	innermost part of the house,
	making a heavy attack
	on the women’s quarters;
	and the interpreters of this dream
	proclaimed, under a divine guarantee,
	[c dimgray][sup]10[/sup][/c]
	that those beneath the earth were furiously aggrieved
	and wrathful against the killers.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]8[/sup][/c]On head or breast or both, as a gesture of mourning (like the
	gashing of cheeks and rending of garments mentioned below).
	[c dimgray][sup]9[/sup][/c]lit. “linen-ruining tearings of woven garments have resounded
	due to grief”.
	[c dimgray][sup]10[/sup][/c]i.e. under oath (to give an honest interpretation).

	Such is the graceless favour
	[c dimgray][sup]11[/sup][/c] to avert trouble—
	O Mother Earth!
	[c dimgray][sup]12[/sup][/c]—that she is seeking to do by sending
	me,
	that godless woman. This is a word
	that I am afraid to utter:
	[c dimgray][sup]13[/sup][/c]
	what expiation is there when blood has been shed on the
	ground?
	O hearth full of woe!
	O ruin of the house!
	Sunless darkness, abhorred by all,
	shrouds the house
	because its rulers have perished.
	[c dimgray][sup]14[/sup][/c]
	The reverence—once unconquerable, invincible,
	impregnable—
	that penetrated the ears and hearts of the people
	is now departing; someone
	is afraid.
	[c dimgray][sup]15[/sup][/c] Good fortune,
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]11[/sup][/c]The “favour” that Clytaemestra is ostensibly bestowing on
	the spirit of Agamemnon is “graceless” because her sole motive is
	not to benefit him but to protect herself.
	[c dimgray][sup]12[/sup][/c]Earth, as the oldest and greatest of chthonic powers, is
	likely to be offended by the abuse of chthonic rites to which the
	chorus are being forced to be party.
	[c dimgray][sup]13[/sup][/c]The view taken here is that this refers to the next sentence:
	if it is true that bloodshed can never be expiated, then the chorus
	are risking divine wrath and punishment by performing a ritual whose purpose is to expiate it. Others take the reference to be to
	the prayers that will accompany the ritual, or to the words “godless
	woman” (in the latter case the sentence “This is a word that I
	am afraid to utter” would be parenthetical).
	[c dimgray][sup]14[/sup][/c]The reference is primarily to the death of Agamemnon, but
	(i) this was a sequel to other deaths in the family (cf. 1065–72) and
	(ii) it was the end (unless Orestes were eventually to return) of the
	legitimate royal house of Argos.
	[c dimgray][sup]15[/sup][/c]It is not clear (and it is not clear whether the poet meant it to
	be clear) whether this is a guarded way of saying that the usurping
	rulers are afraid of the people, or whether it means that the people
	are now in terror of (instead of revering) their rulers (in which
	case the translation would be “men are afraid”). For a similar
	ambiguity cf. [c dimgray]Eum[/c]. 690–2.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 217[/c]

	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]16[/sup][/c]On the first of the two interpretations given in the previous
	note, the point being made is: our rulers “worship” Fortune,
	thinking that if their luck holds they will be safe, and shut their
	eyes to the certainty that Justice will sooner or later catch up with
	them.
	[c dimgray][sup]17[/sup][/c]The general point is evidently “justice is sometimes slow
	but always sure”; the most obvious (but far from certain) interpretation
	of the details, taking light and darkness as representing life
	and death, is that some are punished quickly, some late in life,
	some only after death (cf. [c dimgray]Eum[/c]. 175–8, 267–275, 339–340, [c dimgray]Seven[/c]
	742–5, [c dimgray]Supp[/c]. 413–6).

	Servant women who keep the house in good order, since

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]18[/sup][/c]lit. “a hand-polluting murder”.
	[c dimgray][sup]19[/sup][/c]I translate my very
	tentative supplement (replacing the intrusive gloss καθαίροντες) purely for the sake of continuity. A reference to water would certainly
	help to ease the difficulty noted by K. Sier, [c dimgray]Die lyrischen
	Partien der Choephoren des Aischylos[/c] (Stuttgart, 1988) 44, that
	πόρος is not normally used to mean “stream” unless words in the
	context make it clear that this is its sense.

	army (presumably Argive or Argive-led). It is left vague when and
	where this occurred; it cannot have been in the recent Trojan War,
	since the women are old (171) and yet were taken “from \[their\]
	father\[s’\] house\[s\]”, i.e. while still unmarried.
	[c dimgray][sup]21[/sup][/c]The scholia quote a proverb, “Slave, obey your masters in
	right things and in wrong”. In Sophocles’ [c dimgray]Antigone[/c] (666–7) Creon
	misapplies this maxim to claim that the [c dimgray]citizen[/c] owes an absolute
	duty of obedience to state authority.
	[c dimgray][sup]22[/sup][/c]i.e. covering my face (both as a mourning gesture and to
	conceal the tears).

	[c darkmagenta][b]Libation-Bearers[/b][/c]
	pour these drink-offerings of mourning? How can I speak
	sensibly? How will I pray to my father? Should I say that I
	am bringing them from a loving wife to a dear husband—
	when they come from my mother? Or should I say it this
	way, as is the custom among mankind, that he should repay
	with blessings those who sent him these honours—\[[c dimgray]sarcastically[/c]\]
	truly the repayment their crimes deserve? Or
	should I pour them out in silence—a mark of dishonour,
	just as my father perished dishonourably—for the earth to
	drink up, and go, like someone getting rid of the vessel
	used in a purification ritual,
	[c dimgray][sup]23[/sup][/c] throwing the jar away behind
	me without turning my eyes? I don’t have the courage for
	that,
	[c dimgray][sup]24[/sup][/c] and I can’t think what to say when I pour this thick-flowing
	offering at my father’s tomb. Please, my friends,
	share the responsibility for this decision; for we cherish the
	same enmity within our home. Don’t hide your thoughts
	within your heart for fear of anyone: the same fate lies in
	store for the free man as for him who is enslaved to the
	hand of another. Please speak, if you have any better ideas
	than what I have said.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	I respect your father’s tomb as if it were an altar, and as you
	bid me, I will speak my mind out.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]23[/sup][/c]“This refers to an Athenian custom: when they purified a
	house with an earthenware censer, they threw the pot away at a
	crossroads and withdrew without looking back” (scholia).
	[c dimgray][sup]24[/sup][/c]Not so much because it would anger Clytaemestra in the
	unlikely event of her getting to know about it, as because it might
	anger Agamemnon if he misunderstood Electra’s contempt for
	the offerings as contempt for himself.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 223[/c]

-146.229 (AESCHYLUS, Oresteia. Libation-Bearers)
%Aeschylus Libation-Bearers
AESCHYLUS, Oresteia. Libation-Bearers
	[c darkmagenta][b]AESCHYLUS, Oresteia. Libation-Bearers[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Aeschylus[/b][/c]
	φίλον τ᾿ Ὀρέστην φῶς ἄναψον ἐν δόμοις.
	πεπραμένοι γὰρ νῦν γέ πως ἀλώμεθα
	πρὸς τῆς τεκούσης, ἄνδρα δ᾿ ἀντηλλάξατο
	Αἴγισθον, ὅσπερ σοῦ φόνου μεταίτιος.
	[c dimgray]135[/c]κἀγὼ μὲν ἀντίδουλος, ἐκ δὲ χρημάτων
	φεύγων Ὀρέστης ἐστίν, οἱ δ᾿ ὑπερκόπως
	ἐν τοῖσι σοῖς πόνοισι χλίουσιν μέγα.
	ἐλθεῖν δ᾿ Ὀρέστην δεῦρο σὺν τύχῃ τινὶ
	κατεύχομαί σοι, καὶ σὺ κλῦθί μου, πάτερ·
	[c dimgray]140[/c]αὐτῇ τέ μοι δὸς σωφρονεστέραν πολὺ
	μητρὸς γενέσθαι χεῖρά τ᾿ εὐσεβεστέραν.
	ἡμῖν μὲν εὐχὰς τάσδε, τοῖς δ᾿ ἐναντίοις
	λέγω φανῆναι σοῦ, πάτερ, τιμάορον,
	καὶ τοὺς κτανόντας ἀντικατθανεῖν δίκῃ·
	[c dimgray]145[/c]ταῦτ᾿ ἐν μέσῳ τίθημι τῆς κεδνῆς ἀρᾶς,
	κείνοις λέγουσα τήνδε τὴν κακὴν ἀράν·
	ἡμῖν δὲ πομπὸς ἴσθι τῶν ἐσθλῶν ἄνω
	σὺν θεοῖσι καὶ Γῇ καὶ Δίκῃ νικηφόρῳ.
	τοιαῖσδ᾿ ἐπ᾿ εὐχαῖς τάσδ᾿ ἐπισπένδω χοάς·
	[c dimgray]150[/c]ὑμᾶς δὲ κωκυτοῖς ἐπανθίζειν νόμος,
	παιῶνα τοῦ θανόντος ἐξαυδωμένας.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]131[/sup][/c]φῶς ἄναψον ἔν Schneidewin (φῶς τ᾿ ἄν.), Wilamowitz:
	πῶς ἀνάξομεν M [c dimgray][sup]i[/sup][/c]Σ[c dimgray][sup]M[/sup][/c].<li id="note_LCL146_228_132" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]132[/sup][/c]πεπραμένοι Portus: πεπραγμένοι M.<li id="note_LCL146_228_136" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]136[/sup][/c]φεύγων Robortello, Turnebus: φεύγειν M.<li id="note_LCL146_228_137" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]137[/sup][/c]μέγα Turnebus: μέτα M.<li id="note_LCL146_228_140" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]140[/sup][/c]σωφρονεστέραν M[c dimgray][sup]s[/sup][/c]: σωφρονεστέρα M.<li id="note_LCL146_228_144" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]144[/sup][/c]δίκῃ Portus: δίκην M. | 145 κεδνῆς Butler: κακῆς M.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 228[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Libation-Bearers[/b][/c]
	me, and kindle a light in your house in the shape of my beloved
	Orestes. For at present we are virtually vagrants,
	sold by our mother, who has received in exchange a new
	man—Aegisthus, the same who shared the guilt of your
	murder. I am in the position of a slave,
	[c dimgray][sup]26[/sup][/c] Orestes is in exile,
	deprived of his property, and they are greatly and extravagantly
	luxuriating in the wealth for which you toiled. I pray
	to you—and do hear me, father—for Orestes to come here
	by some stroke of fortune; and for myself, grant that I may
	be far more virtuous than my mother, and more righteous
	in action. These prayers for us. Upon our enemies I ask for
	there to appear an avenger for you, father, and for the killers
	to meet justice and perish in their turn—I place this in
	the middle of my prayer for good, uttering this prayer for
	evil against them; but for us, be a sender of blessings from
	below, together with the gods, and Earth, and Justice to
	bring us victory. Such are the prayers I make before pouring
	these drink-offerings; \[[c dimgray]to the chorus[/c]\] the custom is
	for you to adorn them with wailing, uttering a paean to the
	deceased.
	[c dimgray][sup]27[/sup][/c] \[[c dimgray]She pours out the offerings on the ground
	from the three jars in succession, while the chorus[/c] sing.\]
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]26[/sup][/c]Meaning primarily that, though she must by now be well
	into her twenties, she has still not been given in marriage (cf. 487)
	as any free daughter of a family routinely would be in her mid-teens.
	[c dimgray][sup]27[/sup][/c]An oxymoron, like the “paean to the Furies” at [c dimgray]Ag.[/c] 645, but
	not quite such a “blasphemous paradox” as that, since the ceremony,
	as reshaped by Electra and the chorus, is now designed to
	secure the victory of Agamemnon’s heirs and the restoration of his
	honour, to which a paean would be appropriate.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 229[/c]

AESCHYLUS, Oresteia. Libation-Bearers
	[c darkmagenta][b]AESCHYLUS, Oresteia. Libation-Bearers[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Aeschylus[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΧΟΡΟΣ[/b][/c]

	ἵετε δάκρυ καναχὲς
	ὀλομένῳ δεσπότᾳ
	πρὸς ἔρυμα τόδε κεδνῶν, κακῶν δ᾿
	[c dimgray]155[/c]ἀπότροπον ἄγος ἀπεύχετον,
	κεχυμένων χοᾶν.
	κλύε δέ μοι, σέβας, κλύ᾿, ὦ δέσποτ᾿, ἐξ
	ἀμαυρᾶς φρενός.
	ὀτοτοτοτοτοτοῖ·
	[c dimgray]160[/c]ἰώ, τίς δορισθενὴς εἶσ᾿ ἀνὴρ
	ἀναλυτὴρ δόμων, Σκυθικά τ᾿ ἐν χεροῖν
	ἐν ἔργῳ βέλη πιπάλλων Ἄρεως
	σχέδιά τ᾿ αὐτόκωπα νωμῶν ξίφη;

	[c darkmagenta][b]ΗΛΕΚΤΡΑ[/b][/c]

	[c dimgray]164[/c]ἔχει μὲν ἤδη γαπότους χοὰς πατήρ·
	[c dimgray]166[/c]νέου δὲ μύθου τοῦδε κοινωνήσατε.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]

	M. | 160 δορισθενὴς anon: δορυσθενὴς M.<li id="note_LCL146_230_160" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]160[/sup][/c]εἶσ᾿ ἀνὴρ Weil: ἀνὴρ M.<li id="note_LCL146_230_161" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]161[/sup][/c]Σκυθικά Robortello: Σκυθιτά M: (Σκύθ)ησ M[c dimgray][sup]sscr[/sup][/c].<li id="note_LCL146_230_162" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]162[/sup][/c]ἐν ἔργῳ Paley: παλίντον᾿ ἐν ἔργῳ M: perh. ἐπ᾿ ἔργῳ?<li id="note_LCL146_230_163" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]163[/sup][/c]ξίφη (explicitly contrasted with βέλη) Σ[c dimgray][sup]M[/sup][/c]: βέλη M.<li id="note_LCL146_230_164" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]164[/sup][/c]γαπότους Turnebus: ἀπό, του M (ἀ in an erasure).

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Libation-Bearers[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]

	Let the tears fall loudly
	for our departed master
	at this stronghold of the good, which averts
	the abominable pollution of the wicked,
	[c dimgray][sup]28[/sup][/c]
	now the drink-offerings have been poured.
	Hear, I pray you, revered one! Hear, my master,
	in the gloominess of your heart!
	Ototototototoi!
	Oh, if only there would come a man,
	[c dimgray][sup]29[/sup][/c] mighty with the
	spear,
	to set the house free again, brandishing in his hands
	Scythian weapons
	[c dimgray][sup]30[/sup][/c] in
	[c dimgray][sup]31[/sup][/c] the work of war
	and wielding a sword,
	[c dimgray][sup]32[/sup][/c] of one piece with its hilt, for
	close fighting!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]electra[/b][/c]
	Now my father has the drink-offerings—the earth has
	swallowed them; but here is something new about which I
	want to share a word with you.

	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]

	sometimes have the appearance of tendons” (Garvie).

	[c dimgray][sup]43[/sup][/c]The text is in detail uncertain, but there can be little doubt

	his head.
	[c dimgray][sup]45[/sup][/c]Evidently a garment, or part of a garment, that Orestes
	is wearing. In Euripides ([c dimgray]Electra[/c] 538–544) Orestes’ old servant
	speaks in terms appropriate to a whole garment, and Electra
	points out that this is absurd, since such a garment, made when
	Orestes was an infant, would be far too small for him to wear as an
	adult; but Aeschylus’ language is at least as consistent with the
	idea that the “piece of weaving” is merely a cloth, woven and embroidered
	long ago by Electra, which has since been worked into,
	or sewn on to, the garment Orestes is now wearing.

	brood of the eagle father, of him who died in the

	[c dimgray][sup]53[/sup][/c] The bereaved children
	are hard pressed by ravenous hunger, for they are not
	yet full-grown so as to be able to bring home to the nest the
	prey their father hunted. So too
	[c dimgray][sup]54[/sup][/c] you can see this woman,
	Electra, and me, children robbed of their father, both alike
	in banishment from their home.
	[c dimgray][sup]55[/sup][/c] And if you allow us nestlings
	to perish, whose father was the great sacrificer who
	greatly glorified you, from whence will you get the honour
	of a fine feast given with comparable generosity? If you
	let the brood of the eagle perish, you would never again
	be able to send mortals signs that they would readily believe;
	[c dimgray][sup]56[/sup][/c]
	and if this ruling stock is allowed to shrivel away entirely,
	it cannot minister to your altars on days when oxen
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]53[/sup][/c]Clytaemestra was compared to a serpent in [c dimgray]Ag.[/c] 1233. Vipers
	do not in fact kill their prey by coiling round them; but it was believed
	that “when they copulate . . . the female seizes the male by
	the neck, holds him tight and does not let him go until she has bitten
	it through. . . . But . . . the young, when they are still in their
	mother’s womb, take revenge for their father by eating through
	her belly . . . and emerge from her body in that way” (Herodotus 3.109). The relevance of this to Agamemnon, his wife and his children
	will be evident even before we learn that Clytaemestra in her
	dream had given birth to a snake, with which Orestes identifies
	himself (527–533, 542–550).
	[c dimgray][sup]54[/sup][/c]The speech proceeds as though the metaphorical self-description
	in 247–251 had been a literal description of the plight
	of a pair of young eagles.
	[c dimgray][sup]55[/sup][/c]Electra has not literally been banished, but she has been
	treated in a manner unbefitting a member of the family and has
	described both herself and Orestes as “virtual vagrants” (132).
	[c dimgray][sup]56[/sup][/c]This is ambiguous, perhaps designedly, between a literal interpretation
	(“if there are no eagles there can be no omens”—so
	that Zeus will be damaging his own interests, just as he will if he
	destroys the house of Agamemnon) and a metaphorical one (“if
	you destroy the children of the ‘eagle’ Agamemnon \[who as a king
	was under your special protection, cf. [c dimgray]Ag.[/c] 43–44\] you will forfeit
	all credibility in human eyes”).
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[c darkmagenta][b]Libation-Bearers[/b][/c]
	revealed the effects of the wrath of hostile powers from
	under the earth against mortals, and spoke of these dreadful
	afflictions—leprous ulcers attacking the flesh, eating
	away its pristine appearance with savage jaws, and short
	white hairs arising on the disease site.
	[c dimgray][sup]62[/sup][/c] He spoke too of
	other assaults of Furies, generated by the blood of a father:
	[c dimgray][sup]63[/sup][/c]
	the dark weapon of the powers below, arising from
	those of one’s kin who have fallen and beg for justice, together
	with madness and empty night-time terrors, derange
	him, harry him, and chase him from his city, physically
	humiliated by a metal collar.
	[c dimgray][sup]64[/sup][/c] And men such as this,
	he said, are not permitted to have a share in the mixing-bowl
	[c dimgray][sup]65[/sup][/c]
	or in the pouring of a friendly libation; the father’s
	unseen wrath keeps him away from altars; no one will receive
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]62[/sup][/c]For this characteristic of the skin-disease (λεύκη) that is
	here being described, cf. Aristotle, [c dimgray]Historia Animalium[/c] 518a12–13
	and \[Aristotle\], [c dimgray]On Colours[/c] 797b14–16.
	[c dimgray][sup]63[/sup][/c]Line 285 (“seeing clearly, moving his/her/their eyebrows in the dark”) can hardly belong here; a detailed description of, say, a
	nightmare vision would break the connection between the statement
	of the Furies’ various torments in 286–290—of which nightmares
	(288) are only one—and the “headline” sentence 283–4 of
	which that statement provides a detailed exposition. Possibly the
	line is a remnant of a passage (from another Aeschylean play?)
	cited by a commentator in illustration of 288.
	[c dimgray][sup]64[/sup][/c]There is probably an allusion to rituals involving human
	scapegoats (φάρμακοι) who were ceremonially flogged out of a
	city as a purification rite (see Hipponax frr. 5–10 and 104.49;
	Harpocration φ5; W. Burkert, [c dimgray]Greek Religion[/c] tr. J. Raffan \[Oxford,
	1985\] 82–84). At Athens they were draped with necklaces
	of dried figs (Photius, [c dimgray]Bibliotheca[/c] 279 p.534a2–11); here this is
	replaced by a metal collar (for this sense of πλάστιγξ cf. \[Euripides\],
	[c dimgray]Rhesus[/c] 303), perhaps with allusion to the collar used in execution
	by [c dimgray]apotympanismos[/c] (see Introduction to [c dimgray]Prometheus Bound[/c]).
	See L. Battezzato, [c dimgray]Studi Classici e Orientali[/c] 42 (1992) 71–76.
	[c dimgray][sup]65[/sup][/c]i.e. in the wine at a symposium.

	[c dimgray][sup]66[/sup][/c]This exclusion from the sharing of rituals and of roofs, with
	which Orestes is threatened if he does not carry out the revenge

	throughout the Greek world, for those who [c dimgray]had[/c] committed homicide
	or been complicit in it (cf. [c dimgray]Eum[/c]. 655–6; Sophocles, [c dimgray]Oedipus the King[/c] 236–241; Demosthenes 20.158).
	[c dimgray][sup]67[/sup][/c]This refers primarily to wasting of the still living body (cf.
	Sophron fr. 54 K-A; also Demosthenes 25.61, of the effect of long
	imprisonment) but may also hint at the possibility of the dead
	body being left unburied.
	[c dimgray][sup]68[/sup][/c]Some such supplement is necessary; 302–4 cannot (as
	Garvie wishes) be closely linked with 301, because the question
	who is to possess Agamemnon’s property and the question how
	Argos is to be governed are in principle two entirely separate
	issues (cf. [c dimgray]Odyssey[/c] 1.389–398).

	[c dimgray][sup]70[/sup][/c]lit. “let him/her pay”; the chorus are presumably thinking of
	Clytaemestra, who actually struck the “bloody strokes”, but they
	do not make the payer’s identity (or even gender) explicit.
	[c dimgray][sup]71[/sup][/c]So Sier understands ὁμοίως (rather than “all the same,
	nevertheless”, which most recent editors favour). The fact that
	lamentation, which the living find displeasing and ill-omened, is
	gratifying to the dead is in harmony, not in contrast, with the fact
	that light and darkness are opposites.
	[c dimgray][sup]72[/sup][/c]The inevitable tension between thinking of the dead as
	dwelling in their tombs, and thinking of them as dwelling in the
	remote realm of Hades, surfaces here as the near-contradiction
	between this line and 317–8 (“from afar to where your resting-place
	confines you”).
	[c dimgray][sup]73[/sup][/c]“He who dies” and “he who can harm” are the same person.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	of old.” Contrariwise, Polyxene in Euripides’ [c dimgray]Hecuba[/c] (551–2),
	though a princess, fears that if she dies like a slave she will be a
	slave in Hades.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 257[/c]

	Rather should his killers have been slain so,
	[c dimgray][sup]79[/sup][/c]
	<so that> someone far away
	[c dimgray][sup]80[/sup][/c]
	would have learned of their deadly fate
	without experiencing these present troubles.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]

	That, my child, would be better than gold;
	you talk of something greater than great,
	than Hyperborean, good fortune
	[c dimgray][sup]81[/sup][/c]—because talking
	comes cheap!
	[c dimgray][sup]82[/sup][/c]
	But the crack of this double lash
	strikes home: on one side those who might have helped
	are now beneath the earth,
	[c dimgray][sup]83[/sup][/c] while on the other the
	unclean hands
	of the rulers, <the cause> of these
	hateful <sufferings, are a reproach to the father>
	[c dimgray][sup]84[/sup][/c]
	and even more so to the children.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]79[/sup][/c]This can hardly mean “slain in battle at Troy”, since that
	would be inapplicable to Clytaemestra, and in any case Electra
	would hardly wish, even hypothetically, for what would have been
	a glorious death for Aegisthus; rather, in the light of the following
	πρόσω, it will be taken to mean more generally “far from home”.
	[c dimgray][sup]80[/sup][/c]As the last words of the sentence show, Electra is referring
	to those who have in actuality experienced “these present troubles”—herself,
	Agamemnon’s family, and perhaps the Argives
	generally.
	[c dimgray][sup]81[/sup][/c]Cf. Pindar, [c dimgray]Pythian[/c] 10.29–44 (no mortal but Perseus has ever reached the land of the Hyperboreans; Apollo delights in
	their feasts, which abound in music and dance, and they are free of
	disease and old age, of toil and warfare).
	[c dimgray][sup]82[/sup][/c]lit. “because you [c dimgray]can[/c] (sc. talk)”.
	[c dimgray][sup]83[/sup][/c]We are less likely to think here of the old men of the chorus
	in [c dimgray]Agamemnon[/c] (as West,[c dimgray] Studies[/c] 243 n.16 does) than (after 355–6
	and 365) of those who fought with Agamemnon at Troy, virtually
	all of whom (in Aeschylus’ version) perished either in the war or
	on the voyage home ([c dimgray]Ag.[/c] 636–680); so apparently the scholia (“our
	allies, those around Agamemnon”). The expression will simultaneously
	remind us of the avengers’ other allies beneath the earth,
	the chthonic gods and the spirit of Agamemnon; but they can look
	for no armed assistance from any mortal [c dimgray]on[/c] the earth.
	[c dimgray][sup]84[/sup][/c]I translate West’s [c dimgray]exempli gratia[/c] supplement; something
	powerful is certainly needed to have the effect on Orestes that he
	describes in 380–1.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	That pierced straight through
	my ear, like an arrow.
	Zeus, Zeus,
	[c dimgray][sup]85[/sup][/c] who sends up from below
	avenging ruin, soon or late,
	against audacious, reckless
	human violence! For my parents, both alike, there will
	be payment!
	[c dimgray][sup]86[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]

	May it be my lot to raise a massed
	[c dimgray][sup]87[/sup][/c] cry
	of triumph over a man
	struck down and a woman
	perishing; for why should I conceal
	what kind of thought is hovering
	within my mind? Ahead of the prow
	of my heart there blows a harsh wind
	of anger, of raging hatred.
	[c dimgray][sup]88[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]85[/sup][/c]Presumably addressing “the Zeus of the underworld”, i.e.
	Hades (see on [c dimgray]Ag.[/c] 1386–7).
	[c dimgray][sup]86[/sup][/c]τοκεῦσι could equally well be dative of the recipient (“to my
	parents”) or of the agent (“by my parents”); in fact, of course, the
	payment will be made by one parent to the other.
	[c dimgray][sup]87[/sup][/c]This, or something like it, must be the meaning of πυκάεντ´
	(derived from the adverb πύκα “densely”), if this barely attested
	word, conjectured here by Dindorf, did indeed exist. The transmitted
	reading, πευκήεντ´, gives good sense (“piercing”) but
	raises serious metrical problems here and in the antistrophe
	(410).
	[c dimgray][sup]88[/sup][/c]The image of a mental “headwind” suggests that they feel
	irresistibly driven, in spite of any possible softer inclinations, to
	long eagerly for the violent death of Aegisthus and Clytaemestra,
	even though they are by now aware, from Orestes’ report of
	Apollo’s oracle, that this must involve matricide. Similarly Agamemnon
	is described as “blowing with [c dimgray]the blast of fortune that
	struck him[/c]” ([c dimgray]Ag.[/c] 186) when he changed course ([c dimgray]Ag.[/c] 219) and zealously
	sacrificed his daughter.

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Libation-Bearers[/b][/c]
	my arms stretch out, hitting and grasping,
	[c dimgray][sup]96[/sup][/c]
	beating thick and fast, making many a smirch to
	behold,
	[c dimgray][sup]97[/sup][/c]
	from above, from high above, and my wretched head
	rings with the sound of my battering.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]electra[/b][/c]

	Ió, ió, cruel mother
	of limitless audacity, it was a cruel funeral
	when you had the hardihood to bury your husband,
	a king, without the presence of his city’s people,
	without mourning and with no lamentation!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	<span class="speaker">chorus
	[c dimgray][sup]98[/sup][/c] \[[c dimgray]to orestes[/c]\]
	And—so you may know this—he was mutilated
	[c dimgray][sup]99[/sup][/c] as well;
	and the perpetrator was she who buried him thus,
	striving to make his death
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]96[/sup][/c]As if to tear out hair; cf. [c dimgray]Pers.[/c] 1056; Sophocles, [c dimgray]Ajax[/c] 310,
	634; Euripides, [c dimgray]Andromache[/c] 826, [c dimgray]Trojan Women[/c] 279.
	[c dimgray][sup]97[/sup][/c]i.e. drawing blood; with the whole passage cf. 23–31.
	[c dimgray][sup]98[/sup][/c]I have accepted the transposition of strophe and antistrophe:
	Orestes’ reaction in 434–8 is too strong to be plausibly
	provoked merely by the statement—which can hardly come as a
	surprise to him—that there was no public mourning when Agamemnon
	was buried, and τὸ πᾶν ἀτίμως ἔλεξας (434) suggests
	that he has been told more than that.
	[c dimgray][sup]99[/sup][/c]By cutting off his extremities (hands and feet, sometimes
	also nose and ears), stringing them together and tying them
	around his neck and under his armpits (μασχάλαι) with a view,
	[c dimgray]inter alia[/c], to disabling his ghost from pursuit and vengeance. Cf.
	Sophocles, [c dimgray]Electra[/c] 445; Sophocles fr. 528, 623 (probably Troilus
	mutilated by Achilles); Apollonius Rhodius 4.477 (Medea’s brother
	Apsyrtus mutilated by Jason); and see E. Rohde, [c dimgray]Psyche[/c] (tr. W. B.
	Hillis, London, 1925) 582–6.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[c dimgray][sup]103[/sup][/c]When a wound became, or was expected to become, septic,
	it was the practice to insert a plug of lint (μοτός)—a “tent”, in the parlance of early modern surgeons—so as to keep the wound open

	[c dimgray]On Wounds in the Head[/c] 14 and [c dimgray]Diseases[/c] 2.47.
	[c dimgray][sup]104[/sup][/c]I have translated Wecklein’s restoration of the badly corrupt
	text; a wish for marriage, which Electra has been disgracefully
	denied for many years (cf. on 135), seems highly likely in view

	Attic double consonants -ρρ- and -ττ- to -ρσ- and -σσ-.
	[c dimgray][sup]110[/sup][/c]i.e. as he was before he was disfigured by wounding and
	mutilation.

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]electra[/b][/c]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]111[/sup][/c]A metaphor from wrestling.
	[c dimgray][sup]112[/sup][/c]This sententious passage is inappropriate in a scene of
	short, impassioned appeals, and spoils both the symmetry
	between the two speakers and (by explaining what needs no explanation)
	the impact of the bold paradox of 504. It is quoted by Clem- ent of Alexandria (see textual note) in a curiously different form,
	the first sentence being given as παῖδες δὲ ἀνδρὶ κατθανόντι
	(κατ᾿ αἶαν ὄντι cod., corr. Dobree) κληδόνες γεγάασι, and he attributes
	the passage to Sophocles (an ascription which all recent
	editors of Sophoclean fragments have by implication rejected).
	Since γεγάασι (an epic form not otherwise found in tragedy at all)
	could not stand in spoken iambics yet can hardly be accounted for
	as a corruption, the most likely explanation of the presence of the
	lines in our text, as Garvie suggests, is that they were originally a
	lyric passage written as an illustrative parallel in the margin, later
	copied into the text and then adapted into iambic verses.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	ὡς ἂν δόλῳ κτείναντες ἄνδρα τίμιον
	δόλῳ γε καὶ ληφθῶσιν, ἐν ταὐτῷ βρόχῳ
	θανόντες, ᾗ καὶ Λοξίας ἐφήμισεν,
	ἄναξ Ἀπόλλων, μάντις ἀψευδὴς τὸ πρίν.

	ἥξω σὺν ἀνδρὶ τῷδ᾿ ἐφ᾿ ἑρκείους πύλας
	Πυλάδῃ—ξένος δὲ καὶ δορύξενος δόμων—ἄμφω

	that, having killed a man of renown by trickery, so too they

	[c dimgray][sup]119[/sup][/c]In fact, when the pair come to the door, only Orestes
	speaks, and he speaks normal tragic Attic (as does everyone else in
	tragedy, including those who in “real” life would have known little
	or no Greek of any kind); this sentence serves as an instruction to
	the audience to [c dimgray]imagine[/c] that he is speaking Phocian. Much of
	Mount Parnassus was in Phocian territory.
	[c dimgray][sup]120[/sup][/c]i.e. travellers from abroad hoping to be given hospitality
	(and perhaps also protection from enemies, whence ἱκέτην “suppliant”
	in 569); the idea is that Aegisthus will eventually be forced
	to admit them for fear of getting a bad name.
	[c dimgray][sup]121[/sup][/c]i.e. grants me an audience (as is presently explained, he
	will not be given a chance to actually speak).

	that cause terrible, fearful suffering,
	and the bosom of the deep
	teems with hostile monsters;
	torches flaming on high,
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]122[/sup][/c]lit. “swift-footed piece of metalwork”.
	[c dimgray][sup]123[/sup][/c]Another allusion to the third libation (see notes on [c dimgray]Supp.[/c]
	26, [c dimgray]Ag.[/c] 246, 1385–7)—which was, however, of wine [c dimgray]mixed with
	water[/c] (Diodorus Siculus 4.3.4). The Fury’s [c dimgray]second[/c] draught was,
	of course, the murder of Agamemnon; her [c dimgray]first[/c] is probably to
	be identified with the murder and butchery of the children of
	Thyestes (cf. 1065–76 and [c dimgray]Ag.[/c] 1090–1129, 1186–1241).
	[c dimgray][sup]124[/sup][/c]That the power to whom Orestes here entrusts his fortunes
	is Hermes was convincingly argued by A. F. Garvie, [c dimgray]BICS[/c] 17
	(1970) 85–86. Hermes is the god of contests (ἐναγώνιος: cf.
	Aesch. fr. 384; Pindar, [c dimgray]Pythian[/c] 2.10; Aristophanes, [c dimgray]Wealth[/c] 1161–2),
	and he is appealed to at 727–9 in a close echo of the present
	passage. Others have taken the power addressed here to be Apollo
	or the spirit of Agamemnon.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	evidence that some animals were killed.

	the daughter of Thestius,
	[c dimgray][sup]127[/sup][/c] the woman who lit the fire,
	burning up the red brand
	that was coeval with her son, ever since
	he had cried when he came from her womb,
	and that kept measure with his life all its length
	till the day decreed by fate.
	There is another one in story fit to be loathed,

	who caused the death of a man of close kin

	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]127[/sup][/c]Althaea, the mother of Meleager. When her son was a week
	old, she was told by the Fates that he would die when the log then
	burning on the hearth was consumed; she seized the log and kept
	it in a chest. But when she heard that her brothers had been killed
	by Meleager in a quarrel over the Calydonian boar, she threw the
	log into the fire, and when it was burnt up Meleager, far away,
	almost instantly died. See Bacchylides 5.93–154; \[Apollodorus\],
	[c dimgray]Library[/c] 1.8.1–3; Pausanias 10.31.4.
	[c dimgray][sup]128[/sup][/c]Scylla, daughter of Nisus king of Megara. When her city
	was besieged by Minos of Crete, she betrayed it to him by cutting
	off the purple lock on her father’s head (in some versions it is a
	single hair), without which he (or, as others tell the story, the city)
	could not survive. In other accounts (all much later; the fullest are
	in the pseudo-Virgilian [c dimgray]Ciris[/c] and Ovid, [c dimgray]Metamorphoses[/c] 8.6–151)
	Scylla is in love with Minos; here, in the absence of any pre-Aeschylean
	version of the myth, we cannot tell whether we are to
	understand the golden necklace as a love-gift or a bribe.
	[c dimgray][sup]129[/sup][/c]A play on Scylla’s name, which means “bitch-pup”.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 291[/c]

%Aeschylus Libation-Bearers
AESCHYLUS, Oresteia. Libation-Bearers
	[c darkmagenta][b]AESCHYLUS, Oresteia. Libation-Bearers[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Aeschylus[/b][/c]
	γυναικοβούλους τε μήτιδας †φρενῶν†
	ἐπ᾿ ἀνδρὶ τευχεσφόρῳ,
	†ἐπ᾿ ἀνδρὶ δηΐοις ἐπικότω σέβας†.
	τίω δ᾿ ἀθέρμαντον ἑστίαν δόμων
	[c dimgray]630[/c]γυναικείαν τ᾿ ἄτολμον αἰχμᾶν.

	[c dimgray]639 στρ. δ[/c] τόδ᾿ ἄγχι πλευμόνων ξίφος
	[c dimgray]640[/c]διανταίαν ὀξυπευκὲς οὐτᾷ
	διαὶ Δίκας—τὸ μὴ θέμις—λὰξ
	πέδον πατουμένας,
	τὸ πᾶν Διὸς σέβας παρεκ-
	[c dimgray]645[/c]βάντος οὐ θεμιστῶς.

	[c dimgray]ἀντ. δ[/c] Δίκας δ᾿ ἐρείδεται πυθμήν,
	προχαλκεύει δ᾿ Αἶσα φασγανουργός·
	τέκνον δ᾿ ἐπεισφέρει δόμοις
	[c dimgray]650[/c]αἱμάτων παλαιτέρων
	τίνειν μύσος χρόνῳ κλυτὰ
	βυσσόφρων Ἐρινύς.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]626[/sup][/c]φρενῶν Μ: θροεῖν or φράσω West.<li id="note_LCL146_294_628" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]628[/sup][/c]perh. e.g. <ὃς ἔσκε> (West) λαοῖς (Paley) ἐπίσκοπον
	(-σκόπῳ Martin) σέβας.<li id="note_LCL146_294_629" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]629[/sup][/c]τίω Portus: τίων M.<li id="note_LCL146_294_630" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]630[/sup][/c]τ᾿ Hermann: om. M.<li id="note_LCL146_294_639" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]639[/sup][/c]τόδ᾿ Young: τὸ δ᾿ M.<li id="note_LCL146_294_641" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]641[/sup][/c]οὐτᾷ Hermann: σοῦται Μ.<li id="note_LCL146_294_642" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]642[/sup][/c]θέμις H. L. Ahrens: θέμις γὰρ οὐ Μ.<li id="note_LCL146_294_643" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]643[/sup][/c]πατουμένας H. L. Ahrens: πατούμενον Μ.<li id="note_LCL146_294_644-5" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]644-5[/sup][/c]παρεκβάντος Auratus: παρεκβάντες M.<li id="note_LCL146_294_647" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]647[/sup][/c]προχαλκεύει Jacob: προσχαλκεύει M.<li id="note_LCL146_294_649-650" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]649-650[/sup][/c]δόμοις H. L. Ahrens (οἴκοις Σ[c dimgray][sup]M[/sup][/c]), αἱμάτων Σ[c dimgray][sup]M[/sup][/c]:
	διμασε δωμάτων M.<li id="note_LCL146_294_651" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]651[/sup][/c]τίνειν Lachmann: τίνει M.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 294[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Libation-Bearers[/b][/c]
	and the crafty plotting of a woman
	against a man who bore arms,
	<who was a revered guardian to his people>.
	[c dimgray][sup]137[/sup][/c]
	I honour a domestic hearth that is not made hot
	[c dimgray][sup]138[/sup][/c]
	and a woman whom power does not make audacious.
	This sword
	[c dimgray][sup]139[/sup][/c] pierces,
	sharp and penetrating, right to the lungs,
	because Justice, most wrongfully,
	is trampled underfoot to the ground,
	when someone, against all right, has utterly
	flouted the majesty of Zeus.
	But the foundations of Justice are firmly set,
	and the swordsmith Destiny is preparing the weapon;
	and a child is being imported into the house,
	to pay at last for the stain
	of older deeds of blood, by the far-famed,
	deep-thinking Fury.
	[c dimgray][sup]140[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]137[/sup][/c]The text of this line is very corrupt, and the first two words,
	ἐπ᾿ ἀνδρὶ, may have been wrongly repeated from the previous
	line; I translate the very tentative restoration offered in the textual
	note.
	[c dimgray][sup]138[/sup][/c]By dangerous passions such as made Althaea burn
	the fatal brand (604–9) or Clytaemestra embark on her affair with
	Aegisthus (cf. [c dimgray]Ag.[/c] 1435–6).
	[c dimgray][sup]139[/sup][/c]The figurative “sword” is the
	pain of beholding the murderers seemingly triumphant; cf. 184,
	380–1, [c dimgray]Eum.[/c] 135–6, 155–161.
	[c dimgray][sup]140[/sup][/c]The epithets κλυτὰ βυσσόφρων “far-famed, deep-thinking”
	seem to play on the name Κλυται-μήστρα “famous plotter”.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 295[/c]
