-146.297 (AESCHYLUS, Oresteia. Libation-Bearers)
%Aeschylus Libation-Bearers
AESCHYLUS, Oresteia. Libation-Bearers
	[c darkmagenta][b]AESCHYLUS, Oresteia. Libation-Bearers[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Aeschylus[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΟΡΕΣΤΗΣ[/b][/c]

	παῖ παῖ, θύρας ἄκουσον ἑρκείας κτύπον.
	τίς ἔνδον, ὦ παῖ; παῖ μάλ᾿ αὖ· τίς ἐν δόμοις;
	[c dimgray]655[/c]τρίτον τόδ᾿ ἐκπέραμα δωμάτων καλῶ,
	εἴπερ φιλόξεν᾿ ἐστὶν Αἰγίσθου διαί.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΘΥΡΩΡΟΣ[/b][/c]

	εἶἑν, ἀκούω. ποδαπὸς ὁ ξένος; πόθεν;
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΟΡΕΣΤΗΣ[/b][/c]

	ἄγγελλε τοῖσι κυρίοισι δωμάτων,
	πρὸς οὕσπερ ἥκω καὶ φέρω καινοὺς λόγους.
	[c dimgray]660[/c]τάχυνε δ᾿, ὡς καὶ νυκτὸς ἅρμ᾿ ἐπείγεται
	σκοτεινόν, ὥρα δ᾿ ἐμπόρους μεθιέναι
	ἄγκυραν ἐν δόμοισι πανδόκοις ξένων.
	ἐξελθέτω τις δωμάτων τελεσφόρος,
	γυνή γ᾿ ἄπαρχος—ἄνδρα δ᾿ εὐπρεπέστερον·
	[c dimgray]665[/c]αἰδὼς γὰρ ἐν λέσχαισιν οὖσ᾿ ἐπαργέμους
	λόγους τίθησιν· εἶπε θαρσήσας ἀνὴρ
	πρὸς ἄνδρα κἀσήμηνεν ἐμφανὲς τέκμαρ.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΚΛΥΤΑΙΜΗΣΤΡΑ[/b][/c]

	ξένοι, λέγοιτ᾿ ἂν εἴ τι δεῖ· πάρεστι γὰρ
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]654[/sup][/c]αὖ· τίς Schwerdt: αὖθις M.<li id="note_LCL146_296_664" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]664[/sup][/c]γ᾿ ἄπαρχος H. L. Ahrens: ταπαρχος M: τόπαρχος M[c dimgray][sup]s[/sup][/c]<li id="note_LCL146_296_665" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]665[/sup][/c]λέσχαισιν Emperius, οὖσ᾿ Bothe: λεχθεῖσιν οὐκ Μ.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 296[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Libation-Bearers[/b][/c]<span class="stage">\[[c dimgray]
	orestes[/c] and pylades re-enter, disguised as travellers
	from Phocis. orestes goes up to the palace door and begins
	to knock loudly and repeatedly.\]
	[c darkmagenta][b]orestes[/b][/c]
	Boy, boy! Can you hear the sound of the front door? Who’s
	in there, boy? Boy, I say again! Who’s at home? This is the
	third time I’m calling for someone to come out of the
	house, if Aegisthus makes it a hospitable one.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Doorkeeper \[[c dimgray]behind the door, not opening it[/c][/b][/c]
	\]All right, all right, I can hear you. Where’s the visitor from?
	Where, I say?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]orestes[/b][/c]
	Take a message to the masters of the house; I’ve come with
	news for them. And hurry, because night’s dark chariot is
	already advancing rapidly, and it’s time for travellers to
	drop anchor in houses that make all visitors welcome. Let
	someone come out who has authority in the house, the
	woman who is its mistress—but it would be more fitting for
	a man to come. When there’s bashfulness in a conversation,
	[c dimgray][sup]141[/sup][/c]
	it makes what is said obscure. A man speaking to a
	man is confident and uses words that reveal his meaning
	clearly.<span class="stage">\[[c dimgray]The door opens and clytaemestra[/c] appears, with attendants\]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Clytaemestra[/b][/c]
	Strangers, please tell me anything you need. We have here
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]141[/sup][/c]As there was almost bound to be, on both sides, in a conversation
	between a man and a woman previously unknown to each
	other.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 297[/c]

-146.299 (AESCHYLUS, Oresteia. Libation-Bearers)
%Aeschylus Libation-Bearers
AESCHYLUS, Oresteia. Libation-Bearers
	[c darkmagenta][b]AESCHYLUS, Oresteia. Libation-Bearers[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Aeschylus[/b][/c]
	ὁποῖάπερ δόμοισι τοῖσδ᾿ ἐπεικότα,
	[c dimgray]670[/c]καὶ θερμὰ λουτρὰ καὶ πόνων θελκτηρία
	στρωμνή, δικαίων τ᾿ ὀμμάτων παρουσία.
	εἰ δ᾿ ἄλλο πρᾶξαι δεῖ τι βουλιώτερον,
	ἀνδρῶν τόδ᾿ ἐστὶν ἔργον, οἷς κοινώσομεν.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΟΡΕΣΤΗΣ[/b][/c]

	ξένος μέν εἰμι Δαυλιεὺς ἐκ Φωκέων·
	[c dimgray]675[/c]στείχοντα δ᾿ αὐτόφορτον οἰκείᾳ σαγῇ
	εἰς Ἄργος, ὥσπερ δεῦρ᾿ ἀπεζύγην πόδας,
	ἀγνὼς πρὸς ἀγνῶτ᾿ εἶπε συμβαλὼν ἀνήρ,
	ἐξιστορήσας καὶ σαφηνισθεὶς ὁδόν,
	Στροφίος ὁ Φωκεύς (πεύθομαι γὰρ ἐν λόγῳ)·
	[c dimgray]680[/c]“ἐπείπερ ἄλλως, ὦ ξέν᾿, εἰς Ἄργος κίεις,
	πρὸς τοὺς τεκόντας πανδίκως μεμνημένος
	τεθνεῶτ᾿ Ὀρέστην εἰπέ, μηδαμῶς λάθῃ.
	εἴτ᾿ οὖν κομίζειν δόξα νικήσει φίλων,
	εἴτ᾿ οὖν μέτοικον, εἰς τὸ πᾶν αἰεὶ ξένον,
	[c dimgray]685[/c]θάπτειν, ἐφετμὰς τάσδε πόρθμευσον πάλιν.
	νῦν γὰρ λέβητος χαλκέου πλευρώματα
	σποδὸν κέκευθεν ἀνδρὸς εὖ κεκλαυμένου.“
	τοσαῦτ᾿ ἀκούσας εἶπον. εἰ δὲ τυγχάνω
	τοῖς κυρίοισι καὶ προσήκουσιν λέγων
	[c dimgray]690[/c]οὐκ οἶδα· τὸν τεκόντα δ᾿ εἰκὸς εἰδέναι.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]675[/sup][/c]οἰκείᾳ σαγῇ (σάγῃ) Turnebus: οἰκίαισἄγη Μ.<li id="note_LCL146_298_678" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]678[/sup][/c]σαφηνισθεὶς Heimsoeth, cf. Σ[c dimgray][sup]Μ[/sup][/c] μαθών: σαφηνίσας Μ.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 298[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Libation-Bearers[/b][/c]
	just the kinds of things that befit a house like this—hot
	baths, good bedding to soothe away your fatigue, and the
	company of honest faces. If anything else needs to be done
	that calls for more deliberation, then that is a job for men,
	and we will communicate it to them.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]orestes[/b][/c]
	I am a stranger here, from Daulia
	[c dimgray][sup]142[/sup][/c] in Phocis. I was travelling
	to Argos, carrying my own luggage on my own shoulders,
	just as I was when I arrived here,
	[c dimgray][sup]143[/sup][/c] when a man I met
	said to me—neither of us knew the other—after asking
	and being told where I was going (he was Strophius the
	Phocian, I learned his name in our conversation): “Since
	you’re bound for Argos anyway, sir, please remember carefully
	to tell his parents that Orestes is dead; don’t forget on
	any account. Whether it turns out that the preferred decision
	in his family is to bring him home, or whether it is to
	bury him as a foreign resident, a permanent and perpetual
	alien, please convey back here their instructions about
	this. The walls of a bronze urn already enfold the ashes of
	the man, who has been well wept over.” That’s all he said to
	me, and I’ve now said it too. Whether I’m actually speaking
	to the appropriate people, his relatives, I don’t know,
	but it’s proper that his father should know the news.
	[c dimgray][sup]144[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]142[/sup][/c]Daulia (or Daulis) was in eastern Phocis, not far from the
	Boeotian border and about 10 km west of Chaeronea.
	[c dimgray][sup]143[/sup][/c]lit. “just as I unyoked my feet here”.
	[c dimgray][sup]144[/sup][/c]τὸν τεκόντα δ᾿ εἰκὸς εἰδέναι could also be taken (with savage
	irony) to mean “but probably you know who his father is”.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 299[/c]

-146.301 (AESCHYLUS, Oresteia. Libation-Bearers)
%Aeschylus Libation-Bearers
AESCHYLUS, Oresteia. Libation-Bearers
	[c darkmagenta][b]AESCHYLUS, Oresteia. Libation-Bearers[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Aeschylus[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΚΛΥΤΑΙΜΗΣΤΡΑ[/b][/c]

	οἲ ᾿γώ, κατ᾿ ἄκρας †ἐνπᾶς ὡς† πορθούμεθα.
	ὦ δυσπάλαιστε τῶνδε δωμάτων Ἀρά,
	ὡς πόλλ᾿ ἐπωπᾷς κἀκποδὼν εὖ κείμενα·
	τόξοις πρόσωθεν εὐσκόποις χειρουμένη
	[c dimgray]695[/c]φίλων ἀποψιλοῖς με τὴν παναθλίαν.
	καὶ νῦν Ὀρέστης—ἦν γὰρ εὐβούλως ἔχων,
	ἔξω κομίζων ὀλεθρίου πηλοῦ πόδα·
	νῦν δ᾿ ἥπερ ἐν δόμοισι βακχείας κακῆς
	ἰατρὸς ἐλπίς ἦν, προδοῦσαν ἔγγραφε.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΟΡΕΣΤΗΣ[/b][/c]

	[c dimgray]700[/c]ἐγὼ μὲν οὖν ξένοισιν ὧδ᾿ εὐδαίμοσιν
	κεδνῶν ἕκατι πραγμάτων ἂν ἤθελον
	γνωτὸς γενέσθαι καὶ ξενωθῆναι· τί γὰρ
	ξένου ξένοισίν ἐστιν εὐμενέστερον;
	πρὸς δυσσεβείας δ᾿ ἦν ἐμοὶ τόδ᾿ ἐν φρεσίν,
	[c dimgray]705[/c]τοιόνδε πρᾶγμα μὴ καρανῶσαι φίλοις,
	καταινέσαντα καὶ κατεξενωμένον.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]691[/sup][/c]ἐνπᾶς ὡς Μ (πᾶσ᾿ Μ[c dimgray][sup]s[/sup][/c]): εἶπας ὡς Bamberger: παντελῶς
	Blaydes.<li id="note_LCL146_300_697" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]697[/sup][/c]κομίζων Σ[c dimgray][sup]M[/sup][/c]: νομίζων Μ.<li id="note_LCL146_300_698" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]698[/sup][/c]κακῆς Portus: καλῆς M.<li id="note_LCL146_300_699" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]699[/sup][/c]προδοῦσαν Pauw, ἔγγραφε Stephanus (τάξον αὐτὴν
	ἀφανισθεῖσαν Σ[c dimgray][sup]Μ[/sup][/c]): παροῦσαν ἐγγράφει Μ.<li id="note_LCL146_300_704" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]704[/sup][/c]δ᾿ ἦν Auratus, Portus: ἦν Μ.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 300[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Libation-Bearers[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Clytaemestra[/b][/c]
	Ah me, we are completely, utterly ruined!
	[c dimgray][sup]145[/sup][/c] Curse of this
	house, so hard to wrestle free of, how much you keep your
	eye on, even when it’s placed well out of the way! Scoring
	hits at long range with well-aimed arrows, you strip me,
	wretched me, of my loved ones! And now Orestes—he was
	showing wisdom in keeping his feet clear of the deadly
	mire; but now, the hope there was in the house of a cure for
	your evil revelry
	[c dimgray][sup]146[/sup][/c]—write it down as having betrayed us!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]orestes[/b][/c]
	I would have wished to make the acquaintance of such
	prosperous hosts, and to be entertained by them, as a
	bringer of good news;
	[c dimgray][sup]147[/sup][/c] for what friendship is there
	greater than that of host and guest? But I would have
	thought it an act of impiety to fail to complete such a task
	for my friends, after having agreed to and after having
	been welcomed as a guest.
	[c dimgray][sup]148[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]145[/sup][/c]lit. “entirely sacked from top to bottom” like a captured city
	(I have assumed that M’s meaningless ἐνπᾶς ὡς derives from a
	gloss which has displaced an adverb meaning “entirely”, possibly
	but not necessarily Blaydes’ παντελῶς).
	[c dimgray][sup]146[/sup][/c]For this image cf. [c dimgray]Ag.[/c] 1186–93.
	[c dimgray][sup]147[/sup][/c]lit. “on account of good events”.
	[c dimgray][sup]148[/sup][/c]This sentence is probably to be taken as having two meanings.
	Clytaemestra will understand the “task” as the job of bringing
	the message, “friends” as a generalizing plural referring to
	Strophius, and “having agreed to” as referring to a promise made
	to Strophius; for Orestes and the audience, the “task” is his revenge,
	his “friends” are his family and especially his father, and
	“having agreed to” refers to his acceptance of the task imposed on
	him by Apollo.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 301[/c]

-146.303 (AESCHYLUS, Oresteia. Libation-Bearers)
%Aeschylus Libation-Bearers
AESCHYLUS, Oresteia. Libation-Bearers
	[c darkmagenta][b]AESCHYLUS, Oresteia. Libation-Bearers[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Aeschylus[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΚΛΥΤΑΙΜΗΣΤΡΑ[/b][/c]

	οὔτοι κυρήσεις μείον᾿ ἀξίων σέθεν,
	οὐδ᾿ ἧσσον ἂν γένοιο δώμασιν φίλος.
	ἄλλος δ᾿ ὁμοίως ἦλθεν ἂν τάδ᾿ ἀγγελῶν.
	[c dimgray]710[/c]ἀλλ᾿ ἔσθ᾿ ὁ καιρὸς ἡμερεύοντας ξένους
	μακρᾶς κελεύθου τυγχάνειν τὰ πρόσφορα·
	ἄγ᾿ αὐτὸν εἰς ἀνδρῶνας εὐξένους δόμων
	ὀπισθόπουν τε τόνδε καὶ ξυνέμπορον,
	κἀκεῖ κυρούντων δώμασιν τὰ πρόσφορα.
	[c dimgray]715[/c]αἰνῶ δὲ πράσσειν ὡς ὑπευθύνῳ τάδε.
	ἡμεις δὲ ταῦτα τοῖς κρατοῦσι δωμάτων
	κοινώσομέν τε κοὐ σπανίζοντες φίλων
	βουλευσόμεσθα τῆσδε συμφορᾶς πέρι.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΧΟΡΟΣ[/b][/c]

	εἶἑν, φίλιαι δμωΐδες οἴκων,
	[c dimgray]720[/c]πότε δὴ στομάτων
	δείξομεν ἰσχὺν ἐπ᾿ Ὀρέστῃ;
	ὦ πότνια Χθὼν καὶ πότνι᾿ ἀκτὴ
	χώματος, ἣ νῦν ἐπὶ ναυάρχῳ
	σώματι κεῖσαι τῷ βασιλείῳ,
	[c dimgray]725[/c]νῦν ἐπάκουσον, νῦν ἐπάρηξον·
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]707[/sup][/c]μείον᾿ Blass, ἀξίων Σ[c dimgray][sup]M[/sup][/c]: μείων (μεῖον Μ[c dimgray][sup]pc[/sup][/c]) ἀξίως M.<li id="note_LCL146_302_713" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]713[/sup][/c]so Pauw (τε already Portus): ὀπισθόπους δὲ τούσδε καὶ
	ξυνεμπόρους M.<li id="note_LCL146_302_715" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]715[/sup][/c]ὑπευθύνῳ Turnebus (cf. Σ[c dimgray][sup]M[/sup][/c] ὑποδίκῳ): ἐπευθύνω Μ (-ωι
	M[c dimgray][sup]s[/sup][/c]).<li id="note_LCL146_302_717" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]717[/sup][/c]κοινώσομέν [c dimgray]m[/c]: κοινώσωμέν M.<li id="note_LCL146_302_718" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]718[/sup][/c]βουλευσόμεσθα Stephanus: βουλευόμεθα M.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 302[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Libation-Bearers[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Clytaemestra[/b][/c]
	You will not receive less than you deserve, nor will you be
	any less a friend to this house. Someone else would have
	come anyway to bring this news. But it’s the time when
	guests who have spent the whole day on a long journey
	should get a fitting reception. \[[c dimgray]To one of her attendants[/c]\]
	Take him to the men’s guest-quarters of the palace, together
	with this fellow-traveller who follows him, and
	there in the house let them be treated as befits them. I
	advise you to do this in the expectation of being held
	responsible.
	[c dimgray][sup]149[/sup][/c] \[[c dimgray]Turning back to orestes[/c] and pylades\]
	Meanwhile we will communicate this to the masters of the
	House
	[c dimgray][sup]150[/sup][/c] and, since we are not short of friends, we will take
	counsel about this sad event.<span class="stage">\[[c dimgray]
	clytaemestra[/c] goes into the palace, and one of her servants
	escorts orestes and pylades inside.\]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]

	Come now, dear serving-women of the house,
	when, pray, shall we display
	the power of our lips in aid of Orestes?
	O mighty Earth, O mighty mound
	of the tomb that now lies heaped
	over the corpse of the king who commanded the fleet,
	now give ear, now give aid!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]149[/sup][/c]A veiled threat of punishment if the task is not properly
	done.
	[c dimgray][sup]150[/sup][/c]The plural is a generalizing one; the actual reference is
	only to Aegisthus.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 303[/c]

	[c dimgray]730[/c]ἔοικεν ἁνὴρ ὁ ξένος τεύχειν κακόν·
	τροφὸν δ᾿ Ὀρέστου τήνδ᾿ ὁρῶ κεκλαυμένην.
	ποῖ δὴ πατεῖς, Κίλισσα, δωμάτων πύλας;

	[c darkmagenta][b]ΚΙΛΙΣΣΑ[/b][/c]

	Αἴγισθον ἡ κρατοῦσα τοῖς ξένοις καλεῖν
	[c dimgray]735[/c]ὅπως τάχιστ᾿ ἄνωγεν, ὡς σαφέστερον

	ἐλθὼν πύθηται τήνδε. πρὸς μὲν οἰκέτας
	θέτο σκυθρωπὸν ὄμμα, τόν γ᾿ ἐντὸς γέλων
	κεύθουσ᾿ ἐπ᾿ ἔργοις διαπεπραγμένοις καλῶς
	[c dimgray]740[/c]κείνῃ, δόμοις δὲ τοῖσδε παγκάκως ἔχει

	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]

	καὶ τὸν νύχιον χθόνιόν θ᾿ Ἑρ. Hartung: νύχιον δ᾿ Ἑρ. Hermann.<li id="note_LCL146_304_729" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]729[/sup][/c]τούσδ᾿ Hermann, ἐφορεῦσαι Conington: τοῖσδ᾿ ἐφοδεῦσαι M. | 734 τοῖς ξένοις Pauw: τοὺς ξένους M.<li id="note_LCL146_304_738" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]738[/sup][/c]ὄμμα, τόν γ᾿ ἐντὸς West (ὄμμα, τὸν δ᾿ ἐντὸς H. L.
	Ahrens): ἐντὸς ὀμμάτων M. | 740 ἔχει Robortello, Turnebus

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Libation-Bearers[/b][/c]
	For now is the right time for guileful Persuasion
	to enter the arena together with him, and for Hermes of
	the Night,
	Hermes of the Underworld,
	[c dimgray][sup]151[/sup][/c] to watch over these men
	in their deadly contest with the sword.<span class="stage">\[[c dimgray]
	cilissa[/c] comes out of the palace.\]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	The man from abroad seems to be causing some trouble:
	here comes Orestes’ nurse, I see, in tears. Where are you
	bound for, Cilissa,
	[c dimgray][sup]152[/sup][/c] walking over the threshold of the
	palace? Grief is your unhired fellow-traveller.
	[c dimgray][sup]153[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Cilissa[/b][/c]
	The mistress has ordered me to summon Aegisthus as
	quickly as possible to see the visitors, so that he can come
	and learn about this newly-reported information more
	clearly, man from man. In front of the servants she put on
	a sorrowful face—concealing the laughter that is underneath
	on account of the event that has come to pass, which
	is a good thing for her, but for this house things are thoroughly
	bad, as a result of the news that the visitors have reported
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]151[/sup][/c]This phrase may (or may not) have found its way into the
	text from a gloss on “Hermes of the Night”. For Hermes’ associa- tion with night, cf. [c dimgray]Homeric Hymn to Hermes[/c] 66–145, 155–6, 282–290, 358, 578.
	[c dimgray][sup]152[/sup][/c]This name indicates that the nurse is a
	native of Cilicia in south-eastern Asia Minor. She is the only ordinary
	slave (as distinct from captives of noble birth such as Cassandra)
	to be given a name in any surviving tragedy.
	[c dimgray][sup]153[/sup][/c]Someone going on a journey who did not have a suitable
	slave of his own, and wanted to have his luggage carried for him,
	might hire a man to do so (cf. Aristophanes, [c dimgray]Frogs[/c] 165–177);
	Cilissa, by contrast, is accompanied by a companion (grief) whom
	she has not hired and would rather be without.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 305[/c]

-146.307 (AESCHYLUS, Oresteia. Libation-Bearers)
%Aeschylus Libation-Bearers
AESCHYLUS, Oresteia. Libation-Bearers
	[c darkmagenta][b]AESCHYLUS, Oresteia. Libation-Bearers[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Aeschylus[/b][/c]
	ἦ δὴ κλυὼν ἐκεῖνος εὐφρανεῖ νόον,
	εὖτ᾿ ἂν πύθηται μῦθον. ὦ τάλαιν᾿ ἐγώ·
	ὥς μοι τὰ μὲν παλαιὰ συγκεκραμένα
	[c dimgray]745[/c]ἄλγη δύσοιστα τοῖσδ᾿ ἐν Ἀτρέως δόμοις
	τυχόντ᾿ ἐμὴν ἤλγυνεν ἐν στέρνοις φρένα,
	ἀλλ᾿ οὔ τί πω τοιόνδε πῆμ᾿ ἀνεσχόμην.
	τὰ μὲν γὰρ ἄλλα τλημόνως ἤντλουν κακά·
	φίλον δ᾿ Ὀρέστην, τῆς ἐμῆς ψυχῆς τριβήν,
	[c dimgray]750[/c]ὃν ἐξέθρεψα μητρόθεν δεδεγμένη,
	καὶ νυκτιπλάγκτων ὀρθίων κελευμάτων
	< | >
	καὶ πολλὰ καὶ μοχθήρ᾿ ἀνωφέλητ᾿ ἐμοὶ
	τλάσῃ· τὸ μὴ φρονοῦν γὰρ ὡσπερεὶ βοτὸν
	τρέφειν ἀνάγκη—πῶς γὰρ οὔ;—τροφοῦ φρενί·
	[c dimgray]755[/c]οὐ γάρ τι φωνεῖ παῖς ἐτ᾿ ὢν ἐν σπαργάνοις
	εἰ λιμός, ἢ δίψη τις, ἢ λιψουρία
	ἔχει· νέα δὲ νηδὺς αὐτάρχης τέκνων.
	τούτων πρόμαντις οὖσα, πολλὰ δ᾿ οἴομαι
	ψευσθεῖσα, παιδὸς σπαργάνων φαιδρύντρια,
	[c dimgray]760[/c]κναφεὺς τροφεύς τε ταὐτὸν εἰχέτην τέλος.
	ἐγὼ διπλᾶς δὴ τάσδε χειρωναξίας
	ἔχουσ᾿ Ὀρέστην ἐξεθρεψάμην πατρί·
	τεθνηκότος δὲ νῦν τάλαινα πεύθομαι.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]742[/sup][/c]ἐκεῖνος Robortello: ἐκεῖνον M.<li id="note_LCL146_306_751-2" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]751-2[/sup][/c]lacuna posited by Hermann.<li id="note_LCL146_306_754" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]754[/sup][/c]τροφοῦ φρενί Thomson: τρόπῳ φρενός M.<li id="note_LCL146_306_756" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]756[/sup][/c]εἰ Stanley: ἢ M.<li id="note_LCL146_306_757" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]757[/sup][/c]αὐτάρχης Blomfield: αὐτάρκης M.<li id="note_LCL146_306_760" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]760[/sup][/c]κναφεὺς Dobree, τροφεύς m: γναφεὺς στροφεύς M.<li id="note_LCL146_306_761" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]761[/sup][/c]δὴ Paley: δὲ M.<li id="note_LCL146_306_762" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]762[/sup][/c]ἐξεθρεψάμην Auratus or Portus: ἐξεδεξάμην M.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 306[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Libation-Bearers[/b][/c]
	very plainly. For certain, hearing it will bring joy to
	that man’s heart when he learns of the story. O wretched
	me! For I found the old griefs that have happened in this
	house of Atreus hard enough to bear, all mixed together as
	they were, and they pained my heart within my breast; but
	I have never yet had to endure a sorrow like this. Under the
	other troubles I patiently bore up. But dear Orestes, who
	wore away my life with toil, whom I reared after receiving
	him straight from his mother’s womb! <Over and over
	again I heard> his shrill, imperative cries, which forced me
	to wander around at night <and perform> many disagreeable
	tasks which I had to endure and which did me no
	good.
	[c dimgray][sup]154[/sup][/c] A child without intelligence must needs be reared
	like an animal—how could it be otherwise?—by the intelligence
	of his nurse; when he’s still an infant in swaddling
	clothes he can’t speak at all if he’s in the grip of hunger or
	thirst, say, or of an urge to make water—and the immature
	bowel of small children is its own master. I had to divine
	these things in advance, and often, I fancy, I was mistaken,
	and as cleaner of the baby’s wrappings—well, a launderer
	and a caterer were holding the same post. Practising both
	these two crafts, I reared up Orestes for his father; and
	now, to my misery, I learn that he is dead! And I’m going
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]154[/sup][/c]The loss of (probably) one line has made this sentence unintelligible
	as it stands in the text; the supplements adopted here
	are based loosely on a tentative restoration of the missing line by
	West (<πολλῶν κλυούσῃ πράγματ᾿ ἐμπέδως παρῆν>).
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 307[/c]

	[c dimgray][sup]156[/sup][/c]This passage, like several others in this ode, is almost hopelessly
	corrupt. I translate here the highly tentative restoration offered
	in the textual note, which owes much to, though it does not
	precisely follow, proposals made by Garvie in his commentary,
	particularly his suggestion that σωφ-ροσυνευ may conceal φῶς
	(cf. 131, 809–810, 863, 961) or something like it.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	Every word I have uttered has been in accordance with
	justice:

	above his foes, for if you raise him to greatness
	you will receive in return, with delight,
	twofold and threefold recompense.
	[c dimgray][sup]157[/sup][/c]
	Know that the orphaned colt yoked to the chariot
	is the son of a man you loved;

	impose a measure and
	a steady rhythm,
	that this ground
	[c dimgray][sup]158[/sup][/c] may see the <swift> striving
	<of his legs>
	[c dimgray][sup]159[/sup][/c] reach the end of the course.
	And you who within the house
	tend the inner storeroom that rejoices in its wealth,
	[c dimgray][sup]160[/sup][/c]
	hear us, gods who share our wishes!

	[c dimgray]Helen[/c] 208) and “house-floor” (e.g. [c dimgray]Iliad[/c] 4.2, [c dimgray]Odyssey[/c] 10.227).

	word or words; I translate my modification of a suggestion by

	[c darkmagenta][b]Libation-Bearers[/b][/c]
	Bring <back our master, and>
	[c dimgray][sup]161[/sup][/c]
	remove the blood of long-past deeds
	by a fresh act of justice:
	may the ancient murder breed no more in the house.
	And you who dwell at the great, well-built
	portal,
	[c dimgray][sup]162[/sup][/c] let the man’s house raise its head in happiness,
	and let it, with friendly eyes,
	behold in him the brilliant light
	of freedom, after long being veiled in darkness.
	And may the son of Maia
	[c dimgray][sup]163[/sup][/c] aid him,
	as by rights he should; for he is the best of sternwinds
	to waft an action on, if he chooses.
	He makes many obscure things plain,
	[c dimgray][sup]164[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]161[/sup][/c]The supplementation of the text, and even the meaning of
	ἄγετε, are quite uncertain; Sier, for example, proposes ἄγετε, <τῶν μέλεσθ᾿ ἐναργῶς> (“come, make manifest your concern
	with it \[the house\]”.
	[c dimgray][sup]162[/sup][/c]This god is almost certainly Apollo, and the “portal” (literally
	“mouth”) is usually identified with some feature of the sanctuary
	of Delphi; but the word στόμιον is not used elsewhere in connection
	with Delphi, the gods addressed before and after this
	stanza are closely connected with the palace (for Hermes cf. 1,
	583), and the house is strongly in the chorus’s mind throughout
	this ode (786, 790, 798, 800–1, 806, 808, 820, 835). Sier is therefore
	probably right to suppose that the chorus are addressing
	Apollo Agyieus (cf. [c dimgray]Ag.[/c] 1081) and that the “portal” is that of the
	palace.
	[c dimgray][sup]163[/sup][/c]Hermes.
	[c dimgray][sup]164[/sup][/c]For example in his roles as the guide of travellers (Hermes
	Hegemonios; cf. e.g. Theocritus 25.4–6) and the patron of interpreters
	(ἑρμηνεῖς); but this aspect of Hermes is mentioned here
	only as a foil to set off by contrast the aspect of him in which the
	chorus are really interested, his powers of deception.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 315[/c]

	of man-slaughtering cleavers are either on the point
	of bringing about the complete destruction,
	for ever, of Agamemnon’s house,
	or he
	[c dimgray][sup]172[/sup][/c] will cause fire and light to be kindled

	the governing rulership of the city
	and the great wealth of his fathers.

	[c dimgray][sup]183[/sup][/c]This line is a blend of two ideas: (i) “trying to persuade you
	is as futile as talking to the dead” (cf. Menander, [c dimgray]Dis Exapaton[/c] 28–29

	[c dimgray]logos[/c]), (ii) “I am uttering my own funeral lament while still alive”
	(cf. [c dimgray]Ag.[/c] 1322–3, [c dimgray]Supp.[/c] 117). As the first half of the play showed,

	and that oath has been duly kept. \[[c dimgray]Pointing to the robe[/c]\] Behold
	also, you who are hearing of these crimes, the contrivance
	that imprisoned my wretched father, that fettered
	his arms and bound his feet together. \[[c dimgray]To his attendants[/c]\]
	Spread it out, standing beside it in a circle, and display the
	device that made him helpless, the garment to cover a man
	which he could not strip off, in order that the Father may
	see it—I don’t mean [c dimgray]my[/c] father, but him who has been
	watching over all these events
	[c dimgray][sup]193[/sup][/c]—so that he may one day
	appear for me in a trial, to testify that I was justified in pursuing
	this killing of my mother. (I don’t count the death of
	Aegisthus; he has received the due punishment of an adulterer,
	in accordance with custom.
	[c dimgray][sup]194[/sup][/c]) \[[c dimgray]Extending an arm
	towards the robe, which has now been fully spread out[/c]\]
	What should I call it to hit on the apt word? Something to
	catch a hunted beast, or a drape to cover a corpse in its
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]193[/sup][/c]i.e. Zeus (as god of the bright sky). An ancient reader took
	the reference to be to the Sun “who sees and hears all things” ([c dimgray]Odyssey[/c]
	11.109), and his gloss was later expanded into an iambic line
	(986); but Orestes’ original intention, before he realized he might
	be misunderstood as referring to Agamemnon, was to say πατήρ
	[c dimgray]tout court[/c], and the only god who can be spoken of as πατήρ [c dimgray]tout
	court[/c], without naming him and without reference to any children
	of his, is Zeus. See West, [c dimgray]Studies[/c] 262–3 (reporting or developing
	an insight of W. S. Barrett).
	[c dimgray][sup]194[/sup][/c]An adulterer (though only, strictly speaking, if caught in
	the act) could be summarily killed by the head of the household of
	the woman he had seduced. See Lysias 1 [c dimgray]passim[/c]; Demosthenes
	23.53.
	[m1]\ [/m]

L. Ahrens: κἀνδίκου Μ.<li id="note_LCL146_340_1006" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]1006[/sup][/c]πρόσθεν Turnebus: πρόσθ᾿ Μ.

	[c darkmagenta][b]Libation-Bearers[/b][/c]
	coffin,
	[c dimgray][sup]195[/sup][/c] feet and all? No, you should call it a net, a snare,
	a hobbling-robe. This is the sort of thing that a footpad
	might get for himself, a man who led a life of beguiling
	travellers and robbing them of their money;
	[c dimgray][sup]196[/sup][/c] with this
	treacherous device, you know, he could do away with many
	men and delight
	[c dimgray][sup]197[/sup][/c] his heart greatly. But the woman who
	contrived this hateful device against her husband, when
	she had borne the weight of his children beneath her girdle—children
	who were once her friends
	[c dimgray][sup]198[/sup][/c] but are now, as
	they have shown, her deadly enemies
	[c dimgray][sup]199[/sup][/c]—what do you
	think of her? That if she were a moray-eel or a viper, she
	would make a man rot by her mere touch even though he
	had not been bitten,
	[c dimgray][sup]200[/sup][/c] such was her audacity and the wickedness
	of her mind? May I never have such a wife as that in
	my house: I would sooner die by the gods’ hand, childless!
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]195[/sup][/c]The same word (δροίτη) is used in [c dimgray]Ag.[/c] 1540 and [c dimgray]Eum.[/c] 633
	to denote the bathtub in which Agamemnon was killed.
	[c dimgray][sup]196[/sup][/c]Since this man is a murderer (ἀναιρῶν 1004) as well as a
	robber, we are probably meant to assume that he would lure travellers
	into his house, ensnare them in the robe (perhaps, as in Agamemnon’s
	case, after a bath), kill them and take their money. Such
	a figure would bear considerable resemblance to the criminals,
	preying on travellers, whom Theseus killed on his way from
	Trozen to Athens (Diodorus Siculus 4.59.2–5; Plutarch, [c dimgray]Theseus[/c]
	8–11), especially Procrustes.
	[c dimgray][sup]197[/sup][/c]lit. “warm”.
	[c dimgray][sup]198[/sup][/c]In infancy, before she had wronged them.
	[c dimgray][sup]199[/sup][/c]lit. “a hostile deadly creature”, recalling the snake of Clytaemestra’s
	dream.
	[c dimgray][sup]200[/sup][/c]Certain kinds of snake were believed to be capable of
	doing this (see e.g. \[Aristotle\], [c dimgray]On Marvellous Things Heard[/c]
	845b16–32).
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]203[/sup][/c]The wrath in question is that of Clytaemestra’s spirit

	home very shortly after the death of Clytaemestra and Aegisthus. Presumably in the lost satyr-drama [c dimgray]Proteus[/c] the seer
	Proteus will have given Menelaus predictions and instructions
	about his return (cf. [c dimgray]Odyssey[/c] 4.543–7), but we do not know how
	precise these were—and those watching the first performance of
	[c dimgray]Libation-Bearers[/c] will not have known this either.
	[c dimgray][sup]208[/sup][/c]This line almost exactly repeats [c dimgray]Ag.[/c] 1282, which referred to
	Orestes’ time in exile [c dimgray]before[/c] he returned to take his revenge.
	[c dimgray][sup]209[/sup][/c]I translate my tentative restoration, which cannot be very
	far from the sense of the lost line: the plural τάσδε κληδόνας
	makes it likely that Orestes mentioned [c dimgray]two[/c] features of the reputation
	he would leave behind him, and the chorus’s response makes
	it likely that he laid the stress on the feature that weighed against
	him.
	[c dimgray][sup]210[/sup][/c]Like the Furies on several vase-paintings from the third
	quarter of the fifth century; see Prag pll. 30a,b, 32a.
	[c dimgray][sup]211[/sup][/c]In their hair (like Gorgons; cf. [c dimgray]Prom.[/c] 798–800) and/or
	around their arms; see Prag pll. 31a,b, 32a.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 347[/c]

	Apollo took control of the shrine by force from a chthonic precursor,

	Tauris[/c] 1234–83).

	which Apollo was said to have been born, north of his temple on
	Delos.

	Apollo had landed in Boeotia ([c dimgray]Homeric Hymn to Apollo[/c] 223;
	Pindar fr. 286); for this Athenian variant, cf. Ephorus, [c dimgray]FGrH[/c] 70 F
	31b. This is the first mention of Athens, or of Athena, in the trilogy.

	2.547). The road they made was that “by which the Athenians
	now send their sacred embassy to the Pythian festival” (Ephorus
	loc.cit.); according to the scholia here, when such embassies travelled
	along the road, they were preceded by men carrying axes “as
	though to tame the land”.

	subterranean passage, is unlikely to have been practicable; even

	[c dimgray]Hecuba[/c] appears [c dimgray]above[/c] the level of the main performing
	area (cf. [c dimgray]Hecuba[/c] 30–31). An entrance from the [c dimgray]skēnē[/c], into which
	Apollo has just withdrawn to re-emerge at 179, might be confusing.
	It may thus be best to suppose that the actor simply entered
	by a side-passage (presumably the opposite one to that by which
	Orestes has just departed).

	to me, for I have been speaking to save my very soul.[c dimgray][sup]38[/sup][/c] Take
	heed, you goddesses from below the earth: I who now call
	you in your dream, I am Clytaemestra!<span class="stage italic">The furies make a whining sound.[c dimgray][sup]39[/sup][/c]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]34[/sup][/c]Here the manuscripts add two extra lines: “For the sleeping
	mind is bright with eyes, whereas in daytime mortals’ destiny is to
	have no prevision.” The second of these lines is worse than irrelevant
	(the Furies are not mortals, are not being invited to see the
	future, and would be able to see Clytaemestra’s wounds just as
	well, if not better, were they awake); and while the first might well
	in itself be acceptable, it makes so neat an antithesis with the second
	that one is almost inevitably driven to conclude that the two
	lines were written to stand together—in which case they were not
	written to stand here.
	[c dimgray][sup]35[/sup][/c]These two phrases should be taken as synonymous.
	[c dimgray][sup]36[/sup][/c]Sacrifices to chthonic divinities were made not on a raised
	altar (βωμός) but at a dug-out hearth on the ground (ἐσχάρα).
	[c dimgray][sup]37[/sup][/c]i.e. with none of the [c dimgray]upper-world[/c] gods.
	[c dimgray][sup]38[/sup][/c]Normally περὶ ψυχῆς would mean “for my life, with my life
	at stake”; but, with Clytaemestra already dead, the phrase is ambiguous
	between a metaphorical sense “on a matter of vital concern”
	and a literal, but abnormal, sense “for <the welfare of> my
	soul <in Hades>”.
	[c dimgray][sup]39[/sup][/c]This sound would be represented in Greek letters as μυ μυ
	(cf. Aristophanes, [c dimgray]Knights[/c] 10), hence the stage-direction μυγμός
	in the manuscripts.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 369[/c]

	Such are the actions of the younger gods,
	who are exercising total power, beyond what justice
	allows.
	I can see that the prophetic throne
	is dripping with gore from head to foot,
	and that the navel of earth has acquired for its own
	a horrible blood-pollution.
	Seer though he is,[c dimgray][sup]48[/sup][/c] he has polluted and defiled
	the inner sanctum of his own house—himself setting the
	pollution in motion, himself inviting it in—
	violating the laws of the gods by honouring what is
	mortal
	while annulling the ancient dispensations of destiny,[c dimgray][sup]49[/sup][/c]
	[c dimgray]and[/c] giving offence to [c dimgray]me[/c]! And he will not enable that
	man to get free:
	even if he flees beneath the earth, he will never be
	freed,
	but, polluted suppliant that he is, he will be going
	where he will get another avenger[c dimgray][sup]50[/sup][/c] on his head.

	M: οὐκ ἂρ ἀνηστῆρες (sscr. ἀνυστ-) vel sim. [c dimgray]f.[/c]<li id="note_LCL146_378_189" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]189[/sup][/c]λευσμός Casaubon: λευσμόν codd.<li id="note_LCL146_378_191" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]191[/sup][/c]ἀποπτύστου Blaydes: ἀπόπτυστοι codd.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 378[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Eumenides[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]apollo[/b][/c]
	Out, I tell you, get out of this house at once! Get away from
	my inner prophetic sanctum, in case you find yourself on
	the receiving end of a winged flashing snake[c dimgray][sup]51[/sup][/c] speeding
	from my golden bowstring, and vomit out in agony black
	foam taken from human bodies, bringing up the clots of
	blood that you have sucked. It is utterly unfitting that you
	should have the least contact with this house: you belong
	where there are head-chopping, eye-gouging judgements
	and slaughters,[c dimgray][sup]52[/sup][/c] where eunuchs are punished by the destruction
	of their children’s seed,[c dimgray][sup]53[/sup][/c] where there is mutilation
	of extremities[c dimgray][sup]54[/sup][/c] and stoning,[c dimgray][sup]55[/sup][/c] and where men moan
	with long and piteous cries after being impaled under the
	spine.[c dimgray][sup]56[/sup][/c] Do you hear what kind of festivity, detestable to
	the gods, you have a fondness for? The whole nature of
	your appearance indicates as much. Such beings ought
	properly to dwell in the den of some blood-swilling lion,
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]51[/sup][/c]A “kenning”for an arrow, which flies like a bird and bites
	like a snake.
	[c dimgray][sup]52[/sup][/c]Like most of the other atrocities mentioned in the next few
	lines, blinding and beheading were seen as “barbarian”(especially
	Persian) practices (cf. e.g. [c dimgray]Pers.[/c] 369–371; Xenophon, [c dimgray]Anabasis[/c]
	1.9.13), unknown or very rare among Greeks.
	[c dimgray][sup]53[/sup][/c]How deeply most Greeks detested the practice of castration
	(whether punitive or otherwise) is well illustrated by the story of Hermotimus and Panionius (Herodotus 8.104–6). The present
	passage seems to envisage castration being inflicted not only on a
	criminal but also on his sons (as indeed happened to Panionius);
	for the punishment of a criminal’s children, cf. Herodotus 3.119,
	7.39.2–3. The usual construal of this passage, which makes it refer
	to the castration of young boys (not as a punishment, but in order
	to sell them as eunuch slaves), is rightly criticized by M. Hendry,
	[c dimgray]Hermes[/c] 126 (1998) 380–2, though he is not responsible for the interpretation
	offered here.
	[c dimgray][sup]54[/sup][/c]Hands, feet, nose and/or ears;
	cf. Herodotus 3.69.5, 3.118.2, 3.154–5, 9.112.1.
	[c dimgray][sup]55[/sup][/c]Unlike the other practices mentioned, stoning was familiar
	to Greeks (cf. [c dimgray]Ag[/c]. 1615–6), but normally as a method of spontaneous
	lynching rather than of judicial punishment (as in the case of
	Lycides at Athens in 480/79, Herodotus 9.5).
	[c dimgray][sup]56[/sup][/c]For this form of execution, commonly used by the Persians,
	cf. Herodotus 1.128,2, 3.159.1, 4.43.6; \[Euripides,\] [c dimgray]Rhesus[/c] 512–7.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 382[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Eumenides[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	But this function has been assigned to us—
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]apollo[/b][/c]
	What is this honourable role of yours? Go on, boast of your
	noble privilege!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	We drive from their homes those who assault their mothers.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]apollo[/b][/c]
	What about a woman who slays her husband?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	That would not be a kindred murder of a person of the
	same blood.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]apollo[/b][/c]
	Truly you have held in utter contempt the pledges of Hera,
	goddess of marriage,[c dimgray][sup]60[/sup][/c] and of Zeus, and <treated> them as
	being of no account; and Cypris[c dimgray][sup]61[/sup][/c] too is cast aside in dishonour
	by this argument, she from whom come the closest,
	dearest ties that mortals have. The bed of a man and a
	woman, when hallowed by destiny,[c dimgray][sup]62[/sup][/c] is something mightier
	than an oath,[c dimgray][sup]63[/sup][/c] and Justice stands sentinel over it. If, then,
	you go easy on those who kill each other by not punishing
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]60[/sup][/c]Hera in this function bears the same epithet (τελεία) as
	Zeus “the Fulfiller”(28).
	[c dimgray][sup]61[/sup][/c]Aphrodite.
	[c dimgray][sup]62[/sup][/c]The idea is apparently that a well-matched marriage is as it
	were predestined by Μοῖρα, or (as the modern proverb has it) “made in heaven”; cf. [c dimgray]Odyssey[/c] 16.392 γήμαιθ᾿ ὅς κε πλεῖστα πόροι καὶ μόρσιμος ἔλθοι.
	[c dimgray][sup]63[/sup][/c]This implies that an oath to violate the obligations of marriage
	(such as the mutual oaths of Clytaemestra and Aegisthus, cf.
	[c dimgray]Cho[/c]. 977–9) has, or should have, no binding force; Apollo will
	later say that the same is true of any oath which, if kept, would go
	against the will of Zeus (621).
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[c darkmagenta][b]orestes[/b][/c]
	Lady Athena, I have come here on the instructions of
	Loxias. Be kind and receive this wanderer—not a suppliant
	for purification nor one with unclean hands, but weakened
	now and worn away[c dimgray][sup]66[/sup][/c] in the homes of other men and
	by journeying in their company.[c dimgray][sup]67[/sup][/c] Crossing over sea and
	land alike, obeying the oracular behests of Loxias, I have
	arrived at your house, goddess, and before your image.
	Here I shall keep vigil and await a final judgement.<span class="stage">\[[c dimgray]He sits down, clasping the image in his arms. The chorus[/c]
	enter, by the same way by which he had come. They move
	this way and that like hounds casting about in search of a
	scent, until their leader gives a cry of satisfaction.\]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	Aha! This is the clear track of the man! Follow the guidance
	of the voiceless informant! Like a hound on the trail
	of a wounded fawn, we are tracking him down by the drip
	of blood. My lungs are puffing with my long toil, which
	would have exhausted a mortal: our flock has ranged over
	every place on earth, and I have passed over the sea, in
	wingless flight, no less swiftly than a ship. And now that
	[m1]\ [/m]

	αὐθέντης the phrase αὐτουργίαι . . . probably carries simultaneously
	a second meaning, “acts of wanton wickedness” or
	the like, foreshadowing the broader jurisdiction which will be
	claimed by or for the Furies in later passages (421, 517ff, 930–1,
	950ff).
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[c dimgray][sup]94[/sup][/c]The Furies are apparently
	claiming that they do the Olympians a favour by relieving them of
	the unpleasant duty of punishing, or even inquiring into, murders
	within the family. The text, however, is very uncertain here.
	[c dimgray][sup]95[/sup][/c]Here, and in the lines that follow, the words seem to carry
	some indication of the choreography: one may picture the circle of
	dancers closing in on their victim while flapping their dark garments
	with sinister effect, then (372–4) leaping high and coming
	down hard as if to stamp the life out of him, then perhaps (375–6)
	extending a leg as if to trip up a runner.

	[c darkmagenta][b]Eumenides[/b][/c]
	by the gods? I have
	an ancient privilege, nor am I without honour,
	even though I have my assigned station beneath the
	earth
	in the sunless darkness.<span class="stage">\[[c dimgray]Enter Athena[/c], clad in armour and wearing her aegis.\][c dimgray][sup]100[/sup][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Athena[/b][/c]
	From far away I heard a cry summoning me, from the Scamander,
	where I was staking my claim to the land which
	the leaders and chiefs of the Achaeans had apportioned to
	me entirely, absolutely and for ever, a large share of the
	captured property, as a special gift set aside for the children
	of Theseus.[c dimgray][sup]101[/sup][/c] From there I have come on rapid and
	unwearied foot, not flying on wings but flapping the folds
	of my aegis.[c dimgray][sup]102[/sup][/c] Now, seeing these new visitors to my land,
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]100[/sup][/c]It is not clear whether Athena enters on foot or by means of
	the [c dimgray]mēchanē;[/c] in either case she will have appeared from the opposite
	direction to that from which Orestes and the Furies arrived.
	[c dimgray][sup]101[/sup][/c]This may refer to the Athenians in general (cf. 13, 1011)
	and/or to the actual sons of Theseus (Acamas and Demophon),
	who in the cyclic epics and in Athenian tradition (though not in
	the [c dimgray]Iliad[/c]) played a prominent part in the Trojan War (cf. [c dimgray]Little Iliad[/c]) fr. 17 West; [c dimgray]Sack of Trog[/c] fr. 6 West; Sophocles, [c dimgray]Philoctetes[/c] 562,
	Euripides, [c dimgray]Hecuba[/c] 123–9, [c dimgray]Iphigeneia at Aulis[/c] 247–252). The land referred to is usually taken to be Sigeum, a fortress near the site
	of Troy, between the Hellespont and the lowest reaches of the
	Scamander, which had once been disputed between Athens and
	Mytilene (Herodotus 5.94–95); in the early fifth century it was a
	Persian possession, but Athenian forces had seen action there in
	465/4 ([c dimgray]The Athenian Agora[/c] xvii 1.32, 119) and by 451/0 Sigeum
	was a member of the Athenian alliance ([c dimgray]IG[/c] i[c dimgray][sup]3[/sup][/c] 17).
	[c dimgray][sup]102[/sup][/c]Athena’s aegis is represented in art as a garment (now
	short, now long, and often scaly) fringed with tassels or with
	snakes, either worn over the shoulders or hung over the left arm.
	In the manuscripts there follows a line (“yoking this chariot to
	colts in their prime”) which implies, contrary to 403, that Athena
	entered in a horse-drawn vehicle; this was doubtless written to replace
	404 for a production in which her entrance was staged in
	that way.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 405[/c]

	the earth we are called the Curses.[c dimgray][sup]103[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Athena[/b][/c]
	I now know your parentage, and the name by which you
	are called . . . .
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	And you will soon learn my privileges also.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Athena[/b][/c]
	I would, if someone gave me a clear account of them.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	We drive from their homes those who kill human beings.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]103[/sup][/c]This and [c dimgray]Seven[/c] 70 (Ἀρά τ᾿ Ἐρινὺς πατρός) are the only
	passages in which the Furies (Erinyes) are explicitly given the
	name “Curses” (Ἀραί). In Homer, however, the Erinyes appear
	most frequently as the divine embodiments of a curse, especially
	the curse of a wronged parent ([c dimgray]Iliad[/c] 9.454, 571; 21.412; [c dimgray]Odyssey[/c]
	2.135, 11.280).
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Eumenides[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Athena[/b][/c]
	And where does the killer’s flight end?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Athena[/b][/c]

	this man?
	[m1]\ [/m]

	mother.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Athena[/b][/c]
	Was that because of compulsion, or because he was in fear
	of someone’s wrath?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	Why, what goad is there so powerful that it can drive one to
	commit matricide?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Athena[/b][/c]
	Two parties are present: I have had only half the story.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	He will not accept our oath, nor be willing to offer his
	own.[c dimgray][sup]104[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]104[/sup][/c]The Furies are, in effect, challenging Orestes to a contest
	of oaths: they will swear that he killed his mother, and he must
	swear that he did not or, if he refuses to do so, lose his case.
	Orestes, of course, could not possibly accept this challenge, and Athena—taking note, no doubt, of how the Furies evaded her
	very pertinent question about what caused Orestes to act as he
	did—perceives that the challenge is a ploy designed to secure
	Orestes’ condemnation on an issue which is not in dispute
	(whether Orestes actually killed his mother) while avoiding the
	issue which [c dimgray]is[/c] in dispute (whether the killing was justified or excusable).
	On the oath-challenge procedure in classical Athenian
	courts see D. C. Mirhady, [c dimgray]CQ[/c] 41 (1991) 78–83.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[c dimgray][sup]441[/sup][/c]μὴ ᾿ν West: ἐν M[c dimgray][sup]s[/sup][/c] [c dimgray]f[/c]: om. M (leaving 6–7 letter spaces
	blank).<li id="note_LCL146_412_445" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]445[/sup][/c]ἔχων Wieseler: ἔχει codd.<li id="note_LCL146_412_446" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]446[/sup][/c]ἐφεζόμην Wieseler: ἐφεζομένη codd.<li id="note_LCL146_412_450" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]450[/sup][/c]-ωσι νεοθήλου Turnebus: -ουσιν οθήλου (οθηλοῦ M[c dimgray][sup]ac[/sup][/c])

	[c dimgray]Page number 412[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Eumenides[/b][/c]
	a suppliant deserving respect, not one after the manner
	of Ixion.[c dimgray][sup]105[/sup][/c] To all this, give me a reply that I can readily
	understand.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]orestes[/b][/c]
	Lady Athena, I will begin from your last words by removing
	a great anxiety. I am not a suppliant seeking purification,
	and I have not sat down clasping your image with pollution
	on my hand. I will give you powerful proof of this.
	It is the law that a man who has committed homicide
	must not speak until blood has dripped over him from the
	slaughter of a young sucking beast at the hands of a man
	who can cleanse blood-pollution. I have long since been
	purified in this way at other houses,[c dimgray][sup]106[/sup][/c] both by animal victims
	and by flowing streams.[c dimgray][sup]107[/sup][/c] That is what I say to set this
	anxiety aside; now you will quickly learn my origin. I am an
	Argive, and you know my father well—Agamemnon, commander
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]105[/sup][/c]Ixion, who had murdered his father-in-law (treacherously
	and without provocation, in order to avoid paying his just debts),
	supplicated Zeus for purification, was granted it, and proved himself
	utterly unworthy of this divine favour by attempting to seduce
	Hera: see Pindar, [c dimgray]Pythian[/c] 2.21–48 (with scholia) and Diodorus Siculus 4.69.3–5. A suppliant “with trust in justice \[and\] deserving
	respect” would thus certainly not be one “after the manner of
	Ixion” (and hence I have adopted West’s tentative insertion of a
	negative in the text—see [c dimgray]Studies[/c] 280–1); and Orestes evidently
	also detects in Athena’s words some concern as to whether he, like
	Ixion, is still under blood-pollution, as one would [c dimgray]prima facie[/c]
	expect a suppliant homicide to be.
	[c dimgray][sup]106[/sup][/c]The plurals οἴκοισι . . . βοτοῖσι . . . πόροις indicate that
	Orestes is claiming to have been ritually purified not only at Delphi
	but also at one or more (unspecified) other locations. There
	was a local tradition of such a purification at Trozen (Pausanias
	2.31.4) and there may well have been other such traditions elsewhere.
	[c dimgray][sup]107[/sup][/c]Water as well as blood was used in purification rites; see R.
	Parker, [c dimgray]Miasma[/c] (Oxford, 1983) 226–7.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 413[/c]

Schmidt: καὶ μὴ τυχοῦσαι codd.<li id="note_LCL146_416_481" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]481[/sup][/c]so codd. (δὲ <δὴ> [c dimgray]z[/c], ἀμηχάνων E): πέμπειν αὐτὰς ἀμηνίτως
	δυσχερές ἐστιν ἐμοί Σ[c dimgray][sup]M[/sup][/c]: τε for δὲ Bourdelot: δυσπήμαντ᾿
	Scaliger, δυσπάλαμν᾿ Hartung: ἀμηνίτως ἐμοί Tyrwhitt: perh. τ᾿
	ἀμηνίτως ἐμοὶ δυσμήχανα.<li id="note_LCL146_416_483" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]483[/sup][/c]αἰδουμένους Conington: αἱρουμένους codd.<li id="note_LCL146_416_486" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]486[/sup][/c]ὀρθώματα Pauw: ὁρκώματα codd. (in M κώ is written
	over an erasure).<li id="note_LCL146_416_489" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]489[/sup][/c]placed here by M: in [c dimgray]f[/c] it follows 485.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 416[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Eumenides[/b][/c]
	have an allotted function that is hard to dismiss, and if
	they do not get a victorious outcome, the poison that will
	afterwards fall from their outraged pride into the soil will
	be an unbearable, unending plague for this land. That is
	how it is: both options, to let you remain or to send you
	away,[c dimgray][sup]112[/sup][/c] are very hard for me to take without incurring
	wrath.[c dimgray][sup]113[/sup][/c] Nevertheless, since this matter has fallen upon us
	here, I shall choose for my city men without fault to be
	judges of homicide, respecting the ordinance of an oath
	which I shall establish for all time. \[[c dimgray]Addressing both
	orestes[/c] and the chorus\]Will you please collect[c dimgray][sup]114[/sup][/c] testimonies
	and proofs as supporting props for your pleas; I will
	come back when I have chosen the best among my citizens
	to decide this issue well and truly, not being led by unrighteous
	thoughts to violate their oath in any way at all.<span class="stage">\[[c dimgray]Exit Athena[/c].\]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]112[/sup][/c]This must be addressed to Orestes (cf. 473), not the Furies:
	the possibility that the Furies may remain in Athens is not raised
	by anyone until 711 at least, and perhaps not until 804–7.
	[c dimgray][sup]113[/sup][/c]This is the meaning given by the scholia and required by
	the context; but while ἀμηνίτως can be restored with confidence,
	there is no simple emendation of the unmetrical δυσπήματ᾿ that
	gives the required sense (except Hartung’s δυσπάλαμν᾿—but
	δυσπάλαμνος is nowhere attested, and εὐπάλαμνος not till
	Byzantine times). My tentative emendation is based on an earlier
	suggestion by Thomson (δυσμήχανον πέμπειν τ᾿ ἀμηνίτως ἐμοί).
	Athena will incur the Furies’ wrath if she decides in
	Orestes’ favour, and the wrath of the betrayed suppliant (cf. 233–
	4) if she decides against him.
	[c dimgray][sup]114[/sup][/c]lit. “summon”.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[c darkmagenta][b]Eumenides[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]

	Now comes the overthrow of ordained
	laws, if the injurious cause
	of this slayer of his mother
	is going to prevail.
	This event will at once unite
	all mortals in total licentiousness.
	Many very real sufferings,
	wounds inflicted by their children, await parents
	in the future, as time passes.
	For no one will be assailed by wrath arising from such
	deeds,
	not even the wrath of us wild beings
	who watch all that mortals do:
	I will unleash every kind of death upon them.
	Proclaiming loudly the evils that have befallen their
	neighbours,
	they will search eagerly far and wide[c dimgray][sup]115[/sup][/c]
	for something to end or abate their troubles,
	but the remedies they prepare will not be efficacious
	and their efforts to allay the plague will be vain.
	And let no one call on us
	when struck by disaster,
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]115[/sup][/c]lit. “one from one place, another from another”.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	crying out these words,
	“O Justice,
	O mighty Furies!”[c dimgray][sup]116[/sup][/c]
	Some father perhaps
	or some mother who has just become a victim
	may well lament this lament,
	since the house of Justice will have fallen.
	There is a proper place for the fear-inspiring,
	and for fear to sit high
	in the soul as its overseer:
	it is beneficial
	to learn good sense under the pressure of distress.
	What man that does not at all nourish
	his heart on <fear>[c dimgray][sup]117[/sup][/c]—
	or what community of men, it makes no difference—
	will still revere Justice?
	Do not praise
	either a life of anarchy
	or a life under despotism:
	in everything god has given pre-eminence to the mean,
	though he governs different spheres in different
	ways.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]

	this (cf. 699).

	[c darkmagenta][b]Eumenides[/b][/c]
	I speak a word that fits together with that:
	Outrage is in very truth the child of Impiety,
	but from a healthy mind
	springs prosperity, dear to all
	and much prayed for.
	I say to you, as a universal rule:
	respect the altar of Justice,
	and do not,
	with a view to gain, spurn and trample it with godless
	foot, for punishment will follow:
	the appointed end awaits.
	In view of this, let everyone give proper honour to the
	sanctity of parents
	and be respectful
	of the honour due to guests
	from one who is master of a house.
	In this way he will be righteous without painful
	compulsion,
	will not fail to enjoy prosperity,
	and will never come to utter destruction.
	But he, I say, who audaciously acts contrary to this,
	lawlessly
	carrying a heavy cargo[c dimgray][sup]118[/sup][/c] heaped up in confusion, against
	justice,
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[c dimgray][sup]118[/sup][/c]i.e. amassing great wealth; for the image of the rich man as
	sea-captain cf. [c dimgray]Ag[/c]. 1005–13.

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 426[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Eumenides[/b][/c]
	to the host. For now that this council is being convened, it
	will be helpful if all are silent and attentive to my ordinances—
	both the whole city for all time to come[c dimgray][sup]123[/sup][/c] and
	also these men \[[c dimgray]indicating the judges[/c]\],[c dimgray][sup]124[/sup][/c] so that the case
	may be properly decided.<span class="stage">\[[c dimgray]The trumpet is sounded, and the herald is about to make
	his proclamation when he is forestalled by the unexpected
	arrival of Apollo[/c].\]Lord Apollo, rule over your own domain. Say what concern
	you have with this dispute.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]apollo[/b][/c]
	I have come to bear witness—for this man is a lawful suppliant
	who came to the hearth of my house, and it was I
	who purified him from the taint of homicide—and also to
	speak myself as his advocate. I bear the responsibility for
	the killing of this man’s mother. Do you please bring this
	case before the court, and determine it to the best of your
	wisdom.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Athena \[[c dimgray]to the chorus[/c][/b][/c]
	\]It is for you to speak; I do hereby bring the case before the
	court. The prosecutor, if he speaks first and tells the tale
	from the beginning, can give us proper information about
	the case.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]123[/sup][/c]i.e. the theatre audience.
	[c dimgray][sup]124[/sup][/c]Grammatically speaking, τούσδ᾿ could also denote the par- ties to the case (Orestes and the Furies). When, though, Athena
	finally delivers the speech embodying her “ordinances” (681–710;
	note its opening, κλύοιτ᾿ ἂν ἤδη θεσμόν), she does not address
	the parties at all: her first and last lines (681–2, 708b-710) are addressed
	to the judges, and the rest of the speech to “my citizens for
	the future” (707–8).

	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]613[/sup][/c]δοκῶ van Herwerden: δοκεῖ M.<li id="note_LCL146_432_615" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]615[/sup][/c]ὢν δ᾿ Canter: δ᾿ ὢν M.<li id="note_LCL146_432_618" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]618[/sup][/c]’κέλευσε Porson: κελεύσει M.

	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	How else did she nourish you, you filthy murderer, beneath
	her girdle?[c dimgray][sup]127[/sup][/c] Do you disavow your mother’s blood,
	the nearest and dearest to your own?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]orestes \[[c dimgray]turning to Apollo[/c][/b][/c]
	\]Testify now for me, Apollo, and expound whether I killed
	her with justice. That I did the deed, as is the fact, I do not
	deny; but judge this bloodshed, whether I seem in your
	eyes to have done it justly or not, so that I may tell this
	court.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Apollo \[[c dimgray]to the court[/c][/b][/c]
	\]I shall say to you, to this great institution ordained by
	Athena, “justly”; and, as a seer, I shall not be telling a lie. I
	have never said anything on my prophetic throne—not
	about a man, not about a woman, not about a city—except
	at the bidding of Zeus, father of the Olympians. I tell you
	solemnly to understand well how strong is this plea of justification,
	and I tell you to follow the counsel of the Father;
	for an oath can in no way be stronger than Zeus.[c dimgray][sup]128[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	Zeus, according to you, gave you this oracle to tell to this
	man Orestes, that in avenging the murder of his father he
	should take no account at all of the rights of his mother?
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]127[/sup][/c]It was believed that the embryo received nourishment
	through blood-vessels in the umbilical cord, whose origin was in
	the mother’s heart or liver (Empedocles A79 D-K; Aristotle, [c dimgray]De
	Generatione Animalium[/c] 740a24–36).
	[c dimgray][sup]128[/sup][/c]This can only be a thinly veiled recommendation to the
	judges to disregard their oath to judge fairly between the parties
	(contrast 680, 710).

	oratory. Usually they are said to have been attempting to

	her homeland in an earlier expedition, but there was another tradition
	(cf. Lysias 2.4–6) according to which their invasion was an
	unprovoked act of aggression. There was a sanctuary called the
	Amazoneion on the alleged site of the Amazons’ camp on the
	Areopagus (Diodorus Siculus 4.28.2–3; Cleidemus, [c dimgray]FGrH[/c] 323 F
	18).

	the existing citadel, and sacrificed to Ares, whence this
	crag and hill was given the name of the Areopagus.[c dimgray][sup]147[/sup][/c]
	Upon it, the respect and inborn fear of the citizens will
	prevent any wrong being done,[c dimgray][sup]148[/sup][/c] alike by day and by
	night, if the citizens themselves do not make innovative
	additions to the laws: if you sully clear water with foul infusions
	of mud, you will never get a drink.[c dimgray][sup]149[/sup][/c] I counsel my
	citizens to maintain, and practise reverently, a system
	which is neither anarchic nor despotic, and not to cast fear
	completely out of the city; for what mortal respects justice,
	if he fears nothing? If, I tell you, you righteously fear an august
	body like this, you will have a bulwark to keep your
	land and city safe such as no one in the world has, neither
	among the Scythians nor in the land of Pelops.[c dimgray][sup]150[/sup][/c] This
	council, untouched by thought of gain, reverend, quick to
	anger, a wakeful sentinel for the land to protect those who
	sleep, I hereby establish. I have made this long speech to
	advise my citizens for the future. Now \[[c dimgray]to the judges[/c]\] you
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]147[/sup][/c]This aetiology for the name of the Areopagus appears to
	have been invented by Aeschylus; most of our other sources (start- ing with Euripides, [c dimgray]Electra[/c] 1258–62) derive the name from the
	trial of Ares for killing Halirrothius, son of Poseidon.
	[c dimgray][sup]148[/sup][/c]The text could mean that the citizenry will be deterred
	from wrongdoing by their respect for, and fear of, the Areopagus
	council, or, equally well, that the council will be deterred from
	wrongdoing by its respect for, and fear of, the citizenry.
	[c dimgray][sup]149[/sup][/c]On possible interpretations of these lines as commenting
	on contemporary political issues, see Introduction.
	[c dimgray][sup]150[/sup][/c]i.e. the Peloponnese, in particular its most powerful state
	Sparta (Aeschylus seems to have forgotten that Athens’ new ally
	Argos was also in the Peloponnese). Both Scythians (e.g. \[Aesch.\]
	fr. 198) and Spartans (e.g. Herodotus 1.65–66, Thucydides 1.18.1)
	were famous for having good laws and faithfully abiding by them
	(εὐνομία).

	judges goes to the urns, casts his vote, and returns to his
	seat[/c].\]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	And I advise you strictly to avoid dishonouring us, for we
	can be dangerous company to this land.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]apollo[/b][/c]
	And [c dimgray]I[/c] bid you fear the oracles that came from me and Zeus,
	and not render them fruitless.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	You involve yourself with bloodstained activities when that
	is not your allotted province; in future you will be giving
	responses dwelling in an unclean oracular sanctuary.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]apollo[/b][/c]
	Are you saying that my Father is at all disappointed in the
	decision he made when Ixion, the first murderer, supplicated
	him for purification?[c dimgray][sup]151[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	You say he isn’t; but if I don’t get justice, I shall be dangerous
	company to this land in future.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]apollo[/b][/c]
	You receive no honour among either the younger or the
	older gods. I am going to be victorious.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]151[/sup][/c]The Furies surprisingly miss an open goal here; see note on
	441.

	[c darkmagenta][b]Eumenides[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Athena[/b][/c]
	You are [c dimgray]not[/c] dishonoured! And do not yield to excessive anger
	and, goddesses that you are, afflict mortals with an evil
	canker on their land. I for my part have trust in Zeus,
	and—what need have I to say more?—and, alone among
	the gods, I know the keys to the chamber in which his
	thunderbolt is sealed up. But there is no need for that. Be
	readily persuaded by me: do not loose off against this land
	the words of a foolish tongue, saying that no fruit-bearing
	things shall thrive. Lull to rest the bitter force of the black
	surge; think of yourselves as being held in august honour
	and as sharers of my home. From this land, mighty as it
	shall be, you will for ever receive the first-fruits, sacrifices
	before childbirth and before the completion of marriage,
	and you will thank me for these words.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]

	That I should be treated so—
	ah!—
	I, the old and wise, and should dwell in this land,
	dishonoured—ah!—and abhorred!
	I breathe out total fury and total wrath!
	Oioi, dah, pheu!
	What is this pain that penetrates my side?
	Hear me, O mother Night!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 459[/c]

	[c dimgray][sup]169[/sup][/c]lit. “from men and processions of women”.
	[c dimgray][sup]170[/sup][/c]i.e. influences that sharpen in men’s hearts the spirit of
	wrathful violence. The denunciation of civil war, which begins
	here and continues till 866, appears to be a last-minute addition
	by the poet to an already completed script. It makes this speech of
	Athena’s substantially longer than her three others in this scene,
	and τοιαῦτ᾿ in 867 refers back not to what now directly precedes
	it, but to 854–7; on the other hand the passage cannot be a post-
	Aeschylean interpolation, since there is no post-Aeschylean date
	to which its message, which deplores civil war [c dimgray]but positively encourages
	external war[/c] (864), would be appropriate. See E. R.
	Dodds, [c dimgray]PCPS[/c] 6 (1960) 23–24 = [c dimgray]The Ancient Concept of Progress[/c]
	(Oxford, 1973) 51–52.

	[c dimgray]890[/c]ἔξεστι γάρ σοι τῆσδε γαμόρῳ χθονὸς
	εἶναι δικαίως εἰς τὸ πᾶν τιμωμένῃ.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΧΟΡΟΣ[/b][/c]

	ἄνασσ᾿ Ἀθάνα, τίνα με φὴς ἕξειν ἕδραν;

	[c dimgray]895[/c]ὡς μή τιν᾿ οἶκον εὐθενεῖν ἄνευ σέθεν.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	σὺ τοῦτο πράξεις, ὥστ᾿ ἐμὲ σθένειν τόσον;

	καί μοι πρόπαντος ἐγγύην θήσει χρόνου;

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]890[/sup][/c]τῆσδε E: τῇδε M G F [c dimgray]z[/c].<li id="note_LCL146_464_892" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]892[/sup][/c]ἕξειν Elmsley: ἔχειν codd.<li id="note_LCL146_464_895" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]895[/sup][/c]εὐθενεῖν Scaliger: εὐσθενεῖν codd.<li id="note_LCL146_464_898" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]898[/sup][/c]πρόαντος Abresch: πρὸ παντὸς codd.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 464[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Eumenides[/b][/c]
	are wandering in dishonour, banished from this land by
	me, young as I am, and the men who inhabit my city. If you
	have reverence for the awesome power of Persuasion, the
	charm and enchantment of my tongue—\[[c dimgray]with a change of
	tone[/c]\] well, anyway, please do stay. But if you prefer not to,
	it would be unjust for you to let fall on this city any wrath,
	or any anger, or any harm to its people; for you have the opportunity
	to be a landholder in this country, and be justly
	honoured for ever.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	Lady Athena, what abode do you say I am to have?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Athena[/b][/c]
	One that is free from all pain and distress. Please accept it.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	Suppose I do accept it: what privilege awaits me?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Athena[/b][/c]
	That no house will prosper without your aid.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	[c dimgray]You[/c] will bring that about, so as to give [c dimgray]me[/c] such great
	power?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Athena[/b][/c]
	Yes, I will uphold the fortunes of those who revere you.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	And you will guarantee me this for all future time?

	[c dimgray]900[/c]θέλξειν μ᾿ ἔοικας, καὶ μεθίσταμαι κότου.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]ΑΘΗΝΑΙΑ[/b][/c]

	τοιγὰρ κατὰ χθόν᾿ οὖσ᾿ ἐπικτήσῃ φίλους.

	τί οὖν μ᾿ ἄνωγας τῇδ᾿ ἐφυμνῆσαι χθονί;
	[m1]\ [/m]

	ὁποῖα νίκης μὴ κακῆς ἐπίσκοπα,
	καὶ ταῦτα γῆθεν ἔκ τε ποντίας δρόσου
	[c dimgray]905[/c]ἐξ οὐρανοῦ τε· κἀνέμων ἀήματα
	εὐηλίως πνέοντ᾿ ἐπιστείχειν χθόνα·
	καρπόν τε γαίας καὶ βοτῶν ἐπίρρυτον
	ἀστοῖσιν εὐθενοῦντα μὴ κάμνειν χρόνῳ·
	καὶ τῶν βροτείων σπερμάτων σωτηρίαν.
	[c dimgray]910[/c]τῶν δ᾿ εὐσεβούντων ἐκφορωτέρα πέλοις·
	στέργω γάρ, ἀνδρὸς φιτυποίμενος δίκην,
	τὸ τῶν δικαίων τῶνδ᾿ ἀπένθητον γένος.
	τοιαῦτά σοὔστι· τῶν ἀρειφάτων δ᾿ ἐγὼ
	πρεπτῶν ἀγώνων οὐκ ἀνέξομαι τὸ μὴ οὐ
	[c dimgray]915[/c]τήνδ᾿ ἀστύνικον ἐν βροτοῖς τιμᾶν πόλιν.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]907[/sup][/c]βοτῶν anon.: βροτῶν codd.<li id="note_LCL146_466_910" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]910[/sup][/c]δ᾿ εὐσεβούντων
	Heath: δυσσεβούντων [c dimgray]f[/c]: δυσσεβούντων δ᾿ M.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 466[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Eumenides[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Athena[/b][/c]
	Yes, I am free not to promise what I will not fulfil.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	I think you are going to charm me, and I am moving away
	from my anger.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Athena[/b][/c]
	That means that you are going to stay in this land and gain
	new friends.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]
	So what blessings do you bid me invoke upon this land?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Athena[/b][/c]
	Such as are appropriate to an honourable victory, coming
	moreover both from the earth, and from the waters of the
	sea, and from the heavens; and for the gales of wind to
	come over the land breathing the air of bright sunshine;
	and for the fruitfulness of the citizens’ land and livestock to
	thrive in abundance, and not to fail with the passage of
	time; and for the preservation of human seed.[c dimgray][sup]173[/sup][/c] But may
	you give greater fertility to those who are pious; for like a
	shepherd of plants,[c dimgray][sup]174[/sup][/c] I cherish the race to which these
	righteous men[c dimgray][sup]175[/sup][/c] belong. Such things as these are for you
	to grant; for my part, I would find it unendurable not to
	honour this city among men by making her a city of victory
	in glorious martial struggles.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]173[/sup][/c]Probably meaning that women may be granted safe, fullterm
	pregnancy and live birth.
	[c dimgray][sup]174[/sup][/c]i.e. a cultivator who feels the same personal bond to each
	one of his plants that a shepherd feels to each animal in his flock;
	this would particularly apply to Attica’s many growers of grapes,
	olives and figs.
	[c dimgray][sup]175[/sup][/c]Probably referring to the members of the Areopagus
	Council (“the best among my citizens”, 487); Athena will no doubt
	have made her meaning clear by a gesture.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Eumenides[/b][/c]

	I will accept a residence with Pallas,
	and I will not dishonour the city

	and Ares—the guard-post of the gods,
	the protector of their altars, the delight

	for which city I pray,

	It is out of goodwill towards my citizens
	that I do this, inviting these great divinities,
	hard to please, to settle here.

	does not know whence come the blows that fall upon his

	age, but much to the Athens of Aeschylus’ day, which claimed
	to have defended, and to be taking vengeance on behalf of, the
	gods and their sanctuaries against the sacrilegious Persians who
	had looted and destroyed temples and altars in Athens and in
	many other places (cf. [c dimgray]Persians[/c] 809–812).
	[c dimgray][sup]177[/sup][/c]The transmitted text would give the absurd meaning “And
	he who does not meet with their hostility . . .”

	hale him before them,[c dimgray][sup]178[/sup][/c] and silent destruction,

	crushes him because of their hostile wrath.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]

	And may no wind bringing harm to trees—
	I declare my own gracious gift—
	blow scorching heat that robs plants of their buds:
	let that not pass the borders of the land.
	Nor let any grievous, crop-destroying
	plague come upon them;
	may their flocks flourish, and may Pan[c dimgray][sup]179[/sup][/c]
	rear them to bear twin young
	at the appointed time; and may their offspring always
	have riches in their soil, and repay
	the lucky find granted them by the gods.[c dimgray][sup]180[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Athena \[[c dimgray]to the members of the Areopagus council[/c][/b][/c]
	\]
	Bulwark of the city, do you hear
	what these words are accomplishing?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]178[/sup][/c]This does not mean that the Furies will be punishing innocent
	Athenians for the sins of their ancestors; that is not something Athena would welcome, particularly after having saved a non-
	Athenian matricide from their wrath. The sentence should be
	read in the light of the assumption that children can be expected
	to inherit the character and dispositions of their parents (cf. 910–
	2, [c dimgray]Ag[/c]. 727–8, etc.); we have seen examples earlier in the trilogy—
	Atreus and Agamemnon were both child-killers, Thyestes and
	Aegisthus both adulterers. See A. F. Garvie, [c dimgray]Aeschylus: Choephori[/c]
	(Oxford, 1986) xxviii.
	[c dimgray][sup]179[/sup][/c]The god of shepherds (cf. [c dimgray]Homeric Hymn[/c] 19).
	[c dimgray][sup]180[/sup][/c]The reference is to the silver mines of Laurium (cf. [c dimgray]Pers[/c].
	238); the Athenians will “repay” the gods’ gift by using part of it to
	finance sacrifices and/or by depositing in sacred treasuries what is
	not required for current expenditure.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 471[/c]

	πάντᾳ τιμιώταται θεῶν.

	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]953[/sup][/c]φανέρ᾿ ὡς Meineke: φανερῶς codd.<li id="note_LCL146_472_954" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]954[/sup][/c]δακρύων [c dimgray]z[/c]: κρύων M [c dimgray]f[/c].<li id="note_LCL146_472_960" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]960[/sup][/c]κῦρος Heyse: κύρι᾿ M[c dimgray][sup]pc[/sup][/c]: κ* ρι᾿ M[c dimgray][sup]ac[/sup][/c]: κύριες [c dimgray]f[/c].<li id="note_LCL146_472_961" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]961[/sup][/c]θεαὶ τῶν codd.: θεαί τ᾿ ὦ Hermann: θεοὶ καὶ Butler.<li id="note_LCL146_472_964" class="note text">[c dimgray][sup]964[/sup][/c]μετάκοινοι Turnebus: μεγάκοινοι [c dimgray]f[/c]: μέγακοινοι M.

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Eumenides[/b][/c]
	For the august Fury has great power
	among the immortals and among those beneath the
	earth;[c dimgray][sup]181[/sup][/c]
	and as regards humans it is manifest how decisively
	they effect their will, furnishing
	to some joyful song,
	to others a life
	dim-eyed with tears.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]

	I forbid the misfortunes
	that make men die before their time,
	and ask you to grant that lovely young women
	live and get husbands, you gods who rightfully
	possess that power[c dimgray][sup]182[/sup][/c] and you Fates,
	our sisters, children of the same mother,[c dimgray][sup]183[/sup][/c]
	divinities just in apportionment,
	sharers in every house,[c dimgray][sup]184[/sup][/c]
	of weighty power at all times,
	in every way the most highly honoured of gods
	in their righteous visitations.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]181[/sup][/c]This phrase may denote either the chthonic gods (in which
	case “the immortals”, like “the gods” in 644 and elsewhere, will refer
	to the heavenly gods only) or the souls of the dead in Hades.
	[c dimgray][sup]182[/sup][/c]I translate Butler’s conjecture; the gods meant are presumably
	Zeus and Hera, the patrons of marriage, and perhaps also
	Aphrodite (cf. 213–6, and 217 for the Fates’ connection with marriage).
	[c dimgray][sup]183[/sup][/c]The Fates are children of Night (with no father) in Hesiod,
	[c dimgray]Theogony[/c] 217.
	[c dimgray][sup]184[/sup][/c]Because the continuity of every οἶκος depends upon marriage
	and birth, with both of which the Fates are closely connected.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 473[/c]

	[c darkmagenta][b]Eumenides[/b][/c]

	Now, I declare, that they are accomplishing
	these things, in goodwill towards my country,
	I rejoice; and I am happy that the eyes of Persuasion
	watched over my tongue and lips[c dimgray][sup]185[/sup][/c]
	when they responded to these beings who were savagely
	rebuffing me.
	Yes, Zeus of Assemblies[c dimgray][sup]186[/sup][/c] has triumphed;
	and my struggle in the cause of good
	has won a victory that will last for ever.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]chorus[/b][/c]

	I pray that civil strife,
	insatiate of evil,
	may never rage in this city;
	and may the dust not drink up the dark blood of the
	citizens
	and then, out of lust for revenge,
	eagerly welcome the city’s ruin
	through retaliatory murder;[c dimgray][sup]187[/sup][/c]
	rather may they give happiness in return for happiness,
	resolved to be united in their friendship
	and unanimous in their enmity;
	for this is a cure for many ills among men.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]185[/sup][/c]i.e, that the goddess Persuasion (Peitho) blessed and
	guided my speech.
	[c dimgray][sup]186[/sup][/c]Zeus Agoraios, whose altar, at Athens, stood not only in the
	Agora (market-place) but also on the Pnyx where the citizen as- sembly (ἐκκλησία) held its meetings (cf. scholia to Aristophanes,
	[c dimgray]Knights[/c] 410).
	[c dimgray][sup]187[/sup][/c]In [c dimgray]Choi.[/c] 400–2 it was said that the murder-victim’s blood,
	spilt on the ground, “demand\[s\]” the shedding of other blood in
	requital: here similar emotions and desires are ascribed to the
	very dust in which that blood has been absorbed. The emotions
	and desires are actually those of the faction-fighters who are determined
	to avenge their kinsmen’s or comrades’ blood even if the
	consequence is catastrophe for the entire community.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 475[/c]
