	as an immigrant here, you will have no cause
	to complain about your fortunes in life.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Athena[/b][/c]
	I thank you for these words of blessing, and I will escort
	you, by the light of blazing torches, to your place below and
	beneath the earth, together with my servants[c dimgray][sup]194[/sup][/c] who guard
	my image—and rightly so; for I invite you to come right to
	the jewel[c dimgray][sup]195[/sup][/c] of the whole land of Theseus, an honoured
	band <of awesome goddesses. People of Cecrops,> honour
	<them>[c dimgray][sup]196[/sup][/c] with special robes dyed with purple, and then
	let the flame of fire set forward, so that for the future these
	companions of ours in this land may be friendly towards it
	and give it the glorious blessing of manly excellence.[c dimgray][sup]197[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]194[/sup][/c]The Greek text specifies them as female. They probably
	consist of the priestess of Athena Polias; her two adult assistants,
	the κοσμώ and the τραπεζώ or τραπεζοφόρος (Lycurgus fr. 47
	Blass; Istros,[c dimgray] FGrH[/c] 334 F 9); and one or more of the groups of
	young girls, chosen from the old Athenian aristocracy, who served
	for a fixed term during which they lived on the Acropolis, such as
	the ἀρρηφόροι and the ἐργαστῖναι. See M. P. J. Dillon, [c dimgray]Girls and
	Women in Classical Greek Religion[/c] (London, 2002) 57–60, 84–89.
	[c dimgray][sup]195[/sup][/c]lit. “eye”; the reference is to the Acropolis. The actual cave- sanctuary of the Semnai Theai was close under the Areopagus
	(though on the side facing the Acropolis); “it seems that Aeschylus
	has taken a slight liberty with topographical fact in order to bring
	the cult of the reformed Erinyes close to that of Athena Polias”
	(A. L. Brown, [c dimgray]CQ[/c] 34 \[1984\] 274).
	[c dimgray][sup]196[/sup][/c]On the text of this passage, see Brown [c dimgray]op.cit.[/c] 272–5, and
	my 1989 commentary [c dimgray]ad loc.[/c] In order to give a continuous rendering,
	I translate a restoration, suggested in my commentary by way
	of example, which assumes that only one line has been lost. It is
	also possible, though, that the lacuna is longer and contained
	more explicit reference to the fact that the Furies’ purple robes
	are reminiscent of those worn by μέτοικοι (see on 1011) in the
	Panathenaic procession (Photius s.v. σκάφας, citing Menander fr.
	147 K-A); in that case the lost passage might have ended e.g. <ἀλλ᾿
	ὡς μετοίκους τάσδε τὰς σεμνὰς θεὰς>, and line 1027 (“of girls,
	of women, and a procession of old women”), which (following
	Brown) I have deleted, might be a surviving fragment of it.
	[c dimgray][sup]197[/sup][/c]lit. “be glorious with the good fortune of manly excellence”.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 481[/c]

	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Eumenides[/b][/c]<span class="stage">\[[c dimgray]By now the chorus have had the purple robes draped over
	them. Athena[/c] takes her place in the procession, which
	now begins to move off.[c dimgray][sup]198[/sup][/c]\]
	[c darkmagenta][b]the processional escort[/b][/c]

	Come on your way, you great, honour-loving,
	childless children of Night,[c dimgray][sup]199[/sup][/c] with our friendly escort.
	Speak fair,[c dimgray][sup]200[/sup][/c] people of the land![c dimgray][sup]201[/sup][/c]
	In the age-old recesses of the earth
	may you receive great reverence with rituals and
	sacrifices.
	Speak fair, all you masses![c dimgray][sup]202[/sup][/c]
	Favourably and righteously minded towards our land,
	come hither, Awesome Goddesses, delighting
	in the fire that devours our torches on your way.
	Now raise a cry of triumph to crown our song!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]198[/sup][/c]It may be inferred from hints in the text (see my 1989
	commentary, p. 278) that the order of the procession was approximately
	as follows: (two?) torch-bearers; Athena; her cultic household,
	led by the priestess, together with the sacrificial animal (s);
	the Areopagus Council, led by the herald and trumpeter (cf. 566–9);
	the Furies, now the Semnai Theai. For the audience, this
	spectacle would probably be reminiscent both of the Panathenaic
	procession (cf. on 1028) and of the great procession in honour of the Semnai Theai themselves (see Introduction), in which the
	members of the Areopagus Council, with which the Semnai Theai
	were so closely associated, surely had a prominent role.
	[c dimgray][sup]199[/sup][/c]“Childless” because under the new dispensation crime will
	no longer “breed” fresh crime. Another possible understanding of
	the phrase is “children of Night who are no children” (i.e. are
	aged); neither interpretation need be excluded.
	[c dimgray][sup]200[/sup][/c]i.e. keep silence. These injunctions at the end of each
	stanza may be uttered by the priestess alone.
	[c dimgray][sup]201[/sup][/c]Probably addressed to the members of the Areopagus
	Council, the representatives on stage of the male citizen body.
	[c dimgray][sup]202[/sup][/c]Probably addressed to the theatre audience.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 483[/c]

	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]203[/sup][/c]The text is desperately corrupt. I translate, without much
	conviction, the restoration of it proposed by West ([c dimgray]Studies[/c] 294–5),
	except that I cannot accept his πανδάιδ᾿ οἶκον “your home full of
	torches” (apart from anything else, δαΐς or δᾴς “torch” is not
	found in Aeschylus) and suspect that the transmitted letters
	ἐνδαιδες are a mechanical repetition of (σπ)ονδαιδες earlier in
	the line that has displaced the true text. An alternative possibility
	might be πάνδικον οἶκον “the home that is justly yours” (cf., for
	the idea, 891; for the word, 804 and [c dimgray]Supp[/c]. 776). It is also quite possible
	that Παλλάδος ἀσοῖς may belong to this rather than the
	following sentence, being governed by a now lost or hopelessly
	corrupted verb. In that case the next sentence, beginning with
	Ζεὺς might mean “Thus Zeus the all-seeing and Destiny have descended
	together”, sc. from the Acropolis in the procession—
	Zeus being represented by his daughter Athena (cf. 736–8, 973),
	Destiny by the Erinyes-Semnai, sisters of the Fates (cf. 961–2),
	and the union of the two in a single procession symbolizing the
	restoration of harmony among the gods and, it may be hoped,
	among the Athenian people.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[b]ΑΘΑΜΑΣ[/b]
	[c dimgray]Athamas, son of Aeolus, was a central figure in several
	myths, mostly concerned with the actions and fate of his
	wives and children. These were the subject of several tragedies,
	including three by Sophocles and three by Euripides.
	We do not know what part of Athamas’ story was dealt
	with in Aeschylus’ play; our only clue is provided by two
	fragments (frr. 1, 2a) which show that there was mention of
	a child (probably one of a pair) being thrown into a cauldron.
	This will refer to one or the other of Athamas’ two
	children by his second wife Ino, Learchus and Melicertes.
	According to pseudo-Apollodorus (3.4.3, cf. 1.9.2) Athamas
	and Ino were driven mad by Hera for having agreed
	to care for the child Dionysus (whose mother Semele was
	Ino’s sister): Athamas shot Learchus with an arrow, under
	the delusion that he was a deer, while Ino threw Melicertes
	into a boiling cauldron and leaped into the sea, taking the
	cauldron with her. In another version, preserved in the ancient
	introduction (Hypothesis) to Pindar’s[/c] Isthmians, [c dimgray]it
	was Learchus, after he had been killed, whom Ino put in
	the cauldron (presumably in the hope of restoring him to
	life—compare the story of Medea and the daughters of[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	1

	τὸν μὲν τρίπους ἐδέξατ᾿ οἰκεῖος λέβης
	αἰεὶ φυλάσσων τὴν ὑπὲρ πυρὸς στάσιν
	[m1]\ [/m]
	 Athenaeus 2.37e
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 2[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Athamas[/b][/c]

	[b]Athamas[/b]
	[c dimgray]Pelias), and it was only later that she was driven mad and
	leaped into the sea with Melicertes; but this was clearly not
	the version Aeschylus gave, since[/c]τὸν μὲν [c dimgray]in fr. 1 shows that
	the boy who was boiled was mentioned before the one who
	was shot. In any case, the account appears to be a retrospective
	summary rather than a full narrative, and Aeschylus’
	play will therefore have been about something that befell
	Athamas[/c] after [c dimgray]his loss of Ino and her children. The
	story about Athamas that was dramatized most often was
	that of the near-sacrifice of Phrixus, his son by Nephele,
	who eventually escaped with his sister Helle on a golden
	ram (Helle falling off into what became known as the Hellespont,
	Phrixus safely reaching Colchis). This story usually
	begins with a plot against the sons of Nephele by their
	stepmother Ino, but in some accounts (reported by a scholiast
	to Pindar,[/c] Pythian  4.288 \[162\]), the stepmother is
	differently named, and the mythographer Pherecydes (fr.
	98 Fowler), a contemporary of Aeschylus, named her as
	Themisto—who is virtually always Athamas’ last [c dimgray]wife, after
	Nephele and Ino. Possibly therefore Aeschylus’ play
	dealt with the Phrixus story but placed it after (and not,
	like most later accounts, before) the Learchus-Melicertes
	story.[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	1
	One of them was swallowed up by a three-legged household
	cauldron, which always kept its place over the fire.
	[m1]\ [/m]

-505.007 (AESCHYLUS, Attributed Fragments)

	[b]Aitnaiai[/b]
	[c dimgray]According to the[/c] Life of Aeschylus  (§9), this play was
	produced, during one of Aeschylus’ visits to Sicily, at (or
	at least in honour of) the new city of Aetna, which was
	founded by Hieron of Syracuse in 476/5 bc. Fragments
	of what is probably a hypothesis of the play are preserved
	in Oxyrhynchus Papyrus [c dimgray]2257; they reveal that, most abnormally,
	it had many changes of scene, the setting being
	successively Aetna (perhaps the mountain rather than
	the city), Xuthia (a district near Leontini), Aetna again,
	Leontini, Syracuse, and another unidentifiable locality—al
	of them places within Hieron’s dominions. References
	to the play by Macrobius[/c] (Saturnalia [c dimgray]5.19.16–31[/c]) [c dimgray]and
	Stephanus of Byzantium (496.7–13) suggest strongly,
	though they do not conclusively prove, that the play told
	the story of a Sicilian nymph called Thaleia, daughter of
	Hephaestus (fr. 7), who was made pregnant by Zeus and
	then swallowed up by the earth—some say by command of
	the jealous Hera, others by the act of Zeus to protect her
	from Hera’s wrath. The chorus of women of Aetna (or
	maybe rather of mountain nymphs, sisters of Thaleia?)
	may perhaps have been wandering across Sicily in search
	of her. In due time her twin offspring emerged from[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 6[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Women of Aetna[/b][/c]

	[b]Women of Aetna ([c dimgray]or[/c] nymphs of mount etna?)[/b]
	[c dimgray]below ground and were named the Palici (see fr. 6); they
	became gods, worshipped (originally by the indigenous
	Sicels) at a lake in south-eastern Sicily (now the Lago
	Naftia). The catalogue of Aeschylus’ plays found in some
	medieval manuscripts lists both a “genuine” and a “spurious”[/c]
	Women of Aetna; [c dimgray]these designations are not found
	elsewhere, and it has been suggested that some time after
	the play was produced in Sicily, Aeschylus—or possibly
	his son Euphorion—revised it for production at Athens,
	and that both the original and the revised text survived at
	least into Hellenistic times.[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]On the question whether the “Dike play” (frr. 281a,
	281b, perhaps 451n) was identical with Women of Aetna,
	see introductory note to that play.[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Recent studies[/c]: C. Dougherty, “Linguistic colonialism in Aeschylus’
	[c dimgray]Aetnaeae”, GRBS[/c] 22 (1991) 119–132; C. Corbato, “Le ‘Etnee’
	di Eschilo”, in B. Gentili ed. [c dimgray]Catania antica[/c] (Pisa, 1996) 61–72;
	G. Basta-Donzelli, “Katane-Aitna tra Pindaro ed Eschilo”, [c dimgray]ibid[/c].
	73–95; A. Ippolito, “De Aeschyli deperdita fabula quae Aitnaiai
	inscribitur”, [c dimgray]Latinitas[/c] 45 (1997) 3–12; l. Poli-Palladini, “Some reflections
	on Aeschylus’ ‘Aetnae(ae)’, [c dimgray]RhM[/c] 144 (2001) 287–325.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 7[/c]

	[b]ΑΜΥΜΩΝΗ[/b]
	[c dimgray]This was the satyr-drama of the Danaid tetralogy. The
	story behind it is told, with some variations, by several
	later mythographers, notably pseudo-Apollodorus (2.1.4)
	and Hyginus[/c] (Fabulae [c dimgray]169a). Amymone, one of the daughters
	of Danaus, was sent into the Argive countryside to
	fetch water, and there attracted the attention of a satyr (accounts
	differ as to how this happened) who attempted to
	rape her. She called for help to Poseidon, who appeared at
	once, put the satyr to flight, and then himself lay with
	Amymone; afterwards he created for her the spring of
	Lerna by striking the ground with his trident. In the play
	there must of course have been a whole chorus of satyrs,
	and they can have been driven off (if at all) only at the end
	of the drama; a series of vase-paintings from the late fifth
	and early fourth centuries (see for example KPS, pl. 18a,[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 8[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Amymone[/b][/c]
	6
	[c darkmagenta][b]A[/b][/c]
	 . So what name will mortals give them?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]B[/b][/c]
	 . Zeus ordains that they be called the holy Palici.[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]A[/b][/c]
	 . And will the name of Palici be appropriate and
	permanent?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]B[/b][/c]
	 . Yes, for they have [c dimgray]come back[/c] from the darkness to
	this realm of light.

	[b]Amymone[/b]
	[c dimgray]18b) suggest that at one stage—as we might expect—Amymone
	was besieged lustfully by the whole band,
	but that eventually Poseidon pacified them and the play
	ended with them joining in celebration of his union with
	Amymone. Echoes of the preceding tragic trilogy are evident,
	as Amymone, like her sisters, is placed by her father
	in a dangerous situation, is threatened with and resists
	forcible violation by an arrogant, shameless band of males,
	and is finally joined in an apparently willing union with an
	honourable suitor who becomes a benefactor of Argos; it
	may also be significant that in[/c] Suppliants [c dimgray](1023–9) the
	Danaids are made to praise the rivers of Argos as givers of
	both vegetal and human fertility.[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Recent studies[/c]: A. Wessels and R. Krumeich in KPS 91–97; P.
	Yziquel, [c dimgray]CGITA[/c] 14 (2001) 1–22, esp. 13–19; Podlecki 8–9.

-505.015 (AESCHYLUS, Attributed Fragments)

AESCHYLUS, Attributed Fragments
	[c darkmagenta][b]AESCHYLUS, Attributed Fragments[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Attributed Fragments[/b][/c]

	[b]ΑΡΓΩ ἢ ΚΩΠΑΣΤΑΙ[/b]
	[c dimgray]This play was obviously about the Argonautic expedition,
	but all we can say about it for certain is that mention
	was made of the marvellous beam of the ship which
	had the power of speech (frr. 20, 20a) and of the helmsman
	(T)iphys (fr. 21). Since the latter died before reaching
	Colchis (Apollonius Rhodius 2.851–860), it is a reasonable
	supposition that the play dealt with the early stages of the
	expedition, perhaps even with its very beginning (with
	Iolcus as its scene).[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Since only five known Aeschylean plays had an Argonautic
	connection, one of which[/c] (Phineus) [c dimgray]is known to have
	been produced together with plays on other subjects, it
	is likely that the remaining four[/c]—The Argo, Lemnian
	Women, Hypsipyle [c dimgray]and[/c] Cabeiri—[c dimgray]formed a tetralogy[/c]. The
	Argo [c dimgray]has usually been put down as one of the three tragedies
	in this production, most likely the first. However, it
	then becomes very difficult to account for its alternative
	title.[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]This second title is found only in the medieval catalogue
	of plays, where it appears as[/c] Κωπαστής[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c] (The Oarsman).
	[c dimgray]This is an impossible title for a tragedy, and the emendation[/c]
	Κωπασταί [c dimgray]is unavoidable. Even then, “oarsmen” is a[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]So M: κωπευστής V: Κωπευσταί Welcker: Κωπασταί Hippenstiel.

	[c darkmagenta][b]The Argo [c dimgray]or[/c] Oarsmen[/b][/c]

	[b]The Argo [c dimgray]or[/c] Oarsmen[/b]
	[c dimgray]surprising description of a chorus presumably consisting
	of the noble heroes who manned the[/c] Argo,  and the title
	would fit much better a chorus of satyrs who, as often happens,
	are engaged in an unfamiliar, often menial occupation.[c dimgray][sup]2[/sup][/c]
	This would also make good sense of the context in
	which Philo quotes fr. 20: he says that the Argo, [c dimgray]“being endowed
	with soul and reason, would not allow slaves to step
	aboard her”. Very possibly the satyrs (who are slaves of Dionysus),
	attracted by the prospect of winning the Golden
	Fleece, volunteered to crew the[/c] Argo [c dimgray]for Jason (perhaps not
	much to his liking) and were prevented from doing so by
	the ship herself (probably the speaking beam complained,
	cf. fr. 20).[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Recent studies[/c]: B. Deforge, “Eschyle et la légende des Argonautes”,
	[c dimgray]REG[/c] 100 (1987) 30–44 (esp. 33–36); D. Holwerda, “Zur
	Interpretation und Emendation zweier Aischylos-Fragmente”,
	in H. Hofmann and A. M. Harder ed. [c dimgray]Fragmenta Dramatica[/c]
	(Göttingen, 1991) 1–7, at 1–3; A. Wessels and R. Krumeich in KPS
	204–5.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]2[/sup][/c]As in Euripides’ [c dimgray]Cyclops[/c] (where they are shepherds);
	on this common satyric theme see further R. A. S. Seaford,
	[c dimgray]Euripides: Cyclops[/c] (Oxford, 1984) 33–36.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 15[/c]

	[b]Atalanta[/b]
	[c dimgray]A play of this name is listed in the medieval catalogue, but
	it is nowhere else quoted or referred to, and we have no
	way of telling which of the various stories about Atalanta it
	presented; it is perhaps most likely, though, that the play
	had to do with her participation in the Calydonian Boar
	Hunt, a famous heroic episode not otherwise known to
	have formed the subject of any complete play of Aeschylus
	(though compare[/c] Libation-Bearers [c dimgray]602–612, on the death
	of Meleager).[/c]

	[b]Bacchae[/b]
	[c dimgray]This play is known only from its inclusion in the medieval
	catalogue of plays and from a single citation by Stobaeus
	(see below), and it may have been identical with one of the
	better-attested Dionysiac plays such as[/c] Bassarids, Woolcarders
	[c dimgray]or[/c] Pentheus [c dimgray](qq.v.) The one surviving fragment
	would suit any play about the punishment of an enemy of
	Dionysus.[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]sc. when a slave stepped on board (Holwerda); that Philo’s
	context requires the line to have approximately this meaning was
	seen by Radt ([c dimgray]TrGF[/c] iii 135).
	[m1]\ [/m]

-505.019 (AESCHYLUS, Attributed Fragments)
%Attributed Fragments Bassarids
AESCHYLUS, Attributed Fragments
	[c darkmagenta][b]AESCHYLUS, Attributed Fragments[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Attributed Fragments[/b][/c]
	22

	τό τοι κακὸν ποδῶκες ἔρχεται βροτοῖς
	καὶ τἀμπλάκημα τῷ περῶντι τὴν θέμιν
	[m1]\ [/m]
	Stobaeus 1.3.26–27; Theophilus of Antioch, [c dimgray]To Autolycus[/c] 2.37
	(Theophilus does not name the play)

	[b]ΒΑΣΣΑΡΙΔΕΣ[/b]
	[c dimgray]This was the second play of the Thracian or Lycurgus
	tetralogy, following[/c] Edonians [c dimgray]and preceding[/c] Youths [c dimgray]and
	the satyr-drama[/c] Lycurgus. [c dimgray]It is known from the[/c] Cataterisms
	[c dimgray]of pseudo-Eratosthenes (§24; see West[/c], Studies  33–36)
	that the play dealt with the death of Orpheus at the
	hands of Thracian women, who in this version, unusually,
	are devotees of Dionysus, called Bassarids. “Orpheus,” we
	are told, “after going down to Hades in quest of his wife
	and seeing what things were like there, ceased to honour
	Dionysus, by whom he had been glorified, and regarded
	the Sun (whom he also called Apollo) as the greatest of the
	gods; he would rise before daybreak and await the sunrise
	on the \[Thracian\] mountain called Pangaeum, so as to be
	the first to see the Sun. Dionysus was angry at this and sent
	against him the Bassarids (as the tragic poet Aeschulus
	says), who tore him in pieces and scattered his limbs far
	and wide; but the Muses collected them together and buried
	him at the place called Leibethra \[in Macedonia\].” It
	has been persuasively argued that Aeschylus’ story reflects
	a rivalry between the Pythagorean sect (whose most vener-
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 18[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Bassarids[/b][/c]
	22
	Evil, you see, comes swiftly upon mortals: the offence
	comes home to him who breaks the bounds of right.

	[b]Bassarids[/b]
	[c dimgray]ated deity was Apollo) and Dionysiac mystery-cults, which
	both claimed Orpheus as their prophet, and that the Dionysus-
	Apollo conflict provided the overarching theme of
	the whole trilogy, ending (in[/c] Youths) [c dimgray]with the firm establishment
	in Thrace of cults of both gods. Like[/c] Edonians
	([c dimgray]q.v.), this play clearly served in part as a model for Euripides[/c]’
	Bacchae.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]The play is sometimes cited as[/c] Βασσαρίδες [c dimgray]and sometimes
	as[/c] Βασσάραι: [c dimgray]the manuscripts of pseudo-Eratosthenes
	are divided between the two forms. In[/c] Edonians ([c dimgray]fr.
	59) Aeschylus uses the word[/c] βασσάρα [c dimgray]in reference to a
	garment, so it is perhaps more likely that he called the
	Thracian women by the longer name.[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Recent studies[/c]: West, [c dimgray]Studies[/c] 26–50, esp. 32–46; F. Jouan, “Dionysos
	chez Eschyle”, [c dimgray]Kernos[/c] 5 (1992) 71–86, esp. 74–75; M. Di
	Marco, “Dioniso ed Orfeo nelle [c dimgray]Bassaridi[/c] di Eschilo”, in
	A. Masaracchia ed. [c dimgray]Orfeo e l’orfismo[/c] (Rome, 1993) 101–153;
	C. Marcaccini, “Considerazioni sulla morte di Orfeo in Thracia”,
	[c dimgray]Prometheus[/c] 21 (1995) 241–252; R. A. S. Seaford, “Mystic light in
	Aeschylus’ [c dimgray]Bassarai[/c]”, CQ 55 (2005) 602–6.
	[m1]\ [/m]

-505.025 (AESCHYLUS, Attributed Fragments)
%Attributed Fragments Glaucus the Sea-God
AESCHYLUS, Attributed Fragments

	[c darkmagenta][b]Attributed Fragments[/b][/c]
	25a

	καλοῖσι λουτροῖς ἐκλελουμένος δέμας
	εἰς ὑψίκρημνον Ἱμέραν ἀφικόμην
	[m1]\ [/m]
	Scholia to Pindar, [c dimgray]Pythian[/c] 1 \[79\] 153.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	1 ἐκλελουμένος Heyne: ἐκλέλουμαι codd.
	2 εἰς codd.:
	εἶθ᾿ Burzacchini  Ἱμέραν Heyne: Ἱμέραν δ᾿ codd.

	[b]ΓΛΑΥΚΟΣ ΠΟΝΤΙΟΣ[/b]
	[c dimgray]The Glaucus of this play was a fisherman of Anthedon, on
	the Boeotian shore of the Euripus facing Euboea. Having
	caught and landed a fish, he threw it on some grass; it ate
	the grass and came back to life. Glaucus then ate the grass
	himself, leaped into the sea and became a sea-god with prophetic
	powers. See Pausanias 9.22.7; Ovid[/c], Metamorphoses
	13.917–965; [c dimgray]and the scholia to Euripides[/c], Orestes 364
	[c dimgray]and to Lycophron[/c], Alexandra 754. [c dimgray]It is not clear how the
	story was given dramatic shape; since Glaucus was a character
	after his transformation (fr. 29), it probably had a
	seashore setting. In the papyrus fragment 25e a countryman,
	probably an oxherd, seems to be reporting the first
	appearance of the new god in the waters of the Euripus;[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 24[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Glaucus the Sea-God[/b][/c]
	25a
	Having thoroughly washed myself in its fair streams,[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]
	I came to Himera on its high cliffs.

	[b]Glaucus The Sea-God[/b]
	[c dimgray]according to Plato[/c] (Republic [c dimgray]611c-d) he was almost unrecognizable
	because his body had been battered by the wave
	and covered with stones, seaweed and shellfish (cf. fr. 34).
	Glaucus himself will have come on stage in a later scene,
	and his appearance will presumably have answered to this
	description. This grotesquerie, the theme of revivification
	and immortality, and the apparent absence of any tragically
	sinister plot-features, have suggested to many that
	this was a satyr-play, and this would be confirmed by the
	appearance of the untragic word[/c] θηρίον [c dimgray]in fr. 26 if we
	could be sure that its text was sound[/c].
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Recent study[/c]: A. Wessels and R. Krumeich in KPS 125–130;
	Podlecki 12.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]i.e. those of the river Himeras.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 25[/c]

	[c dimgray]On this scanty papyrus fragment, it is possible to read four to si
	Xletters from the beginning of each of five consecutive lines, and one
	to six letters from the middle of about eleven lines; change of
	speaker is marked twice, and at line 7 the speaker label “Chorus”
	appears. The other speaker may well be the oxherd who is the
	speaker in fr. 25e. From the chorus’s first utterance the only certain
	word is[/c] Tell ([c dimgray]3), but from the other speaker’s reply it is evident
	that they are expressing scepticism about the reliability of his
	story. The skeleton of his reply appears to be[/c] Stop what you’re saying!
	[c dimgray](4)[/c] . . . For the \[eyes?\] of old men are not short-sighted nor . . .
	[c dimgray](5–6). In the next few lines, spoken by the chorus, no word can be
	made out, but in line 11 we find nor followed by some word connected
	with horses. It may be added that in the left margin, opposite
	line 5, stands a note explaining the name[/c] Euripus ([c dimgray]fr. 25c),
	which presumably appeared in the (lost) preceding column[/c].

-505.033 (AESCHYLUS, Attributed Fragments)
%Attributed Fragments Glaucus of Potniae
AESCHYLUS, Attributed Fragments
	[c darkmagenta][b]AESCHYLUS, Attributed Fragments[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Attributed Fragments[/b][/c]
	31

	κἄπειτ᾿ Ἀθήνας Διάδας παρεκπερῶν
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Life of Aratus[/c] 1 p. 77.5–6 Maass = p. 7.8 Martin
	[m1]\ [/m]
	Διάδας παρεκπερῶν (παρὲκ περῶν) Scaliger: δαΐδας παρ᾿ ἐκ
	περσῶν cod.

	[b]ΓΛΑΥΚΟΣ ΠΟΤΝΙΕΥΣ[/b]
	[c dimgray]Glaucus of Potniae (a town about 2 km south of Thebes)
	was famous for having been devoured by his own mares
	during the chariot-race at the funeral games for Pelias.
	Our sources give various explanations of how this came
	to happen, which are not necessarily incompatible. The
	fourth-century scholar Asclepiades, in his Tales Told
	in Tragedy[/c] [c dimgray]([/c]Τραγῳδούμενα: FGrH [c dimgray]12 F 1), said that
	Glaucus had reared the mares on human flesh, to make
	them fiercer in war, and that they turned on him when they
	ran short of this food; his source was almost certainly Aeschylus’
	drama, since no other major tragic dramatist made
	this story the subject of a play. Virgil, however[/c] (Georgics
	[c dimgray]3.266–8[/c]),  in a passage on the power of sexual desire in
	horses and other animals, ascribes the madness of Glaucus’
	mares to the influence of Venus/Aphrodite, and his commentator
	Servius (ad loc.) says this was because he had neglected
	her worship and/or because, in order to increase
	the mares’ speed, he had not allowed them to mate. In the
	fragments of the play we can probably detect Glaucus de-
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 32[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Glaucus of Potniae[/b][/c]
	31
	And then, going on past Athenae Diades[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c] . . .
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Probably again from the oxherd’s narrative.[/c]

	[b]Glaucus of Potniae[/b]
	[c dimgray]parting for the games (cf. fr. 36.5–6), perhaps after an attempt
	to dissuade him (fr. 37 may be his reply to this); the
	catastrophe will have been narrated in a messenger-speech
	(frr. 38 and 39, and parts of fr. 36b), apparently to Glaucus’
	wife (fr. 36b.2.II.9[/c] γύναι lady), [c dimgray]and fr. 36b.7 may possibly
	contain an affirmation of the power of Aphrodite[/c].
	[m1]\ [/m]
	Glaucus of Potniae [c dimgray]was produced together with[/c] Persians
	[c dimgray]in 472 (see Introduction to[/c] Persians, [c dimgray]where the possibility
	is discussed that it may have included a prophecy of
	the defeat of the Carthaginians at Himera in 480). In this
	connection it is striking that Glaucus, like Xerxes, is being
	punished in part for violating the order of nature (Xerxes
	turned sea into land; Glaucus is turning grass-eating animals
	into flesh-eaters and denying them the right to breed).[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]The papyrus fragments, though preserved and published
	separately (as[/c] Oxyrhynchus Papyrus [c dimgray]2160 and[/c] PSI
	[c dimgray]1210), are all parts of the same copy. Except for fr. 36 and
	fr. 36b.7 (see below), none presents enough coherent text to
	be worth printing here[/c].
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]A settlement on Euboea, believed to be an Athenian foundation,
	overlooking the Euripus a short distance east of Cape
	Cenaeum.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 33[/c]

	[c dimgray]This was the third play of the Danaid tetralogy. Its action
	began on the morning after the Danaids’ murder of their
	bridegrooms (fr. 43); how it may then have developed is
	discussed in the introduction to[/c] Suppliants. [c dimgray]For the possibility
	that[/c] Suppliants [c dimgray]977–9 was transferred to that place
	from[/c] Danaids [c dimgray]by a later producer, see discussion[/c] ad loc.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 39[/c]

	The holy Heaven passionately desires to penetrate the
	Earth, and passionate desire takes hold of Earth for union
	with Heaven. Rain falls from the brimming fountains of
	Heaven and makes Earth conceive, and she brings forth
	for mortals grazing for their flocks, cereals to sustain their
	life, and the fruit of trees: by the wedlock of the rain she
	comes to her fulfilment.[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c] Of this, I am in part the cause.

	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]For the custom of singing a “waking song” (διεγερτικόν) outside
	the bridal chamber on the morning after a wedding, cf.
	Theocritus 18.56–57 with scholia.
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]τέλειος “final, perfect, fulfilled” was often used in reference
	to marriage, and according to Pollux (3.38) the word could actually
	mean “married”. Hera as goddess of marriage was Ἤρα τελέια
	([c dimgray]Eumenides[/c] 214, Aesch. fr. 383), and sacrifices made by,
	or on behalf of, maidens before their marriage were called
	προτέλεια (or, in [c dimgray]Eumenides[/c] 835, θύη πρὸ . . . γαμηλίου τέλους).

-505.043 (AESCHYLUS, Attributed Fragments)
%Attributed Fragments Net-Haulers
AESCHYLUS, Attributed Fragments
	[c darkmagenta][b]AESCHYLUS, Attributed Fragments[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Attributed Fragments[/b][/c]

	[b]ΔΙΚΤΥΟΥΛΚΟΙ[/b]
	[c dimgray]We owe our knowledge of this play almost entirely to a series
	of papyrus fragments, which confirmed the guess of
	Gottfried Hermann that the play was set on the island of
	Seriphos (mentioned in fr. 47b.1) and dealt with the arrival
	there of Danaë and the infant Perseus, whom Danaë’s father
	Acrisius had set adrift on the sea in a wooden chest,
	and the kind reception given them by Dictys, the brother
	of the local king Polydectes. The fragments show plainly
	that the play was a satyr-drama, and it is tempting to associate
	it with two other plays about Perseus[/c], Phorcides [c dimgray]and[/c]
	Polydectes; [c dimgray]however, no fourth play suggests itself to complete
	a tetralogy.[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]The first major fragment (46a) comes from the prologue:
	a fisherman has apparently netted a large object offshore,
	and seeks help in bringing it to land. The fragment
	ends with a call for all and sundry to come and help, which
	will have brought the satyrs onstage. There will then have
	been a long scene, from which the play took its name, during
	which the chest is hauled on shore; fr. 46c gives us a
	snatch of this. Finally the chest will have been landed;
	Dictys (who seems to have been present from the start)
	must have gone away for some reason, and the satyrs open[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 42[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Net-Haulers[/b][/c]

	[b]Net-Haulers[/b]
	[c dimgray]the chest and find Danaë and Perseus in it. Their intense
	erotic interest in Danaë, which dominates fr. 47a, will undoubtedly,
	as is usual, have come to nothing, and Dictys
	will eventually have rescued her.[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]To the thirty-sixth line of fr. 47a is prefixed the letter
	theta, a “stichometric” mark indicating that this was the
	800th line of the play; but we are clearly then still some way
	from the end of the action, so it seems likely that this satyr-drama
	was about as long as most of Aeschylus’ surviving
	tragedies—in marked contrast to a later satyr-drama such
	as Euripides’[/c] Cyclops, [c dimgray]which at 709 lines is less than half
	the length of an average Euripidean tragedy.[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Recent studies[/c]: M. Guardo, “Note critico-testuali ai Δικτυουλκοί
	(fr. 47a R.)”, [c dimgray]Giornale Filologico Ferrarese[/c] 12 (1989) 17–18; M. R.
	Halleran, “The speaker(s) of Aeschylus, Diktyoulkoi fr. 47a Radt
	(= P.Oxy. 2161) 821–32”, [c dimgray]ZPE[/c] 79 (1989) 267–9; Sommerstein [c dimgray]AT[/c]
	330–3; S. E. Goins, “The date of Aeschylus’ Perseus tetralogy”,
	[c dimgray]RhM[/c] 140 (1997) 193–210; A. Wessels and R. Krumeich in KPS
	107–124; W. B. Henry and R. Nünlist, “Aeschylus, Dictyulci (fr.
	47a Radt) und Isthmiastae (fr. 78 a-d)”, [c dimgray]ZPE[/c] 129 (2000) 13–16, at
	13–14; Podlecki 9–11.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 43[/c]

	Euripides, Theseus secures possession of the bodies by defeating
	the Thebans in battle; in Aeschylus, according
	to Plutarch (compare also Isocrates,[/c] Panathenaicus [c dimgray]168–171),
	he did so by a negotiated agreement, and afterwards[/c]

	[b]ΕΠΙΓΟΝΟΙ[/b]
	[c dimgray]The story of the Epigoni—the sons of the Seven against
	Thebes, who succeeded where their fathers had failed, capturing
	and destroying the city—was the subject of one of
	the poems in the Epic Cycle. The only clue to Aeschylus’
	treatment of the story is the reference in fr. 55 to the pouring
	of libations in connection with a wedding; but whose
	wedding can it have been? One of the Epigoni was Alcmeon,
	son of Amphiaraus and Eriphyle, and Sophocles’[/c]
	Epigoni [c dimgray](whether or not it was the same play as his[/c]
	Eriphyle[c dimgray]) was centred on the story of Alcmeon’s killing
	of his mother in revenge for her treachery against
	Amphiaraus in sending him to his death at Thebes; and a
	tantalizing fragment of the[/c] Eriphyle [c dimgray]of Stesichorus ([/c]SLG
	[c dimgray]148 col. ii) seems to speak of Eriphyle making a journey to[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	55

	λοιβὰς Διὸς μὲν πρῶτον ὡραίου γάμου
	Ἥρας τε
	* * * * *
	τὴν δευτέραν γε κρᾶσιν ἥρωσιν νέμω
	* * * * *
	τρίτον Διὸς σωτῆρος εὐκταίαν λίβα
	[m1]\ [/m]
	Scholia to Pindar, [c dimgray]Isthmian[/c] 6.\[7\]10; Arsenius 10.77a (lines 1–3)
	[m1]\ [/m]
	3 γε B: τε D: om. Arsenius: δὲ Schütz
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 58[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Epigoni[/b][/c]

	[b]Epigoni[/b]
	[c dimgray]arrange a marriage between her son and “the daughter of
	arrogant Anaxander” (a figure not known from any other
	source). One could envisage a drama that included the celebration
	of Alcmeon’s marriage (or perhaps betrothal) and
	culminated in the matricide, all against the background
	of the attack upon Thebes, and probably involving Adrastus
	(who was Eriphyle’s brother); but there may well be
	other possibilities of which we know nothing. The play
	would fit into a trilogic sequence with[/c] Women of Argos
	[c dimgray]and[/c] Eleusinians [c dimgray](qq.v.), in both of which Adrastus will
	also have appeared; Euripides too, at the end of[/c] Suppliants,
	[c dimgray]makes a close connection between the recovery and
	burial of the bodies of the Seven and the war of revenge by
	their sons.[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	55
	First \[I make\] the libation of Zeus and Hera, for a marriage
	in good season.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	* * * * *
	[m1]\ [/m]
	The second share of the mixed wine I allot to the Heroes.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	* * * * *
	[m1]\ [/m]
	Thirdly, a libation and prayer to Zeus the Saviour.[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]This was the usual sequence of libations after a meal, except
	that the first was normally to Olympian Zeus alone; here, in the
	context of marriage, his consort Hera is appropriately added.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 59[/c]

-505.061 (AESCHYLUS, Attributed Fragments)
%Attributed Fragments Edonians
AESCHYLUS, Attributed Fragments
	[c darkmagenta][b]AESCHYLUS, Attributed Fragments[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Attributed Fragments[/b][/c]

	[b]ΗΔΩΝΟΙ[/b]
	[c dimgray]This was the first play of the tetralogy known as the[/c]
	Lycurgeia [c dimgray](Aristophanes,[/c] Women at the Thesmophoria
	[c dimgray]135) and probably, except for the satyr-drama[/c] Lycurgus,
	 the only one in which Lycurgus, king of the Edonians (a
	Thracian people living near the river Strymon), actually
	appeared. It told the story of his attempt to suppress the
	worship of Dionysus in his kingdom, along more or less the
	same lines as \[Apollodorus,\] Library 3.5.1. At the start of
	the play Dionysus had just arrived in Thrace with his
	male and female followers. Lycurgus had both him and
	the women bacchants arrested, but they miraculously escaped,
	and Dionysus then drove Lycurgus mad, so that
	he killed his own son Dryas with an axe, believing that
	he was cutting a vine-branch. Lycurgus may well in the
	end, as in \[Apollodorus\] and as in Sophocles, Antigone
	[c dimgray]955–965, have been imprisoned perpetually in a rocky
	chamber on Mount Pangaeum. It has been attractively
	conjectured that Orpheus, who was the central figure of
	The following play[/c] (Bassarids, [c dimgray]q.v.), also figured in this
	one, before his apostasy, as a devotee (maybe a priest) of[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 60[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Edonians[/b][/c]

	[b]Edonians[/b]
	[c dimgray]Dionysus, imprisoned with his master by Lycurgus (cf. fr.
	60); West, Studies 29–30, has suggested that Orpheus
	“warned Lycurgus of the unwisdom of theomachy”, but
	that his warnings were ignored. This play was extensively
	imitated by Euripides when he wrote about the fate of another
	enemy of Dionysus in[/c] The Bacchae, [c dimgray]and the Roman
	poet Naevius in his[/c] Lucurgos [c dimgray]seems to have followed it
	closely.[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]The apparent presence of a stage-building (fr. 58) suggests
	that this was a late play of Aeschylus, and West,
	Studies 48–50, has argued that there is other evidence
	corroborating this. If so, Aeschylus will have been following
	in the footsteps of Polyphrasmon, son of his old rival
	Phrynichus, who produced a[/c] Lycurgeia [c dimgray]in 467.[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Recent studies:[/c] West, [c dimgray]Studie[/c]s 26–32, 48–50; F. Jouan, “Dionysos
	chez Eschyle”, [c dimgray]Kernos[/c] 5 (1992) 71–86, esp. 73–74; M. Di Marco,
	“Dioniso ed Orfeo nelle [c dimgray]Bassaridi[/c] di Eschilo”, in A. Masaracchia
	ed. [c dimgray]Orfeo e l’orfismo[/c] (Rome, 1993) 101–153; P. Mureddu, “Le
	‘lunghe gambe’ di Dioniso (Aesch. fr. 62 R.)”, [c dimgray]Eikasmos[/c] 5 (1994)
	81–88; [c dimgray]ead.[/c], “Note dionisiache: osservazioni sulle ‘Baccanti’ di
	Euripide e sugli ‘Edoni’ di Eschilo”, [c dimgray]Lexis[/c] 18 (2000) 117–125.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 61[/c]

	\[[c dimgray]to Dionysus[/c]\][c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]Whence comes this epicene? What is its country, what its
	garb?* * * * *What do you say? Why are you silent?[c dimgray][sup]2[/sup][/c]

	was he?[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]For this interpretation of the obscure word χλούνης, compare
	[c dimgray]Adespota Iambica[/c] fr. 51 West, and see P. Mureddu, [c dimgray]Eikasmos[/c]
	5(1994) 81–88. The point of the joke is that street robbers have to
	be fast runners to get away from their enraged victims. The Aristophanic scholiast states that “he \[i.e. Lycurgus\] says
	\[this\] in [c dimgray]The Edonians[/c] to Dionysus after his arrest”.
	[c dimgray][sup]2[/sup][/c]In Aristophanes’ [c dimgray]Women at the Thesmophoria[/c] these questions are
	part of a long series addressed by Euripides’ (brother?-)in-law to
	the effeminate tragic poet Agathon; he describes himself as speaking
	“in the manner of Aeschylus, from the [c dimgray]Lycurgeia[/c]”. I translate
	the whole speech here, italicizing the words that seem to me most
	likely to come unaltered from Aeschylus (only the first question is
	explicitly attested as his by the scholiast): “[c dimgray]Whence comes this
	epicene? What is its country, what its garb[/c]? What confusion of
	lifestyles is this? What has a bass to say to a [c dimgray]saffron gown[/c], or a lyre
	to a hair-net? What’s an oil-flask doing with a breast-band? How
	incongruous! [c dimgray]And what partnership can there be between[/c] a mirror
	[c dimgray]and a sword? And as for yourself, boy, are you being brought up as
	a man[/c]? Then where’s your prick? Where’s your cloak? Where are
	your Laconian shoes? Or as a woman, then? Then where are your
	tits? [c dimgray]What do you say? Why are you silent[/c]? Or shall I find you out
	by your song, seeing that you don’t want to tell me yourself?”
	[m1]\ [/m]

-505.069 (AESCHYLUS, Attributed Fragments)
%Attributed Fragments Daughters of the Sun
AESCHYLUS, Attributed Fragments
	[c darkmagenta][b]AESCHYLUS, Attributed Fragments[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Attributed Fragments[/b][/c]

	[b]ΗΛΙΑΔΕΣ[/b]
	[c dimgray]Pliny the Elder[/c] (Natural History [c dimgray]37.31–32) names Aeschylus
	among a number of poets who told of how, when
	Phaëthon perished by the thunderbolt of Zeus, his sisters
	were turned into poplar trees and shed tears of amber by[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 68[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Daughters of the Sun[/b][/c]

	[b]Daughters of the Sun[/b]
	[c dimgray]the river Eridanus.[/c][c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c] [c dimgray]Since Phaëthon was a son of the Sungod
	Helios, this evidence alone would leave little doubt that[/c]
	Daughters of the Sun [c dimgray]presented, as later did Euripides’[/c]
	Phaëthon, [c dimgray]the story of how he met his death when attempting
	to drive his father’s chariot through the sky; and this assumption
	is confirmed by fr. 71 (on which see footnote).
	The fragments do not enable us to define the plot more
	closely than this.[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]This river was very vaguely located by early Greeks. Herodotus
	(3.115) criticized poets who spoke of the Eridanus as flowing into
	“the sea to the north . . . on the far side of Europe”. By the time of
	Euripides ([c dimgray]Hippolytus[/c] 737–741) the Eridanus was envisaged as
	flowing into the Adriatic, and perhaps already identified with the
	Po; and fr. 71 seems to be consistent with this view. Pliny’s statement
	that Aeschylus located the river in Iberia and identified it
	with the Rhodanus (Rhône) may be explained by supposing
	that Aeschylus believed the Po and the Rhône to be joined together,
	far inland (an idea later exploited by Apollonius Rhodius,
	[c dimgray]Argonautica[/c] 4.627–8), and that, like several other fifth- and
	fourth-century writers, he thought of “Iberia” as beginning at the
	Rhône rather than at the Pyrenees (cf. Herodorus fr. 2 Fowler
	\[Iberian tribes extending as far as the Rhône\]; Scylax, [c dimgray]Periplous[/c] 3
	\[a mixed population of Iberians and Ligurians between the Pyrenees
	and the Rhône\]; Thucydides 6.2.2 \[the Sicans displaced
	by Ligurians from the river Sicanus in Iberia\]; and probably Herodotus
	1.163.1 \[“Tyrrhenia, Iberia and Tartessus” apparently representing
	the whole European shore from the Tiber to Cadiz\]).
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 69[/c]

	at my father’s setting
	is the cup fashioned by Hephaestus,[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]

	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]The location of the fabulous “Rhipaean mountains”. It is usually
	taken to be in the far north, but it could hardly then have a
	connection with Helios, and the Sophocles scholiast who quotes
	this fragment positively asserts that Rhipae was in the far [c dimgray]west[/c]
	(πρὸς τῇ δύσει) Neither the passage on which he is commenting
	([c dimgray]Oedipus at Colonus[/c] 1248, where a location in the far north is
	guaranteed by the context), nor a passage of Alcman which he
	cites ([c dimgray]PMG[/c]90), offer any support to this view, so it is reasonable to
	suppose that the Aeschylus passage once did, and that it has been
	truncated in transmission.
	[c dimgray][sup]2[/sup][/c][c dimgray]Heracleia[/c] fr. 12West; Peisander, [c dimgray]Heracleia[/c] fr. 5West; Pherecydes
	fr. 18a Fowler. This is approximately what sense and
	context require, and οἰδματόεντ᾿ Ὠκεανοῦ (or οἰδματόεντος
	ποταμοῦ) would be reconcilable with the (ionic) metre, but it
	would then be very hard to explain how φέρει δρόμου came to
	stand in the transmitted text.

	[c darkmagenta][b]Children of Heracles[/b][/c]

	[b]Children of Heracles[/b]
	[c dimgray]All that can be said with confidence about this play is that it
	dealt in some way with the fate of Heracles’ children after
	the end of his earthly life, and that he himself made an appearance
	in it, probably as a god (frr. 73b, 75a); perhaps
	his family had not previously known of his apotheosis. It is
	not unlikely that Aeschylus, like Euripides in his play of the
	same name, presented the story, of which Athenians were
	always proud, of how Athens had defended Heracles’ children
	against their father’s old persecutor Eurystheus; but
	there is simply no actual evidence either for or against this
	supposition.[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Recent studies:[/c] T. C. W. Stinton, “The apotheosis of Heracles
	from the pyre”, in L. Rodley ed. [c dimgray]Papers given at a Colloquium on
	Greek Drama in honour of R. P. Winnington-Ingram[/c] (London,
	1986) 1–15, at p.6 = Stinton, [c dimgray]Collected Papers on Greek Tragedy[/c]
	(Oxford, 1990) 493–507, at pp. 500–1; A. H. Sommerstein,
	“Ἀμφιμήτωρ” [c dimgray]CQ[/c] 37 (1987) 498–500; P. Holt, “Heracles’ apotheosis
	in lost Greek literature and art”, [c dimgray]L’Antiquité Classique[/c] 61
	(1992) 38–59; J. Wilkins, [c dimgray]Euripides: Heraclidae[/c] (Oxford, 1993)
	xviii–xix; C. Hahnemann, “Mount Oita revisited: Sophocles’ [c dimgray]Trachiniai[/c]
	in light of the evidence of Aeschylus’ [c dimgray]Herakleidai”, ZPE[/c]
	126 (1999) 67–73.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 75[/c]

	thi\]s these children of mine, who had two mothers,[c dimgray][sup]2[/sup][/c] \[carryi\]
	ng me aloft, placed me among the \[wood\] for the fire,
	\[in agony,\] my skin peeling \[from the effect\] of the poison.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]Cf. Sophocles, [c dimgray]Trachinian Maidens[/c] 1195–7, 1213.
	[c dimgray][sup]2[/sup][/c]The usual story was that the children of Heracles who remained
	together as a group after his passing all had Deianeira as their
	mother. Either Aeschylus included among their number one or
	more of Heracles’ many children by other women, or, as I suggested
	in [c dimgray]CQ[/c] 37 (1987) 498–500, the children’s second “mother”
	is Iole, who had been about to supplant Deianeira as Heracles’
	consort.

-505.081 (AESCHYLUS, Attributed Fragments)
%Attributed Fragments Chamber-Makers
AESCHYLUS, Attributed Fragments
	[c darkmagenta][b]AESCHYLUS, Attributed Fragments[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Attributed Fragments[/b][/c]
	75a

	κἀξῃονήθην, κοὐδὲν ἦν προσωτέρω
	[m1]\ [/m]
	Photius, [c dimgray]Lexicon[/c] ε1245; [c dimgray]Etymologicum Genuinum, Etymologicum
	Symeonis, Etymologicum Magnum[/c] s.v. ἐξῃονήθην (citing
	that word only, without attribution to Aeschylus)
	[m1]\ [/m]
	κἀξῃονήθην Tsantsanoglou (cf. the [c dimgray]Etymologica[/c]): κἀξαιονήθην
	Photius[c dimgray][sup]ac[/sup][/c] (-ξοιο- Photius[c dimgray][sup]pc[/sup][/c])

	[b]ΘΑΛΑΜΟΠΟΙΟΙ[/b]
	[c dimgray]Of this play we know nothing for sure except that it existed
	and, as fr. 78 shows, was indeed concerned with the building
	of a chamber or chambers—very likely, in view of the
	usual connotations of[/c] θάλαμος [c dimgray]in tragedy, for one or more
	bridal couples. The apparent presence of a chorus employed
	on a building project has led to its being widely,
	though not universally, accepted that this was a satyrdrama[/c].
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]It has, however, been twice independently suggested
	in recent years that fr. 451l Radt ([/c]Oxyrhynchus Papyrus
	[c dimgray]2254) may come from[/c] Chamber-Makers. [c dimgray]The fragment
	is almost certainly from a satyr-drama, as the reference
	to[/c] these beasts [c dimgray](line 15) indicates; it makes mention of a[/c]
	θάλαμος [c dimgray](line 22) and of a wife (line 26); and the reference
	to someone or something[/c] Teucrian [c dimgray](line 25), and what
	seems to be an address to Priam (line 12), make it likely
	that the play was set in Troy. Mette had already proposed
	that the fragment might come from a satyr-drama linked
	to the Achilles trilogy[/c] (Myrmidons, Nereids, Phrygians),
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 80[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Chamber-Makers[/b][/c]
	75a
	And I was drenched, and after that there was nothing
	more.
	[m1]\ [/m]


	[b]Chamber-Makers[/b]
	[c dimgray]and[/c] Chamber-Makers [c dimgray]could well be that play; the fragment
	is accordingly treated here as belonging to[/c] Chamber-Makers,  and renumbered 78a. Since only one chamber
	appears to be in question, the play probably centred on a
	single rather than a multiple wedding. Di Marco thought
	of Paris and Helen, but there is perhaps more to be said for
	Hector and Andromache:[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c] Hector, unlike Paris or Helen,
	was an important figure in the Achilles trilogy, offstage at
	first but later (as a corpse) onstage, and Aeschylus seems to
	have gone out of his way in Phrygians to mention Hector’s
	marriage (fr. 267).
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Recent studies[/c]: M. Di Marco, “P. Oxy. 2254: dai Thalamopoioi di
	Eschilo?”, [c dimgray]QUCC[/c] 45 (1993) 49–56; Sommerstein [c dimgray]AT[/c] 348.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]This story, which appears to be distinctively Attic (though a
	Boeotian variant of it appears in Herodotus 7.198.2), is evidenced
	by a series of vase-paintings, the earliest from about 460 bc, discussed
	by C. A. Faraone, [c dimgray]JHS[/c] 117 (1997) 43–46.
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]The wedding of Hector and Andromache, and the great public
	rejoicing that accompanied it, are the subject of an unusually well-preserved
	poem by Sappho (fr. 44).
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 81[/c]

	[b]ΘΕΩΡΟΙ Η ΙΣΘΜΙΑΣΤΑΙ[/b]
	[c dimgray]Our knowledge of this play is almost entirely dependent on
	the fragments preserved as[/c] Oxyrhynchus Papyrus [c dimgray]2162.
	Their arrangement is now fairly firmly established, except
	for one narrow strip (fr. 78b). The scene is before the temple
	of Poseidon at the Isthmus of Corinth, the occasion that
	of a celebration of the Isthmian Games. The “story so far”
	appears to be that Dionysus has been training the satyrs
	for a dancing performance at a great festival (33, 71–74),
	but that they have run away from him, decided to become
	athletes instead, and been taken under the wing of another
	character, who has been identified as Sisyphus or Theseus[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 82[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]The Sacred Delegation[/b][/c]
	100
	But Ares is always in the habit of plucking off all that is best
	in an army.

	<h2>The Sacred Delegation
	[c dimgray]or[/c] at the Isthmian Games</h2>
	[c dimgray](rival claimants to the title of founder of the Games), as
	Daedalus, and as Hephaestus. In the papyrus, we first see
	the satyrs receiving likenesses of themselves (possibly in
	the form of masks), at which they marvel (1–17); they are
	about to fix them on the front of the temple (18–22) when
	Dionysus enters and upbraids, mocks and threatens them
	for their disloyalty to him (23–78). They remain defiant
	(79–84). Someone then presents the satyrs with some “new
	toys” made with adze and anvil, which they are reluctant
	to accept (85ff); this may be their new protector returning,
	bringing athletic equipment (e.g. javelins) for the games,
	but it is more probably Dionysus, displaying shackles
	which he will make them wear if they remain disobedient
	to him (see Taplin, Stagecraft 421–2). In the end the satyrs
	will certainly have been reconciled to Dionysus, but we
	cannot tell how this may have come about. The play must[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]The “Lesbian cyma(tium)”—now usually called [c dimgray]cyma reversa[/c]—was
	a moulding typical of the Ionic order. It was usually
	ornamented with the “leaf-and-dart” pattern, in the simpler forms
	of which the “leaf” is a pendent shape rather like a heraldic shield,
	i.e. a triangle with bulging curved sides and its apex at the bottom.
	See D. S. Robertson, [c dimgray]Greek and Roman Architecture[/c][c dimgray][sup]2[/sup][/c] (Cambridge,
	1943) 37–38 with figs. 16a and 41.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 83[/c]

	 \[.\]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Dionysus[/b][/c]
	Ah, I was bound to find you some time, my good fellows! I
	won’t say of you that you travelled[c dimgray][sup]5[/sup][/c] incognito: your journey
	it\[self\] con\[firmed\] this for me . . . seeing these \[tracks (?)\]
	. . . \[ . . . informed (?) me of t\]his and gave me clear guidance.
	\[I knew (?) . . . \], when I saw your \[phalli\] short like a
	mouse’s tail,[c dimgray][sup]6[/sup][/c] that you were polishing up your Isthmian
	\[wrestling\], and that you hadn’t neglected it but were in
	good training.[c dimgray][sup]7[/sup][/c] Well, if you’d stayed faithful to the old
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]5[/sup][/c]From ὁδοιπορῶν and κέλευθος we can gather that the satyrs’
	previous lodgings had been some distance from the Isthmus
	(perhaps in Corinth city, but quite possibly further afield, e.g.
	Phleius—home town of the first great satyr-dramatist, Pratinas—or
	even Athens) and that they had then absconded.
	[c dimgray][sup]6[/sup][/c]The reference is to the practice, regular among ancient Greek athletes,
	of tying up the penis in a curled shape (just “like a mouse’s
	tail”) by a string tied round the foreskin and then round the waist
	(often, but wrongly, called “infibulation”). See D. Sansone, [c dimgray]Greek
	Athletics and the Genesis of Sport[/c] (Berkeley, 1988) 119–122 and
	figs. 20, 22, 23. For the satyrs to come on stage in this condition
	would make a striking contrast with their accustomed state of hyper-erection.
	[c dimgray][sup]7[/sup][/c]There is probably a [c dimgray]double entendre[/c] in this
	sentence πάλη and derivatives, (ἐκ)τρίβειν, γυμνάζομαι, and
	references to the Isthmus, were all capable of being understood in
	sexual senses (see J. J. Henderson, [c dimgray]The Maculate Muse[/c] \[New Haven,
	1975\] 137–8, 169, 176; Palaestra, Gymnasium and Isthmias
	were all names of real or fictitious [c dimgray]hetairai[/c])—which might suggest
	an alternative explanation for the state of the satyrs’ phalli!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 89[/c]

	\[ . . . \] covering \[yourself\] with a shield[c dimgray][sup]14[/sup][/c] \[ . . . \] and you disseminate
	this story \[ . . . \] and utter against me \[words that
	are\] out of \[order (?)\], that I am no good at \[fighting (?)\]

	fresh \[allegations (?)\], more hateful than any of \[your
	previous insults (?)\], and you vilify[c dimgray][sup]15[/sup][/c] me myself \[and the

	. . . \] and none of the old people or of the young willingly
	stays away from these double-file[c dimgray][sup]16[/sup][/c] \[dances\]. But you are
	playing the Isthmian athlete and gar\[landing\] yourselves
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]14[/sup][/c]Kamerbeek attractively suggested that the satyrs had been
	intending not only to wrestle but also to compete in the foot-race
	in armour (ὁπλιτοδρομία).
	[c dimgray][sup]15[/sup][/c]lit. “soak” (like a garment being washed); cf. the English
	phrase “take to the cleaners” (= criticize severely).
	[c dimgray][sup]16[/sup][/c]This seems to indicate that in Aeschylus’ time the normal
	formation of a satyric chorus was in two rows (with six performers
	in each). According to Pollux (4.108–9), the [c dimgray]tragic[/c] chorus (in the
	later fifth century, when it had fifteen members) normally performed
	in three rows of five; it is a plausible, but far from secure,
	inference that both types of chorus (which were composed of the
	same performers) changed from two to three rows at the same
	time as they changed their numbers.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]17[/sup][/c]The Isthmian temple of Poseidon was surrounded by a pine
	grove (Strabo 8.6.22, Pausanias 2.1.7), and victorious athletes
	there were originally crowned with a pine wreath, later replaced
	by a celery wreath in imitation of the Nemean games (see Plutarch,
	[c dimgray]Moralia[/c] 675d-677b; by Plutarch’s time the wreath was of
	pine once more).
	[c dimgray][sup]18[/sup][/c]Typically used for Dionysiac wreaths; cf. e.g. Euripides,
	[c dimgray]Bacchae[/c] 81, 105, 177.
	[c dimgray][sup]19[/sup][/c]If Dionysus is indeed here referring to the objects soon to
	be offered to the chorus as “novel toys”, the fact that (so far as we
	know) neither he nor the chorus has made any previous mention
	of them in the 55 lines he has been on stage makes it likely that
	they are not in his own hands but are being carried by attendants,
	who hitherto have been positioned unobtrusively but now step
	forward.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[c dimgray][sup]20[/sup][/c]It remains disputed whether the character who takes part in
	this dialogue is Dionysus (so e.g. Diggle) or the satyrs’ new patron
	(so e.g. Lloyd-Jones, Wessels & Krumeich). I prefer Dionysus,
	partly for the reasons given by Taplin [c dimgray]Stagecraft[/c] 421–2, and also
	because (i) line 77 is unquestionably a threat of punishment (cf.
	81), which one would expect to be followed up when the satyrs remain
	recalcitrant, and (ii) \[τ\] καινὰ ταῦτα (85) is not how one
	would expect a supporter of athletes to describe athletics, but
	rather recalls Dionysus’ disparaging words at 32–35. In this case,
	of course, Dionysus’ words about his “gifts” will be ironic throughout.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 97[/c]

	[b]Thracian Women[/b]
	[c dimgray]We learn from scholia on Sophocles’ Ajax (on lines 134, 815
	and 833) that this play included the suicide of Ajax, which
	was narrated by a messenger; that Ajax was invulnerable
	except in one spot (because, when he was a baby, Heracles
	had covered him with his lion-skin), and as a result was
	unable to strike himself the fatal blow until “a goddess”
	(Athena?) showed him the right place to do so (the armpit);
	and that the “Thracian women” of the chorus were war
	captives. The play almost certainly followed[/c] The Award of
	the Arms [c dimgray](q.v.), and the third play of the trilogy is likely to
	have been[/c] Women of Salamis ([c dimgray]q.v.[/c])
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[b]ΙΞΙΩΝ[/b]
	[c dimgray]Of the two well-known stories about Ixion, that of his
	treacherous murder of his father-in-law (D)eïoneus appears
	to have been dramatized by Aeschylus in[/c] Perrhaebian
	Women [c dimgray](q.v.). This leaves for[/c] Ixion [c dimgray]the other tale,
	which follows on from it, of how gods and men alike were
	so horrified at this murder (the first ever committed in
	which the victim was a kinsman) that none of them was
	willing to purify Ixion; of how Zeus at length took pity on
	him, and not only purified him but took him up to heaven;
	of how Ixion, despite having received this great boon from
	Zeus, committed the ultimate[/c] hybris [c dimgray]of attempting to seduce
	Hera (Zeus deceived him into lying instead with a
	cloud in her shape); and of how in punishment he was
	bound to a wheel “on which he rolls around everywhere,[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	90
	βίου πονηροῦ θάνατος εὐκλεέστερος
	[m1]\ [/m]
	Stobaeus 4.53.15

	[b]Ixion[/b]
	[c dimgray]proclaiming to mortals that they must repay their benefactors
	with kind deeds in return” (Pindar,[/c] Pythian [c dimgray]2.21–24).
	Aeschylus refers twice in[/c] Eumenides [c dimgray](439–441, 717–8) to
	Ixion’s successful supplication to Zeus (though not to its
	consequences). It is not clear, however, how the tale can
	have been adapted for dramatic treatment, nor even
	whether it was a tragedy or a satyr-drama (fr. 90 suggests
	the former, fr. 91 the latter). The setting, at any rate, was
	evidently on earth, not in heaven, so probably Ixion was
	depicted in his period of isolation as an abhorred, polluted
	murderer with whom no one would associate—except,
	maybe, the satyrs? The play need not have been produced
	together with[/c] Perrhaebian Women; [c dimgray]no plausible suggestion
	has ever been made as to how they could have formed
	part of a connected trilogy or tetralogy.[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	90

	[b]Iphigeneia[/b]
	[c dimgray]We cannot tell whether this play was parallel in subject
	to Euripides’[/c] Iphigeneia at Aulis [c dimgray](and to Sophocles’[/c]
	Iphigeneia) [c dimgray]or to his[/c] Iphigeneia in Tauris; [c dimgray]we only know
	that in it a woman, whether Iphigeneia or another, was involved
	in a quarrel in which high words were spoken (fr.
	94); one possibility is that this woman was Clytaemestra,
	who appeared both in Sophocles’ and in Euripides’ plays
	about the Aulis sacrifice.[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	94
	It is not right to revile women.[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c] How could it be?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]lit. “half-holed”, i.e. with three finger-holes instead of six.
	Since the verb καταπίνω “swallow whole, gulp down”—here apparently
	used metaphorically to mean “vanquish easily”—is not
	found in tragedy proper, this fragment should probably be assigned
	to a satyr chorus and indicates the genre of the play. It has
	sometimes been found tempting to interpret the fragment as applying
	figuratively to the transgressions of Ixion, but it is more
	likely to relate to something of more interest to satyrs.
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]In itself the phrase could also mean “to be reviled by
	women” (for the two senses compare, respectively, Epicharmus
	fr. 32.6 K-A and Sophocles, [c dimgray]Ajax[/c] 722); but χρὴ (the only other
	possible supplement, δεῖ, means in Aeschylus “it is needed”, “it is
	necessary”, or “it is destined”, none of which fits the context here)
	asserts an ethical or social [c dimgray]duty[/c], and it makes no sense to speak of
	an ethical or social duty not to be reviled by women. The speaker
	is thus probably a woman, and quite possibly Clytaemestra, who in
	[c dimgray]Agamemnon[/c] is very sensitive to male disparagement or condescension.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[b]KABEIPOI[/b]
	[c dimgray]The Cabeiri were minor gods, with varying attributes and
	functions, worshipped at various locations in Boeotia and
	the northern Aegean, especially Thebes and Lemnos. From
	Athenaeus (10.428f) we learn that Jason and his companions
	appeared in this play, and that in one scene they
	were drunk; since the passage blames Aeschylus for being
	“the first to introduce the sight of drunken men into tragedy”,
	it is clear that this play was a tragedy, not a satyr-drama,
	in which drunkenness would have been nothing
	unusual. The play included a catalogue of the Argonauts
	(so the scholia to Pindar,[/c] Pythian  4.\[171\] 303). It has usually
	been associated with the Argonauts’ stay in Lemnos, as
	a sequel to Hypsipyle [c dimgray](q.v.). Deforge (see below) has suggested
	that the play may rather have dealt with a subse-[/c]

	λείπειν ἀφνεοῖσι δόμοισι

	Bekkeri[/c] 1.115.3 ὑδρηροὺς πίθους καὶ οἰνηρούς· Αἰσχύλος Καβείροις

	[b]Cabeiri[/b]
	[c dimgray]quent visit they made to Samothrace, where according to
	Apollonius Rhodius (1.915–921) they were initiated into
	the local mysteries of the Great Gods—who in the fifth century
	and later were widely identified, rightly or wrongly,
	with the Cabeiri (Herodotus 2.51.2; Stesimbrotus,[/c] FGrH
	[c dimgray]107 F 20; Plutarch,[/c] Marcellus  30.6); but the wine/drunkenness
	theme (evident also in frr. 96 and 97) points strongly to
	Lemnos, where wine vessels were the most characteristic
	dedication at the Cabeiri’s sanctuary.[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c] If the play followed
	Hypsipyle [c dimgray]within a tetralogy, the other companion plays
	were probably[/c] Lemnian Women [c dimgray]and[/c] The Argo [c dimgray](qq.v.)[/c]

	[c dimgray]REG[/c] 100 (1987) 30–44, esp. 39–41; Podlecki 12–13.

	[b]ΚΑΛΛΙΣΤΩ[/b]
	[c dimgray]The maiden Callisto was a hunting companion of Artemis
	in Arcadia; she was made pregnant by Zeus, and before
	giving birth was transformed into a bear (by Zeus or Hera
	or Artemis); her child, however (who in some accounts
	had to be taken from her womb after Artemis had shot her),
	was a human one, Arcas, the eponymous ancestor of the
	Arcadians. Callisto’s ultimate destiny, by order of Zeus,
	was to be placed in the heavens as the constellation of the
	Great Bear. There are very many variant forms of this
	story (see for example Hesiod fr. 163; Pausanias 8.3.6–[/c]

	[b]ΚΑΡΕΣ Η ΕΥΡΩΠΗ[/b]
	 Europa, who in most accounts is a Phoenician by birth and
	a sister of Cadmus, was abducted by Zeus in the form of
	a bull (or, in this play, by a bull sent by Zeus \[fr. 99.1–2\])
	and taken to Crete, where she gave birth to Minos and
	Rhadamanthys; in some accounts, including the one followed
	in this play, she also has a third son, Sarpedon, destined
	to be killed at Troy (so Hesiod frr. 140, 141). In this
	play Europa, who must now be elderly, is evidently living
	in Caria—which, as Strabo (14.3.3) complains, the dramatist
	seems to have identified or confused with Sarpedon’s
	homeland of Lycia; Minos is dead (implied by fr. 99.12),
	Rhadamanthys though immortal has departed from earth,
	and she is anxious about the welfare of Sarpedon. There
	can be little doubt that the play culminated in the arrival of
	news of Sarpedon’s death, followed probably by the return
	[m1]\ [/m]

	kind that tragedy loved to exploit (e.g. Arcas killed and cut
	up by his grandfather Lycaon to make a cannibalistic meal

	We do not know how Aeschylus treated the subject,

	[b]ΚΕΡΚΥΩΝ[/b]
	 This play is stated to be a satyr-drama by Hesychius on two
	(α6122, ε6960) of the four occasions when he quotes it.
	Cercyon was a king of Eleusis (Aeschylus’ home town)
	who forced all passers-by to wrestle with him, and always
	killed them, until challenged by Theseus; one of the
	metopes of the Athenian Hephaisteion confirms the fifthcentury
	currency of the account found in \[Apollodorus\],
	Epitome 1.3, that Theseus defeated him by lifting him up
	and dashing him against the ground, and there is vaguer
	reference to Theseus “closing Cercyon’s wrestling school”
	[m1]\ [/m]
	102

	ἀμφωτίδες τοι τοῖς ἐνῳδίοις πέλας
	[m1]\ [/m]
	Pollux 10.175
	[m1]\ [/m]
	ἐνῳδίοις Radt, cf. Aesch. fr. 424b (Photius s.v. ἐνωδία):
	ἐνωτίοις codd.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 116[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Cercyon[/b][/c]

	[b]Cercyon[/b]
	[c dimgray]in Bacchylides 18.26–27. The pattern of the play may have
	been similar to that of Euripides[/c]’ Cyclops, [c dimgray]with the satyrs
	(perhaps hitherto enslaved by Cercyon) losing no opportunity
	of displaying their selfishness and cowardice. The
	association—indeed partial identification—between the
	satyrs’ true master Dionysus and Iacchus, the principal
	male divinity worshipped in the Eleusinian Mysteries, may
	well have featured in the play in one way or another[/c].
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Recent studies[/c]: A. Wessels and R. Krumeich in KPS 149–151;
	Podlecki 4–5.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	102
	Ear-guards[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c] next to his earrings.

	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]Worn by wrestlers for protection. The person being described
	evidently has a luxurious lifestyle, but it is not clear
	whether he is Cercyon, or Theseus (thought of as an aristocratic

	Athens), or even Dionysus.

	[b]ΚΗΡΥΚΕΣ[/b]
	[c dimgray]References in Pollux (10.68, 10.186) and Photius[/c] (s.v.
	πυρσοκόρσου λέοντος) [c dimgray]establish that this was a satyrplay,
	and fr. 109 shows that it was concerned with one or
	another of the exploits of Heracles. B. A. van Groningen[/c]
	(Mnemosyne  58 \[1930\] 134) made the very attractive conjecture
	that it referred to one of the first of them, narrated
	by \[Apollodorus\], Library [c dimgray]2.4.9–11. At the age of eighteen,
	Heracles, then living in Thebes, slew a lion on Mount
	Cithaeron and dressed himself in its skin (cf. frr. 109, 110).
	On his way back, he happened to meet the heralds who had
	been sent to Thebes by Erginus, king of the Minyans of
	Orchomenus, to demand Thebes’ annual tribute of a hundred
	cattle; he cut off the heralds’ ears, noses and hands,
	tied them round their necks, and sent them back to Erginus[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	109

	καὶ τῆς σισύρνης τῆς λεοντείου δορᾶς
	[m1]\ [/m]
	Pollux 10.186
	[m1]\ [/m]
	καὶ F S B A: κατὰ C L  σισύρνης C F S: τε σύρνης B A:
	κύρνης L  λεοντείου δορᾶς Mette (<δορᾶς> already Toup),
	cf. Hesychius λ646: λεοντέας B A: λεοντίας C L F S
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 118[/c]

	[c darkmagenta][b]Heralds[/b][/c]

	[b]Heralds[/b]
	[c dimgray]with the message that that was his tribute. Erginus then attacked
	Thebes; his army was routed, and he was killed by
	Heracles[/c].
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]This story in this form cannot, of course, have been converted
	directly into a satyr-play with the satyrs as the heralds,
	since the dramatist could not allow the satyrs to be
	mutilated. However, the satyrs might have usurped the
	role of the heralds (as they seem to have usurped the role of
	Theban councillors in[/c] The Sphinx,  q.v.), changed sides out
	of fear of Heracles and/or because of a promise of reward,
	and encouraged him in his confrontation with the real
	heralds when they arrived.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Recent studies[/c]: A. Wessels and R. Krumeich in KPS 152–6;
	Podlecki 5.

	[b]Circe[/b]
	[c dimgray]Once again, the evidence of quoting authors (here Herodian[/c],
	General Prosody [c dimgray]fr. 12 Hunger and Hesychius
	ζ200) shows this to have been a satyr-play, and it has
	usually been associated with the “Odyssean trilogy” of[/c]
	Ghost-Raisers, Penelope [c dimgray]and[/c] Bone-Gatherers ([c dimgray]qq.v.) It
	presumably dealt with Odysseus’ first visit to Circe after
	his companions had been transformed into pigs: were the
	satyrs Circe’s swineherds (cf. Seaford on Euripides,[/c] Cyclops
	[c dimgray]41–81), as in Euripides[/c]’ Cyclops [c dimgray]they were Polyphemus’
	shepherds? The fragments shed no light on the
	plot[/c].
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Recent studies[/c]: A. Wessels and R. Krumeich in KPS 157–160;
	Podlecki 5.

	[b]ΚΡΗΣΣΑΙ[/b]
	[c dimgray]Our only clue to the subject of this play is fr. 116, a description
	of the varying colours of the blackberry as it ripens;
	this almost certainly links it to the story of Polyidus,
	which was the subject of Sophocles’[/c] Seers [c dimgray]and Euripides’[/c]
	Polyidus.  The story is told by \[Apollodorus\], Library [c dimgray]3.3.1–2
	and Hyginus[/c], Fabulae [c dimgray]136. Glaucus, son of Minos, went
	missing when a child, and Minos was told that he would be
	found by the person who could suggest the best analogy to
	describe a marvellous cow in Minos’ herd which continually
	changed colour—now black, now white, now red. The
	seer Polyidus compared it to a blackberry, and was duly
	asked to find the boy; but he found him dead, drowned in
	a vat of honey. Minos demanded that he restore the boy
	to life; Polyidus did not know how to achieve this, but[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	116

	λευκοῖς τε γὰρ μόροισι καὶ μελαγχίμοις
	καὶ μιλτοπρέπτοις βρίθεται ταὐτοῦ χρόνου
	[m1]\ [/m]
	Athenaeus 2.51d; Eustathius on [c dimgray]Iliad[/c] 22.13
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 122[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Cretan women[/b][/c]

	[b]Cretan women[/b]
	[c dimgray]while shut up with the corpse, he saw a snake bring another
	snake back from the dead by the application of a
	certain herb, and Polyidus then used the same herb to revive
	Glaucus. Minos then demanded that Polyidus teach
	Glaucus the art of divination as the price of being allowed
	to leave Crete, and Polyidus did so, but when his ship was
	getting under way for home he told Glaucus to spit into his
	mouth, and Glaucus instantly forgot all that Polyidus had
	taught him. That this story, in something very like this
	form, was already current in the fifth century we know
	from a white-ground cup of about 440 bc[/c] (London D5)
	which shows a man and boy in a tomb and also two snakes.
	Aeschylus’ play clearly covered at least the first part of this
	story; how far it continued we do not know.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]See further on fr. 451h, which I have suggested may
	come from this play[/c].

	[c dimgray]victim’s blood (fr. 122a). A fragment of a messenger-speech
	that refers to a junction of three roads at Potniae near
	Thebes (fr. 387a) may well be part of a narrative of the

	Laius [c dimgray]or about[/c] Oedipus [c dimgray](q.v.) to be able to say with confidence

	[b]The Lion[/b]
	[c dimgray]Stephanus of Byzantium, who quotes the only line that survives
	from this play (fr. 123), refers to it as a satyr-drama.
	The mythical lion par excellence is surely the Nemean Lion
	which Heracles killed as the first of his Labours, and this
	will have been another instance of the familiar “hero vs.
	monster” scenario in a satyr-play[/c].

	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]This [c dimgray]may[/c] be a metaphorical description of the Nemean Lion;
	but it might also refer to the Lernaean hydra, which was to be
	Heracles’ second Labour—in which case Heracles will presumably

	[b]ΛΗΜΝΙΑΙ[/b]
	[c dimgray]“The Lemnian crime”, the murder by the women of
	Lemnos of their husbands, was proverbially the acme and
	paradigm of human wickedness[/c] (Libation-Bearers [c dimgray]631–7;
	Herodotus 6.138.4). Since Aeschylus[/c]’ Hypsipyle [c dimgray](q.v.) presented
	the aftermath of this crime, with the Argonauts arriving
	at an island with no surviving male inhabitants, it is
	reasonable to suppose that[/c] Lemnian Women [c dimgray]preceded it in
	a trilogy and dramatized the crime itself. The other plays in
	the same production were probably[/c] Cabeiri [c dimgray]and[/c] The Argo
	[c dimgray](qq.v.)[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]The play is named only three times in our sources, and
	while Herodian[/c] (General Prosody [c dimgray]frr. 13, 14 Hunger) twice
	names it as[/c] Λήμνιαι (Lemnian Women), [c dimgray]the medieval[/c]

	[b]ΛΥΚΟΥΡΓΟΣ[/b]
	[c dimgray]The scholia to Aristophanes,[/c] Thesmophoriazusae [c dimgray]135,
	name this as the satyr-play of the Lycurgus tetralogy, following[/c]
	Edonians, Bassarids [c dimgray]and[/c] Youths  (qq.v.) \[Apollodorus\],
	Library [c dimgray]3.5.1, mentions that Lycurgus, in his persecution
	of Dionysus and his followers, took captive not
	only the female bacchants (whose miraculous release was
	one of the high points of[/c] Edonians) [c dimgray]but also the satyrs; this
	detail can hardly be derived from any other source than a
	satyr-drama about Lycurgus. Since the dramatic time of[/c]
	Lycurgus [c dimgray]must logically have been the same as that of[/c]
	Edonians [c dimgray](which began with the first news of the arrival
	of Dionysiac worshippers in Lycurgus’ kingdom, and[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 126[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Lycurgus[/b][/c]

	[b]Lemnian Women[/b]
	[c dimgray]catalogue of Aeschylus’ plays calls it[/c] Λήμνιοι (Lemnians).
	[c dimgray]As in the cases of[/c] Women of Argos [c dimgray]and[/c] Women of Salamis,
	[c dimgray]it is probably the catalogue that is in error; but Deforge
	(see below) accepts[/c] Λήμνιοι [c dimgray]as the title and suggests, without
	any positive evidence, that the play was a satyr-drama—a
	speculation which the contributors to KPS do
	not even deem worthy of being recorded.[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]The two single-word fragments cited by Herodian, and
	published from a Vienna palimpsest in 1967, are the only
	ones known from this play.[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Recent studies[/c]: B. Deforge, “Eschyle et la légende des Argonautes”,
	[c dimgray]REG[/c] 100 (1987) 30–44, esp. 42–43.

	[b]Lycurgus[/b]
	[c dimgray]ended with the disgrace and downfall of the king) it must
	have presented an alternative scenario for the story; this
	would be the only case we know of in which, within a connected
	tetralogy, the plot of the satyr-drama was blatantly
	inconsistent with that of the tragic part of the production.
	If Hermann’s interpretation of fr. 124 (q.v.) is correct,
	Lycurgus was presented as an inhuman tyrant; it has also
	been suggested, on the basis of Nonnus,[/c] Dionysiaca
	[c dimgray]20.226–7 and 248–250, that he tried to “domesticate” the
	satyrs, intending to cut off their equine tails and make
	them sing at his feasts (in honour not of Dionysus, but of
	himself and Ares).[/c]
