	[b]ΜΕΜΝΩΝ[/b]
	[c dimgray]Memnon the Ethiopian, son of the goddess Eos and her
	mortal husband Tithonus, came to aid his uncle Priam and
	the Trojans not long after the death of Hector; he killed
	Nestor’s son, Antilochus, but was then himself killed by
	Achilles. The cyclic epic, the Aethiopis, was named after
	him. Our sources make no acknowledged quotations from[/c]
	Memnon, [c dimgray]but three quotations ascribed to[/c] Agamemnon  do
	not occur in that play, and it is generally and reasonably
	supposed that copyists have each time substituted the more
	familiar play-title for the less familiar. In addition, another
	fragment (fr. 126a \[300\]), speaking of a person of Ethio-Euripides
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 128[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Memnon[/b][/c]
	[c dimgray]Recent studies[/c]: West, [c dimgray]Studies[/c] 26, 47–48; F. Jouan, “Dionysos chez
	Eschyle”, [c dimgray]Kernos[/c] 5 (1992) 71–86, esp. 76; R. Germar and R.
	Krumeich in KPS 164–8; Podlecki 6.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	124
	And he would allow time for these[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c] to dry, and then drink
	beer out of them, and make a proud boast of this in his banqueting
	room.[c dimgray][sup]2[/sup][/c]

	[b]Memnon[/b]
	[c dimgray]pian origin and his native land, can also be plausibly ascribed
	to this play; if that is so, since the speaker has apparently
	not yet met Memnon, the play must have included his
	arrival at Troy, and may have been climaxed by his killing
	of Antilochus; the continuation of the story, and Memnon’s
	own death, will have been presented in[/c] The Weighing of
	Souls [c dimgray](q.v.) For a possible third (or rather first) play to
	complete a trilogy, see note on[/c] The Carians.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]In addition to what can be gleaned from the textual
	fragments, our sources offer three other significant details
	about the play: (1) Aristophanes,[/c] Frogs [c dimgray]963, makes[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]Probably the skulls of men he had killed, as Hermann brilliantly
	conjectured on the basis of Nonnus, [c dimgray]Dionysiaca[/c] 20.149–153,
	166–181. Thirteen centuries after Aeschylus, in AD 811, another
	ruler in Thrace—Krum, khan of the Bulgars—allegedly
	made a drinking cup of the skull of the Byzantine emperor
	Nikephoros I (Theophanes Confessor, [c dimgray]Chronographia[/c] p.491.17–22 de Boor).
	[c dimgray][sup]2[/sup][/c]lit. “men’s room”, a poetic equivalent of the
	more common ἀνδρών. Part of the sting of the remark is that
	Greeks considered beer-drinking unmanly; cf. [c dimgray]Suppliants[/c] 952–3,
	and see my article in [c dimgray]Museum Criticum[/c] 25–28 (1990–3) 59–64.

-505.135 (AESCHYLUS, Attributed Fragments)
%Attributed Fragments Myrmidons
AESCHYLUS, Attributed Fragments
	[c darkmagenta][b]AESCHYLUS, Attributed Fragments[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Attributed Fragments[/b][/c]

	[b]ΜΥΡΜΙΔΟΝΕΣ[/b]
	[c dimgray]This was the first play of a trilogy based on the[/c] Iliad, [c dimgray]being
	followed by[/c] Nereids [c dimgray]and[/c] Phrygians [c dimgray](qq.v.) and perhaps
	by the satyr-drama[/c] Chamber-Makers [c dimgray](q.v.) It corresponded
	approximately to books 9–18 of the epic, and its
	setting appears to have been within the hut of Achilles (fr.
	131.3–4; for imaginary interior settings in the pre[/c]-skene
	[c dimgray]theatre, cf[/c]. Persians [c dimgray]140–1). Achilles sat silent and veiled
	for a long time (cf. Aristophanes[/c], Frogs [c dimgray]911–5), ignoring
	the pleas of his followers the Myrmidons (frr. 131, 132).
	Eventually his old tutor Phoenix persuaded him to break
	his silence (fr. 132b), but only to emphasize, and explain,
	his determination not to go to the aid of the Achaean army
	(fr. 132c). Eventually, when word came that the ships were
	being set on fire (fr. 134), Patroclus, we may presume, as in
	the[/c] Iliad, [c dimgray]persuaded Achilles—in Aeschylus’ treatment the
	two were lovers (Plato,[/c] Symposium [c dimgray]180a; cf. frr. 135–7)—to
	let him go into battle in Achilles’ armour; and presently
	Antilochus (fr. 138) brought Achilles the shattering news of
	Patroclus’ death after splendid heroic exploits (cf. Aristophanes,[/c]
	Frogs [c dimgray]1041), which was soon followed by the arrival
	of Patroclus’ corpse (cf. frr. 135–7). Achilles, as in[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 134[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Myrmidons[/b][/c]

	[b]Myrmidons[/b]
	[c dimgray]Homer, blamed himself for sending Patroclus to his doom
	(fr. 139) and was desperate to go into battle and avenge him
	(fr. 140), but could not, because he now had no armour.[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]A series of vase paintings, showing Odysseus addressing
	an Achilles who is muffled up in his cloak, is probably
	to be associated with our play, particularly since there
	is a parallel series linkable to[/c] Nereids. [c dimgray]By the generally
	accepted dating, the earliest of these vases belongs to the
	490s, but vase dating is not an exact science, and it is unlikely
	that this tetralogy, which was one of Aeschylus’ most
	famous productions, predates his first victory in 484. It
	may very well, indeed, have been the production with
	which he won that victory and made his name for life.[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Recent studies[/c]: A. Garzya, “Sui frammenti dei Mirmidoni di
	Eschilo”, in J. A. López Férez ed. [c dimgray]De Homero a Libanio[/c] (Madrid,
	1995) 41–56; A. Moreau, “Eschyle et les tranches des repas
	d’Homère: la trilogie d’Achille”, [c dimgray]CGITA[/c] 9 (1996) 3–29; Sommerstein
	[c dimgray]AT[/c] 338–343; M. L. West, “[c dimgray]Iliad[/c] and [c dimgray]Aethiopis[/c] on the
	stage: Aeschylus and son”, [c dimgray]CQ[/c] 50 (2000) 338–352, esp. 340–1; P.
	Michelakis, [c dimgray]Achilles in Greek Tragedy[/c] (Cambridge, 2002) 22–57.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 135[/c]

	through anger because of bad leadership?[c dimgray][sup]3[/sup][/c] \[If\] all on my

	from battle, then I \[alone\] am everything to the
	Achaean army:[c dimgray][sup]4[/sup][/c] I have no compunction about uttering
	words like that. \[For who (?)\] would \[say (?)\] that \[leaders
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]Achilles’ point is that by stoning him the Achaean army would be
	doing themselves no good: he would still, even in death, be benefiting
	the Trojans by depriving their enemies of his fighting
	strength.
	[c dimgray][sup]2[/sup][/c]This rendering does not claim to do more than
	give the apparent general sense of the sentence. For death as the
	“healer of troubles” cf. frr. 255, 353.
	[c dimgray][sup]3[/sup][/c]lit. “because of a bad
	shepherd” (i.e. Agamemnon, “shepherd of the people” in Homeric
	phrase).
	[c dimgray][sup]4[/sup][/c]I have followed Norsa & Vitelli’s restorations
	and sentence-divisions in lines 9 and 11. The main alternative,
	represented by Steffen’s restoration in line 9 (see apparatus),
	would make the sense run approximately: “Shall I, for fear of the
	Achaeans, set myself in motion . . ., I who all on my own . . . caused
	so much harm by my absence from battle? I alone am everything
	to the Achaean army.”
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[c dimgray]In the fifteen remaining lines, the intelligible expressions are[/c] I
	have said, and I have not spoken falsely [c dimgray](26),[/c] he[c dimgray][sup]9[/sup][/c] will destroy
	this army [c dimgray](27)[/c], one can see [c dimgray](28)[/c], accuser [c dimgray](30)[/c], you speak freely (?)
	[c dimgray](31)[/c], more fortunate [c dimgray](32)[/c], no one has thoughts [c dimgray](33)[/c], this is in no
	way appropriate [c dimgray](34)[/c], recon\[ci\]liation [c dimgray](35)[/c], propi\[ti\]ation [c dimgray](36)[/c]. [c dimgray]It
	is likely that from line 28 a different character is speaking, arguing
	with some bluntness that Achilles is in the wrong and should
	try to compose his quarrel with Agamemnon; this[/c] may [c dimgray]still be
	Phoenix, but Phoenix’s earlier speech seems to have been rather
	diffident (cf. fr. 132b.5), and it is at least as likely that the speaker
	now is Patroclus, whose intimacy with Achilles would enable him
	to speak more boldly (cf.[/c] Iliad [c dimgray]16.29–35).[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]5[/sup][/c]The demonstrative adjective implies a gesture, possibly towards
	Odysseus if he is present (but even if there was an “embassy”
	scene in the play—for which we have only the uncertain
	evidence of the vase-paintings—Achilles could not have made this
	speech before Phoenix had succeeded in breaking his silence, and
	to have Odysseus present at that stage would require three actors, impossible in an earlyish play), more likely an angry wave in the
	direction in which the rest of the Achaean camp is supposed to lie.
	(Achilles and his men were right at one end of the encampment:
	[c dimgray]Iliad[/c] 8.225–6, 11.8–9.)
	[c dimgray][sup]6[/sup][/c]Cycnus was killed by Achilles at the
	very beginning of the Trojan War ([c dimgray]Cypria[/c] Arg. §10 West); that
	Achilles is speaking of an event early in the war is clear from his
	reference to his “young arms”.
	[c dimgray][sup]7[/sup][/c]If this reading, or something
	like it, is correct, the person meant is evidently Agamemnon.
	[c dimgray][sup]8[/sup][/c]Achilles is referring to himself.
	[c dimgray][sup]9[/sup][/c]Hector?
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[c dimgray]The central character of[/c] Mysians [c dimgray]was Telephus. This can be
	inferred from the mention in the play (fr. 145) of Oeum, a
	village near Telephus’ birthplace Tegea in Arcadia, and
	also from Aristotle’s criticism[/c] (Poetics [c dimgray]1460 a[/c]30–32) of “the
	man in Mysians [c dimgray]who came from Tegea to Mysia without
	ever speaking”—for though Sophocles also wrote a play
	called[/c] Mysians [c dimgray]in which a man, almost certainly Telephus,
	arrives in Mysia from abroad, we know that in Sophocles’
	play this man immediately asks a native what country he is
	in (Sophocles fr. 411). The Aeschylean Telephus had been
	silent because he was under blood-pollution (cf.[/c] Eumenides [c dimgray]448–450), having killed his maternal uncles, the sons[/c]

	[b]Youths[/b]
	[c dimgray]This was the third play of the Lycurgus tetralogy, following[/c]
	Edonians [c dimgray]and[/c] Bassarids  and preceding the satyr-play
	Lycurgus (qq.v.) The fragments give us little clue to its content;
	but it has been attractively suggested by West and by
	Seaford (see below) that, after the violent overthrow by Dionysus
	and his devotees, first of Lycurgus who had rejected
	him, and then of Orpheus who had exalted Apollo/Helios
	above him, Youths  presented a reconciliation in which
	cults of Dionysus and of Apollo/Helios were both firmly established
	in Thrace.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Recent studies:[/c] West, [c dimgray]Studies[/c] 46–47; F. Jouan, “Dionysos chez
	Eschyle”, [c dimgray]Kernos[/c] 5 (1992) 71–86, esp. 75–76; M. Di Marco, “Dioniso
	ed Orfeo nelle [c dimgray]Bassaridi[/c] di Eschilo”, in A. Masaracchia ed.
	[c dimgray]Orfeo e l’orfismo[/c] (Rome, 1993) 101–153; R. A. S. Seaford, “Mystic
	light in Aeschylus’ [c dimgray]Bassarai”[/c], CQ 55 (2005) 602–6, esp. 605–6.2

	[b]NEMEA[/b]
	[c dimgray]Unless this play took its title from the town of Nemea
	or from the Nemean Games (which would be very abnormal,
	either for a tragedy or for a satyr-drama), the title
	must refer to the only known mythical character of that
	name, and probably to the only story about her that is attested
	(by an introductory scholium to Pindar’s[/c] Nemeans),
	[c dimgray]namely that she was the mother of the child Archemorus
	who was killed by a snake at Philus while the expedition of
	the Seven against Thebes was passing through the town,
	and in whose memory their leader, Adrastus, founded the
	Nemean Games. If so, the play will have corresponded[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 154[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]

	the immortals.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	146b

	[m1]\ [/m]


	[b]Nemea[/b]
	[c dimgray]in subject to Euripides’ late play[/c] Hypsipyle, [c dimgray]where, however,
	the boy’s original name is Opheltes (he is renamed
	Archemorus after his death) and his mother’s Eurydice
	(Hypsipyle, in exile from Lemnos, being his nurse). There
	is, however, no reason to believe that Hypsipyle figured in
	Aeschylus’ play. No quotations survive.[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]It is very tempting to associate this play with[/c] Eleusinians,
	Women of Argos, [c dimgray]and[/c] Epigoni [c dimgray](qq.v.), in all of
	which Adrastus was probably a character; if so, it must
	have been a satyr-drama—with an athletic connection, as
	in[/c] The Sacred Delegation.

	[b]ΝΗΡΕΙΔΕΣ[/b]
	[c dimgray]This play has nearly always been regarded as the second
	play of the Achilles trilogy, following[/c] Myrmidons [c dimgray]and preceding[/c] Phrygians ([c dimgray]qq.v.) In the[/c] Iliad [c dimgray](18.35–147), Thetis is
	accompanied by her sisters the Nereids when she comes to
	comfort Achilles after the death of Patroclus, and later
	(19.1–39) she returns alone bringing him the new armour
	which Hephaestus has made. Aeschylus merged these two
	visits into one, making Thetis and the Nereids together
	bring Achilles his armour; the play then probably continued
	with Achilles’ preparations for battle, a report of
	his exploits including the killing of Hector, the funeral of
	Patroclus (cf. fr. 153) and perhaps Achilles’ abusive treatment
	of Hector’s body—roughly the material contained in
	books 19–23 of the[/c] Iliad.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]However, the few surviving fragments explicitly attributed
	to the play contain nothing that obviously refers to
	Hector, Patroclus, or Achilles’ new armour, and it has been
	possible for West (see below) to argue that[/c] Nereids [c dimgray]was the
	third, not the second, play of the trilogy, and that its subject
	was the death of Achilles. West’s arguments are not[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	150
	δελφινηρὸν πεδίον πόντου
	διαμειψάμεναι
	[m1]\ [/m]
	Scholia to Euripides, [c dimgray]Phoenician Maidens[/c] 209
	[m1]\ [/m]
	1 δελφινηρὸν Vr: δελφίνορον cett.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 156[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Nereids[/b][/c]

	[c dimgray]strong (the main one being that he cannot imagine what a
	chorus of Nereids would do in the presence of Hector’s
	body), and are all but conclusively refuted by the artistic
	evidence: simultaneously with the well-known series of
	vase paintings apparently inspired by[/c] Myrmidons, [c dimgray]there
	begins another series (LIMC Achilles nos. 510–525), showing

-505.161 (AESCHYLUS, Attributed Fragments)
%Attributed Fragments Niobe
AESCHYLUS, Attributed Fragments
	[c darkmagenta][b]AESCHYLUS, Attributed Fragments[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Attributed Fragments[/b][/c]
	153

	λεπτὸς δὲ σινδὼν ἀμφιβαλλέσθω χροΐ
	[m1]\ [/m]
	Herodian, [c dimgray]On the Declension of Nouns[/c] ed. A. Hilgard,
	[c dimgray]Excerpta ex libris Herodiani technici[/c] (Leipzig, 1887) p. 22.31.

	[b]NIOBH[/b]
	 Niobe, daughter of Tantalus and wife of Amphion of
	Thebes, offended Apollo and Artemis (and/or their mother
	Leto) by boasting that she had many fine children (in
	Aeschylus the number was fourteen) while Leto had had
	only two; Apollo and Artemis punished her by destroying
	all her children, and she wept inconsolably until the gods
	transformed her into a rock at Mount Sipylus in Lydia
	which continued to shed tears (Iliad 24. 602–617). [c dimgray]Aeschylus’
	play began after the catastrophe, with Niobe sitting
	veiled and wordless at her children’s tomb (fr. 154a. 6–7;
	Aristophanes,[/c] Frogs 911–920; Life of Aeschylus 5); [c dimgray]later
	her father came to Thebes (frr. 154a. 10, 158, 159), presumably
	to comfort her so far as he could and to take her home
	to Lydia, her husband Amphion being probably also dead
	(cf. Ovid,[/c] Metamorphoses [c dimgray]6.271). It is hard to see how
	there can have been much plot development, and the play
	is likely to have concerned itself mainly with Tantalus’ efforts
	to understand, and to come to terms with, so appalling
	a disaster, and to persuade his daughter to do likewise.[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Two lines from the play (now fr. 154a.15–16) attained
	notoriety through being quoted and criticized by Plato[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 160[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Niobe[/b][/c]
	153
	Let fine linen be cast over his body.
	[m1]\ [/m]


	[b]Niobe[/b]
	(Republic [c dimgray]380a) as propagating an unacceptable belief in
	divine malevolence; however, now that a papyrus has given
	us an idea of their context, we can see that Plato was making
	tendentious use of the lines, and that they were designed,
	not primarily to blame the gods, but to introduce a
	criticism of Niobe.[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Two fragments of a line or more ascribed by Radt to this
	play, 157a and 164, have here been omitted. There is no adequate
	reason to suppose that fr. 157a (= Aristophanes,[/c]
	Thesmophoriazusae [c dimgray]889–890, from a scene parodying Euripides’
	Helen) is quoted or adapted from Aeschylus; on fr.
	164, see de Lucia (below).[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Recent studies[/c]: A. Garzya, “Sur la Niobé d’Eschyle”, [c dimgray]REG[/c] 100
	(1987) 185–202; R. de Lucia, “Eschilo, fr. 164 Radt (Niobe): una
	fonte sconosciuta e alcune osservazione”, [c dimgray]Atti dell’ Accademia
	Pontaniana[/c] 38 (1989) 113–120; A. Moreau, “La Niobé d’Eschyle:
	quelques jalons”, REG 108 (1995) 288–307; M. Alfani, “Note sulla
	Niobe di Eschilo”, [c dimgray]Rivista di Cultura Classica e Medioevale[/c] 39
	(1997) 261–9, and “La ‘Niobe’ di Eschilo: una storia degli studi”,
	[c dimgray]Appunti Romani di Filologia[/c] 1 (1999) 1–26; R. A. S. Seaford,
	“Death and wedding in Aeschylus’ [c dimgray]Niobe”[/c], in F. McHardy et al.
	ed. [c dimgray]Lost Dramas of Classical Athens[/c] (Exeter, 2005) 113–127.

	The land I sow extends for twelve days’ journey: the country
	of the Berecyntians,[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c] where the territory of Adrasteia[c dimgray][sup]2[/sup][/c]
	and Mount Ida resound with the lowing and bleating of

	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]The Danube, which separated Thrace from Scythia.
	[c dimgray][sup]2[/sup][/c]The principal river of Colchis, now the Rioni in Georgia.
	[c dimgray][sup]3[/sup][/c]Or “as this”. It is not clear what maiden or maidens are being described
	(the chorus? the daughters of Niobe?) or what is being asserted
	about them. It may or may not be relevant that in [c dimgray]Prometheus
	Bound[/c] (415–6) the Amazon warrior-maidens live in Colchis, and
	in Herodotus (4.110–117) their descendants live in Scythia.
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]A Phrygian tribe.
	[c dimgray][sup]2[/sup][/c]The land on the Asian shore of the
	Propontis (Sea of Marmara) at its western end, between Parium
	and Cyzicus.
	[c dimgray][sup]3[/sup][/c]Meaning here, apparently, the Troad, after
	Erichthonius son of Dardanus ([c dimgray]Iliad[/c] 20.219–230), owner of
	three thousand horses and great-great-grandfather of Priam.
	Thus Tantalus is describing himself as ruler of the whole region
	known to fifth-century Greeks as Phrygia.

	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]In Aristophanes’ play this is part of a response by the hero,
	Peisetaerus, to a threatening tirade by the goddess Iris. She had
	said: “Fool, fool, do not provoke the formidable souls of the gods,
	lest all your race be utterly overthrown by Justice with the mattock
	of Zeus, and smoky flame reduce to ashes your person and the
	enclosure of your house with Licymnian bolts!” (Birds 1238–42),
	to which Peisetaerus replies [c dimgray]inter alia:[/c] “Do you know that if Zeus
	annoys me any further, I will reduce his halls and the home of
	Amphion \[sic\] to ashes with incendiary eagles . . .?” (1246–8),
	after which his menaces become more bird-centred, more comic,
	and finally obscene.
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]i.e. Death is immune to all persuasion.

	[b]ΞΑΝΤΡΙΑΙ[/b]
	[c dimgray]This play is known to have dealt with the fate of an enemy
	of Dionysus at the hands of female bacchants: in fr. 169
	Lyssa, the goddess of madness, urges them on to tear
	their victim in pieces. The death of Pentheus was certainly
	mentioned in the play (fr. 172b), and its location was
	Mount Cithaeron, as in Euripides’[/c]Bacchae.[c dimgray]Since an ancient
	headnote (Hypothesis) to[/c] Bacchae [c dimgray]names[/c] Pentheus
	[c dimgray](q.v.) as the Aeschylean play running parallel to it, it has
	often been suspected that Pentheus’ death was not part of
	the action of [/c]Wool-Carders[c dimgray]but was only predicted in it. In
	view of fr. 169, however, we would then have to suppose
	that in the play named after him Pentheus only appeared
	as a corpse, if at all—for which there would be no parallel[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 170[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Wool-Carders[/b][/c]
	162
	[c darkmagenta][b]Niobe[/b][/c]
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]Those who are near of kin to the gods and close to Zeus,[c dimgray][sup]2[/sup][/c]
	whose altar of Ancestral Zeus is high in the upper air on the
	crags of Ida, and in whom the divine blood has not yet lost
	its potency.

	[b]Wool-Carders[/b]
	[c dimgray]in what we know of Greek tragedy. This is probably, all the
	same, the least bad of the available hypotheses. Alternative
	possibilities are (i) that[/c] Wool-Carders [c dimgray]and[/c] Pentheus  are
	two names for the same play (but Galen quotes lines from
	both plays \[frr. 170, 183\], each under its own title, in the
	same passage) and (ii) that the plot of Wool-Carders [c dimgray]had
	nothing to do with Pentheus at all but dealt with another
	Dionysiac story, such as that of the daughters of Minyas
	who resisted Dionysus, were driven mad, and tore the
	son of one of themselves in pieces (but the late Hellenistic
	scholar Asclepiades—see on fr. 220a—clearly associated[/c]
	Wool-Carders [c dimgray]with the Cadmus-Semele-Pentheus story).
	A further complication is the existence of a set of papyrus[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]Strabo states that Niobe is the speaker, and that she is referring
	to the family of Tantalus.
	[c dimgray][sup]2[/sup][/c]No text earlier than or contemporary
	with Aeschylus specifies Tantalus’ parentage, but in all
	later sources bar one (starting with Euripides, [c dimgray]Orestes[/c] 5) he is a
	son of Zeus (the exception is a scholium to the same Euripidean
	passage, which names the mountain-god Tmolus as his father).
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 171[/c]

	Spears of pine blazing with fire.[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]

	[b]Oedipus[/b]
	[c dimgray]This was the second play of the Theban tetralogy, following[/c]
	Laius [c dimgray]and preceding[/c] Seven against Thebes [c dimgray]and[/c] The
	Sphinx; [c dimgray]its possible content is discussed in the introduction
	to[/c] Seven against Thebes. [c dimgray]No fragments survive, unless fr.
	387a, part of a narrative about the murder of Laius, comes
	from this play.[/c]

	[b]The Award of the Arms[/b]
	[c dimgray]The subject of this play was the contest for the armour
	of Achilles, in which Ajax was defeated by Odysseus; the
	play probably formed a trilogy with[/c] Thracian Women [c dimgray]and[/c]
	Women of Salamis [c dimgray](qq.v.). It is likely, in view of fr. 174,
	that Thetis, who offered the armour as a prize for the
	best man in the Achaean army, was a character in the play.
	The play was apparently imitated by the Roman dramatists
	Pacuvius and Accius in tragedies entitled[/c] Armorum
	Iudicium, [c dimgray]and was probably a major source for the accounts
	of the episode by Ovid[/c] (Metamorphoses [c dimgray]12.620–13.381)
	and Quintus of Smyrna[/c] (Posthomerica [c dimgray]5.1–332).[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Recent studies[/c]: M. Librán Moreno, “Philostr. [c dimgray]Her[/c]. 20.2: una posible
	alusión a [c dimgray]El juicio de las armas[/c] de Ésquilo”, [c dimgray]Cuadernos de
	Filología Clásica: estudios griegos y indoeuropeos[/c] 16 (2006) 195–209.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]i.e. torches; cf. Euripides, [c dimgray]Bacchae[/c] 144–7.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]The scholiast says that the speaker was “inviting the Nereids
	to come out <of the sea> and judge <the contest>”, but this may be
	an error: one would not expect goddesses to give an unjust verdict
	unless (like Athena, cf. [c dimgray]Little Iliad[/c] fr. 2 West) they were prejudiced,
	and there would be no reason for the Nereids to be prejudiced
	in favour of Odysseus or against Ajax. The established account
	in the first half of the fifth century was that the contest was
	decided by a vote of the army (Pindar, [c dimgray]Nemean[/c] 8.27; two paintings
	by the Brygos Painter, [c dimgray]LIMC[/c] Aias I 83 and 84), and Sophocles
	([c dimgray]Ajax[/c] 449, 1135–7) assumes that his audience know this.
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]The allegation that Odysseus was really the son of Sisyphus,
	not of Laertes, is repeatedly made in tragedy by his enemies
	(Sophocles, [c dimgray]Ajax[/c] 189; [c dimgray]Philoctetes[/c] 417, 625; fr. 567). The story was
	that he had slept with Anticleia when visiting her father Autolycus
	to reclaim his stolen cattle, or had raped her when she was on her
	way to Ithaca, so that she was already pregnant with Odysseus
	when Laertes married her (scholia to Sophocles, [c dimgray]Ajax[/c] 190).
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[c dimgray]The two surviving fragments of this play both come from a
	speech or speeches by Odysseus, describing the indingnities

	his own palace, by Penelope’s suitors, whose bodies, or perhaps
	rather their ash-urns, are visible on stage(cf. fr. 180.1[/c]ὅδ᾿). [c dimgray]Since[/c] ὀστολογία [c dimgray]is the collection of ashes for burial
	after a body has been cremated (see e.g. Menander,[/c]The
	Shield 77),[c dimgray]it is generally accepted that the play was based
	on the episode in the Odyssey (24.413ff) where the families
	of the suitors collect and bury their bodies (or ship them
	home) and then meet to plot revenge on Odysseus. In the
	epic, however, Odysseus has left the palace for his father’s[/c]

	[b]Bone-Gatherers[/b]
	[c dimgray]country estate; in the play he stands his ground and
	justifies his actions. The play was probably the third in an
	Odyssean trilogy, following[/c] Ghost-Raisers [c dimgray]and[/c] Penelope
	[c dimgray](qq.v.); the accompanying satyr-play was no doubt[/c] Circe
	[c dimgray](q.v.)[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]The references to symposiac games in fr. 179, and to a
	chamber-pot being thrown at Odysseus in fr. 180, have led
	many scholars to believe that[/c] Bone-Gatherers  was a satyr-play.
	To accept this, however, would force us to abandon
	the notion of an Odyssean tetralogy; moreover, Athenaeus
	(1.17c) criticizes Aeschylus (and Sophocles \[fr. 565\], who
	closely imitates fr. 180 of this play) for presenting drunken
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]Or, with Nauck, “. . . in living for one towhom life brings . . .”
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]Or “she” or “it”. We do not know what the subject of the sentence
	was—it need not necessarily have been the owner of the
	lungs; compare e.g. Pindar, [c dimgray]Pythian[/c] 1.1–9, on the effect of music
	in quenching the fire of Zeus’s thunderbolt and lulling his eagle to
	sleep.

	[b]ΠΑΛΑΜΗΔΗΣ[/b]
	[c dimgray]Palamedes is a figure unknown to, or ignored by, the
	poet(s) of the[/c] Iliad [c dimgray]and[/c] Odyssey, [c dimgray]but the tale of how he was
	treacherously murdered during the Trojan War, by Odysseus—in
	some versions alone, in others with Diomedes
	and sometimes Agamemnon as accomplices—was a popular
	one from the cyclic epics onwards, and was dramatized
	by all three of the great tragedians. Odysseus’ motive
	is sometimes revenge, Palamedes having unmasked him
	when he tried to avoid serving in the war by pretending to
	be mad[/c] (Cypria [c dimgray]Arg. §5 West), sometimes jealousy of his
	cleverness. The later accounts, doubtless deriving from one
	or more of the tragic treatments, regularly have Palamedes[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]None of these authors names the play, but both Athenaeus
	and Philodemus make it clear that the victim of the assault was
	Odysseus.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	chamber-pot, and he did not miss his aim; it struck me on

	[b]Palamedes[/b]
	[c dimgray]being condemned by the army on a trumped-up charge of
	treason and put to death by stoning; frr. 181a and 182
	would fit well into such a scenario as part of a defence
	speech. Aeschylus’ play, however, went on beyond Palamedes’
	condemnation and execution, since fr. 181 shows
	that Palamedes’ father, Nauplius, came to Troy (as Sophocles
	later made him do in[/c] The Arrival of Nauplius)  and protested,
	doubtless to little effect, about what had been done
	to his son; the story was that he took revenge later by causing
	the Greek fleet to be wrecked on its way home and/or by
	encouraging the leaders’ wives to have adulterous affairs.

	[b]Perrhaebian Women[/b]
	[c dimgray]This play is generally considered to have dealt with the
	story of Ixion’s treacherous murder of his father-in-law,
	Eioneus or Deioneus. Ixion was king of Gyrton, a city in
	Perrhaebia (northern Thessaly) (Strabo 9.5.19), and the
	three surviving quotations fit very well the story of how
	Ixion, in order to avoid paying (D)eioneus the gifts due by
	custom in exchange for his daughter, invited his father-in-law
	as if to a feast and enticed him into entering a room
	which he had booby-trapped; (D)eioneus fell into a fiery
	pit and perished in the flames (Pindar,[/c] Pythian [c dimgray]2.21–48
	with scholia; Diodorus Siculus 4.69.3–5). The sequel to this
	murder was presented in[/c] Ixion [c dimgray](q.v.), which may or may
	not have been part of the same production.[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	184
	Where are my many choice gifts? Where are the cups
	wrought in gold and silver?
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Presumably Ixion’s father-in-law demanding his bride-gifts.[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]lit. “a pustule”, i.e. a round, bright drop.

	attached to them.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	186
	He has died a disgraceful death by a scheme to defraud
	him of what was his.

	[b]Penelope[/b]
	[c dimgray]From the title and the only surviving fragment (187) we
	can see that this play dramatized the section of the[/c] Odyssey
	[c dimgray]during which Odysseus returned to his own house in the
	guise of a beggar, and that it included a version of the interview
	between him and Penelope which fills most of book 19
	of the epic. We cannot tell what other episodes were included,
	or how closely Aeschylus followed the Homeric
	story, though it is tempting to imagine that the play culminated
	in the (offstage) slaying of Penelope’s suitors and the
	reunion of husband and wife.[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	Penelope [c dimgray]was probably the second play of an Odyssean
	tetralogy, preceded by[/c] Ghost-Raisers [c dimgray](q.v.) and followed
	by[/c] Bone-Gatherers [c dimgray]and the satyr-drama[/c] Circe [c dimgray](qq.v.)[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 193[/c]

	tetralogy, it may either have preceded or followed[/c]
	Phorcides [c dimgray](q.v.), and the accompanying satyr-drama will
	certainly have been[/c] Net-Haulers [c dimgray](q.v.), which featured

	liver. At the beginning of[/c] Prometheus Unbound [c dimgray]this prediction
	has been fulfilled (fr. 193). Prometheus is visited by

	children of bulls,[c dimgray][sup]2[/sup][/c] to take over their labours and be the
	equivalent of slaves.

	[b]Prometheus Unbound[/b]
	[c dimgray]parently been released by Zeus from their underground
	imprisonment, and tells them of his sufferings. Then—again
	as predicted in the previous play—Heracles arrives,
	having got lost on his way to attempt the most distant of his
	Labours, the taking of the apples of the Hesperides (cf.
	Strabo 4.1.7); he shoots the eagle (fr. 200) and is given directions
	for his journey (frr. 195–9). Prometheus and Zeus
	are still at enmity (fr. 201), but there was subsequently a
	reconciliation between them, with Prometheus revealing
	the secret with which he might otherwise have caused the
	overthrow of Zeus—that Thetis, for whom Zeus has conceived
	a passion, is destined to bear a son mightier than his
	father (cf. Philodemus,[/c] On Piety [c dimgray]p.41.4–16 Gomperz): we
	learn of honours given to Prometheus in memory of his[/c]

	of Europe and Asia is a watercourse called the Bosporus; one
	would have expected this to mean the Cimmerian Bosporus (the
	Strait of Kerch, connecting the Black Sea with the Sea of Azov),
	but I have argued [c dimgray]ad loc.[/c] that the author, either inadvertently or
	intentionally, has there confused the Cimmerian Bosporus with
	the Phasis.
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]For classical Greeks this name denoted the whole Indian
	Ocean with its gulfs.
	[c dimgray][sup]2[/sup][/c]The close connection made between
	the Ethiopian bay and the “Red Sea” implies that we are to place it
	in the distant East: cf. [c dimgray]Prometheus Bound[/c] 807–9, Herodotus 7.70, and Euripides fr. 771 (from [c dimgray]Phaethon[/c]) who speaks of “the first
	land on which the rising Sun casts his golden flame, \[which\] the
	neighbouring black men call the shining stables of Dawn and
	the Sun”.

	[c darkmagenta][b]Prometheus Unbound[/b][/c]
	makes a vast racket and, as it flies off into the sky, it licks my
	blood with its tail feathers. And when the liver on which it
	has fed has been renewed and reinflated, then it comes
	back and sets itself greedily again to its cruel feeding. Thus
	I provide nourishment to this warder of my wretched torture,
	who defiles my living body with endless misery; for
	held fast, as you see I am, in Zeus’s chains, I am unable to
	keep this terrible bird away from my breast. And so, bereaved
	of my own self, I endure a succession of anguishing
	torments, ever seeking an end to my suffering, longing
	for death. But the power of Zeus keeps death far away
	from me, and this ancient, lamentable atrocity, accumulated
	through generations of horror,[c dimgray][sup]4[/sup][/c] is indelibly imprinted
	in my body—my body, from which fall drops[c dimgray][sup]5[/sup][/c] melted by
	the heat of the sun, which continually drip on to the rocks
	of the Caucasus.[c dimgray][sup]6[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]4[/sup][/c]Thirteen human generations have passed since Prometheus
	was first bound to the rock ([c dimgray]Prometheus Bound[/c] 774), during a long
	but undefined portion of which he was beneath the earth ([c dimgray]ibid.[/c]
	1020–1).
	[c dimgray][sup]5[/sup][/c]Drops of blood, or rather ichor. According to Apollonius
	Rhodius, [c dimgray]Argonautica[/c] 3.845–866, these drops caused a plant to
	spring up, an ointment extracted from which was later used by
	Medea to make Jason invulnerable for a day; this tale may go back
	to Sophocles’ [c dimgray]Women of Colchis[/c] (cf. the Hypothesis to [c dimgray]Prometheus
	Bound,[/c] and Sophocles fr. 340).
	[c dimgray][sup]6[/sup][/c]Cicero, like most who wrote about Prometheus in antiquity,
	thought that the Caucasus was the scene of his binding; it certainly
	was not so in [c dimgray]Prometheus Bound[/c] (cf. lines 719–720 of that play; the
	Hypothesis nevertheless asserts that the scene is “in Scythia on
	the Caucasian mountains”), and there is no reason to believe that
	it was so in [c dimgray]Prometheus Unbound[/c] either (see A. Bonnafé, [c dimgray]Journal
	des Savants[/c] \[1991\] 153–6). Cicero has doubtless added the word
	for metrical and/or stylistic reasons, unaware that he was introducing
	a geographical error.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	Prometheus the Fire-Bearer [c dimgray]was a serious play forming a
	trilogy with[/c] Prometheus Bound [c dimgray]and[/c] Unbound. [c dimgray]There are,
	however, two serious objections to this view. On the one
	hand, there is no possible place for[/c] Prometheus the Fire-Bearer
	[c dimgray]in a tragic Prometheus-trilogy. It cannot have come
	first, because the exposition of the initial situation in[/c] Prometheus
	Bound [c dimgray](especially in 199–241) is so full and detailed
	as to preclude the possibility that the audience are
	being told all this for the second time; it cannot have come
	second, because Hermes’ prophecy in[/c] Prometheus Bound
	[c dimgray]1014–29 allows for no other events to intervene between
	Prometheus’ return to the daylight and the beginning of his
	torment by the eagle; and it cannot have come third, because[/c]
	Prometheus Unbound [c dimgray]is known to have wound up
	the story of Prometheus so completely that there can have
	been no scope for a further play about him (see introductory
	note to[/c] Prometheus Unbound). [c dimgray]On the other hand,
	since epithets were attached to play-titles precisely for the
	purpose of distinguishing between plays of the same name[/c]

	[b]ΠΡΩΤΕΥΣ[/b]
	[c dimgray]This was the satyr-drama that concluded the Oresteia tetralogy;
	ti is generally agreed that it must have presented
	the adventures of Menelaus in Egypt, which he narrates in
	the fourth book of the[/c] Odyssey (351–580). [c dimgray]Proteus in the[/c]
	Odyssey [c dimgray]was the probhetic, shape-changing “Old Man of
	the Sea”; in Stesichorus (Chamaeleon fr. 29 Wehrli =[/c] PMG
	193), [c dimgray]in Herodotus (2.112–120), and in Euripides’[/c] Helen,
	[c dimgray]he was simply a human king of Egypt. We do not know how
	he was presented in Aeschylus, though the evidence, such
	as it is, tends to favour the Homeric over the Stesichorean
	model (see below). The play’s focus on Menelaus seems to
	be prepared for , earlier in the tetralogy, by references to his[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 220[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]The Escort[/b][/c]
	207b (369)
	A mortal woman created by the fashioning of clay.[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]

	208
	Staying silent when appropriate and saying what suits the
	occasion.[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]

	[b]The Escort[/b]
	[c dimgray]Nothing whatever is known about this play except for its
	title and a one-word citation (fr. 209), neither of which
	gives any clue to its subject-matter.[/c]

	[b]Proteus[/b]
	[c dimgray]disappearance on the homeward voyage from Troy, and his
	possible eventual return, in[/c] Agamemnon [c dimgray](617–633, 674–9)
	and[/c] Libation-Bearers [c dimgray](1041). Some of the descriptions of
	Helen in[/c] Agamemnon, [c dimgray]in particular those at 404–426 and
	737–743, have also led Cunningham and Griffith (see below)
	to suggest that Aeschylus, like Euripides after him,
	used Stesichorus’ idea that the Trojan War was fought for
	a phantom divinely substituted for Helen while the real
	Helen, unknown to Menelaus or anyone else, was in Egypt;
	but fr. 211 suggests that, as in the[/c] Odyssey, [c dimgray]Menelaus was
	not on the Egyptian mainland but on a small island off
	its coast, where he and his party were forced to subsist[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]lit. “from clay-fashioned seed”.
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]This line is almost identical with [c dimgray]Cho.[/c] 582, and very similar
	to [c dimgray]Seven[/c] 619.
	[m1]\ [/m]

-505.223 (AESCHYLUS, Attributed Fragments)

AESCHYLUS, Attributed Fragments
	[c darkmagenta][b]AESCHYLUS, Attributed Fragments[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Attributed Fragments[/b][/c]
	210
	σιτουμένην δύστηνον ἀθλίαν φάβα
	μέσακτα πλευρὰ πρὸς πτύοις πεπληγμένην
	[m1]\ [/m]
	Athenaeus 9.394a
	[m1]\ [/m]
	2 πεπληγμένην Schweighaeuser: πεπλεγμένην cod.

	[b]ΣΑΛΑΜΙΝΙΑΙ[/b]
	[c dimgray]The medieval catalogue calls this play Σαλαμίνιοι, implying
	a chorus of male Salaminians, but this has no support
	among the authors who cite the fragments, and there
	are other errors of the same type in the catalogue (see on[/c]
	Women of Argos and Lemnian Women). [c dimgray]The most famous
	mythical episode to take place on Salamis was the return
	from Troy of Teucer, the half-brother of Ajax, and his[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 222[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Women of Salamis[/b][/c]
	[c dimgray]unheroically on fish (cf.[/c] Odyssey [c dimgray]4.354–369)—and neither
	a human king Proteus, nor Helen as a guest of his,
	would have been living in such a place. The satyrs, who
	may have found themselves on the island as a result of shipwreck
	(as in Euripides’[/c] Cyclops), [c dimgray]perhaps gave assistance
	to Menelaus and escaped with him, though he may well
	have had difficulty in ensuring that they kept their hands
	off Helen. Eido (in Homer, Eidothea), the daughter of Proteus,
	may have been a character in the play (fr. 212).[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Recent discussions[/c]: M. Cunningham, “Thoughts on Aeschylus:
	the satyr play [c dimgray]Proteus[/c]—the ending of the [c dimgray]Oresteia”, Liverpool
	Classical Monthly[/c] 19 (1994) 67–68; Sommerstein [c dimgray]AT[/c] 189–190; R.
	Germar and R. Krumeich in KPS 179–181; P. Yziquel, “Le drame
	satyrique eschyléen”, [c dimgray]CGITA[/c] 14 (2001) 1–22, esp. 10–13; M.
	Griffith, “Slaves of Dionysos: satyrs, audience, and the ends of the
	[c dimgray]Oresteia[/c]”, CA 21 (2002) 195–258, esp. 237–254; D. Del Corno,
	“Odisseo fra i Satiri”, in G. Zanetto et al. ed. [c dimgray]Momenti della
	ricezione omerica[/c] (Milan, 2004) 187–195; Podlecki 7.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	210
	A poor wretched pigeon trying to feed,[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c] which has been
	struck by winnowing-fans and had its ribs clean broken.

	[b]Women Of Salamis[/b]
	[c dimgray]banishment by his angry father Telamon for having failed
	to protect Ajax’s life; he afterwards founded the city of Salamis
	in Cyprus. It is generally accepted that this was the
	subject of this play, and that it probably followed[/c] The
	Award of the Arms [c dimgray]and[/c] Thracian Women [c dimgray](qq.v.) as the
	third play in an Ajax trilogy.[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]sc. on the grain that is being winnowed.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 223[/c]

AESCHYLUS, Attributed Fragments
	[c darkmagenta][b]AESCHYLUS, Attributed Fragments[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Attributed Fragments[/b][/c]
	215a (404)
	Αἴγινα δ᾿ αὕτη πρὸς νότου κεῖται πνοάς
	[m1]\ [/m]
	Strabo 9.1.9(not naming the play; he is discussing Salamis city
	which “faces Aegina and the south”); assigned to this play by Wagner
	[m1]\ [/m]
	216
	εἴ μοι γένοιτο φᾶρος †ἶσον† οὐρανῷ
	[m1]\ [/m]
	Herodian, (i) [c dimgray]General Prosody[/c] i.392.30 Lentz; id., (ii) [c dimgray]On
	Vowels of Doubtful Length[/c] ii.16.6 Lentz; id., (iii) [c dimgray]On Anomalous
	Words[/c] ii. 942.4 Lentz
	[m1]\ [/m]
	εἴ μοι (i, iii): ἐμοὶ (ii)  ἶσον (ii): ἴσον ἐν (i, iii): perh. εἰκὸς?

	[b]ΣΕΜΕΛΗ Η ΥΔΡΟΦΟΡΟΙ[/b]
	[c dimgray]Until fairly recently our main information about this
	play came from a scholium on Apollonius Rhodius’[/c] Argonautica
	 (1.636) which stated that Aeschylus “brought
	\[Semele\] on stage pregnant and divinely possessed, and
	the women who touched her belly also became possessed”.
	These women must evidently have been the chorus of the
	play. They may have been laying hands on Semele’s belly to
	ease her labour pains (cf. Soranus, Gynaecology 2.4.1),
	[c dimgray]and perhaps had brought (hot) water to warm their hands
	for this purpose.[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]The story of Semele’s death is told in many variants, but
	is almost always the same in essentials. Semele, daughter of
	Cadmus of Thebes, having been made pregnant by Zeus,
	was persuaded by the jealous Hera, who visted her in disguise,
	to ask Zeus to come to her in his full divine glory;[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 224[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Semele [c dimgray]or[/c] Water-Carriers[/b][/c]
	215a (404)
	And there lies Aegina, in the direction from which the
	south wind blows.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	216
	If I had[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c] a robe that looked like (?) the heavens[c dimgray][sup]2[/sup][/c] . . .

	[b]Semele [c dimgray]or[/c] Water-Carriers[/b]
	[c dimgray]Zeus, who had previously given her the right to have
	any one request granted, duly came, and Semele was destroyed
	by his lightnings and thunderbolts; Zeus, however,
	snatched the unborn Dionysus from her body, sewed him
	up in his own thigh, and kept him there till he was ready to
	come into the world. The actual or prospective birth of Dionysus
	was certainly a concern of our play, since there was
	mention of the Amphidromia (fr. 222), a household ritual
	for a new-born child; but the few short book-fragments
	that survive told us little more than this.[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	 However, a papyrus published in 1941 (frr. 220a-c
	\[168, 168a-b\]) contains fragments of a choral song which
	mentions Semele and Cadmus, followed by hexameter
	verses some of which are referred to by Plato (Republic
	[c dimgray]381d) as having been spoken by Hera in the disguise of[/c]

-505.227 (AESCHYLUS, Attributed Fragments)

AESCHYLUS, Attributed Fragments
	[c darkmagenta][b]AESCHYLUS, Attributed Fragments[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Attributed Fragments[/b][/c]
	[c dimgray]a mendicant priestess. Hera is not spoken of as having
	adopted this particular disguise in other versions of the
	Semele story, but no one would have doubted that these
	papyrus fragments were indeed from[/c] Semele, [c dimgray]were it not
	for one conflicting piece of evidence: the ancient scholar
	Asclepiades, cited in the scholia to Aristophanes,[/c] Frogs
	[c dimgray]1344, ascribes the first two of the hexameter lines (here fr.
	220a.16–17) to[/c] Wool-Carders [c dimgray](q.v.) and claims to have
	found them in a manuscript he consulted at Athens. This is
	itself a statement that arouses some suspicion, since it implies
	that the lines were[/c] not [c dimgray]in the texts of[/c] Wool-Carders
	 regularly used by the scholars of Alexandria, and in fact
	Asclepiades is a far from reliable witness on matters of this
	kind.[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c] We should certainly not feel it our duty to believe
	him if it entails supposing that Aeschylus brought a disguised
	Hera into Wool-Carders, [c dimgray]a play set at a time when
	Dionysus had grown to maturity and begun to act violently
	against enemies such as Pentheus, when every other mention
	of a disguised Hera in connection with Dionysus refers
	to a time before his birth. We can safely assign the papyrus[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]Of the four other statements by Asclepiades about tragedy
	that survive in the Aristophanic scholia, one is certainly and one
	almost certainly wrong. In [c dimgray]Birds[/c] 348 he detects parody of Euripides’
	[c dimgray]Andromeda[/c], which was not produced until two years after
	[c dimgray]Birds[/c]; and he ascribes [c dimgray]Frogs[/c] 1270 (= Aesch. fr. 238) to Aeschylus’
	[c dimgray]Iphigeneia[/c] when another scholar, Timachidas, said it was from
	[c dimgray]Telephus[/c] (they were probably both guessing: see introductory
	note to [c dimgray]Telephus[/c]). It should be added, too, that [c dimgray]Frogs[/c] 1344 itself
	can hardly be derived from [c dimgray]Wool-Carders[/c] (as Asclepiades
	claimed), or from any other Aeschylean play, when it forms part of
	a song which is presented by the character “Aeschylus” as typically
	Euripidean, and which elsewhere parodies only Euripides!
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 226[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Semele [c dimgray]or[/c] Water-Carriers[/b][/c]
	[c dimgray]fragments to[/c] Semele. [c dimgray]Hera’s words, with their praise of the
	modest (and of course chaste) bride and their hints (fr.
	220a.24–28) that the nymphs may be “harsh and hateful”
	to one who does not meet these standards, seem well designed
	to make the chorus—and Semele herself, if present—even
	more apprehensive than they must already be
	about the risk to her reputation if she is thought to have lost
	her virginity to a mortal, and therefore to put them in a
	mood to listen receptively to a suggestion that she demand
	that Zeus make it manifest to all that[/c] he [c dimgray]is the father of her
	unborn child.[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	 On the question of a trilogy/tetralogy of which Semele
	[c dimgray]may have formed part, see introductory note to[/c] Wool-Carders.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Recent discussions[/c]: F. Jouan, “Dionysos chez Eschyle”, [c dimgray]Kernos[/c] 5
	(1992) 71–86, esp. 77; J. Hadjicosti, “Hera transformed on stage:
	Aeschylus fr. 168”, [c dimgray]Kernos[/c] 19 (2006) 291–301.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[c dimgray]These two plays clearly dealt with two phases of a well-known
	story about Sisyphus, the renowned trickster and
	king of Corinth, told by a scholiast on[/c] Iliad  6.153 who cites
	Pherecydes (fr. 119 Fowler) as his authority. Sisyphus having
	incurred the wrath of Zeus, Zeus sent Death to take him
	away, but Sisyphus bound Death in chains so that no one
	died until Hades[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c] released Death from his bonds. Sisyphus
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]

	good repute ([c dimgray]8), and[/c] and of Cadmus ([c dimgray]9[/c]).
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[c dimgray]or[/c] \[he\] proclaim\[s\] [c dimgray](2)[/c], ailments [c dimgray](3)[/c], I speak [c dimgray](4), and perhaps[/c]
	accept [c dimgray](5).[/c][c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]

	<h2>Sisyphus the Runaway [c dimgray]and[/c]
	Sisyphus the Stone-Roller</h2>
	[c dimgray]had time before he died to instruct his wife, Merope, not to
	make the customary offerings at his tomb, and eventually,
	as he had planned, Hades sent him home to Corinth to remonstrate
	with her—and he stayed there. When, however,
	he finally died of old age, he was punished in the underworld
	by being made to roll a great stone uphill, only for it
	always to roll down again before he had reached the top
	(cf.[/c] Odyssey [c dimgray]11.593–600).[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]It is plausible to suppose that[/c] Sisyphus the Runaway
	[c dimgray]was set in Corinth and presented Sisyphus’ return from the[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]

	person plural; if this is indeed part of the hexameter speech of the
	disguised Hera, the addressees will be either the chorus or the
	nymphs whose priestess she is pretending to be.

	[c dimgray]play or the other (frr. 225, 226, 228 to the[/c] Runaway; 229
	[c dimgray]and 230 to the[/c] Stone-Roller; [c dimgray]227 uncertain). It has sometimes
	been suggested (most recently by Gantz 174) that the
	two plays were actually one and the same; but as Germar et
	al. (below) 182 n.1 point out, the existence of two clearly
	distinct epithets shows that ancient scholars knew of two
	plays and needed to distinguish them[/c].

	KPS 182–8; Podlecki 13.

	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]The Horace passage (cf. opposite) suggests that this footwashing
	was performed by Sisyphus (rather than, say, Merope)
	and that there was something cunning ([c dimgray]vafer[/c]) about it; Germar et
	al. attractively suggest as a possibility that the feet are those of
	Death, and that the invitation to have them washed is a ruse to facilitate
	his being seized and bound. Alternatively this may be
	Merope welcoming Sisyphus back from the dead and treating him
	(wrongly) as one who is now immortal.

	[b]ΤΗΛΕΦΟΣ[/b]
	[c dimgray]After becoming king of Mysia (see on[/c] Mysians), [c dimgray]Telephus
	was wounded by Achilles when Agamemnon’s army landed
	in his country in the belief that they had arrived near Troy.
	Being told by an oracle that his wounder would also be his
	healer, he went to Argos (or Mycenae), where the army
	was assembled, pleaded for assistance, and was eventually
	healed by the verdigris from Achilles’ spear-point; in
	return he agreed to guide the fleet on its voyage to Troy.
	This story was as old as the cyclic epic, the[/c] Cypria [c dimgray](Arg.
	§7 West), and was famously dramatized by Euripides in
	438 bc.[/c] The most sensational episode in Euripides’ play,
	Telephus’ seizure of the infant Orestes as a hostage, may
	have featured already, in a somewhat different (and less violent)
	form, in Aeschylus’ play; this is stated by a scholiast
	on Aristophanes, Acharnians [c dimgray]332, and Csapo and Preiser[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 242[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Telphus[/b][/c]
	236[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]
	The Sphinx, the bitch[c dimgray][sup]2[/sup][/c] that presided over days of ill-fortune

	[b]Telephus[/b]
	([c dimgray]see below) have argued that iconographic evidence supports
	the view that Orestes was first brought into the Telephus
	story not in 438 but in or around the 460s[/c].
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]This play seems to have been lost, or at least to have become
	a bibliographic rarity, at an unusually early date.
	There is only one unequivocal citation of it by any author
	later than the mid fourth century; and fr. 238, which is ascribed
	by one Hellenistic scholar (Timachidas) to[/c] Telephus
	[c dimgray]and by another (Asclepiades) to[/c] Iphigeneia, [c dimgray]was not to be
	found in any Aeschylean text in the Alexandrian Library in
	the time of the great Aristarchus (mid second century bc[/c]).
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Recent discussions[/c]: E. G. Csapo, “Hikesia in the [c dimgray]Telephus[/c] of Aeschylus”,
	QUCC 63 (1990) 41–52; C. Preiser, [c dimgray]Euripides: Telephos[/c]
	(Hildesheim, 2000) 51–59.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]The verse is lyric (dactylic). The Aristophanic scholia explicitly
	ascribe it to [c dimgray]The Sphinx[/c], in which the most plausible place for
	it would be in a retrospective song after the monster’s destruction;
	but Naeke may have been right to suggest that the ascription is erroneous
	and that the line actually came from [c dimgray]Oedipus[/c].
	[c dimgray][sup]2[/sup][/c]The Sphinx is called a dog because she snatched up her prey; in
	[c dimgray]Seven against Thebes[/c] (776–7) she is τὰν ἁρπαξάνδραν κῆρα, in
	Sophocles ([c dimgray]Oedipus the King[/c] 391) ἡ ῥαψῳδὸς . . . κύων.

	[b]ΤΟΞΟΤΙΔΕΣ[/b]
	[c dimgray]It is evident from frr. 241 and 244 that the central figure of
	this play was Actaeon (son of Aristaeus and of Autonoe,
	daughter of Cadmus), who was torn to pieces by his own
	hunting dogs when Artemis turned him into a stag for an
	offence against her (or in some versions, against Zeus—see
	below). Since women archers were not a feature either of
	ancient Greek society or (except in the case of Amazons) of
	the ancient Greek imagination, the chorus is likely to have
	consisted of nymphs accompanying Artemis.[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]It is possible that the play was part of a tetralogy whose
	other plays dealt with Actaeon’s aunt Semele, her son Dionysus,
	and her other nephew Pentheus; see introductory[/c]

-505.249 (AESCHYLUS, Attributed Fragments)
%Attributed Fragments The Nurses of Dionysus
AESCHYLUS, Attributed Fragments
	[c darkmagenta][b]AESCHYLUS, Attributed Fragments[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Attributed Fragments[/b][/c]
	244

	κύνες διημάθυνον ἄνδρα δεσπότην
	[m1]\ [/m]
	Scholia to [c dimgray]Iliad[/c] 9.593 (Αἰσχύλος . . . περὶ τοῦ Ἀκταίωνος
	λέγων)

	[b]ΤΡΟΦΟΙ[/b]
	[c dimgray]The first Hypothesis to Euripides’[/c] Medea  reports that Aeschylus
	in this play told how Medea “rejuvenated the nurses
	of Dionysus, together with their husbands, by boiling
	them”—as in other accounts she had done to Jason and/or
	his father Aeson, and as she had pretended she would do to
	his uncle Pelias. A reference to this story by Ovid (Metamorphoses
	7.294–6) [c dimgray]suggests that Medea did this at the request
	of Dionysus. Rejuvenation—at any rate successful
	rejuvenation—is a theme for satyr-drama, not tragedy; the
	role of Dionysus in the story points the same way, and
	there is virtually no doubt that this play was indeed satyric.
	A vase-painting of about 460 bc[/c] (Ancona, Mus. Naz.
	3198; see e.g. KPS pl. 23a,b) shows on one side a female
	leading an elderly satyr towards a cauldron (exactly as in
	several images in which the woman is Medea and the old
	man Pelias) and on the other side a family scene consisting
	of what seems like the same satyr, now black-haired and
	vigorous, with his wife and a small satyr-child; it could
	very well have been inspired by this play.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]The “nurses of Dionysus” are in most accounts the
	nymphs of Mount Nysa in Thrace; as Germar and[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 248[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]The Nurses of Dionysus[/b][/c]
	244
	The dogs were tearing my \[[c dimgray]or[/c] their\] master to shreds.
	[m1]\ [/m]


	[b]The Nurses of Dionysus[/b]
	[c dimgray]Krumeich (below) point out, nymphs ought to be immortal
	and not need rejuvenation, but perhaps one should not apply
	such logic to a satyr-play. Nor is it clear what Medea is
	doing in this region; perhaps it is after her plot against
	Theseus and her flight from Athens.[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]This play certainly has some abnormal features, not
	least the fact that the satyrs, creatures whose sexual desires
	are always intense and nearly always frustrated, are to all
	appearances happily married. It is also rare for a satyrdrama
	to have a secondary chorus, which the “nurses”
	must have been (unless they were silent throughout). And
	in order for the rejuvenation to take effect, both the satyrs
	and the nymphs must at some point have left the scene and
	presently returned with new masks. It is particularly sad,
	therefore, that we have no quotation from the play more
	than three words long, and no papyrus fragments
	identified.[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]This may well have been the fourth play of a Dionysiac
	tetralogy; see introductory note to[/c] Wool-Carders.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Recent discussions[/c]: R. Germar and R. Krumeich in KPS 197–202;
	Podlecki 14–15.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 249[/c]

	[b]ΥΨΙΠΥΛΗ[/b]
	[c dimgray]Hypsipyle, daughter of Thoas, was the leader of the women
	of Lemnos when they killed all the men on the island (see
	introductory note to[/c] LemnianWomen). [c dimgray]Our only information
	about the play, apart from two single-word quotations,
	comes from a scholium to Apollonius Rhodius,[/c] Argonautica
	[c dimgray]1.769–773. In Aeschylus’ play, according to this
	scholium, when the Argonauts were caught in a storm off
	Lemnos and hoping to come in and land there, the Lemnian
	women “came against them in arms” and refused to let
	them put in unless they swore to have intercourse with the[/c]

	[b]ΦΙΛΟΚΤΗΤΗΣ[/b]
	[c dimgray]Aeschylus, Euripides and Sophocles (in that chronological
	order) all dramatized the story of how Philoctetes, who
	had been abandoned on the island of Lemnos by the Greeks
	on their way to Troy, was persuaded, tricked or forced,
	nine years later, into rejoining the expedition, because the
	Greeks had learned that his presence, or at least that of the
	bow and arrows of Heracles which he possessed, was essential
	if Troy was to be captured. Only Sophocles’ play survives
	complete, but we are provided with much information
	about the other two by Dio Chrysostom, whose 52nd[/c]
	Oration [c dimgray]is a comparison of the three plays. Dio notes that
	in comparison with his successors, Aeschylus is sometimes
	a little insouciant about questions of realistic probability.
	For example, whereas in Euripides’ play Odysseus was
	transformed by Athena so as not to be recognized by
	Philoctetes, and in Sophocles he keeps out of Philoctetes’[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 250[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Hypsipyle[/b][/c]

	[b]Hypsipyle[/b]
	[c dimgray]women as soon as they landed. Such an episode, taking
	place at sea, is not suitable for direct dramatic treatment in
	tragedy, and must therefore have been narrated retrospectively,
	perhaps in a prologue.[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	Hypsipyle [c dimgray]was probably part of an Argonautic tetralogy,
	Following[/c] LemnianWomen [c dimgray]and preceding[/c] Cabeiri
	[c dimgray]and[/c] The Argo ([c dimgray]qq.v[/c].)
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Recent discussions[/c]: B. Deforge, “Eschyle et la légende des Argonautes”,

	strikes Dio as less dishonest and unheroic than his Euripidean
	and Sophoclean counterparts (§§5, 9), even though,
	like them, he used deception to deprive Philoctetes of the

	to minimize the danger in which he would be placing himself

	what Dio is responding to.[/c]

-505.261 (AESCHYLUS, Attributed Fragments)
%Attributed Fragments Phorcides
AESCHYLUS, Attributed Fragments

	[b]ΦΟΡΚΙΔΕΣ[/b]
	 The Phorcides (daughters of Phorcys), or Graeae (“old
	women”), were significant secondary figures in the story of
	Perseus and the Gorgon’s head; their most famous characteristic
	was that they had only one eye and one tooth between
	the three of them, so that Perseus by stealing the
	eye and tooth was able to render them helpless. In one common
	version of the myth, presented for example by Aeschylus’
	contemporary Pherecydes (fr. 11 Fowler), he thereby
	forced them to tell him how to find the nymphs (waternymphs
	\[naiads\] according to the inscription on one sixthcentury
	vase painting \[ LIMC [c dimgray]Perseus 88\]) who possessed
	the winged sandals and cap of invisibility that he needed in
	order to get near the Gorgon Medusa, and the bag[/c] (kibisis)
	 in which to put her head. In this account there is a wide
	gap in space and time between the Graeae and the Gorgons
	themselves; Aeschylus, as we learn from \[Eratosthenes\],
	Catasterisms [c dimgray]22 (= Aeschylus fr. 262), closed this
	gap—doubtless for dramatic convenience—by making the
	Graeae “sentinels” to the Gorgons. Perseus seized their eye
	while one of them was handing it to another, threw it into[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 260[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Phorcides[/b][/c]

	[b]Phorcides[/b]
	[c dimgray]Lake Tritonis (this detail tells us the geographical setting
	of the play), and so was able to get past them, find the
	Gorgons asleep, and cut off Medusa’s head. These exploits
	were apparently reported by a third party in what must
	have been a long and elaborate messenger-speech (cf. fr.
	261), presumably to the chorus (which perhaps consisted
	of nymphs of the lake, friendly to Perseus—cf. above).[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]This play is assigned by Aristotle,[/c] Poetics [c dimgray]1456a2–3, to
	the same subcategory of tragedy as[/c] Prometheus [c dimgray]and “all
	those plays set in Hades”; unfortunately textual corruption
	has left it uncertain how he defined this category. It
	may have been produced together with[/c] Polydectes [c dimgray]and the
	satyr-play[/c] Net-Haulers ([c dimgray]qq.v.), though no other related
	play can be identified that would complete a tetralogy.
	There are some slight indications that this production
	came rather late in Aeschylus’ career[/c].
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Recent discussions[/c]: J. H. Oakley, “Perseus, the Graiai, and Aeschylus’
	[c dimgray]Phorkides[/c]”, AJA 92 (1988) 383–391; Gantz 304–6; S. E.
	Goins, “The date of Aeschylus’ Perseus tetralogy”, [c dimgray]RhM[/c] 140
	(1997) 193–210.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 261[/c]

	[b]ΦΡΥΓΕΣ ἢ ΕΚΤΟΡΟΣ ΛΥΤΡΑ[/b]
	[c dimgray]This was the third play of the Achilles trilogy (following[/c]
	Myrmidons [c dimgray]and[/c] Nereids, [c dimgray]qq.v.), and corresponded closely
	to the final book of the[/c] Iliad. [c dimgray]As in[/c] Myrmidons, [c dimgray]the scene
	was Achilles’ hut. The Phrygians of the title had come
	there with Priam (Aristophanes fr. 696), and as a chorus
	they performed some highly distinctive dances[/c] (ibid.); [c dimgray]they
	were perhaps servants rather than Trojan citizens. Before
	their arrival Achilles had had a short dialogue with Hermes
	(who may have been assigned the role which in[/c] Iliad
	[c dimgray]24.120–142 is played by Thetis) and then, again as in[/c] Myrmidons,
	[c dimgray]sat silent and veiled for a long time (scholia to
	Aristophanes,[/c] Frogs [c dimgray]911[/c]; Life of Aeschylus [c dimgray]6). In the[/c] Iliad
	[c dimgray](22.346–354) Achilles had vowed that he would not return
	Hector’s body for burial even if Priam were to offer Hector’s
	weight in gold as a ransom; in Aeschylus, precisely
	this ransom was offered and accepted, being apparently
	literally weighed in scales against Hector’s corpse (scholia
	to[/c] Iliad [c dimgray]22.351; Lycophron,[/c] Alexandra [c dimgray]269–270 with scholia).
	In addition to Achilles, Priam and Hermes, fr. 267 suggests
	(though it does not prove) that there was a fourth[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 262[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	<header><hgroup>Phrygians [c dimgray]or[/c]
	the Ransoming of Hector</hgroup></header>
	261
	He plunged into the cave like a wild boar.[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]

	picked it up on one of his visits to Sicily; on this, however, see M.
	Griffith in R. D. Dawe ed. [c dimgray]Dionysiaca: Nine Studies . . . presented
	to Sir Denys Page[/c] (Cambridge, 1978) 104–6.

	<h2>Phrygians [c dimgray]or[/c]
	the Ransoming of Hector</h2>
	[c dimgray]individual[/c] dramatis persona, [c dimgray]a woman; the scholiast who
	quotes the fragment identifies her as Andromache, Hector’s
	widow, but the text of the fragment itself, stressing as it
	does the fact that this person[/c] comes from the same city [c dimgray]as
	Andromache, suggests rather that it is someone else, most
	likely Briseis. Did she, Achilles’ heterosexual partner, give
	crucial help to Priam in mollifying Achilles, as Achilles’ homosexual
	partner had mollified him in[/c] Myrmidons [c dimgray](and as
	Tecmessa tries in vain to mollify Ajax in Sophocles’[/c] Ajax)?
	[c dimgray]The play will doubtless have included laments over Hector
	by Priam and the chorus, replacing the laments of the
	women in Troy[/c] (Iliad [c dimgray]24.718–776) which the structure of
	Aeschylus’ play did not allow him to include.[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]The medieval catalogue of Aeschylus’ plays lists Φρύγες
	and Φρύγιοι as two separate dramas. This is the only
	mention of an Aeschylean title Φρύγιοι, and such a title
	would be contrary to fifth-century usage (Φρύγιος being
	then in use only as an adjective). Either, therefore, the title
	Φρύγιοι is a mere doublet of Φρύγες, or else, as Bothe first[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 263[/c]

	Ἀνδραίμονος γένεθλον <‒> Λυρνησσίου,
	ὅθεν περ Ἕκτωρ ἄλοχον ἤγαγεν φίλην
	[m1]\ [/m]
	Scholia to Euripides, [c dimgray]Andromache[/c] 1
	[m1]\ [/m]
	1 <ὦ> Hermann: <ὂν> Wagner

	[b]ΨΥΧΑΓΩΓΟΙ[/b]
	[c dimgray]This play, as fr. 275 shows, dramatized the Homeric
	Nekyia[/c] (Odyssey [c dimgray]11), and, like it, included a prophecy of
	Odysseus’ death, presumably made by Teiresias; we do not
	know how many of the other characters who appear in the
	Homeric episode (the main ones are the sailor Elpenor,
	Odysseus’ mother Anticleia, Agamemnon, Achilles and a
	silent Ajax) figured in Aeschylus’ play. The scene was a lake
	with a connection to the underworld (frr. 273, 273a); it
	has been identified as Lake Avernus in Campania (cf. Maximus
	of Tyre,[/c] Discourses [c dimgray]8.2b), as the Acherusian lake
	in Thesprotia (cf. Herodotus 5.92η.2), and even as Lake
	Stymphalus in Arcadia (so the medieval scholar Thomas
	Magister, on Aristophanes,[/c] Frogs [c dimgray]1266—but Odysseus, in
	a ship, could never have got there), and the chorus consisted
	of devotees of Hermes living beside the lake and
	operating a necromantic sanctuary there (this perhaps
	slightly favours the Thesprotian location; cf. Alexis fr. 93,[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 268[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Ghost-Raisers[/b][/c]
	267
	Child of Andraemon of Lyrnessus, the place from which
	Hector brought his dear wife.[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]

	[b]Ghost-Raisers[/b]
	[c dimgray]from a comedy called[/c] The Thesprotians). [c dimgray]The play probably
	stood first in an Odyssean tetralogy, being followed
	by[/c] Penelope, Bone-Gatherers [c dimgray]and the satyr-drama[/c] Circe
	([c dimgray]qq.v[/c].)
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Recent discussions[/c]: A. Henrichs, “Namenlosigkeit und Euphemismus:
	Zur Ambivalenz der chthonischen Mächte im attischen
	Drama”, in H. Hofmann and A. M. Harder, [c dimgray]Fragmenta Dramatica[/c]
	(Göttingen, 1991) 161–201, at 187–192; Sommerstein, [c dimgray]Aeschylean
	Tragedy[/c] 349–350; M. Librán Moreno, “[c dimgray]TrGF[/c] 2 Adesp. fr. 370
	K.-Sn.: Aeschylus’ [c dimgray]Psychagogoi?”, Exemplaria Classica[/c] 8 (2004)
	7–29; R. Bardel, “Spectral traces: ghosts in tragic fragments”, in F.
	McHardy et al. ed. [c dimgray]Lost Dramas of Classical Athens[/c] (Exeter,
	2005) 83–112, at 85–92; C. Cousin, “La [c dimgray]Nékyia[/c] homérique et
	les fragments des Évocateurs d’âmes d’Eschyle”, [c dimgray]Gaia[/c] 9 (2005)
	137–152.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]In the [c dimgray]Iliad[/c] Andromache comes not from Lyrnessus but from
	Thebe, and her father’s name is Eëtion ([c dimgray]Iliad[/c] 6.395–7). Briseis
	does come from Lyrnessus ([c dimgray]Iliad[/c] 2.689–690, 19.60), but her father’s
	name is Briseus ([c dimgray]Iliad[/c] 1.392 etc.). Achilles had sacked both
	cities in the same campaign (2.690–3), killing Eëtion and his seven
	sons ([c dimgray]Iliad[/c] 6.416–424); thus there was already in Homer a link between
	the fates of Briseis and Andromache, and Aeschylus makes
	this link closer by making them natives of the same city. We cannot
	tell whether Briseis is here being addressed or only spoken about
	(for example in a speech by Achilles explaining to Priam the chain
	of events that led to Hector’s death).
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 269[/c]

	death would come to Odysseus in old age ἐξ ἁλός . . . ἀβληχρός;
	these words were probably intended to mean that Odysseus’
	death would be a gentle one, far from the sea, but they were capable
	of being taken to mean almost exactly the opposite. Aeschylus’
	version, which may be his own invention, is evidently designed to
	save Odysseus from the disgrace of being killed, even unwittingly,

	already so firmly established in the myth that it could not

	from the sixth-century epic known as the [c dimgray]Telegony[/c] or [c dimgray]Thesprotis[/c])
	was that the barb was given by Circe to Telegonus, her son by
	Odysseus, to use as a spear-point, and he killed Odysseus with it
	not knowing him to be his father; but the version we find here is
	given as an alternative by Sextus Empiricus, [c dimgray]Against the Teachers[/c]
	1.267 (though the bird is a seagull rather than a heron). Both are
	ultimately based on Teiresias’ prophecy ([c dimgray]Odyssey[/c] 11.134–6) that

-505.275 (AESCHYLUS, Attributed Fragments)
%Attributed Fragments Oreithyia
AESCHYLUS, Attributed Fragments
	[c darkmagenta][b]AESCHYLUS, Attributed Fragments[/b][/c]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Attributed Fragments[/b][/c]

	[b]ΨΥΧΟΣΤΑΣΙΑ[/b]
	[c dimgray]This play must have been a sequel to[/c] Memnon [c dimgray](q.v.) In it,
	as we learn from Plutarch[/c] (Moralia [c dimgray]17a) and from scholia
	to[/c] Iliad [c dimgray]8.70 and 22.210, Zeus weighed the souls of Achilles
	and Memnon in the scales as they fought each other, and
	the mothers of the two heroes, Thetis and Eos, pleaded
	each on behalf of her son. This weighing of the souls (or
	fates) of Achilles and Memnon appears in art from the sixth
	century onwards (though it is usually Hermes who holds
	the scales), and it doubtless featured in the cyclic epic, the[/c]
	Aethiopis; [c dimgray]it is parodied by Aristophanes in[/c] Frogs [c dimgray]1365–1410.
	A reference by Pollux (4.130) to the weighing scene is
	directly followed by mention of the use of the[/c] mēchanē
	[c dimgray](here called[/c] γέρανος [c dimgray]“crane”) by “Eos snatching up the
	body of Memnon”, and it is likely that he is still thinking of
	the same play (certainly there is no other we know of to
	which he could be referring).[/c]

	[b]ΩΡΕΙΘΥΙΑ[/b]
	[c dimgray]Oreithyia, daughter of the Athenian king Erechtheus, was
	abducted by Boreas (the North Wind) and became the
	mother of Zetes and Calaïs (see introductory note to[/c]
	Phineus). [c dimgray]We only know of the existence of Aeschylus’ play
	about her from a single reference by the rhetorician John of
	Sicily[/c] (Commentary on Hermogenes [c dimgray]On Types of Style
	p.225.24–26 Walz) who paraphrases a passage about
	Boreas “puffing with both his cheeks and stirring up the
	sea”; this seems to come from the same speech by Boreas[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 274[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Oreithyia[/b][/c]

	[b]The Weighing of Souls[/b]
	[c dimgray]This is the only known tragedy in which Zeus was
	definitely present on stage, though it is possible that he
	appeared in[/c] Prometheus Unbound.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]West (see below) has argued that[/c] The Weighing of
	Souls, [c dimgray]like the[/c] Prometheus [c dimgray]plays with which it shares a
	fondness for divine characters and extravagant spectacle,
	was not written by Aeschylus but by his son Euphorion, to
	complete a sequence of plays which Aeschylus had left
	unfinished; see also introductory note to[/c] Carians.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]The only surviving fragments attributed to this play are
	three single words cited by lexicographers[/c].
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Recent discussions[/c]: M. L. West, “[c dimgray]Iliad[/c] and [c dimgray]Aethiopis[/c] on stage:
	Aeschylus and son”, [c dimgray]CQ[/c] 50 (2000) 338–352, esp. 345–7; M.
	Farioli, “Due parodie comiche della ‘psychostasia’: Ar. [c dimgray]Ran.[/c] 1364–1413 e fr.
	504 K.-A.”, [c dimgray]Lexis[/c] 22 (2004) 251–267.

	[b]Oreithyia[/b]
	 from which “Longinus” quoted fr. 281. “Longinus” describes
	that passage, and other expressions such as “vomiting
	towards heaven”[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c] and Boreas being described as a
	“piper”, as “not tragic but paratragic . . . descending from
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]Sidgwick ingeniously combined this phrase with that quoted
	by John of Sicily into a plausible couplet: σιαγόσιν δισσαῖσιν ἐκφυσῶν ἐγὼ | κυκῶ θάλασσαν ἐξεμεῖν πρὸς οὐρανόν (“Puffing

	[b]“The Dike Play”[/b]
	[c dimgray]The play from which come the forty-seven lines, or fragments
	of lines, that survive as frr. 281a and 281b is known
	to be Aeschylean by the appearance in 281a.28 of a phrase
	cited elsewhere as by Aeschylus. The main speaker identifies
	herself as Dike (Justice) in 281a.15, and explains how
	she administers the justice of Zeus; by way of example, she
	then speaks of an insane, shameless child of Zeus and Hera,
	who must be Ares the god of war and violence, and whom
	she has presumably encouraged or forced to direct his hostility
	only against unrighteous communities. She is ad-[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 276[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]“The Dike Play”[/b][/c]
	[c dimgray]the awe-inspiring towards the contemptible”, and it is not
	surprising that[/c] Oreithyia [c dimgray]has sometimes been thought to
	have been a satyr-drama; certainly there is nothing in what
	we know of the myth to suggest how Aeschylus could have
	used it to excite tragic emotion, let alone to generate a
	tragic outcome.[/c]

	[c darkmagenta][b]“The Dike Play”[/b][/c]
	make this plain to see. I reared[c dimgray][sup]4[/sup][/c] the savage son[c dimgray][sup]5[/sup][/c] whom
	Hera \[once\] bore in union with Zeus, an unruly \[child (?)\]
	of swollen spirit, in whose mentality there was no shame;
	\[he shot many (?)\] wayfarers with arrows \[from which\] one
	could \[not escape (?), shameles\]sly (?) slaughtering them
	with the bowstring, \[and\] he laughed and rejoiced \[in doing
	these (?)\] evil deeds \[whenever (?)\] the blood \[of his
	victims (?)\] dripped[c dimgray][sup]6[/sup][/c] \[from his hand\]s (?). \[I . . . \] taking
	\[this to heart (?) . . . an\]d e\[xtend\]ed (?) my hand \[to him (?)
	. . .;\] therefore he is rightly[c dimgray][sup]7[/sup][/c] called \[Ares (?), because . . . \]
	him righteous \[ . . . \] . . .
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]4[/sup][/c]Reading ἔθρε\[ψα\]; the meaning is that she acted as nurse
	and tutor to the young god. The alternative restoration, ἔθρε\[ψε\],
	is clearly inferior: (i) after Dike’s statement of her great power to
	do humans good, we expect to hear of something that [c dimgray]she[/c] has
	done; (ii) if the third-person verb has Hera as its subject (and
	there is no room for any other), her name ought to have been
	placed early in the sentence, not tucked away in a relative clause.
	[c dimgray][sup]5[/sup][/c]This must be Ares, the only universally recognized son of Zeus
	and Hera (Hesiod, [c dimgray]Theogony[/c] 921–3); the other son sometimes
	credited to them, Hephaestus (e.g. [c dimgray]Iliad[/c] 1.577–9, but cf. Hesiod,
	[c dimgray]Theogony[/c] 927–9), obviously does not fit the description given
	here.
	[c dimgray][sup]6[/sup][/c]The papyrus’s marginal variant is surely right:
	φόνος is not a suitable subject either for ἄζοι “dried up (something
	else)” or for ὄζοι “smelt (of something)”.
	[c dimgray][sup]7[/sup][/c]The name
	“Ares” was probably explained through a pun on one of the numerous
	similar words in the tragic lexicon, e.g. ἄρος “benefit” (cf.
	Supp. 885) or ἀρείων “better”. Dike will have gone on to explain
	that she taught Ares to end his acts of random violence (34–37)
	and instead attack only those who did not respect justice, leaving
	others in peace (cf. fr. 451n, if it belongs to this play).
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 285[/c]

	May he not carry a shield next to me, nor be close to me[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c] . . .
	[m1]\ [/m]
	305
	For kindred also knows how to envy.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	307
	He was like a lump of metal receiving hammer-blows as
	the smith works on it, so completely without a groan, like a
	voiceless tunny-fish, did he endure the battering.[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]This metrical fragment is extracted from a sentence of
	Aristides’ which reads in full: “On the contrary, may he not—in
	the words of Aeschylus—either carry a shield next to me or be
	close to me, [c dimgray]who is not a friend to this man[/c] and does not honour
	what it is appropriate to honour.” The italicized clause is somewhat
	poetic in expression (ἐστι “is” is omitted) and can easily be
	modified so as to be metrical; it cannot, however, have directly followed
	“be close to me” in Aeschylus’ text, and Aristides may have
	passed over some words that did not suit his own purposes, e.g.
	δαΐαισιν ἐν μάχαις “in deadly battles”. If the clause “who is not a
	friend to this man” does derive from Aeschylus, “this man” may
	have meant “me” as e.g. in [c dimgray]Ag[/c]. 1438 (where it is “this woman”) and
	Sophocles, [c dimgray]Oedipus the King[/c] 534.
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]See on [c dimgray]Pers[/c]. 424–6.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 297[/c]
