	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]The authors who quote this line (probably from a satyr-drama)
	all agree that tunnies had some abnormality or defect in
	their visual physiology, but not on what this was. Without their dubious
	aid, one would take the line to imply merely that the fish had
	the power to direct its eyes independently of one another; the
	gruesome process of killing them (see on [c dimgray]Pers[/c]. 424–6) would give
	plenty of opportunity for observing this.
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]This and the next two fragments, which Athenaeus quotes
	together with it, are probably from the same scene (evidently of a
	satyr-drama). The speaker of this fragment (who seems to envisage
	eating the whole piglet himself) may well be the notoriously
	gluttonous Heracles, in which case this group of fragments would
	probably come from [c dimgray]Heralds[/c] (so Droysen) or [c dimgray]The Lion[/c].
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]And therefore is being justly punished by losing two of her
	offspring in one day?
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]sc. as that of their father.
	[c dimgray][sup]2[/sup][/c]Imposed on him as a punishment
	by Zeus; cf. [c dimgray]Prom[/c]. 347–350 and Hesiod, [c dimgray]Theogony[/c] 517–520.
	[c dimgray][sup]3[/sup][/c]i.e. stars (the P\[e\]leiades, cf. πέλεια or πελειάς
	“dove”). It is possible that the mourning of the Atlantides/Pleiades
	for their father’s humiliation is being compared to the mourning
	of the Daughters of the Sun for the death of their brother
	Phaëthon.
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]The ethnonym Κουρῆτες, which in antiquity was etymologized
	in many different ways, is here taken to be derived from
	κούρη (Attic κόρη) “maiden”. It was the name borne in the heroic
	age by the people of Pleuron in Aetolia, and is mentioned
	mainly in connection with Pleuron’s neighbour Calydon, the hero
	Meleager, and the story of the Calydonian Boar (e.g. [c dimgray]Iliad[/c] 9.529–599;
	Hesiod fr. 25.9–13; Bacchylides 5.124–6). If our fragment
	came from a play on this subject, that play is almost bound to have
	been [c dimgray]Atalanta[/c] (q.v.)

	[m1]\ [/m]
	Clement of Alexandria, [c dimgray]Stromateis[/c] 6.2.7.6; Stobaeus 3.39.14
	(attributed to Sophocles); Diogenianus 7.35 and Apostolius 12.45
	(unattributed)

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]Implying that anyone who has to travel abroad (like the
	speaker?) is thereby shown not to be truly happy (cf. Euripides fr.
	789a Kannicht, spoken by Odysseus when on a dangerous mission to Lemnos). The second line quoted by Clement appears to be a
	satirical addition by a comic dramatist: a second character asks
	“And what about someone who’s [c dimgray]unhappy[/c]?” and the first replies
	“He should stay at home as well!” It is impossible to tell whether
	the first line is by Aeschylus (so Clement) or by Sophocles (so
	Stobaeus; it is Sophocles fr. 934 in [c dimgray]TrGF[/c]); they cannot both have
	used it, otherwise Clement, who is discussing plagiarism by Greek
	poets, would certainly have mentioned the fact. This line too has
	sometimes been judged spurious, either the work of a comic dramatist
	or a late forger (most recently by A. Colonna, [c dimgray]Sileno[/c] 17
	\[1991\] 239–241); but it appears to have been parodied by Euripides
	(fr. 894, doubtless from a satyr-play: “he who is truly happy
	eats other people’s food”).
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 302[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c darkmagenta][b]Unattributed Fragments[/b][/c]

	notes on the lyre[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c] (?)

	of Toil.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	316
	But I too have a key on my tongue to guard it.[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	317
	He who is truly happy ought to stay at home.[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]lit. “tortoise-shell” (from which the lyre’s sound-box was
	made). Possible restorations of the corrupt text are “clumsily
	striking false notes . . .” (Ellis) or “. . . on the Ionian lyre”
	(Wilamowitz). The fragment is in any case likely to be satyric; the
	speaker seems to be trying to identify a semi-musical noise that
	has struck his/her ears.
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]Cf. [c dimgray]Ag[/c]. 36–37.

	<And> he[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c] dwelt on the excellent offspring I would have,[c dimgray][sup]2[/sup][/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]Or (with the accentuation ἤχει) “that were resounding just
	now”. Perhaps from [c dimgray]Edonians[/c] (cf. fr. 57), or another Dionysiac
	play such as [c dimgray]Wool-Carders[/c] or [c dimgray]Pentheus[/c].
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]Apollo, “singing at her wedding \[to Peleus, which all the gods
	attended\]” (Plato).
	[c dimgray][sup]2[/sup][/c]Achilles. Apollo spoke truly when he
	said that Achilles would never experience sickness, and Thetis
	may later have discovered that the other part of his prophecy was
	also true, if Aeschylus adopted the version of the myth according
	to which Achilles was granted immortality (cf. Euripides, [c dimgray]Andromache[/c]
	1259–61)—or she may even have made it come true
	herself (according to the cyclic epic, the [c dimgray]Aethiopis[/c] \[Arg. §4 West\],
	she snatched her son from his funeral pyre and conveyed him to
	the “White Island”). Apollo’s words were, however, extremely misleading
	by omission and ambiguity: apart from the failure to refer
	to Achilles’ early death, one may note that εὐπαιδία, especially in
	the plural, would hardly suggest a one-child family.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 309[/c]

	[c dimgray]Nicomachean Ethics[/c] 1111a8–10, with the anonymous commentary
	in [c dimgray]CAG[/c] xx 145.23–146.3) that Aeschylus had been
	accused of divulging secrets of the Mysteries in his plays. The
	commentator names five plays—[c dimgray]Archeresses, Priestesses, Sisyphus
	the Stone-Roller, Iphigeneia[/c], and [c dimgray]Oedipus[/c]—none of which is
	otherwise known to have had any Eleusinian connection; without
	that information, or misinformation, one would certainly have
	thought rather of [c dimgray]Eleusinians[/c] or [c dimgray]Cercyon[/c], the only plays known to
	have been set at Eleusis.

	(see introductory note to [c dimgray]Glaucus of Potniae[/c]): wherever Laius was
	going, it was not Delphi, his destination in Sophocles.

	this fragment to [c dimgray]Glaucus of Potniae[/c], in which Poseidon is
	likely to have been prominent and there were probably at least
	two other references to the western Greek lands (frr. 25a, 40a);
	see Introduction to [c dimgray]Persians[/c] (vol. 1) and my forthcoming article
	cited on p. 23.

-505.333 (AESCHYLUS, Probably Aeschylean Papyrus Fragments)
%Papyrus Fragments
AESCHYLUS, Probably Aeschylean Papyrus Fragments
	[c darkmagenta][b]AESCHYLUS, Probably Aeschylean Papyrus Fragments[/b][/c]
		[m1]\ [/m][b]Papyrus Fragments[/b]
	Probably Aeschylean
	Papyrus Fragments
	[c dimgray]The great majority of surviving Aeschylean papyri were
	written in the second century ad[/c] by one single scribe;
	many of these have been printed above under the plays to
	which they belong, but there are a considerable number
	of other fragments in the same hand (frr. 451c–m Radt)
	whose style either points to or at any rate does not exclude
	an attribution to Aeschylus, but which cannot be confidently
	associated with a specific play. There also survive
	many further fragments (frr. 451n–s Radt), likewise Aeschylean
	in style so far as can be judged, in the hand of the
	scribe who wrote the fragments of the “Dike play” (frr.
	281a–b), and one or two in other hands (frr. 451t–u Radt)
	which are generally ascribed to Aeschylus on reasonable
	grounds.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Two of these fragments (frr. 451l and 451k Radt) have
	been ascribed in this edition to specific plays; they appear
	above as frr. 78a (from[/c] Chamber-Makers) [c dimgray]and 180a (from[/c]
	Palamedes) [c dimgray]respectively. Three more (frr. 451h, 451n and
	451q), which meet the criteria for inclusion in this edition
	(preservation of one complete line or two connected half-lines),
	are printed below.[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 333[/c]

-505.335 (AESCHYLUS, Probably Aeschylean Papyrus Fragments)
AESCHYLUS, Probably Aeschylean Papyrus Fragments
	[c darkmagenta][b]AESCHYLUS, Probably Aeschylean Papyrus Fragments[/b][/c]
	[b]Papyrus Fragments[/b]
	[c dimgray]Of most of the remainder there is little that can be said
	with assurance. Fr. 451c comprises 37 lines, most if not all
	of them lyric, whose content appears to have to do largely
	with warfare; at the end (33–37) it seems to be predicted
	that someone who may or may not be described as[/c] courageous
	[c dimgray]will[/c] flee on horseback from an attack [c dimgray]and (but?) that[/c]
	a for\[eign\] soil will receive him. [c dimgray]Fr. 451e refers to someone
	or something[/c] Asian  and several times to musical and other
	sounds; it may well therefore come from a play with strong
	Dionysiac connections, such as one from the Lycurgus or
	the Semele/Pentheus tetralogies. Fr. 451f, which probably
	contains the end of one speech and the beginning of another,
	mentions a bed [c dimgray]or sexual relationship (14) and, just
	previously, that[/c] Hera . . . has come [c dimgray](12–13); it is very
	tempting to associate this with frr. 220a–c and ascribe the
	fragment to[/c] Semele. [c dimgray]In fr. 451g a chorus greets a king, beginning
	with the same words that are used by the Argive elders
	when they greet Agamemnon[/c] (Ag. [c dimgray]783). Fr. 451m consists
	of nearly forty scraps, which are unlikely all to come
	from the same play; one of them mentions[/c] Peleus [c dimgray](1.7), but
	we do not know in what connection. Fr. 451o twice mentions[/c]
	the people of Tenedos [c dimgray](53.3 and 7), and a character
	asks[/c] how is this friendly to ([c dimgray]or[/c] approved by) the \[Ar\]gives?;
	 the only known story which this fits is that of the sacking of
	Tenedos, and the killing of its king Tennes, by the Greek expedition
	on its way to Troy, a story which is told only in
	later sources (e.g. \[Apollodorus\], Epitome [c dimgray]3.23–26) but
	which was the subject of a fifth-century play variously ascribed
	to Euripides and to Critias; this papyrus has thus
	been taken by Mette and others as evidence for an otherwise[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 334[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m][b]Papyrus Fragments[/b]
	[c dimgray]unattested[/c] Tennes [c dimgray]of Aeschylus. Fr. 451s consists of
	more than seventy small pieces of papyrus, again probably
	belonging to several different plays; one (55) has been
	thought to coincide with a book-fragment of[/c] Myrmidons
	[c dimgray](see on fr. 136).[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 335[/c]

	See this, Z\[eus god of\] hos\[pitality . . . \]
	the hospitable \[house (?)\] overt\[hrown\]!
	Is \[there any\] favour from the g\[o\]ds
	for righteous \[m\]e\[n\]?
	This is why, tear\[ing\]
	my hair with merciless hands,[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]
	\[I beat (?)\] this miserable[c dimgray][sup]2[/sup][/c] skull of mine,

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]A chorus of women lament the ruin of a man who had been noted
	for his hospitality and justice, and had apparently suffered as a result
	of these qualities. (It is clear that at least one death has occurred,
	but we cannot tell whether the victim is the hospitable man
	himself, or one or more members of his family, or both.) Perhaps
	the play was[/c] Cretan Women, [c dimgray]and the hospitable man was Minos
	who had lost his young son Glaucus (on Minos’ reputation for justice,
	cf.[/c] Odyssey [c dimgray]11.568–571 and Plato[/c], Apology [c dimgray]41a). Polyidus,
	the seer who discovered Glaucus’ body and later restored him to
	life, was a stranger in Crete (he was a Corinthian: see[/c] Iliad [c dimgray]13.663
	and Pindar,[/c] Olympian [c dimgray]13.74–75), and in the play he may well
	have arrived there only shortly before the disappearance of
	Glaucus—and been blamed for it, and then for the boy’s death.
	Such a scenario would help to explain Minos’ demand—which
	looks as though it were designed to be an impossible one—that he
	should bring Glaucus back to life (or else forfeit his own?)[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	[c dimgray]Page number 337[/c]

	[c dimgray]As Snell and others have noted, this summary of the events leading
	to the death of Ajax almost certainly does[/c] not [c dimgray]come from a play
	about those events themselves; lines 16–17 seem to be comparing
	the fate of Ajax to the actual or prospective fate of someone else. It
	could well, however, as Mette proposed, come from[/c] Women of
	Salamis, [c dimgray]if the comparison is taken to be between Ajax and Teucer.
	In principle it might also come from another play set in Salamis or
	Attica (since “defender of the city” could refer to Ajax’s posthumous
	role as a hero protecting Athens) at some time after the Trojan
	war; but other than[/c] Women of Salamis [c dimgray]and[/c] Eumenides, [c dimgray]no
	Aeschylean play we know of fits that description.[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]

	Fragments
	 This section includes: (i) one fragment (fr. 452a = 61a Radt)
	assigned by Radt, without direct evidence, to a specific
	play of Aeschylus, and which I would regard as only possibly,
	not probably, of Aeschylean authorship;[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c] (ii) the fragments
	of one line or more, other than papyrus fragments,
	printed by Radt in his “Fragmenta dubia” section, excluding
	those for which I see no good reason to regard Aeschylean
	authorship as a substantial possibility;[c dimgray][sup]2[/sup][/c] (iii) four fragments
	(here numbered 489a–d) which in TrGF [c dimgray]are printed
	among the[/c] Adespota [c dimgray]but for which there is a substantial
	possibility of Aeschylus being the author.[/c]
	[m1]\ [/m]
	1 I have excluded altogether fr. 164 Radt, of whose existence
	there is no trace before the sixteenth century; see R. de Lucia,  38 (1989) 113–120.
	2 The excluded
	fragments are frr. 453, 456, 458, 467, and 471–4 Radt; also
	omitted from this section is fr. 469 Radt (= . {286}).

	Erbse); attributed to Aeschylus by Soping and Stanley (misled by
	Eustathius’ reference, just previously, to Pausanias α168 which
	cites Aesch. fr. 419); attribution doubted by Erbse, but can still be
	supported on stylistic grounds
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]

	K. J. Dover (Oxford, 1993) argued the reverse.

	ζόης πονηρᾶς θάνατος αἱρετώτερος·
	τὸ μὴ γενέσθαι δ᾿ ἐστὶν ἢ πεφυκέναι
	κρεῖσσον κακῶς πάσχοντα
	[m1]\ [/m]
	Stobaeus 4.53.17 (Αἰσχύλου); \[Menander\], [c dimgray]Monosticha[/c] 276
	(line 1 only); authenticity doubted by Butler, denied by Dindorf
	[m1]\ [/m]
	1 αἱρετώτερος \[Menander\] (cf. Aristophanes,  84;
	Xenophon,  9.1; Isocrates 4.95):
	εὐπορώτερος Stobaeus
	2 ἐστὶν Grotius: ἐστὶ μᾶλλον codd.
	3 πάσχοντα A (S omits the line): πράσσοντα
	Grotius: πράσσοντι Blaydes
	468
	καὶ μὴ (?) πρὸς ὀργὴν σπλάγχνα θερμήνῃς κότῳ
	[m1]\ [/m]
	Aristophanes, [c dimgray]Frogs[/c] 844 (Dionysus addressing Aeschylus); attributed
	to Aeschylus by Hermann
	[m1]\ [/m]
	καὶ μὴ may be an adjustment by Aristophanes to fit his context
	(so Radt): Aeschylus could have written e.g. μή τοι
	[m1]\ [/m]
	470
	γύναι (?), γυναιξὶ κόσμον ἡ σιγὴ φέρει
	[m1]\ [/m]
	Sophocles, [c dimgray]Ajax[/c] 293: the scholia say that the line is by
	“Aeschines the orator”; Peppink suggested they meant Aeschylus
	[m1]\ [/m]
	γύναι may be a modification by Sophocles (so Radt); Aeschylus
	could have written e.g. αἰεὶ or χρησταῖς
	[m1]\ [/m]

	[m1]\ [/m]

	And (?) do not heat up your inward parts with angry

	[m1]\ [/m]

	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]Cf. fr. 90; Radt suggests that this line is nothing but a variant
	form of fr. 90 (and lines 2–3 an entirely separate quotation by
	Stobaeus from a different author), but the repeated appearance
	of αἱρετώτερος in expressions of the same sentiment in the fifth
	and fourth century (see apparatus) is a phenomenon requiring explanation.
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]Neatly parodied by Euripides, [c dimgray]Cyclops[/c] 424, who for κότῳ

	489a (adesp. 208)
	Hades, the relentless Owner of the Soil,[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c] laid hold on him/
	her.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	489b (adesp. 291)
	. . . to find his death by being torn apart among the rocks.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	<span class="marginNote bottom">[c dimgray]Referring either to the death of Orpheus on Mount Pangaeum, or
	to that of Pentheus on Mount Cithaeron.[/c]
	489c (adesp. 375)
	But if you are terrified by a vision seen in sleep
	and have been visited by the revel-band of Hecate[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c] from
	the underworld . . .
	[m1]\ [/m]
	<span class="marginNote bottom">[c dimgray]Anapaests; probably a chorus reassuring an apprehensive
	hero(ine).[/c]

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]The noun γάμορος, which in ordinary usage means “landowner”,
	appears here to be re-etymologized as “he who received
	the soil (i.e. everything below ground level) for his portion”, sc. in
	the sharing out of the universe between Hades and his brothers
	Zeus and Poseidon ([c dimgray]Iliad[/c] 15.187–191).
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]Cf. Euripides, [c dimgray]Helen[/c] 569–570 where Menelaus, thinking he
	is beholding a phantom in Helen’s shape, begs Hecate to send
	instead “friendly apparitions”, and Helen assures him that the
	woman he sees is not “an attendant of Enodia \[= Hecate\] appearing
	in a vision of the night”.
	[m1]\ [/m]

	θύννος βολαῖος πέλαγος ὣς διαστροβεῖ
	[m1]\ [/m]
	Plutarch, [c dimgray]Lucullus[/c] 1.5 and [c dimgray]Moralia[/c] 554f; attributed to Aeschylus
	by Stark (who assigned it to [c dimgray]Net-Haulers[/c]; but [c dimgray]Glaucus the Seagod[/c]
	is also possible)
	[m1]\ [/m]
	διαστροβεῖ [c dimgray]Mor.:[/c] διεστρόβει [c dimgray]Luc.[/c] (the tense in each case is

	489d (adesp. 391)
	He/it is/was[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c] stirring up the sea like a netted tunny.
	[m1]\ [/m]
	  ( Net-Haulers)  ( Glaucus the Seagod).

	[m1]\ [/m]
	[b][c dimgray]Footnotes[/c][/b]
	[c dimgray][sup]1[/sup][/c]Plutarch quotes the line once in the present tense and once
	in the imperfect, each time using the tense that fits his own context;
	we cannot tell which of the two quotations has been altered
	for this purpose and which has not.
	[c dimgray][sup]2[/sup][/c]In this case the line
	might come either from the prologue (before fr. 46a; the speaker
	would probably be the Fisherman) or from the later scene in
	which the satyrs hauled the chest ashore (the speaker would then
	probably be Silenus). Either way, the tense of the verb would
	probably be present.
	[c dimgray][sup]3[/sup][/c]In this case the line might come
	from the speech of the Oxherd of which fr. 25e is part, and since
	the Oxherd is describing what he [c dimgray]has seen[/c] (κατεῖδον, fr. 25e.12),
	the tense of the verb would doubtless be imperfect.
	[m1]\ [/m]
